abstract: AN IRREPRESSIBLE CONFLICT. -- The distinguished Operatic manager, M. MARETZEK, has come off victor in a curious controversy with the Press in Havana, which is worthy of some note here. During his present very successful season there, the Prensa undertook to wage war against the impresario, and in fact, has done so relentlessly for many rears, the cause arising out of an old Mexican difficulty. The attacks of this sheet became so personal that Mr. MARETZEK felt that it was due to himself to withhold the ordinary courtesies from its representative. In other words, the Prensa man had to buy his own tickets. A lawsuit grew out of this business, and a decision was given against Mr. MARETZEK by a willing Justice of the Peace. Mr. MARETZEK appealed to the highest court in the Island, and obtained a verdict in his favor, reversing the former decision. The critic of the Prensa (who claimed that he had the preference of the seats theretofore occupied by himself over all other purchasers) was mulcted in heavy damages, and the proprietors of the paper, dissatisfied with the course he had pursued, discharged him from their employ. The gentleman's tenacity seems to have been worthy of a better cause, and did not even desert him at this pinch. He refused to be discharged, and it was necessary to call in the police to remove him from the office of the Prensa. Mr. MARETZEK is thus indorsed by the public, the Judiciary and the proprietors of the paper, in the course he felt called upon to take, and is honorably acquitted from any intention of gagging the Press.
lead_paragraph: AN IRREPRESSIBLE CONFLICT. -- The distinguished Operatic manager, M. abstract: The year 1832 is known in modern history as the "aristocratic year of death," for the number and brilliancy of the famous names which star its long necrology. In that year Literature bade farewell to GOETHE and to SCOTT; Science to CHAMPOLLION and CUVIER. Then BENTHAM closed his eyes in peace upon the triumph of the English Reform bill; and TENTERDEN, the ruling passion strong in death, lifted himself from his pillow with his last breath to bid the "Gentlemen of the Jury" once more "retire!" PERIER, the one premier who might perhaps have fixed a constitutional throne in France, and MACKINTOSH, Mme. DE STAEL's "Mr. Harmony," who criticised all parties and commanded none, passed away then together; social science lost SAY, and phrenology SPURZHEIM, and learning the astutely laborious intellect of BUTLER. Then, too, faded out of a world in which he found no place to fit at once the greatness of his name and the frailty of his nature, the shadowy form of the Second NAPOLEON, whom Austrian soldiers bore to an Austrian grave with the Archdukes of his mother's house.

abstract: On Saturday afternoon about five o'clock, while a number of' longshoremen, laborers and others were at work on board the steamship Granada, which was sunk a day or two ago in consequence of being out through by the floating ice, a steam-boiler stationed on her forward deck, and used for draining a pump exploded with terrific force, causing the instantaneous death of one man and the serious scalding of eleven others. The Granada lay alongside of the dock at the foot of Warren-street when the explosion occurred. She had been relieved of nearly all the water, and preparations were in progress to keep two steam-pumps at work throughout the night, operations being conducted under the direction of engineers in the employ of HERBERT & BENNETT, wreckers, who had a large force of men engaged,

abstract: A numerously-attended meeting of the Royal Geographical Society was held in London on the 10th inst., Sir RODERICK MUROUISON presiding. Several papers relative to San Juan and its neighborhood were read; among them, "Journeys in the District, bordering on the Fraser, Thompson, and Harrison Rivers," by Lieuts. MAYNE, R.N., and PALMER, R.E., and Chief Justice M. BEGBIE; communicated by the Duke of NEWCASTLE, Colonial Office.
lead_paragraph: A numerously-attended meeting of the Royal Geographical Society was held in London on the 10th inst., Sir RODERICK MUROUISON presiding. Several papers relative to San Juan and its neighborhood were read; among them, "Journeys in the District, bordering on the Fraser, Thompson, and Harrison Rivers," by Lieuts. MAYNE, R.N., and PALMER, R.E., and Chief Justice M. BEGBIE; communicated by the Duke of NEWCASTLE, Colonial Office. Lieut. MAYNE's report contained much interesting topographical information. It described the character of the soil, the vegetation and productions of the districts traversed, and pointed out the course of the rivers and the general geographical features of the country. Lieut. PALMER noticed the existence of gold in the Upper Fraser River, but observed that the great drawback was the scarcity and enormous price of provisions. Chief-Justice BEGBIE observed that two Indian chiefs paid him a visit while at Cayoosh, and complained of the conduct of citizens of the United States; while, on the other hand, there were many cases of cattle-stealing alleged by the whites against the Indians; this was said to be caused by the want of food; the Indians, many hundreds of whom had died of absolute starvation during the Winter, staling that the salmon had failed them now for three years altogether. They were said to be very lazy and improvident, but the Chief Justice had found them almost everywhere willing to labor hard for hire, and bargaining acutely for wages. The amount of wages for carrying burdens was eight shillings per day. His impression of the Indian population was that they had far more natural intelligence and honesty than the lowest classes of any European country. The chief point which struck him were, first, the ready submission of a foreign population to the declaration of the will of the Executive; secondly, the great preponderance of the Californian element of the population and the paucity of British subjects; thirdly, the great riches, both auriferous and agricultural, of the country; fourthly, the want of some fixity of tenure for agricultural purposes; and, fifthly, the absence of all means of communication except by foaming torrents in canoes, or over goat-tracks on foot, which render all productions of the country except such as, like gold, could be carried with great care in small weight and compass, practically valueless. The chairman, in proposing the thanks of the Society to his Grace the Duke of NEWCASTLE for sending the papers, as well as to the authors, said that he was much struck with the fact that vessels of large tonnage could navigate the rivers, thus affording access to the auriferous regions. The plan of the Island of St. Juan, about which the Governments of the two countries were in dispute, was before them. It was obvious that it would be of the highest importance to have the distinct line of the Fraser River for the transit of their auriferous products. He had specimens of the nuggets found in the Fraser River; they were of small size, but it might turn out that some would yet be found as large as in any of the Australian gold regions. Dr. HODGKIN had been struck by the observations made respecting the Indians. It has been noticed that they were improvident, but he believed that if proper care was taken of them they would prove of great service to the European population, Sir E. BELOHER said that what gave him most concern was the boundary line. In 1838 he had sailed up the Columbia River below the 46th parallel, and had not found one American located there, but on arriving at Fort Vancouver there were some American missionaries, who had been provided by, the Hudson Bay Company with seed, sheep, and every facility for settling; and when a certain number had arrived, they called on the United States Government to establish American rights there, and that was the way England had been ousted from the Columbia river. An insurrection soon after broke out in California, and the "American Governor told him that if the British Government gave up to the United States the southern boundary of the Columbia, she would allow England to fake California for the Mexican debt. He had seen the Mexican Charge d' Affaires, and told him that he had sent a dispatch to England containing that proposition; but, as he was a sailor, and had traveled out of his strict province in writing direct to the Foreign Office, no notice was taken of the communication, and the result was that England lost California, the Columbia, and was "fleeted" up to the forty-ninth degree. Had the British Government adopted the proposal made in 1838, there would be no occasion for the "San Juan difficulty" of the present day. After some observations from Mr. CRAWFORD, denying that the influx of gold would sensibly affect the relative value of metals and provisions, the meeting was adjourned to the 9th of January.

abstract: MR. PRESIDENT AND FELLOW-CITIZENS: I can truly say with the eloquent and accomplished gentleman -- your own townsman -- who first addressed you this evening, that this is the first occasion upon which I have ever had the pleasure of addressing an audience composed like this. It is the first "Union-saving" meeting I ever had the honor or the pleasure of attending. The only thing I have to regret in connection with it is the fact, that I am compelled to present myself before you without having made any preparation whatever for addressing you on this occasion [???]regret this, not for lack of topics or, of something to say upon them, for he must be a stammering patriot who can find nothing to say upon such a theme as this, [applause,] but simply because I am unable to present my thoughts with the method and order calculated to give them most effect.

abstract: CITY MORTALITY. -- During the week ending Saturday last, 126 deaths were reported to the Health Department, classified as follows: Men 19, women 22, boys 45, girls 40; adults 41, children 85; males 64, females 62; colored person 1. There were 15 deaths by consumption, 13 by infantile convulsions, 13 by scarlet fever, and 14 by inflammation of the lungs. There were also six deaths the result of accidents, two from intemperance, two from old age, and one from causes unknown. 18 were over 50 years old, and 68 were under 5 years old, 97 were natives of the United States.
lead_paragraph: CITY MORTALITY. -- During the week ending Saturday last, 126 deaths were reported to the Health Department, classified as follows: Men 19, women 22, boys 45, girls 40; adults 41, children 85; males 64, females 62; colored person 1. abstract: Mr. P.H. Hale, a clerk in the office of the Fifth Auditor, disappeared suddenly from Washington a few days since. On examination, it appeared that, by prefixing his name to un indorsed draft for $1,700 that came to his desk officially, the words "pay to P.H. Hale, or order, assignee," he contrived to get a warrant through the Treasury in his favor, and getting the draft which was issued upon it cashed at the Bank of the Metropolis, suddenly left for parts unknown. The draft was drawn by the American Consul at Lahama, in favor of Capt. Brewer, of Boston, whom Hale represented to be a personal friend, and from whom he professed to have a letter asking his services in procuring the money from the Government. It is stated that Hale has written that he will return to Washington, but he had not made his appearance at last accounts.

abstract: Our Southern friends will bear us witness, we think, that we have not underrated the severity of the strain put upon their forbearance, their self-command and their patriotism by the pressure of recent events in our history. We have endeavored to look at their present position in the presence of JOHN BROWN's foray, and of the fanatical outbursts of sympathy which that foray provoked from the Abolitionists of the North, precisely as they must look at it themselves. It is not easy for Northern men to do this. It is not easy for us, who live in the midst of a society which has found itself strong enough to resist the explosion of all manner of fanatic theories and extravagant experiments, to appreciate the serious and honest anxiety for their own safety which Southern men have felt and expressed from Virginia to Texas, on hearing that a small knot of men in the North were ready to cross the frontier of the slaveholding States and risk their lives in the attempt to incite insurrection among the laboring classes of that region. Nevertheless it is our plain duty to attempt such an appreciation. "We cannot do justice to our Southern fellow-citizens unless we attempt it.

abstract: Hon. HAMILTON FISH, of this City who is the fortunate possessor of the sculptor PALMER's las and noblest work, the "White Captive," has confided this treasure, as our readers know, to the considerate keeping of one of the most respectable print-sellers of New-York, Mr. WM. SCHAUS, at whose charming little gallery in Broadway it is now on exhibition. A writer, whose communication appeared in the TIMES of Friday last, having permitted himself to advance very serious charges against the management of Mr. SCHAUS' rooms, we have received from that gentleman the following note, to which we give place with much pleasure, convinced, as we are, that nothing can be more injurious to the cause of high and true Art than the suggestion of evil where no evil exists, and the thoughtless defamation of pure and honorable men, engaged in the work of creating and disseminating the "eloquent shapes of beauty:"

abstract: LIBANIUS, the rhetorician, in commencing his account of the way in which his contemporaries of ancient Rome celebrated the first day of the New Year, remarks, truthfully, and, it may be added, truistically, (if we may coin such a word,) that all men love holidays. Of course they do, just as all women love admiration, gifts, and the given of gifts. And when holiday-tide arrives, they know how to put it to its best use, and are just as smart in getting the most pleasure out of it as they are in doing as much business as possible in a given amount of time in business season. And of all holidays, the holiday of holidays is New Year's.
lead_paragraph: LIBANIUS, the rhetorician, in commencing his account of the way in which his contemporaries of ancient Rome celebrated the first day of the New Year, remarks, truthfully, and, it may be added, truistically, (if we may coin such a word,) that all men love holidays. abstract: Justice SLOSSON of the Superior Court, closed his judicial labors on Saturday last, and upon taking leave of the Court, made a few feeling remarks expressive of his regrets upon parting with his associates on the Bench, and also thanking the members of the Bar for uniform kindness and courtesy. The learned Judge was much affected, and his remarks were received with equal feeling by the Court and members of the profession present.
lead_paragraph: Justice SLOSSON of the Superior Court, closed his judicial labors on Saturday last, and upon taking leave of the Court, made a few feeling remarks expressive of his regrets upon parting with his associates on the Bench, and also thanking the members of the Bar for uniform kindness and courtesy. The learned Judge was much affected, and his remarks were received with equal feeling by the Court and members of the profession present.

abstract: The beauties of the Central Park will dawn with Spring and fade with Autumn; but its attractions as a place for healthful recreation will be perennial, extending ever through those days of bitterest Winter, when ladies use carriages for shelter and not for show, and the horseman who most delights in the saddle shrinks from the piercing air and the frozen road. The skating-pond proves no less attractive than drives, and walks, and views; and it has in fact given a new impulse to the practice of a diversion which may be almost called an art, and which, from the gradual disappearance of ponds in the vicinity of New-York, was necessarily falling, year after year, more and more into disuse. We rejoice at the returning favor of this elegant and manly amusement, because it holds a high place among those out-door exercises which, by invigorating both body and mind, re-create the whole man. Skating puts every muscle of the body into full play, and keeps them all in alternating movement, with a rapidity and violence which may be moderate or great, according to the skater's health and spirits or his caprice. This must be known to every lover of the ice, who, after having intermitted his practice for a few seasons, spends an hour or two upon the ringing steel. He wakes next morning to the consciousness that every fibre of his body, from the nape of his neck to the tip of his toe, has been subjected to unaccustomed tension.

abstract: By the arrival of the steamship Canada at Halifax, we have dates from Liverpool to Dec. 17, and from Queenstown to the 18th. Prom Prance we learn that the list of plenipotentiaries to the Congress is very nearly complete -- Sardinia, Austria, France, England and Spain having designated their respective delegates. The Congress was not to sit until the middle of January. Some feeling existed in England in regard to the Suez Canal project, the Press generally ridiculing the commercial feasibility of the scheme. The London Post, Lord PALMERSTON's organ, takes, however, a more serious view, urging that if a firman were obtained from the Porte authorizing the enterprise, Egypt would be dissevered from Turkey by the interposition of a slice of the French Empire. There were no new events in the progress of the Moorish war. Troops continue to pass into Africa from Spain; and, in the aggregate, the Spanish arms have not been unsuccessful. Prom Hungary we learn that a national outbreak appears to be inevitable. The decision of the Emperor that none of the reforms demanded by the Hungarian Protestants shall be granted, has excited a universal desire for revolt; and the government of Vienna has thought the crisis sufficiently threatening to require the transfer of large bodies of troops to Hungary. In the meantime, the rumor of the Emperor's intention to abdicate is again circulated, and the Archduchess SOPHIA named as his prompter. Our later advices from India mention that Lord CLYDE is about to return to England, his place at the head of the Indian Army being supplied by Sir HUGH ROSE. The United States sloop of war Germantown and steamer Powhatan were at Shanghai.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the steamship Canada at Halifax, we have dates from Liverpool to Dec. 17, and from Queenstown to the 18th. Prom Prance we learn that the list of plenipotentiaries to the Congress is very nearly complete -- Sardinia, Austria, France, England and Spain having designated their respective delegates. The Congress was not to sit until the middle of January. Some feeling existed in England in regard to the Suez Canal project, the Press generally ridiculing the commercial feasibility of the scheme. The London Post, Lord PALMERSTON's organ, takes, however, a more serious view, urging that if a firman were obtained from the Porte authorizing the enterprise, Egypt would be dissevered from Turkey by the interposition of a slice of the French Empire. There were no new events in the progress of the Moorish war. Troops continue to pass into Africa from Spain; and, in the aggregate, the Spanish arms have not been unsuccessful. Prom Hungary we learn that a national outbreak appears to be inevitable. The decision of the Emperor that none of the reforms demanded by the Hungarian Protestants shall be granted, has excited a universal desire for revolt; and the government of Vienna has thought the crisis sufficiently threatening to require the transfer of large bodies of troops to Hungary. In the meantime, the rumor of the Emperor's intention to abdicate is again circulated, and the Archduchess SOPHIA named as his prompter. Our later advices from India mention that Lord CLYDE is about to return to England, his place at the head of the Indian Army being supplied by Sir HUGH ROSE. The United States sloop of war Germantown and steamer Powhatan were at Shanghai.

abstract: Samuel B. Althause vs. The Mayor, &c. -- The plaintiff in this case, a few days since, obtained an injunction against the defendants, of Justice PIERREPONT, of the Superior Court, restraining them from permitting the New-York and Yonkers Railroad Company from laying tracks through those streets forming what is termed the "Broadway Parallel" route. The Common Council had passed a resolution allowing such tracks to be laid, despite the veto of the Mayor, and this injunction is to prevent the consummation of the plan, if possible.

The plaintiff, Mr. Bourcicault, who was not present, was represented by Mr. Cram; the defendants, Messrs. Fields and Stuart, both of whom were in Court, by Messrs. Jernegan and O'Gorman. Mr. Cram opened for the plaintiff in an able speech, in which he endeavored to show that his client's affidavit was entitled, from Jus proverbial character for honesty and fair-dealing, to more credence than those for the defence, however numerous and well supported. He then advanced a number of legal points for the Court's consideration. Mr. Jernegan, on the other side, offered the following points on behalf of the defendants:

abstract: The New Year will be undergoing its inauguration with the usual festivities, by the time this sheet reaches the eyes of our readers; and if it only prove half as eventful as the one which closed on Saturday night, we may all follow its march with a good deal of pardonable anxiety. Its predecessor has bequeathed it some political problems for solution, which will task all its ingenuity. In the Old World a great war has all hut liberated a great nation from three centuries of slavery, and New-Year's day finds its fate still trembling in the scales of diplomacy.

abstract: FUNERAL OF EX-JUDGE NEVIUS. -- The funeral of Ex-Judge JAMES S. NEVIUS, of Jersey City, took place from his residence in York-street, on Saturday, at 11 o'clock, A.M. Judge NEVIUS has been a prominent member of the New-Jersey Bar for more than forty yea's past, and was one of the Judges of the Supreme Court of the State from 1838 to 1852. His native humor, ready wit, and uniform cheerfulness, rendered Mm exceedingly popular with the members of his profession, as well as with the public, while his judicial career was distinguished for the highest integrity. For the past six months Judge NEVIUS has been in declining health' and for two months preceding his death, which took place on Wednesday last, he had been confined to his room. His age was 64 years. At the close of the funeral services at his residence, which were attended by the members of the Bar and other prominent citizens of Jersey City, the remains were conveyed to New-Brunswick, where a public funeral was held at the First Reformed Dutch Church, and was attended by a large concourse of citizens, including many of the most prominent men of the State. The remains were interred in the Cemetery at New-Brunswick.
lead_paragraph: FUNERAL OF EX-JUDGE NEVIUS. -- The funeral of Ex-Judge JAMES S. NEVIUS, of Jersey City, took place from his residence in York-street, on Saturday, at 11 o'clock, A.M. The remains were interred in the Cemetery at New-Brunswick.

abstract: The U.S. sloop of war Vandalia. Commander ARTHUR SINCLAIR, arrived at this port yesterday, (Jan. 1,) from Valparaiso, making the passage in 81 days, and proceeded direct to the Navy-Yard. She left Panama on the evening of the 31st August, 1859, and reports Oct. 26, lat. 56° 39' S., long., 72° 10' W., spoke English bark Pandora, 28 days from Callao, for Cork, Nov. 22, lat. 24° 08', long. 30° 53', spoke the Dutch ship Wilhelmina, 49 days from Amsterdam, for Batavia, Dec. 3, lat. 70° 72', S., long. 28° 58', spoke American whaling bark Falcon, 52 days from New-Bedford, with 100 bbls. sperm oil, Dec. 18, lat. 18° 47' N., long. 58° 35' W., spoke American hermo brig Amy Harwick, of Richmond, Va., 35 days from Rio Janeiro for New-York; reports the Congress, John Adams and Wyoming (all U.S. vessels) at Rio. The John Adams condemned and waiting orders for home. Just before midnight on the 15th Dec. in lat. 17° 34' N., long. 55° 49' W., experienced the shock of an earthquake, which lasted about five seconds. It was accompanied by a low rumbling noise and strong reverberation throughout the ship, particularly at the helm. The wind, which was northeast, immediately veered to the eastward and decreased.

The John Adams condemned and waiting orders for home. abstract: In the United States Senate, yesterday, Mr. KING of New-York, in presenting the resolutions of the Rochester Union meeting, took occasion to vouch for the decided conservative tendencies of Northern sentiment, and to protest against the facility with which the idea of disunion is discussed. Ex-Governor BROWN, of Mississippi, subsequently spoke at length, complaining of the statement in the President's Message that the question of Slavery is settled; and declared that it never would be settled until adequate provision had been made by act of Congress for the protection of slave-property in the Territories. He had no objection to have such legislation termed a "slave-code;" the epithet was as unexceptionable as a "horse-code" or a "cow-code." Having urged the extreme Southern view upon the subject, Mr. BROWN yielded the floor to Mr. DOOLITTLE, of "Wisconsin, who charged Southern Senators with degrading labor, by declaring it fit only for the negro. The charge was vehemently denied by Messrs. Clay, of Alabama, by Mr. BROWN, and others, and provoked an animated debate.
lead_paragraph: In the United States Senate, yesterday, Mr. KING of New-York, in presenting the resolutions of the Rochester Union meeting, took occasion to vouch for the decided conservative tendencies of Northern sentiment, and to protest against the facility with which the idea of disunion is discussed. He had no objection to have such legislation termed a "slave-code;" the epithet was as unexceptionable as a "horse-code" or a "cow-code." Having urged the extreme Southern view upon the subject, Mr. BROWN yielded the floor to Mr. DOOLITTLE, of "Wisconsin, who charged Southern Senators with degrading labor, by declaring it fit only for the negro. The charge was vehemently denied by Messrs. Clay, of Alabama, by Mr. BROWN, and others, and provoked an animated debate.

Deaths from external and other causes, and depending -upon climate or season -- Asphyxia, 1; burned or scalded, 4; casualties, 3 , cyanosis, 1; drowned, 1; intemperance, 2; lock jaw, 1; lue[???]enerea, 1; malformation, 1; old age, 4; premature birth, 5; suicide, 1; total, 25. In addition to the above, there are 27 stillborn.

abstract: Mr. SEWARD's reception at Auburn on Friday was exceedingly enthusiastic. Ten thousand persons assembled to welcome his return; the streets were hung with banners, the houses covered with inscriptions; the children of the schools were stationed in a body at the Railroad depot, and two military Companies paraded as a guard of honor. On the arrival of Mr. SEWARD he was welcomed by Maj. BRIGGS, and an address was delivered by MICHARL S. MYERS, Esq.
lead_paragraph: Mr. SEWARD's reception at Auburn on Friday was exceedingly enthusiastic. Ten thousand persons assembled to welcome his return; the streets were hung with banners, the houses covered with inscriptions; the children of the schools were stationed in a body at the Railroad depot, and two military Companies paraded as a guard of honor. On the arrival of Mr. SEWARD he was welcomed by Maj. BRIGGS, and an address was delivered by MICHARL S. MYERS, Esq.

abstract: The Message of Governor MORGAN is a much less imposing piece of literary composition than the similar document recently delivered by Governor WISE to the Legislature of Virginia. Where the Executive of the Old Dominion dilates into Pythian pictures of civil war and coming chaos, the Chief Magistrate of the Empire State meekly balances the books of the Commonwealth; and the space which is surrendered by the one to Federal relations and the "great argument" of Union is consumed by the other in a detailed discussion of prison accounts and a careful examination into the claims of rival systems of transportation. This contrast must force itself upon the attention of every man whose fate has compelled him to peruse both of these papers, and it involves perhaps the chief value of Gov. MORGAN's manifesto to the nation at large. For it perfectly illustrates the actual difference between the positions of the Northern and the Southern States. In the message of the Governor of Virginia the affair at Harper's Ferry, with all its antecedents, significances and possible results, led the van and took up the main line of his discourse. Five solid columns of this journal were filled with the lucubrations of the Governor on this head. In the message of the Governor of New-York, the relations of this State with our Southern confederates, and the bearings of the question of Slavery upon our policy past and present, are dismissed with but little more than half a column of type at the end of the document. These we believe to be the relative prominence of these topics in the Northern and the Southern mind at this moment, and if the calmer and more conservative men of the South would but see it and use it properly, in this fact lies a great hope for an escape from the National difficulties which now environ us. The North cherishes a prevailing desire not to be troubled and excited with this matter, and having heartily repudiated JOHN BROWN, asks nothing better of the South than to be delivered from the further necessity of disowning his ghost.

abstract: FORT LEAVENWORTH, Saturday, Dec. 24, 1859. In August last the steamer on which I had taken  passage was detained at this post long enough to take on board 30,000 bushels of condemned "contract corn," which had been purchased in Nebraska at 83c. The Quartermaster, thus freed from this load of "coals sent to Newcastle," has supplied himself at 40c. To the great scandal of army jobbers, he is using corn tainted with Black Republicanism.

abstract: Notwithstanding the excessive coldness of the weather, which continued to increase throughout the day, till towards evening it became quite intense, there was no coldness in the disposition of our citizens towards the celebration of New Year's. Maugre the depression of the thermometer, and the day was splendid indeed. A light blue sky and a sun that tried to thaw the snow, and failed through no fault of his.
lead_paragraph: Notwithstanding the excessive coldness of the weather, which continued to increase throughout the day, till towards evening it became quite intense, there was no coldness in the disposition of our citizens towards the celebration of New Year's. abstract: Justice WELSH, of the City Hall Police Court, called upon Mayor WOOD yesterday, and represented that the rooms assigned to that Court were damp and unhealthy and unfit for his occupancy, on account of the delicate state of his health. The Judge presented this matter several months ago to the consideration of the Common Council, who up to this time have taken no action on the matter. Mayor WOOD admitted the justice of the Judge's complaint, and appeared to think that suitable rooms for the Court might be obtained in some other part of the Hall, or in the neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: Justice WELSH, of the City Hall Police Court, called upon Mayor WOOD yesterday, and represented that the rooms assigned to that Court were damp and unhealthy and unfit for his occupancy, on account of the delicate state of his health. The Judge presented this matter several months ago to the consideration of the Common Council, who up to this time have taken no action on the matter. Mayor WOOD admitted the justice of the Judge's complaint, and appeared to think that suitable rooms for the Court might be obtained in some other part of the Hall, or in the neighborhood.

abstract: The Croton Aqueduct Board have prepared their last annual report, which is now in the hands of the printers. For the past year the total receipts have been $800,219 44. Of this amount $748,030 62 were for water rents, $21,723 for permits to connect with sewers, $10,319 83 for penalties on water rents, and $1,629 25 for old materials sold. The expenditure in supervision and repairs of the Aqueduct, from the Croton Dam to the Receiving Reservoir, has been $18,046 22. This includes a heavy loss sustained by the lower distributing reservoir by the burning of the Crystal Palace, together with the expenses of keeping stations at intervals along the line of the work, for keeping records of the falling of rain. Upon the new reservoir in process of erection in Central Park, including rock excavations and other fundamental work, there has been expended thus far, $501,392 49. Maps and calculations of the topographical surveys of the Croton Valley have been completed during the year, giving the Board accurate knowledge as to the capacity of the Croton River to supply the future wants of the City. There have been laid 17,027 feet of new water-pipe, costing $92,452 01. In repairing and rebuilding old sewers, and repairing culverts and manholes, there has been expended $31,081. For street expenses and paving there has been expended $77,299 11. On account of salaries, there has been paid $26,962 14. Total disbursements on the Croton Water Works extension have been $979,000.

abstract: The correspondent of the St. Paul Minnesotian writes from Minneapolis as follows: "During the time of the visual payment made to the Chippewas a year ago, a Chippewa warrior was shot dead by another of a different band, of the same tribe. Although, strong efforts were made at the time by the civil authorities to effect an arrest, yet the murderer escaped. Nothing was known of his whereabouts until he turned up last week at Swan River. Having entered the camp, the squaw of the murdered warrior recognized him. She immediately procured a gun and shot him dead. His brother, who happened to be present, leveled his rifle and killed the widow on the spot. Her brother then shot the latter, and was in turn killed. Thus, four had fallen to satiate the retaliating vengeance so sweet to savages who have no proper conception of what justice is.
lead_paragraph: The correspondent of the St. Paul Minnesotian writes from Minneapolis as follows: "During the time of the visual payment made to the Chippewas a year ago, a Chippewa warrior was shot dead by another of a different band, of the same tribe. abstract: A fire, most distressing in its results, occurred yesterday morning, in the double four story brick tenement house No. 203 Division-street, by which the lives of two adults and four children were sacrificed It originated in a grocery-store, on the first floor of the building, and situated at the right of the main entrance. Mrs. CHRISTIANA SCHLOSSER was the owner of the store, and the basement of the premises was also occupied as sleeping apartments by Mrs. S. and her family.

Mrs. CHRISTIANA SCHLOSSER was the owner of the store, and the basement of the premises was also occupied as sleeping apartments by Mrs. S. and her family.

abstract: GENTLEMEN: To you has been intrusted the legislative department of the City Government. Under the restrictions of the Charier you are required to pass such ordinances and municipal regulations as will provide for the better improvement, protection, comfort and health of the City. I hope you will appreciate the high character of these trusts. The official position you hold toward the people of a city so distinguished as this should enlarge the comprehension of your duties, and enable you to perform them with a stern fidelity and a just pride. If Now-York is the first city of the Western World, her local government should be made to approximate, in a degree at least, to that prominence. Her rulers, to truly represent her people, should imitate them in enterprise, integrity and intelligence. Of late years the tendency has been in. an opposite direction. As she has grown great and powerful, her municipal government appears to have become the more demoralized and enfeebled. This should not be. Let us jointly endeavor to introduce a more elevated public spirit -- to act as if we were proud of our position, and had no other objects to attain than those which will redound to the honor, interest and prosperity of the Metropolis, whose people we represent.

abstract: "Mercury," writing to the Baltimore Sun, says: "The report of the Auditor of the Treasury for the Post-office Department, not yet published, contains many matters of public interest. A few items now The amount of postage stamps and stamped envelopes sold by postmasters during; the fiscal year, was $6,158,145 90; of which there were used and canceled, $5,741, 130 97. Leaving in the possession of the purchasers, $17,014 93. The average number of accounts of contractors and others engaged in carrying mails, in each quarter, was, on regular mail routes, 8,723; on special mail routes, 3,422; route and express agents, 468; mail passengers and local agents, 1,704; total number of accounts, 14,337. Aggregate of settlements during the year, 57,348. Surplus commissions accrued, after deducting the maximum compensation of the postmasters and necessary incidental expenses: At Baltimore, Md., $672 50 Washington, D.C, $4,706 32; Norfolk, Va., $125 75; Wilmington, Del., $1,865 64; Richmond, Va., $643 28; Petersburgh, Va., $298 48.

abstract: A great many holders of "The Five per cent, Water Stock of the City of New-York," issued under the law of May 2,1834, and redeemable on and after Jan. 1, 1860, amounting to $2,500,000, presented themselves at the Comptroller's office, yesterday, and their certificates, the interest on which ceased yesterday, were duly paid. The Comptroller is ready to redeem all of the outstanding certificates.
lead_paragraph: A great many holders of "The Five per cent, Water Stock of the City of New-York," issued under the law of May 2,1834, and redeemable on and after Jan. 1, 1860, amounting to $2,500,000, presented themselves at the Comptroller's office, yesterday, and their certificates, the interest on which ceased yesterday, were duly paid. The Comptroller is ready to redeem all of the outstanding certificates.

abstract: Mayor Wood's Message has been sent to the Common Council, and will be found in this morning's TIMES. It is mainly devoted to showing that the Mayor, under the present Charter, has little or no influence in the government of the City. He has no control over either the Finances, or the Law Department, or the Police, or Public Education, or the Street Department, or the City Inspector's Department, or the Board of Supervisors.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Wood's Message has been sent to the Common Council, and will be found in this morning's TIMES. It is mainly devoted to showing that the Mayor, under the present Charter, has little or no influence in the government of the City. He has no control over either the Finances, or the Law Department, or the Police, or Public Education, or the Street Department, or the City Inspector's Department, or the Board of Supervisors. The obvious inference from all this is, that the Mayor can scarcely be held responsible for any abuse whatever, except so far as his personal influence is concerned. If the results of this system are bad, the remedy, of course, consists in giving the Mayor more power -- and this Mr. WOOD imperatively demands at the hands of the Legislature.

abstract: It is generally known that Prince Lucien Bonaparte is endeavoring to obtain, for philological purposes, specimens of the several dialects which prevail in this country, the Song of Solomon being selected as the subject of interpretation. He has already secured specimens in the Cumberland, Westmorland, South Lancashire, and many of the Southern dialects; and now requires the "brogue" of Lancashire north of the Kibble. The Prince has visited Lancaster for that purpose, but failed to meet with any one who could assist him in this branch of his inquiry.

abstract: Hon. Isaac Blackford, senior Judge of the Court of Claims, died in Washington on the evening of the 31st ult. He was appointed by President Pierce, in 1853, and was indefatigable in the discharge of his duties. He was a resident of the State of Indiana at  the time of his appointment, held a high rank in the legal profession, and was much esteemed as a citizen and friend.

abstract: The $25,000 added to the appropriations of 1859, by the Common Council, for street cleaning, let it be borne in mind, was made to cover the arrearages of that year. There is no money appropriated at the present time for street cleaning. The Comptroller has addressed a communication to the City Inspector, calling his attention to the 28th, 31st and 22d sections of the amended Charter of 1857, which severally provide that no expense shall be incurred by any of the departments, whether the object of expenditure shall have been ordered by the Common Council or not, unless an appropriation shall have been previously made covering such expense; that no money shall be drawn from the Treasury with such an appropriation; and that no money shall be paid by the City Chamberlain for any object after the amount authorized to be raised by tax therefor is expended. Under these circumstances it would seem that the street cleaning must be stopped until the Tax Levy is passed, unless the Common Council immediately makes appropriation for it, or some one personally assumes the debt thereby to be incurred. The cost of cleaning the streets last week was only $2,528 43, $600 less than it cost the week before. The snow storm, which put a stop to street-cleaning operations, accounts for the decrease.

abstract: By common consent, the second of January was devoted exclusively as a festive season. All business was suspended, and for once there was a general and uninterrupted holiday. Mayor POWELL kept open house at his office in the City Hall, between the hours of 10 o'clock A.M. and 1 o'clock. P.M., and several hundred citizens called upon Mm to pass the compliments of the season. From an early hour in the morning until a very late hour at night, the streets were filled with gentlemen making their accustomed round of New-Year's calls. Nothing occurred, so far as heard, to mar the pleasures of the day.

abstract: The resolutions passed by the late Common Council, indorsing an application to the Legislature on the part of the Central Park Commissioners for permission to raise, if necessary, a loan of $2,500,000, for the completion of the Park, drew from the Ex-Mayor a veto, in which he states at some length his objections to the present rate of expenditure for Park purposes. They are two in number.
lead_paragraph: The resolutions passed by the late Common Council, indorsing an application to the Legislature on the part of the Central Park Commissioners for permission to raise, if necessary, a loan of $2,500,000, for the completion of the Park, drew from the Ex-Mayor a veto, in which he states at some length his objections to the present rate of expenditure for Park purposes. They are two in number. The first is, that it is unfair to throw on posterity the burden of paying for a work which they did not authorize or control; and the second is, that if the contract system were adopted by the Commissioners, the Park could be constructed for a much less sum than it is now costing. He proposes that the work should be completed gradually, in such a way that the taxation of each year should be able to pay for the expenditure of that year. This amounts to a suggestion that the final completion of the Park be deferred for eight or nine years, and that the present generation should pay every cent of the cost.

abstract: David W. Wetmore vs. The Steamboat Granite State. This case came up on exceptions to the report of a Commissioner to whom it was referred to ascertain the damages sustained by the libellant by reason of the sinking of the barge Rambler, owned by him by the Granite State. abstract: After the amount of the salaries of the Inspectors of Registry and their clerks was fixed by the Board of Supervisors, the Comptroller's office was for several days besieged by those who were entitled to the stipulated compensation. Many of those appointed by the Board of Supervisors to act in accordance with the provisions of the Registry Law, were not overburdened with riches, and the unlooked for delay in paying them off, which must continue until the Tax Levy for 1860 is passed by the Legislature, was seriously felt by these. Comptroller HAWS had no authority, of course, to draw his warrants in their favor, and the City Chamberlain was not authorized to pay them.

abstract: Week before last, a rumor of a defalcation in one of the moneyed institutions in State-street was whispered about, but was believed at that time to have no foundation in fact, and it was so announced in the Traveler and other papers. On the same evening, several persons expressed the opinion, notwithstanding the denial of the evening papers, that the rumor was true. This was allowed to pass without further notice, but last week a bank-officer again stated that a defalcation had occurred, and that the deficiency had been settled by the friends of the guilty party. It was for the purpose of having this matter set at rest, if possible, that the paragraph was published in ear paper of Wednesday. Since that publication, the Manager of the Clearing-house, Mr. GROVES, has called upon us to state that no defalcation is knows to have taken place in any of the Banks of Boston, and the Bee, one of whose editors is a Bank Commissioner, declares that no foundation can be found for the rumor. If such is the fact, we are glad to know it, and we are especially pleased to know that there has been no compounding of felony like that of twenty years ago, when a Bank officer, after disgorging $50,000 or more, was allowed to go without prosecution. Our Boston Banks are well conducted, and no reproach upon their good fame, either privately or through the Press, should be allowed to exist unexplained or uncontradicted. -- Boston Traveller, Dec. 30

abstract: Horace F. Clark and Edward N. Dickerson and Albert G. Sloo vs. George Law, the Panama-Railroad Company, the North Atlantic Steamship Company, and Marshall O. Roberts. -- This action was reported in the TIMES of Dec. 12, 1859, and was before Justice DALY in the Common Pleas. It was a controversy in relation to the ownership of certain dock properly situate on the Isthmus and which the plaintiffs claim belong to them, as the Trustees of the United States Mail Steamship Company; while Mr. Law claimed to be the owner of the fee, and that the other defendants as well as the Company represented by the plaintiffs, were his tenants and had each of them acknowledged his title by payment of mortgage, and that the plaintiff could not now, in consequence thereof, set up adverse claims to title. A temporary injunction was allowed, but after the order to show cause was argued, and the matter held under advisement until now, Judge DALY dissolves the injunction, and renders judgment in favor of Law.
lead_paragraph: Horace F. Clark and Edward N. Dickerson and Albert G. Sloo vs. George Law, the Panama-Railroad Company, the North Atlantic Steamship Company, and Marshall O. Roberts. -- This action was reported in the TIMES of Dec. 12, 1859, and was before Justice DALY in the Common Pleas. A temporary injunction was allowed, but after the order to show cause was argued, and the matter held under advisement until now, Judge DALY dissolves the injunction, and renders judgment in favor of Law.

abstract: A meeting comprising about fifty colored persons and half as many whites, convened at the corner of Broadway and Eleventh-street, Brooklyn, Eastern District, last evening. The object, as stated in the call, was to reply to the insults to the African race offered by Mr. CHARLES O'CONOR in his speech at the late Union meeting, in which he sustained the Divine origin and justness of Slavery. Mr. W.A. HODGES was chosen Chairman of the meeting.

abstract: FLORIAN CARTELLO, an Italian, was found on Tuesday night, by Officer ELDER, of the Sixth Precinct, impaled on the iron railings in front of the lager bier saloon No. 74 Duane-street. The man was not quite dead at the time he was discovered, but he expired soon afterwards. The body was removed to the Sixth Ward Station-house. From the evidence which was given at the inquest, held at this place by Coroner SCHIRMER, it appeared that deceased boarded at the house No. 74 Duane-street, and had for some days past been laboring under an attack of delirium, tremens. It is supposed that in his delirum he precipitated himself from a fourth-story window. Deceased was 55 years of age and unmarried.

abstract: MURDER IN PHILADELPHIA. -- Yesterday morning, towards.2 o'clock, a homicide took place in Currant-alley, below Locust-street, in the Eighth Ward. A young man named ANDREW JOHNSON, a deputy constable in the Fourth Ward, was the victim. He was in the house No. 226 Currant-alley, kept by a woman named ANNE JOHNSON when the occurrence took place. ABBE is known as "Madame Rush," and has the reputation of keeping a bawdy panel-house. According to the story of the deceased he was in the house, and the woman attempted to rob him; a scuffle ensued, during which two men named BISHOP RUTTER, alias "Bush Rutter," and WM. BURKE, alias "Burkey," rushed in upon him and inflicted the wounds which caused his death. Two of the Eighth Ward officers were passing at the time, and hearing the scuffle, entered and arrested BURKE, RUTTEK, ANNE JOHNSON, and the deceased. BURKE was found in a place of concealment, from which he was taken. JOHNSON was taken to the hospital in a dying condition. There whre some ten or twelve stabs in his body, in one of which was found a common pocket-knife blade about two and a half inches in length. Soon after reaching the hospital he expired. -- Philadelphia Press, Jan. 4.

abstract: The St. Lawrence is not a mile broad at Quebec; it is two miles across at Montreal. Yet it now takes but five minutes to dash from one to the other shore at Montreal, while at Quebec from one to six hours are necessary! In the one case the passenger rushes through the Victoria Bridge; in the other he entrusts himself to a canoe.
lead_paragraph: Correspondence of the New-York Times.

abstract: The bill to abolish the franking privilege was introduced into the Senate of the United States by Ex-Gov. POWELL, of Kentucky.
lead_paragraph: The bill to abolish the franking privilege was introduced into the Senate of the United States by Ex-Gov. POWELL, of Kentucky. Then came up again the Houmas Land Fraud, a memorial in reference to which Mr. TOOMBS desired to have referred to the Committee on Public Lands. This reference having been objected to, it was finally consigned to a Select Committee of five. Mr. WIGFALL, the newly-chosen Senator from Texas, was introduced by his colleague, and took the oath. The word "servile," applied to the Free States by Mr. MASON, on a previous occasion, elicited an explanation from that gentleman, the purport of which was that as whites filled menial positions at the North, the epithet was not inapplicable to Northern society. At length Mr. HARLAN, of Iowa, who was entitled to the floor, obtained it. He entered into an extended discussion of that portion of the President's Message which alludes to the question of Slavery in the Territories, insisting that the ordinance of 1787 was a binding compact, which no judicial decision could abrogate. A warm debate ensued, in which Messrs. PUGH, TRUMBULL and HARLAN participated. Mr. FOSTER, of Connecticut, subsequently obtained a hearing for an attack on the President's recommendations touching Mexico. He desired to know with what propriety we could make war on a foreign power for the protection of American citizens, when American citizens are more severely treated on our own soil than anywhere abroad. He proceeded to read extracts from newspapers to show how universally and indiscriminately Northern people are proscribed in the Slave States. He also objected to the Executive programme upon Constitutional grounds. After a brief Executive Session the Senate adjourned.

abstract: The chief interest in the State Comptroller's Annual Report, which we published at length in the TIMES of yesterday, relates to the Canal Finances. These, from the constitutional diversion in 1846 of a large share of the annual surplus revenues of the Canal to the General Fund, and from the important cause of the rapid fall, of late years, in the gross receipts from tolls, have become a charge in a certain measure upon the tax list of the people. The figures of the Report, however, show that after all the financial results of our Canal system, from 1817 to the present day, are taken into account, we have little reason to complain of the difference last year between the 8960,000 surplus revenue from this source and the $1,460,000 interest charge upon the Canal Debt, as it then stood. That the Canals have failed to meet the whole interest charge and all other requirements of the Constitution of 1846, may be the fault in part of extravagant or unwise management, but the main difficulty is unquestionably in the progress, amounting almost to revolution, in the business of internal transportation from the lakes to the seaboard, which no reasonable legislation could check, even if it were desirable, and no discriminating tax upon the rival routes of trade within the State, can remedy. The latter might, possibly, in some measure, be practicable, if the Western trade were within the control, in any sense, of the State of New-York alone. But as Pennsylvania and Maryland are formidable rivals on the South, and the Canada roads are rapidly rising into importance by their direct connection with Detroit and Portland as rivals on the North, for our own domestic carrying and passenger trade, we apprehend that all attempts at discrimination against our New-York roads in favor of the Canals, would result in driving business from both and lessening the commerce of our great seaboard metropolis.

abstract: Officer Houghton, of the Second Precinct, yesterday arrested John S. Brennan, 18 years of age, residing at No. 218 West Twenty-fifth-street, and James E. Silvey, 17 years of age, of No. 291 Tenth-street, on a charge of forgery preferred by John J. Kelly, a merchant, doing business at the corner of Pine and Water streets. It is alleged that Mr. Kelly's name was forged some months ago by Brennan, to a check on the Market Bank, for $124. On this the money was obtained from the Bank by Silvey, and while the funds lasted the young men enjoyed themselves without limitation. Their next effort to obtain money in a similar manner proved a failure. Having presented a check on the same bank for $95, bearing Mr. Kelly's signature, its worthlessness was detected, and Silyer's arrest was effected. His confederate, Brennan, was also taken into custody. Both the lads confessed their guilt, and they were committed by Justice CONNOLLY for examination.

abstract: REPRINTS OF FOREIGN REVIEWS. -- LEONARD SCOTT & Co. continue the republication of the principal Reviews of Great Britain, and Blackwood's Magazine, in the same style and at the price which have made them so popular hitherto. These works have become a necessity to everyone who desires to keep himself properly informed upon the leading topics of current interest and discussion. They do not excite so much commotion as they did in their earlier days, mainly because the daily press has made such rapid strides in advance, and covers so much more of the ground which they were originally intended to occupy. But they were never abler or more interesting and valuable than now. The terms on which they are published will be found in another column.

abstract: The Herald, which is the Underground Abolition organ prepared for circulation in the Southern States, reprints THEODORE PARKER'S declaration, that every slave has a right to kill his master, and that it may be the duty of every freeman to help him, if he can thus secure his liberty.
lead_paragraph: The Herald, which is the Underground Abolition organ prepared for circulation in the Southern States, reprints THEODORE PARKER'S declaration, that every slave has a right to kill his master, and that it may be the duty of every freeman to help him, if he can thus secure his liberty. This is an excellent suggestion for the slaves and the non-slaveholding whites among the Herald's readers at the South, -- and is intended doubtless to take special effect upon them, and stir up another attempt at insurrection. By way of making the appeal still more direct and forcible, the Herald represents PARKER as one "who has long been one of the thinkers and leaders of the Republican Party," -- and thus holds out the idea that the whole party entertains the same sentiments, and is prepared to act upon them whenever the slaves and white non-slaveholders will make a beginning.

abstract: On the 14th ult. a paper on the Great Eastern steamship was read by Mr. W. HAWES before the London Society of Arts, Mr. R.W. CRAWFORD, one of the members for the City of London, in the Chair. Mr. HAWES traced the idea of the great ship from its conception in the brain of Mr. BRUNEL to its realization in the yard of Mr. SCOTT RUSSELL, and gave a brief description of the vessel; after which he proceeded to speak of her destiny, and the great changes in steam navigation and iron ship-building which he believes she will inaugurate. In so doing, he noticed a remark which has been made respecting the absence of means to warm the state rooms and other saloons on a voyage to America:

Mr. HAWES traced the idea of the great ship from its conception in the brain of Mr. BRUNEL to its realization in the yard of Mr. SCOTT RUSSELL, and gave a brief description of the vessel; after which he proceeded to speak of her destiny, and the great changes in steam navigation and iron ship-building which he believes she will inaugurate. In so doing, he noticed a remark which has been made respecting the absence of means to warm the state rooms and other saloons on a voyage to America:

abstract: SALE OF THE STEAMBOAT COMMONWEALTH.-- The steamboat Commonwealth, of the Norwich and New-London line, has been sold to Mr. DANIEL DREW, for the New-Jersey Steamboat Company, and will hereafter run on the Stonington route, in connection  with the Plymouth Rock. This result was foreshadowed a year ago, when an effort was made to obtain from the Norwich and Worcester Railroad Company a more liberal share of the earnings of the route for the boats.
lead_paragraph: SALE OF THE STEAMBOAT COMMONWEALTH.-- The steamboat Commonwealth, of the Norwich and New-London line, has been sold to Mr. DANIEL DREW, for the New-Jersey Steamboat Company, and will hereafter run on the Stonington route, in connection with the Plymouth Rock. This result was foreshadowed a year ago, when an effort was made to obtain from the Norwich and Worcester Railroad Company a more liberal share of the earnings of the route for the boats. At the expiration of the contract, on the first of January, the Railroad Company was informed that unless better terms were conceded, the other parties to the contract would be compelled to supply the service with inferior boats. Failing to accomplish such an agreement as was desired, the sate mentioned above was effected. The line, however, is to be kept up, as the Company still have the Connecticut and Worcester, besides their [???]pellers, by which passengers and freight will go forward as usual. It is probable that the two lines will now change piers, the business of the Stonington [???]te being transferred to Tier No. 18, foot of Cort[???]dt-street, North River; the Norwich propellers and steamers taking possession of Pier No. 2, North River, the present depot of the Stonington [???]ne. As the Norwich river is frozen over, the steamers now and passengers and freight at New-London, the connection being made by the New-London, Palmer and Norwich Railroad. The Commonwealth left Allyn's Point, for the last time, on Monday evening, the 2d instant, since which time she has made no trip. The Connecticut is still running, and left New-London yesterday morning, having been detained to receive the freight which it is now necessary to send around by the way of Norwich. The Commonwealth was built in 1855, at Greenpoint, by LAWRENCE & FOULKS, and the engine by the Morgan Ironworks. She cost $240,000, and has been a very fortunate boat, never having met with any serious accident. Capt. WILLIAMS, the present popular commander, will continue to have charge of her on the new route.

abstract: The special correspondent in Italy of the London Daily News went to Scandiano to see a battalion of 400 children, quartered in the old castle. He says: "The first idea of recruiting this legion of children belongs to Gen. GARIBALDI. When engaged in the South American wars, and in the defence of Rome in 1849, this gallant leader had noticed that boys between the ages of 13 and 15 years had proved useful in the daring military operations he was called to accomplish. At the beginning of the late campaign, having found that the Lombard cities through which he marched his triumphant legions had given their contingent of young soldiers, he at once made up his mind to have a battalion of adolescenti organized. An intelligent young officer, whom he had known during the Roman campaign of 1849, being near at hand, he intrusted him with the formation of the legion, which at the beginning aid not number more than 150. Austrian persecutions and patriotism soon increased the number of the adolescenti, so that the battalion has now completed its numerical strength. These little soldiers are dressed in a dark green tunic, with red cuffs with a white edge, and dark green trousers. On my arrival here this morning from Reggio I happened to see them while maneuvering on the parade ground opposite to the castle. I was really at the same time astonished and amused to see how perfect and orderly their movements were. They went through all sorts of military evolutions with such steadiness and precision as could scarcely have been surpassed by grownup soldiers after many months of training and drilling. Their commanding officer, Count JOHN ARRIVABENE, is a young nobleman of three-and-twenty. He belongs to an illustrious Mantuan family, which, since 1821, has contributed a great many soldiers to the cause of national independence. Although I really believe that this battalion of boys will do good service should it be called to fight against the enemies of Italian independence, its chief importance is of a moral kind, and is such as will be easily under stood by all sensible men in Europe. This gathering of the representatives of the rising generation around the flag of their country should be taken as a warning to Europe that there cannot be any compromise, any temporary solution, of a question which has taken such hold not only of all classes but all ages."

abstract: The Mayor's Office is to be open for the transaction of public business from 9 A.M. to 3 P.M. hereafter. Yesterday the influx of office-seekers and others thither was uninterrupted during office hours. Officer WILSON B. DUTCHER, of the Twentieth Precinct, who was the doorman of the present Mayor when he was Chief Magistrate before, has been detailed for duty at the Mayor's office by the General Superintendent, at the request of Mayor WOOD. Officers BALDWIN and MCARTHUR, who were posted at the Mayor's office under the old regime, have been directed to report to Capt. LEONARD, of the Twenty-sixth Precinct, for patrol duty.

abstract: At the request of his congregation, Rev. T. Starr King, of Boston, has withdrawn his letter of resignation, and has accepted leave of absence for fifteen months. This will enable him to remain in California a year, and if at any time he should feel desirous to dissolye his connection with the parish, he can do so, and the Society has the same power. This arrangement received the unanimous assent of the large parish meeting, and is in the highest degree creditable to all parties. Mr. King will probably sail for San Francisco early in April.

abstract: We published yesterday a remarkable letter from LIEBIG, the great German chemist, addressed to MECHI, the famous English farmer, upon that most momentous of all sublunary themes, the production of corn. He shows that the corn-producing power of the civilized, cultivated countries of the globe, is rapidly becoming exhausted; that it is owing to guano that the decline has not been more rapid and more marked; but that the existing supply of...
lead_paragraph: We published yesterday a remarkable letter from LIEBIG, the great German chemist, addressed to MECHI, the famous English farmer, upon that most momentous of all sublunary themes, the production of corn. He shows that the corn-producing power of the civilized, cultivated countries of the globe, is rapidly becoming exhausted; that it is owing to guano that the decline has not been more rapid and more marked; but that the existing supply of guano, if it continues to be consumed at its present rate, will not last more than twenty-five or thirty years at the utmost. He predicts accordingly, that unless war, or pestilence, or famine, or emigration en masse, largely diminishes the population of the older countries, they will find themselves, at no very distant day, if the existing system of cultivation be pursued, in actual want of bread, and the Malthusian theory will thus receive an early and certainly unlooked-for exemplification.
headline: {'main': 'Dearth of Food--A Startling View.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Dearth of Food--A Startling View.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The regular stated meeting of the Academy of Medicine was held on Wednesday evening last, Dr. J. WATSON, President, in the Chair. The business of the evening was the annual election of some of the officers whose term had expired, and while the ballot was held the President called up the subject of croup and diphtheria, about which there was much confusion in the journals of England and France, and both differing from the American view of these diseases. He then requested Dr. FRANCIS, as the oldest member present, to state his views on the subject. Dr. F. proceeded to give a brief resume of the past literature on the subject -- contrasted the opposing views of Drs. BARD and BAILEY, of this City -- said that Dr. BAILEY's pathology was that it was an inflammatory disease, and his practice, founded upon, this belief -- which was of emetics, hot baths, and even the lancet -- had never been improved. BARD, on the contrary, gave stimulants, but not with the success of BAILEY. JOHN HUNTER agreed with BAILEY. English writers however, seem to have an astonishing ignorance of croup for HAMILTON speaks of the disease as if it lasted a week or more, when hours would be more like it. He had great faith in vitriolic emetics, and gave instances where he had saved lives by heroic doses of the sulphate of zinc. He does not use caustics or stimulants.

abstract: The question of a Broadway Railroad is rapidly settling itself, or rather, the companies which monopolize the present conveyance of City passengers are practically settling it. They are managing the roads and vehicles under their control in such a manner as to make absolutely imperative some additional accommodations for City locomotion.
lead_paragraph: The question of a Broadway Railroad is rapidly settling itself, or rather, the companies which monopolize the present conveyance of City passengers are practically settling it. They are managing the roads and vehicles under their control in such a manner as to make absolutely imperative some additional accommodations for City locomotion. Under present arrangements it is utterly impossible to get down town in the morning, or up-town at night, with any comfort, either by railroad or by omnibus. All attempts to limit any of these vehicles to the number of passengers they will hold, have been abandoned. Omnibuses already full are regularly stopped for fresh accessions, and those who have seats are compelled to give them up, or have stout men and women treading on their toes or tumbling into their laps during the whole journey. Any remonstrance on the part of passengers provokes insolence from the driver, and sour looks from the new comers. Some passenger, moreover, must volunteer to collect the fares, or submit to have his toes stepped on in regular succession by every other inmate. The fares are collected "on entering," so that any dissatisfied person is at full liberty to leave at any moment, and give up his seat to somebody else.
headline: {'main': 'City Railroads and City Travel.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'City Railroads and City Travel.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Mr. MASON'S explanation of what he meant by the epithet "servile" which he applies to Northern States, to distinguish them from what are called the "Slave States" of the South, is a very good specimen of that laborious hunting for parallels which in heated controversies often supplies the place of argument.
lead_paragraph: Mr. MASON'S explanation of what he meant by the epithet "servile" which he applies to Northern States, to distinguish them from what are called the "Slave States" of the South, is a very good specimen of that laborious hunting for parallels which in heated controversies often supplies the place of argument. The Senator from Virginia is apparently, and we must say, when we consider his theory and practice of social economy, rather oddly restive under the designation of "Slave States " commonly applied to his own part of the country, and while he is unable to dispute the accuracy of the term, seeks to lessen its force by the invention of a new phrase to define the exact condition of domestic servants at the North, or rather of those among the servants of the North who wear livery. He seems to attach a serious importance to "livery," as an instrument in assimilating the real condition of a hired servant at the North to that of a negro slave at the South; and if there be any solid comfort concealed in the comparison we certainly would not grudge it him. But wherein that comfort consists we confess we do not see. It is due to all parties in the controversy which is now rending the country, to admit that there is a real, radical and essential difference in the condition of the laboring classes in the two sections of the Union, and all attempts to make it appear that there is no such difference at all, or that the difference is but superficial and trifling, instead of allaying must increase the existing irritation. If all the servants at the North wore livery instead of a very small number, as is actually the case, this sartorial fact would prove nothing for Mr. MASON's side of the case. Livery is simply a coat of a particular color, with buttons of a particular kind, and, of itself, the wearing of livery is in no way degrading or humiliating. Whether it shall disgrace the wearer or not depends altogether upon his reason for appearing in it. If he wears it in virtue of a contract voluntarily entered into by himself, and supported by a valuable consideration -- a contract which he can abrogate at any time upon reasonable notice -- it is ridiculous to assert that he is degraded or made servile by his coat and buttons any more than by fulfilling any other agreement which may entail discomfort or inconvenience. There is a certain loss of "independence" implied in doing anything for other people, but the constant and incessant doing of things which we would not do if we could help it, and which are more or less irksome and disagreeable, is unfortunately one of the first conditions of existence for the mass of mankind throughout the world, even at the present day. "Wearing a livery is one mode of proclaiming to everybody that the wearer is a coachman or footman; but if he is remunerated at his own price for any loss and damage which this sort of advertisement may entail on him, it is very difficult to see in what essential particular he is worse off than a Senator of the United States, an officer of the American army, or anybody else who accepts pay for publicly exercising his vocation. If he were compelled to wear the livery whether he would or no, on pain of imprisonment or flogging, or some other physical indignity and violence, it would of course alter the whole aspect of the case. In short, it is not in their manner of passing their time or in the nature of their occupations, that Northern laborers differ from Southern slaves, but in their motive for following any occupation at all. Both of them dig and delve, and lead, as all men must lead who labor for a livelihood a tolerably uncomfortable life; but the free laborer does so in virtue of a voluntary and legal contract the slave simply to avoid punishment. In the comparisons which Southern gentlemen are constantly drawing between the condition of the two classes, this distinction is entirely overlooked; but we must say we do not see what is gained by the sophism fur sophism it is.
headline: {'main': 'Slavery and Servitude.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Slavery and Servitude.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

lead_paragraph: The communication from our Vera Cruz correspondent, which appeared in the TIMES of Wednesday, announced the fact that the Church faction in the City of Mexico, with Messrs. GABRIAC, JECKER Co., would shrink from no expense, and stick at no measures, to prevent the ratification of the McLane treaty by the United States Congress. The Journal of Commerce, of Thursday, contains a communication purporting to be from its Washington correspondent, in which are to be found such reckless statements, so much animosity towards the Liberals, and a defence of MIRAMON so labored and extravagant, that it is impossible to avoid regarding them as a timely commentary upon the warning of our correspondent.

abstract: The steamship Bohemian arrived at Portland last evening, from Liverpool December 21, and from Queenstown Dec. 22. The news is four days later. The meeting of the Congress is definitely fixed for January 20. The Representatives of the Powers are nearly all officially announced, as already indicated, including Count CAVOUR for Sardinia. The London Times, commenting on the execution of BROWN, ridicules the Northern sympathy when too late, and predicts that the matter will tend to strengthen the South. The weather in England and France was excessively severe, but had moderated. The Spanish forces were concentrated at Ceuta, but the Moors were still the assailants. Another engagement was reported, and as disastrous to the Moors. Numerous political arrests at Naples are reported. The reported intended abdication of the Emperor of Austria is unfounded. Austria was reducing her army. The affairs of Hungary were daily more threatening. Important submissions to Russia in the Caucusas were reported.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Bohemian arrived at Portland last evening, from Liverpool December 21, and from Queenstown Dec. 22. The news is four days later. abstract: Mayor WOOD has issued a public notice of certain rules by which he proposes to be governed in administering the high office to which he has been chosen. In the main these rules are admirable, and one of them in particular, which promises the establishment of a sort of bureau for the protection of emigrants, immediately under the eye of the Mayor himself, in the City Hall, deserves to be commended in the warmest terms.
lead_paragraph: Mayor WOOD has issued a public notice of certain rules by which he proposes to be governed in administering the high office to which he has been chosen. In the main these rules are admirable, and one of them in particular, which promises the establishment of a sort of bureau for the protection of emigrants, immediately under the eye of the Mayor himself, in the City Hall, deserves to be commended in the warmest terms. If Mayor WOOD will but carry out this regulation in the spirit and the letter, he will fairly earn a civic crown. Nothing has contributed more to lower the character of our City, at home and abroad, than the disgraceful degree in which our authorities have fallen short of their duty to the poor and friendless foreigners whom our laws, our necessities, and the splendid opportunities of our empire, are perpetually inviting to our shores.

abstract: The Trustees of the Massachusetts State Reform School state that the number of inmates of that institution is 507. The number known to have deceased is 42. This leaves a total of 1,988, whose history has been the subject of inquiry. Of this number the career of about 300 cannot be traced with certainty. The history and character of 1,053 boys have been ascertained -- 281 of these have turned out badly. This is 14 1-7 per cent. on the total of 1,988 -- 1,372 of these boys are known to have done well. This is 69 per cent. of all who have gone forth from the institution. In this calculation, in all cases of doubt, the doubt is reckoned against the institution; although in a large number of instances the probabilities were in favor of a thorough reformation.
lead_paragraph: The Trustees of the Massachusetts State Reform School state that the number of inmates of that institution is 507. The number known to have deceased is 42. abstract: The Chambers of Commerce of Hamburg and Bremen have issued a memorial on the subject of the rights of neutrals at sea in time of war, and are about to make an attempt to bring the whole subject once more before the coming European Congress at Paris. As the case stands at present, the European Powers have abolished privateering, and have acknowledged that the neutral flag shall cover even an enemy's goods.
lead_paragraph: The Chambers of Commerce of Hamburg and Bremen have issued a memorial on the subject of the rights of neutrals at sea in time of war, and are about to make an attempt to bring the whole subject once more before the coming European Congress at Paris. As the case stands at present, the European Powers have abolished privateering, and have acknowledged that the neutral flag shall cover even an enemy's goods. They have exempted neutral goods also under an enemy's flag from capture, always excepting, of course, the case of contraband of war. Our Government has already given in its adhesion to these rules, excluding that which abolishes privateering, on which point the United States maintain their old rights, but offer to adopt this rule, also, if the European Powers will agree to declare all private property at sea inviolate, precisely as private property on shore now is, in time of war. The Hanse Towns now ask for the following settlement of certain vexed questions:
