abstract: ANTI-RENTISM. -- There was some anti-rent excitement in Sandlake, Rensselaer County, on Wednesday, consequent upon the seizure of fourteen head of cattle, the property of a farmer named WHEELER, by Deputy-Sheriffs GRIGGS and MINICK, on an execution of about $600, issued in favor of W.S. CHURCH. The cattle were taken to Troy and are advertised to be sold on Tuesday next. Several anti-renters undertook to make a rescue, but WHEELER counseled peace, and they allowed the cattle to be removed. -- Albany Argus, Jan. 6.

abstract: Now we submit that this is putting FARNHAM in exactly the position of JOHN BROWN. FARNHAM went to Africa in the teeth of the laws, just as BROWN, in the teeth of the laws went to Virginia, for the benefit of the negroes. The one is a martyr of Slavery, the other a martyr of Freedom, and both out of pure love for the negro. FARNHAM is worse than a fool: he is a philanthropist: a sort of marine HOWARD, who sought to "do good by stealth," and may well therefore "blush to find it fame."

abstract: The proposal made by Mr. MONTGOMERY, of Pennsylvania, for a temporary organization of the House, for the purpose of voting money to pay the Government contractors, appears on the face of it to be illegal, or at all events, unprecedented, and we presume therefore it will not be entertained. But we must say we cannot help regretting that it is not feasible and will not be adopted. If a Speaker could be elected and hold office just long enough to enable the House to vote the supplies for the coming year, we do not believe the people would trouble themselves much about its doings afterwards. The appropriations made, it would no doubt instantly veer to the old occupation of discussing Slavery, the political antecedents of the members, and HELPER's book, and would drag along through the remainder of the session almost unnoticed. The only thing which causes anybody now to devote any attention to the dreary columns of verbiage and vituperation which the telegraph forwards us every day from Washington, is the feeling that they may perhaps contain indications of the chances of an organization, or of the person likely to be elected Speaker. But if the hope, as well as the pressing necessity of having a Speaker at all, were once past, the number of those who would find any time for their perusal would be exceedingly small, and the members of the House would return to their homes at the proper period without exciting either attention or remark.
lead_paragraph: The proposal made by Mr. MONTGOMERY, of Pennsylvania, for a temporary organization of the House, for the purpose of voting money to pay the Government contractors, appears on the face of it to be illegal, or at all events, unprecedented, and we presume therefore it will not be entertained. But we must say we cannot help regretting that it is not feasible and will not be adopted. If a Speaker could be elected and hold office just long enough to enable the House to vote the supplies for the coming year, we do not believe the people would trouble themselves much about its doings afterwards. The appropriations made, it would no doubt instantly veer to the old occupation of discussing Slavery, the political antecedents of the members, and HELPER's book, and would drag along through the remainder of the session almost unnoticed. The only thing which causes anybody now to devote any attention to the dreary columns of verbiage and vituperation which the telegraph forwards us every day from Washington, is the feeling that they may perhaps contain indications of the chances of an organization, or of the person likely to be elected Speaker. But if the hope, as well as the pressing necessity of having a Speaker at all, were once past, the number of those who would find any time for their perusal would be exceedingly small, and the members of the House would return to their homes at the proper period without exciting either attention or remark.

abstract: A DESPERATE MURDERER. -- We learn from the Mount Holly (N.Y.) Mirror, that on Thursday evening of last week LYNCH attempted to escape from the Court-room where his trial was going on. At the time the Court adjourned, about 7 o'clock, the number in attendance was unusually large, LYNCH started from his seat, as the prisoner began to move out, and in the crowd and confusion, he had got half-way to the door, before the discovery was made. He was proceeding towards the door as fast as possible, when he was seized and secured, though not without a hard struggle. During the remainder of his trial, two or three constables were constantly by his side. After the verdict of the Jury, and he was taken back to his cell, it was deemed necessary to put him in irons, and to accomplish this, it required the full strength of five men. He begged of the Sheriff to shoot him, out him in pieces, or kill him in any way, and it he would not do it, go and ask the Judge to do it, rather than to chain him to the floor.

abstract: A FAITHFUL ALLY. -- The underground Abolition organ is doing its work thoroughly. Having exhausted the incendiary literature of the ultra Abolitionists elicited by the John Brown affair, it has now sent special reporters to examine the condition of the fugitive slaves in Canada, and is also compiling a history of all the attempts which have been made in past years to organize insurrections among the Southern slaves. Going thus into the South, the Herald informs the negroes of the region that is ready to receive them, and then gives them the benefit of past experience as to the best mode of organizing fresh rebellion. While its editorial articles quiet the unsuspecting slave-owners, its news columns are filled with the most inflammatory appeals to the slaves. Who hereafter will stigmatize the Abolitionists as mere speculative enthusiasts?

abstract: DISCOVERY OF COUNTERFEIT BILLS. -- The Cincinnati Enquirer says: "A few days since, a man of good address and genteel appearance, called at the residence of Mr. WILLIAMS, in Manufacturer's Block, Newport, and, after inquiring for the head of the family, who was absent at the time, left a package with Mrs. W., carefully folded in a shawl, which he said a Mr. RIGGS would call for during the day. The package was laid aside, but as Mr. RIGGS did not call for it at the appointed time, it was opened, and found to contain about $7,000, in three, five, ten and twenty-dollar bills, all counterfeit, on the following banks: $2,000 on the North-western Bank of Virginia; $3,000 on the Hatter's Bank of Connecticut; $200 on the Merchants' Bank of Connecticut; and $2,000 on the Farmers' and Traders' Bank of Pennsylvania. The bills are said to be well executed, and nearly all signed and ready for 'shoving.' It is thought by the Newport officers that a good deal of other bogus money is secreted in their town, and now that they are in possession of a clue.

abstract: The Italian question, matured amidst the struggles and sufferings of half a century, has just entered a phase which it may be perhaps permitted us to consider the final one. Under the penalty of allowing Europe to rush into complications, the issue of which could be foreseen by no person, it is necessary that Italy shall cease to be a menace to a prey for the nations that surround her.

abstract: The first annual report of the State Assessors, which was received yesterday, is among the most important which will come before the Legislature this session. It is in two parts -- the first giving the proceedings of the Assessors in regard to equalizing the taxes the past year, and embracing a large amount of interesting statistics. The second recommends an entire and radical change in the present assessment laws, so as to equalize the taxes upon all the property of the State, by adopting the gross income, rather than property, as the bases for taxing.

abstract: To America belongs the honor of giving to the world many new inventions of great practical importance to mankind. Prominent among these are the Electric Telegraph, the Reaper and Mower, and the Sewing-Machine. What the telegraph is to the commercial world, the reaper to the agricultural, the sewing-machine is to the domestic.

Nothing in fiction can surpass the dramatic contrasts of the Wanderer's experience. To-day a lovely...
lead_paragraph: Gen. HENNINGSEN's letter, which we published on Thursday, to Capt. FARNHAM, late of the Wanderer, and now lying in jail at Savannah on a charge of slave-trading, is perfectly of a piece, in the way of originality, with the whole curious and unprecedented history of that now famous vessel. Nothing in fiction can surpass the dramatic contrasts of the Wanderer's experience. To-day a lovely yacht lying u.t anchor in Iteiv-5:ork Bay, under the flag of a club of elegant nautical amateurs; to-morrow a slave-ship, gliding along with her hideous freight beneath t?fie cliffs of Southern Cuba; no:as ing at fast and loose in either character upon the coast of Africa, by turns the delight of British tars and of slay e-dealing negro kings; then slipping craftily out from the very clutches of the -enue of Savannah ;_ again, stealing Portuguese women from an AClantic island, or showing her heels. to her own commander, and making miraculous speed into the arms of the American Government at Boston : would, indeed, be hard to suggest a fairer theme for the genius of a Cooper, a Chamfer, or a Sue, than this truthful story of a " Shimmer of the Seas."

abstract: Samuel B. Althause vs. The Mayor, &c. -- This is the case in which a temporary injunction was issued against the Common Council by Justice PIERREPONT, of the Superior Court, on the 29th of December. The order to show cause why the injunction should not be made perpetual was now returnable. Plaintiff asked leave to amend the pleadings by joining a new party plaintiff, who is alleged to be interested in preventing the proposed action of the Common Council. He asked for further time in which to amend. The leave was finally granted, and the case set down for Wednesday next.

abstract: The Senate was not in session yesterday. In the House, Mr. PORCHER MILES, of South Carolina, resumed the floor to complete his remarks, which the Anti-Lecompton squabble of Thursday had blown to the winds. The hope of organization, he declared, had ceased to be rational; and he could see but one way of solving the perplexity, and that is to refer the whole question directly to the people -- to leave the choice of a Speaker to a general election. He declared his willingness to sustain an Anti-Lecompton Democrat; but he could not be brought to support an American. Mr. MAYNARD, of Tennessee, however, was more acceptable than Mr. GILMRR, of North Carolina, as he claimed to be independent of that or of any other political organization. Mr. ADRAIN, of New-Jersey, defended himself against the allusions of Mr. HICKMAN, by stating the position of himself and his Anti-Lecomptonite friends. A sharp colloquy between him and the Pennsylvania member ensued, the latter charging Mr. ADRAIN with having been elected by Republican votes, and yet refusing to aid in the election of a Republican Speaker. Mr. CLARK, of New-York, declared that it would be impossible to define the relations of the Anti-Lecompton men with the Administration party, until the latter had announced what disposition it was prepared to make of the approaching application of Kansas for admission as a State. At the close of Mr. CLARK's remarks, Mr. HICKMAN moved the plurality rule, as an amendment to the motion for a ballot. Pending the motion, Mr. BRIGGS, of New-York, rose to define his position, as the only representative of the American party at the North. He admitted that he owed his election the Republican support; and in that connection expressed his willingness to sustain for the Speakership any Republican not committed to the Helper Circular; and even announced his confidence in the conservatism of Mr. SHERMAN. But it was for a distinctly conservative and national man he preferred to give his support, and he was prepared to give it at the earliest opportunity. After a humorous dialogue with Mr. JOHN COCHRANE, Mr. BRIGGS gave way and a ballot was ordered. Mr. Sherman received 109; Mr. McClernand, 37; Mr. Bocock, 32; Mr. Quarles, 13; Mr. Davis, of Indiana, 9; Mr. Gilmer, 4; Mr. Houston, 3; scattering, 16. Necessary to a choice 112. The House then adjourned.

abstract: Francis D. Canterbury, a young man of respectable appearance, was taken before Justice STEERS yesterday on a charge of having swindled Wm. Slyvert a grocer's clerk. It is alleged that Canterbury selected a lot of groceries, a few days since, at the store where Slyvert was employed, and directed them to be rent to No. 71 Bowery, where he would be waiting to receive them, and pay the bill. Slyvert conveyed the goods to the place designated, and delivered them to Canterbury, who requested him to stay a moment and he would bring the money. Instead of keeping his promise, he dodged out of a back-door with his booty. The discomfited messenger has since kept a watch for Mr. Canterbury, and observing him yesterday, caused his apprehension. The prisoner was taken before Justice STEERS, and committed to answer a charge of frand. He is said to have procured his groceries in a similar manner for some time past, and others of his victims will probably enter complaints.

abstract: SUICIDE OF AN INVALID. -- An inquest was held yesterday upon the body of PIEREE C. SERE[???], a gentlemen 72 years of age, who resided with his daughter at No. 87 Eighth-avenue. From the evidence, it appeared that for a number of years the deceased had been subject to attacks of nervous debility, which caused great mental depression. On the 4th inst., be wrote the following letter: "A mes enfans -- Voy[???] je ne p[???]s pas me guerir, je me donne le mort p[???] abreger mes peines -- SERRE." After having placed this document where his children would find it, he swallowed two ounces of arsenic. In a few hours, and when the drug began to exhibit its effect, he told what he had done, and a physician was called, but efforts for his relief were unavailing, and the unfortunate man died at noon on Thursday. A verdict death by suicide was rendered.

abstract: A day or two since we quoted a paragraph from the Belfast correspondent of the London Times, "What they say of us in Ireland," without comment. We revert to it now, not because we suppose the slanderous statements need refuting here, but to utter a word of caution to the English Press about catching up all the incredible stories that may be told to the discredit of our country -- whether by prejudiced writers there or by strolling Americans in Europe. "An American gentleman" is reported as giving before an Association for Irish Emigrants some ugly statistics of the condition of the Irish in New-York:

abstract: The clerks in the Comptroller's office are busily engaged in preparing the annual report, which will not present to the Common Council until Feb. 1. The delay is not at all censurable, for it must be borne in mind that much of the report must be based upon data furnished by the coordinate departments of the City Government, and until these are made up and rent to the Comptroller lie cannot get fairly to work upon his annual resume of financial transactions. Toe Finance Department is the great heart of the Municipal body politic: its arteries are ramified upon every other brunch of the Government -- Legislation, Executive, and Judicial; and according as it is in a condition to "bleed freely," they are "vital to the tips." All the statistics are now, however, in the possession of the Finance Department, and as soon as they can be marshaled into column the document will be sent to the Common Council. The redemption of the Water Stock of 1834 is progressing rapidly. As the interest on the certificates ceased last Tuesday, probably the holders will lose no time in presenting them for payment.

abstract: The treaty lately negotiated between Great Britain and Honduras has been extensively noticed in the Press of this country, but it may not be generally known that, in this treaty be ratified by the London Cabinet, England will have surrendered the position she assumed in rejecting the Dallas-Clarendon Treaty, containing the amendments of the United States Senate. This last-mentioned treaty provided that Great Britain should surrender the Bay Islands to the State of Honduras, but made such conditions and restrictions as might be agreed upon in a treaty to be negotiated, between those two Powers. This provision was objectionable to the Senate, and it was accordingly stricken out. Who could venture to say what these conditions and restrictions might be? Who knew that they would not be seriously injurious to American interests, if not totally destructive of our Central American policy? Indeed, a draft of the treaty to be negotiated had already been drawn up in Downing-street, which provided for the prohibition of Slavery in the Bay Islands, and securing to the colonists special political privileges and rights, tantamount to a separate and independent Government. Hence it was that the Senate so amended the treaty as to require an unconditional restoration of these islands to the State to which they properly belonged.

This provision was objectionable to the Senate, and it was accordingly stricken out. Who could venture to say what these conditions and restrictions might be? Who knew that they would not be seriously injurious to American interests, if not totally destructive of our Central American policy? Indeed, a draft of the treaty to be negotiated had already been drawn up in Downing-street, which provided for the prohibition of Slavery in the Bay Islands, and securing to the colonists special political privileges and rights, tantamount to a separate and independent Government. Hence it was that the Senate so amended the treaty as to require an unconditional restoration of these islands to the State to which they properly belonged.

abstract: MURDER IN WINSTED, CT. -- EDWARD COFFEE, a young man 22 years of age, was murdered in Winsted early Sunday evening, by a man named MICHAEL CONNEL. From what we can learn, the parties had been in altercation some days before, and the matter was seemingly settled. But about 6 o'clock last Sunday evening, CONNEL called at a place where COFFEE was stopping, and invited him out, when he stabbed him in the neck, inflicting a large and frightful wound, and COFFEE knocked him down. CONNEL rose and stabbed him again, this time in the abdomen, making a fatal wound. COFFEE lived about two hours. His body was brought to this city, where he had friends, and was buried yesterday. Jan. 4. He used to work at G.S. LINCOLN & Co.'s. Arch-street, and is represented as an industrious, peaceable young man. He was unmarried. CONNEL was arrested the same evening, and is now in jail at Litchfield. He will be examined next Saturday, on a charge of murder. -- Hartford Times, Jan. 5.

abstract: The second concert of the present season came off on Saturday night, with the usual concomitant of a storm. Under circumstances so depressing, it would not have been remarkable if the house had presented a comparatively empty appearance, but the subscribers to the Society are famous for their endurance, and there was scarcely a perceptible thinning in the ranks, despite the fierce attack of the Pluvial forces.

abstract: It is said that according to private advices received in London, from Buenos Ayres, two days later than those recently published, a change of ministry had suddenly taken place and that Senors TEJEDOR and PENA, both moderate men, had been appointed, with a view, it is believed, of coming to some arrangements with URQUIZA, which would be greatly facilitated by Mr. THORNTON, the English Minister. The National Guard, it appears, disgusted with the management of the army by Col. MITRE, had refused to march on another campaign, although they would defend their city to the last.

abstract: DEATH OF CENTENNARIANS. -- A negro woman named Clara Wilson, died near Alton, Ill., Dec. 13, at the age of 124. She settled near Alton in 1840, being then nearly one hundred years old. The Alton Courier says: "She was born and raised in South Carolina, and her earliest recollections were of Charleston, in that State, which she remembers as a smart village, instead of the great city it now is. She grew up on the plantation, field work being her task so long as she was a slave.....James McDermott died a short time since in Richland County, Ohio, aged 101 years. The Cincinnati Enquirer says: "He was born in Lancaster County, Penn., in August, 1758, and enlisted in the army of the Revolution in 1777. While in Kentucky he was engaged in several severe skirmishes with the Indians, and on one occasion took one of their number prisoner. After returning home he volunteered, and at the close of the war he settled In Mercer County, Penn., from whence, in 1815, he removed to Richland County, Ohio......The Boston Traveller announces the death of "Mother Boston," the oldest woman in Massachusetts at the age of upwards of one hundred years. She was a negress; her real name Catharine Boston. The Traveller says: She was born in Reading, Mass., and in her younger days was held as a slave. For a time she lived in Reading, Mass., but upon her emancipation and marriage she moved to the North End of this city. Through her long life her health has been remarkably good, and up to within a brief period she has been a regular attendant upon church service.

abstract: The reception of Bishop Odenheimer, of New-Jersey, on taking possession of the Episcopal residence at Riverside, (late Bishop Doane's,) was very gratifying. The Burlington Dollar Newspaper says: �When his family took possession of Riverside, they found the pantries crowded with everything that either housewife or cook could desire -� a barrel of sugar in one, of flour in another �- with other immediate necessaries in provision, the surprise offerings of Episcopalians here. Then came a purse of $200 from Episcopalians in Mount Holy, to bear the expense of removal from Philadelphia. These donations offered some manifestation of the affection already entertained for Bishop Odenheimer."

abstract: If Parliamentary Goverment is no longer considered on its trial, certainly Municipal Corporations have still to make good their claim to superiority. abstract: Movements are on foot to erect monuments to KANE, to COOPER, to IRVING, and other Americans who have conferred honor on the country by their works of genius or their deeds of heroism. We regard them with apprehension and alarm. Enshrined only in the memories of their countrymen, these illustrious men are reasonably sure of a fragrant and reproachless repose. But if to the authorities of this City is to be entrusted the sacred task of perpetuating their glory, its prospective fate may well inspire their surviving friends with the most melancholy forebodings. Let them consult the experience of the past as affording the best indication of the future.
lead_paragraph: Movements are on foot to erect monuments to KANE, to COOPER, to IRVING, and other Americans who have conferred honor on the country by their works of genius or their deeds of heroism. abstract: A new and singular chapter opens on our Western carrying trade with the recent completion of the great Victoria Bridge over the St. Lawrence, at Montreal. When the Grand Trunk Railway of Canada was projected, seven years ago, and found a ready and powerful financial support in London, it seemed to be, and was pronounced on this side the Canada line, the wildest, most extravagant and least profitable of the undertakings of the North American railway excitement of that time. It started on an assured minimum basis of nine millions sterling, and has actually cost nearly twelve millions, or about $60,000,000 Federal money. Our own Illinois Central, running North and South from the Lakes to the Mississippi, with its land mortgage of $17,000,000, and traversing the established or favorite theory of Western internal trade that only an East and West line could be made to pay, was deemed sufficiently Utopian. It was for years afforded "a very wide berth" by nearly all prudent and sagacious capitalists on this side the Atlantic, and the whole scheme abandoned to the Land-loving and Stock-jobbing proclivities of our wealthy English cousins. They subscribed freely to its Land mortgage, and soon after monopolized its intoxicating scrip privileges, which, from promising to be made full stock, after an assessment of only five dollars each, from the surplus profits of the Land grant -- thus presenting the holders with a Railway of seven hundred miles, cost free -- has already absorbed seventy dollars each, or, altogether, two and a half millions sterling of hard English cash, and the end not yet.
lead_paragraph: A new and singular chapter opens on our Western carrying trade with the recent completion of the great Victoria Bridge over the St. Lawrence, at Montreal. When the Grand Trunk Railway of Canada was projected, seven years ago, and found a ready and powerful financial support in London, it seemed to be, and was pronounced on this side the Canada line, the wildest, most extravagant and least profitable of the undertakings of the North American railway excitement of that time. It started on an assured minimum basis of nine millions sterling, and has actually cost nearly twelve millions, or about $60,000,000 Federal money. Our own Illinois Central, running North and South from the Lakes to the Mississippi, with its land mortgage of $17,000,000, and traversing the established or favorite theory of Western internal trade that only an East and West line could be made to pay, was deemed sufficiently Utopian. It was for years afforded "a very wide berth" by nearly all prudent and sagacious capitalists on this side the Atlantic, and the whole scheme abandoned to the Land-loving and Stock-jobbing proclivities of our wealthy English cousins. They subscribed freely to its Land mortgage, and soon after monopolized its intoxicating scrip privileges, which, from promising to be made full stock, after an assessment of only five dollars each, from the surplus profits of the Land grant -- thus presenting the holders with a Railway of seven hundred miles, cost free -- has already absorbed seventy dollars each, or, altogether, two and a half millions sterling of hard English cash, and the end not yet.

abstract: The Democratic State Convention met here today to nominate Delegates to Charleston. The temporary organization was presided over by Hon. Mr. McCONNEL, of Moran County. A Committee on Permanent Organization, consisting of two Delegates from each Congressional District, was appointed. The Convention then adjourned till 1 P.M. During the recess speeches were made by S.S. MARSHALL and U.F. LINDER, urging harmonious and conservative action and conciliation towards the Buchanan Party in Illinois.
lead_paragraph: From the Springfield State Journal, Jan. 5.

abstract: ECCLESIASTICAL DISCIPLINE. -� The Bishop of London seems to have almost as odd notions of discipline as the Court-martial which convicted Major WYSE of fraud the other day in San Juan, and contented itself with punishing him with a short term of arrest, and a warning that if he continued to swindle the Government he would have to quit the service. The Bishop has had the misfortune to have in his diocese a clergyman named BONWELL, a married man with two children. The reverend gentleman met a young lady while on a visit at the house of one of his friends, fell in love with her, represented himself to be a widower with child and in    this guise offered her his hand and was accepted. The affair had gone thus far, when it reached the Bishop's ears, who thereupon sent for Mr. BONWELL, and, to use the words of his Lordship's counsel at the legal inquiry which has since taken place, �administered a severe reprimand, which he hoped would cause him to behave better in future." The upshot of the matter was that the young lady was betrayed by her reverend lover, and the consequent exposure has led to a commission of inquiry under the Church-Discipline act.

abstract: If I say a word to-day in regard to the weather, it is because the cold has acquired an intensity which entitles it to the dignity of an event. For five days, the Fahrenheit scale has balanced between eighteen and twenty-eight degrees below freezing point, in the heart of the city; while at certain points in the country, six points below the bulb has been attained according to the indications of the centigrade scale.
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Thursday, Dec. 22, 1859.

abstract: In the early part of last Fall, JAMES GRAY ran away from his master, in Missouri, and succeeded in reaching Sandoval, Marion County, Ill., where he was seized by three men, who attempted to kidnap him, not knowing that he was a fugitive slave. An old man named ROOTS became acquainted with the circumstances, and obliged the kidnappers to commit their captive to the Union County Jail, whence he was subsequently taken, on a writ of habeas corpus.

abstract: AMERICAN CARS IN THE EAST. -- The Springfield Republican gives an extended account of a royal railway carriage which has been constructed for the Viceroy of Egypt by Messrs. THOMAS W. WASON & Co., the builders of the cars for the railroad which extends from Alexandria to the Red Sea. This carriage is sixty-seven feet long, and rests upon two double tracks, each one consisting of two distinct trucks connected together. There are, in all, three compartments, each twenty feet long and ten feet wide -- the middle one being a[???] pavilion which is surmounted by a raised roof like the central part of a house, supported by silver plated columns with highly ornamented brackets. A heavy wire fence or railing, about three feet high, runs along the outer sides of the pavilion, finished with a silver-plated to rail, and with gates on each side, and steps that may be let down to leave the car, and when not wanted for use thrown into an ornamental appendage to the sides of the car, The ornamental work of the car is exceedingly elaborate and beautiful in all its parts, as may be inferred from the fact that the cost of the vehicle will exceed 10,000. It will have to be taken apart in order to convey it to its destination.

abstract: THE DISCHARGED CLERKS AND THE SOUTHERN TRADE. -- A meeting of the clerks recently discharged from the establishment of Mr. A.T. STEWART, was advertised to be held on Saturday evening in the basement of the Church No. 130 Stanton-street. The Trustees of the Church, however, withdrew their consent for the use of the room, fearing that they would be considered as indorsing resolutions censuring Mr. STEWART, which they supposed would be passed. In consequence of this action the contemplated meeting was not held. The clerks discharged were mainly from the retail department, and state that they have no reason to believe that their dismissal was owing to the falling off of the Southern trade. The difficulty which one of the clerks had with Mr. STEWART, resulting in the latter being struck by the clerk, originated in the refusal of the employer to give a certificate to the fact that the clerk had been in his employ six years. The assailant was arrested and confined in the Tombs over night, but was liberated in the morning. From what could be gathered from the clerks present at the place of the proposed meeting, there was no intention of censuring Mr. STEWART. It was simply proposed to form a mutual protective and benefit association similar to those already in existence among the trades.
lead_paragraph: THE DISCHARGED CLERKS AND THE SOUTHERN TRADE. -- A meeting of the clerks recently discharged from the establishment of Mr. A.T. abstract: By the arrival of the mail steamer Arabia, we have Liverpool advices to Dec. 24. The intelligence by the Kangaroo, which also arrived yesterday, bringing dates to the 22d, has been anticipated. The principal topic of discussion in the London and Paris journals is a pamphlet on the adjustment of the claims of the Pope at the approaching Congress, the pamphlet being understood to emanate from the pen that laid down the programme of the Italian war, in the " NAPOLEAN III. and Italy " of last Spring, although the name of M. DE LA GUEER RONIKRE appears on the title-page. The object of this important semiofficial paper is to demonstrate that while it is desirable to maintain the temporal power of the Pope, that aim can be best achieved in curtailing his dominions by the excision of the Romagna, and by instituting administrative reforms in the remaining States. The opinions thus pronounced are understood to be those which will govern the action of the French delegation in the Congress, and are regarded by the London Times as an adhesion to the policy of England. The Congress had been called for Jan. 19. The participation in its labors of Count CAVOUR as one of the delegates of Sardinia, is confirmed. It is also stated that the Republic of San Marino has prepared an appeal to the Congress against the pretensions and encroachments of the crown of Sardinia. The symptoms of disaffection heretofore noticed as increasing in Hungary, appear to have reached a crisis. Private letters from Pesth state that the Protestant population had openly demonstrated their hostility to the Government of Vienna, and a dispatch, at the latest moment from Paris, announces that the revolution had actually broken out. Another battle had occurred in Morocco, the Spaniards, if we may trust their own reports, being still the victors. Russia has at last brought the Caucasian war to a conclusion, the last of the rebel chiefs. MOHAMMED ARNIM, having laid down his arms, and submitted. The news from England is of no interest.

PHILLIPS and GREATOREX, Alderman MECHI, and others. About 200 gentlemen sat down to dinner.

abstract: EXPLOSION OF PERCUSSION-CAP FACTORY -- ONE MAN KILLED. -- Between 9 and 10 o'clock Saturday morning last, the percussion cap factory in Carroll, near First-street, Gowanus, owned by Dr. ISAAC GOLDWORHT, exploded, killing instantly a young man named CHARLES HALLENBROCK, the only person on the premises at the time. A part of this same place was blown up a few weeks ago. There was one life lost at that time. Coroner HORTON will investigate the case to-day.

abstract: This was the day advertised for selling the steamships belonging to the old United States Mail Line, in pursuance of the deed of trust executed by GEORGE LAW to certain Trustees, for the benefit of A.G. SLCO, from whom LAW purchased the mail contract which lately expired, but subsequently relet to Commodore VANDERBILT. The sale has been postponed till the 25th instant, at the same place and hour, by order of MARSHALL O. ROBERTS, Agent, and one of the Trustees. The ships advertised for sale, together with their tackle, apparel, furniture and all other appurtenances, are the Illinois, Star of the West, Empire City, Moses Taylor and Philadelphia.

abstract: It seems, as far as present appearances go, not at all unlikely that before the Congress now about to assemble at Paris brings its sittings to a close, Hungary may present a case for its consideration possessing very strong points of resemblance to that of Romagna; or in other words, that a convulsion in the Austrian empire may bring about once more such a state of things in Hungary as that which preceded the Russian intervention in 1849 -- a victorious Magyar army in complete possession of the country, and the Austrian troops worsted and driven across the frontier. The crime which Europe permitted to be perpetrated in the forcible subversion of the Hungarian Constitution in that unhappy year, cannot, under the construction given to popular rights by the leading Powers with reference to Italy, be now repeated. The day for interference on the side of despotism seems to have gone by, and Austria must stand or fall without hope of aid from any quarter.

The day for interference on the side of despotism seems to have gone by, and Austria must stand or fall without hope of aid from any quarter.

abstract: An inquest was yesterday held by Coroner JACKMAN, at the Ninth Precinct Station-house, upon the remains of GEO. W. CHURCH, who was fatally injured in a fight which occurred on the 2d inst., at the grocery store of JOHN HOLLINS, at the corner of Jane and Washington streets. From the evidence, it appeared that on the afternoon of the day in question, a number of men, among whom was STEPHEN S. KENNEDY, a carman, went into the grocery, and, after calling for refreshments, became engaged in a quarrel with the proprietor. Finally, KENNEDY, it is said, assaulted HOLLINS, and the deceased, who res[???]ed over the store, hearing the noise of the affray, ran down to learn the cause of the disturbance. Just at this time HOLLINS succeeded in ejecting KENNEDY from the store, and Mr. CHURCH, with others, followed him to the sidewalk, where the fight was renewed. The deceased was then knocked down, and beaten with [???] cart-rung, it is supposed either by KENNEDY or by one of his companions. The injured man was conveyed to his apartments, and a physician was called to attend him, but as no danger was apprehended, no publicity was given to the matter. KENNEDY was subsequently arrested on suspicion of having struck the fatal blow, but was discharged for lack of evidence, and now the police suspect MARTIN TOOLE of having perpetrated the homicide, and officers are in search of him. Drs. BEACH and EDWARDS made a post-mortem examination of the body, and gave their opinion, that death was caused by compression of the brain, resulting from a fracture of the skull. Deceased was a respectable man, 38 years of age. He has left a widow and four children.

abstract: It is generally understood that Southern traders who get their goods at the North, have adopted the policy of giving their orders to commercial houses whose political opinions and views of Slavery are supposed to be in harmony with those entertained in the Southern States. How far this policy has been reduced to practice, we are not informed; but it is advocated in Southern journals, and the determination to adopt it has, in some cases, been announced.

abstract: The California advices published in THE TIMES of this morning, contain important and later intelligence from Japan, brought by the Russian war steamer No-vick, from Hakodadi to San Francisco. We have on several occasions obtained later news from Japan, through this channel, in advance of the regular mails, by way of England. When the telegraphic arrangements on the line of overland mail are completed, marine communication between California and the East will no doubt be more regular and frequent. Our more speedy and direct intercourse with China and Japan will then be by the American route.

abstract: The People vs. George Bownc. -- This was a certiorari to bring up the papers in the case from the Court of Sessions for review by Justice LEONARD, of Chambers of the Supreme Court. The object of the proceeding was to have the case sent to the Oyer and Terminer for new trial, the first trial having been at the Sessions. The prisoner was convicted upon the charge of uttering a forged draft, but was never sentenced. He was remanded to the Tombs, where he has lain ever since. Upon the first trial a bi[???] of exceptions was made, upon which the case was taken to the General Term of the Supreme Court, and upon reading the papers, that Court reversed the judgment of the Court of Sessions, rendering a verbal opinion, and sent the case back for new trial. As the General Term delivered no written opinion in the case, the counsel for the prisoner became afraid that Judge RUSSELL, of the Sessions, would take no notice of the points of law passed upon, but again adhere to his former rulings, and, by so doing, cause the second trial to result the same as the first. Hence this motion.
lead_paragraph: The People vs. George Bownc. -- This was a certiorari to bring up the papers in the case from the Court of Sessions for review by Justice LEONARD, of Chambers of the Supreme Court. The object of the proceeding was to have the case sent to the Oyer and Terminer for new trial, the first trial having been at the Sessions. Upon the first trial a bi[???] of exceptions was made, upon which the case was taken to the General Term of the Supreme Court, and upon reading the papers, that Court reversed the judgment of the Court of Sessions, rendering a verbal opinion, and sent the case back for new trial. As the General Term delivered no written opinion in the case, the counsel for the prisoner became afraid that Judge RUSSELL, of the Sessions, would take no notice of the points of law passed upon, but again adhere to his former rulings, and, by so doing, cause the second trial to result the same as the first. Hence this motion.

abstract: The new Police Station-house which has just been completed at Jersey City, was opened last evening with appropriate ceremonies. The building, which is of brick, is situated at the junction of Gregory-street and Washington-place, is two stories in height, with a basement story of ten feet. The structure covers a space thirty feet wide by ninety feet in depth, and with an economical regard to the wants of the city, contains accommodations for the business of the various Departments more immediately connected with the City Police. Below, the space is divided into the heating-room, ten cells for the detention of prisoners, intended to hold two in each room, and has rooms fitted up for lodgers, with sleeping accommodations for twenty-four. In the rear is the cooking department. This story, which is all above ground, is well lighted, ventilated and warmed. The first, or main story, is entered by a flight of steps, the front room being appropriated to the office. The remainder of the floor is divided by a hall, on one side of which are comfortably-furnished rooms for the detention of witnesses, bath-room, and the family rooms of the City Marshal. On the opposite side are the reception-room, the Marshal's office, and the private office of the Chief of Police. The front part of the upper story is devoted to the City Recorder's Court, and the rear to the Fire Marshal. The whole is surmounted by a bell-tower and observatory, the top of which is about one hundred feet above the street, from which a commanding view is obtained of the city and of the surrounding country. The bell weighs 4,260 pounds, and is considered to be of excellent tone.

abstract: Mrs. Ann Wallingford, who, when Anne Rochforth, was madly beloved by George the Fourth, then Prince of Wales, died lately in London. The Court Circular says she was also asked in marriage by the Duke of B -- for his son the Marquis of C -- s; while the Prince of Wales solicited her to bestow her hand upon himself, backing his suit by an offer of a private marriage, princely settlement, &c. The young lady, wavering and somewhat perplexed between these noble offers which courted her acceptance, requested Lady Jersey to give her advice how she should act. The Countess recommended her not to consult her heart upon the occasion, but St. Nicholas, who was the patron saint of virgins. The saint accordingly appeared to her, but whether when sleeping or waking history is silent, but he decided against both. Soon after Miss Rochforth met Mr. Henry Wallingford, then the handsomest man of the day. A mutual passion sprang up between them, and in due course they were united. Mr. Wallingford died in 1810, so that his wife has survived him for the long term of 40 years.

abstract: On two former occasions the difficulty of the election of a Speaker of the House of Representatives has been obviated by the adoption of the plurality rule. The first was in 1849. Sixty-two ballots had been taken, and three weeks time had been wasted in the fruitless attempt to effect a choice. A resolution was then offered by Mr. STANTON, of Tennessee, substantially to the effect that, after three more unsuccessful ballotings, the member who should then receive the highest number of votes, provided it was a majority of a quorum, should be declared to have been chosen Speaker. The resolution was adopted by a majority of seven, and HOWELL COBB was elected, having received 102 votes out of 221, or nine less than a majority.
lead_paragraph: On two former occasions the difficulty of the election of a Speaker of the House of Representatives has been obviated by the adoption of the plurality rule. The first was in 1849. abstract: A correspondent of the Daily Telegraph writing from Vienna, says: "It is an acknowledged fact that the Marquis de Moustier, in his position of French ambassador at Berlin, essentially contributed to the fall of Sebastopol, on Sept. 8, 1855. Your readers will recollect that in the Autumn of that year one of the royal valets, in the palace of Sans Souci, was found to have been for some time in the habit of opening the dispatch boxes and taking out the contents. A year after that discovery, which created the greatest sensation in Germany and Europe in general, the farthless servant and another individual who had assisted him in purloining the valuable papers, were sentenced to eight years' penal servitude, on the charge of high treason. To the political world it was no secret, even at the time, that the dispatches in question had been stolen at the instigation of a diplomatist of high standing, and that the Marquis de Mousuer had been in a position to transmit their contents to the Emperor Napoleon Many of the documents were from the pen of Count Monster, the then military ambassador of Prussia at the Court of St. Petersburg; and the intelligence communicated in them with respect to the fortifications of Sebastopol, and the condition of the Russian defences in general, enabled the French commander to select for his point of attack one of the few sites from which the Crimean stronghold could be taken.

abstract: THE POLITICS OF EUROPE. -- A little volume of 250 duodecimo pages has recently been published in Philadelphia, from the pen of F.J. GRUND, Esq., entitled "Thoughts and Reflections on the Present Position of Europe, and its probable consequences to the United States," which embodies a more compact and instructive summary of current European politics than is to be found in any other quarter within our knowledge. Mr. GRUND has long been known from his connection with journalism and party politics, -- and this little work shows him to be among the best informed and ablest students of current history. The recent Italian War is the central incident of the treatise, -- which opens by a historical statement of the causes which led to the crisis, the development of political events in the several countries of the Continent, and the motives which induced the Emperor NAPOLEON to become the ally of Sardinia in the war with Austria. The general results and consequences of the war are also traced, and the closing chapter is devoted to a consideration of the true policy for the United States to pursue in her intercourse with foreign Powers.
lead_paragraph: THE POLITICS OF EUROPE. -- A little volume of 250 duodecimo pages has recently been published in Philadelphia, from the pen of F.J. The recent Italian War is the central incident of the treatise, -- which opens by a historical statement of the causes which led to the crisis, the development of political events in the several countries of the Continent, and the motives which induced the Emperor NAPOLEON to become the ally of Sardinia in the war with Austria. The general results and consequences of the war are also traced, and the closing chapter is devoted to a consideration of the true policy for the United States to pursue in her intercourse with foreign Powers.

abstract: LAURA KEENE's THEATRE. -- The Dramatist can scarcely impose on himself a more meritorious task than that of condensing Sir WALTER SCOTT, unless, indeed, he undertake at once to reduce that great and immortal author to English, so that he may be understood by people who had the misfortune to be born where there did not happen to be a "wee bit plaidie" on the premises. Mr. BOURCICAULT has performed the first office for the "Heart of Mid Lothian," and his experience and eclecticism have resulted in an effective drama. From the second experiment he has more than shrunk. Instead of setting his face against a jargon which is almost unintelligible, (out of the British Isles,) he has crowded the dialogue with the broadest Scoticisms. Some of the best points of the play were as dimly taken by the audience as if they had been uttered in Greek.

abstract: Although trade statistics, as a rule, may be a dry subject to the general newspaper reader, we suggest that some interesting points are presented this morning by the Custom-house returns of the foreign commerce of the port of New-York during the year just closed. New-York has no reason to complain of her position as the first importing and distributing market on the Continent; nor yet of the steady centralization of this branch of trade, as measured by the increased per centage of the total imports of the whole country, which the present annual summary illustrates. The entries of foreign merchandise for the year amount to two hundred and fory-two millions in value, before the impost duties are added. These, by the present tariff, average about sixteen per cent. Of the gross entries of the year, the value of two hundred and thirty-two millions, exclusive of the impost, or about two hundred and seventy millions value, has been actually marketed, or distributed to the country. This sum exceeds, by about one-sixth, the heavy distribution made in the year 1856 -- the season before the crisis. At the same time it is made to a population throughout the United States, increased in about the same proportion, taking into account the accession by immigration. This large distribution of foreign goods is by no means significant of an increased extravagance in their consumption, generally, by the whole country. The relative trade at New-York has gone up from 62 to 65 per cent. since 1856, and we look to see this proportion more than maintained in 1860. At the same time we must regret that we cannot claim that the proportion of these goods freighted from Europe in American bottoms is even equal to that of 1856. The admission is not creditable to the country, but it is not new to our own readers, as we have heretofore shown in these columns that our steam marine is sadly falling behind that of England, and that even Germany is in advance of us in the European trade. The humiliation may stop, but not the loss to our general commerce, with the fact that the Collins line has been driven from this trade, and that the Vanderbilt and Livingston lines, to Havre and Southampton, bear but small account to the Cunard, Hamburgh, North German, Liverpool (or Dale), and Quebec competition. The freight earnings of our merchant sailing fleet have been sadly interfered with by the same cause. The screw-steamers of British construction -- they are nearly all built on the Clyde and at Newcastle-on-Tyne -- and of European ownership, are now, and for a year or two past have been, the great carriers for the New-York Import trade. We count the difference against our own tonnage, including the old Liverpool sailing lines, by millions per annum on Dry Goods and other light merchandise alone. Of the one hundred and thirteen millions Dry Goods brought into New-York from abroad, last year, we doubt whether twenty per cent, was delivered by American vessels. And a very considerable portion of general merchandise, such as Sheffield and Birmingham abrics from England, and Wines and Brandies from the Continent, are diverted from our carrying business in the same way.

abstract: The NEW-YORK TIMES is the youngest of the daily newspapers of the City of New-York. The first number was issued on the 18th of September, 1851 -- so that it has only just completed the eighth year of its publication. But it has already become one of the most widely known and most firmly established daily journals of the United States. Its circulation is quite as large as that of any other daily of its class in the City of New-York, -- and in reputation for enterprise, energy, and reliability, it may fairly challenge comparison with any other newspaper in the country.

abstract: SENEX. Conductor, who is that imperious, disdainful, and highly-ornamented young lady, who wears golden manacles, and glories in a golden cross? The skirts of her charity covered several adjacent sinners, and, at her egress, she created a vaccum, if not a sensation, and was followed by a whirlwind.

abstract: GOV. abstract: The Royal Mail Steamer Teviot, with the London mails of the 17th of November, arrived at this port yesterday morning! She brings intelligence that the Queen has conferred the dignity of Knighthood upon BRYAN EDWARDS, Esq., Chief-Justice of Jamaica. Mr. EDWARDS is the son of the celebrated historian of the West Indies.
lead_paragraph: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Dec. 10, 1859.

abstract: The Tammany Society or Colombian Order celebrated last night the Anniversary of the Battle of New-Orleans. The commemoration lacked neither in numbers nor dignity. The hall was appropriately and elaborately decorated. The walls were festooned with flags and banners, among which were interspersed the emblems respectively adopted by the States. Pictures, busts, and national souvenirs were  exhibited at appropriate intervals.
lead_paragraph: The Tammany Society or Colombian Order celebrated last night the Anniversary of the Battle of New-Orleans. The commemoration lacked neither in numbers nor dignity. The hall was appropriately and elaborately decorated. The walls were festooned with flags and banners, among which were interspersed the emblems respectively adopted by the States. Pictures, busts, and national souvenirs were exhibited at appropriate intervals. The ceiling was canopied in the national colors, with striking effect. On the floor crowds of dancers assembled, and continued their pleasures without intermission until a few minutes before 12 o'clock, when the members of the Society and the invited guests marched into the ball-room, and having traversed the long avenues of friends who had been drawn up to receive them, at length halted; whereupon Mr. ISAAC V. FOWLER, the Grand Sachem, was introduced by Mr. DOUGLAS TAYLOR, and the cheering having subsided, said:

abstract: Rev. PETER CARTWRIGHT, the well-known Methodist pioneer clergyman of the West, lectured last evening to a large audience in the Methodist Episcopal Church, in Greene-street, upon life in the Western wilds. By way of introduction, he said he would give a short sketch of his history. He was born in Virginia, reared in Kentucky, and had been a citizen of the Mississippi valley for 68 years. He was now in his seventy-fifth year, and had spent 67 years of his life in the faithful preaching of the Gospel of the Methodist Church. Shortly after the Revolutionary War his father moved with his family into the Western country, which was then a wilderness of wild beasts and still wilder Indians. It was impossible for one who had never been a resident upon the frontier to realize the condition of life at that time. There were no schools, no preachers, no newspapers, no organized associations whatever. As late as 1811 there had been but one conference of the Methodist Church in the whole West, and the Church numbered at that time less than 2,000 souls, including the Northwest, West and Southwest. A preacher at that time was liable to be sent on a circuit of a thousand miles. The men of God at that period were wont to travel as best they could from court to court, and from place to place, wherever they could find a gathering of the people, to plant the standard of the Redeemer. On rare occasions he had the opportunity to listen to one and another of their pioneer preachers, but the best preacher to him in those early days was a pious mother, for whom he would bless God in Heaven forever and ever. Under the preaching of one of those traveling clergymen he embraced religion. His youthful companions thought him crazy, and an old Scotch doctor who lived neighbor to his father, and who, withal, was a confirmed infidel, on learning that PETER had got converted, straightway hastened to his father's cabin to see about it. Alter a faithful examination of his bumps, he pronounced him deranged, and advised his father to shave his head and put on a blistering plaster. His father, however, did not follow the Doctor's advice, and the following Sabbath the young convert essayed to preach his first sermon, and invited the old Doctor to come and hear him. The Doctor came -- there was a powerful manifestation of the Holy Spirit, and they had a solemn time. During the sermon, a lady member of the congregation fell in a trance. The old Scotch Doctor sprang to her assistance, and applied his hartshorn to her nose. Young CARTWRIGHT interfered and told the Doctor to stand aside -- that the lady was his patient and needed prayer more than hartshorn. The lady soon revived and sprang towards the Doctor, whereat the old infidel took to his heels as though the d -- l was after him. Shortly after this, one of the Elders offered to give him a license to exhort; but he told the Elder that he couldn't exhort unless he felt happy, and when he felt happy he should exhort anyhow. This was all the license he ever received to preach the Gospel until many years after he was ordained a presiding Elder. He, however, continued to preach in his own way, or to exhort, or whatever they pleased to call it, and with a library consisting of part of an old Bible, the Methodist Book of Discipline, and a hymn book, he traveled around the country, talking religion as he understood it, or rather as he felt it, and had the pleasure of seeing hundreds converted through his instrumentality. At the end of six months the presiding Elder came to him and handed him six dollars. While traveling near the head of the Cumberland River he made the acquaintance of a Justice of the Peace who had recently lost a child. He was asked to preach the funeral sermon, and did so; whereupon he was requested to tarry for several days. He complied, and preached nightly in the log meeting-house, the people coming from twenty miles round about to hear him. A revival was the consequence, and in a few days 23 converts were gathered into the fold, including the Justice of the Peace. After he had left, some Baptist preachers, who had been sent out as missionaries, chanced that way, and what with their everlasting hullabaloo about "water," "water," "immersion," "immersion," they got his young flock into a state of perfect confusion. They sent for him, and he returned to the place, underwent an examination at the hands of the Baptists, and was pronounced a genuine Christian. A day was appointed by the Baptist elders to baptize him and his converts. At the appointed time they all appeared on the banks of the river, when CARTWRIGHT declined the ceremony, on the ground that he had been once baptized by sprinkling, and he considered that sufficient. His converts all followed his example, and thus the ceremony was cut short. The same day, being communion, the young converts, with their leaders, took their seats in the congregation, and had the mortification of seeing the bread and wine carried past them, and administered only to those who were classed by the elders as belonging to "our order." CARTWRIGHT arose in the meeting and demanded that the sacrament should be administered to himself and his converts. The Deacon said to the Elder, "Shall I do it?" The Elder said "No." Thereupon CARTWRIGHT withdrew with his flock, and mounting a log in front of the church, proceeded to defend himself in the true Western style, "roaring and thundering," to use his own words, "like a unicorn." He told them that since they were not permitted to enter that church, he would raise one for himself, "And this," said the speaker, "was the first church I ever established."

The Elder said "No." Thereupon CARTWRIGHT withdrew with his flock, and mounting a log in front of the church, proceeded to defend himself in the true Western style, "roaring and thundering," to use his own words, "like a unicorn." He told them that since they were not permitted to enter that church, he would raise one for himself, "And this," said the speaker, "was the first church I ever established."

abstract: The pamphlet of M. DE LA GUERRONIERE, which is regarded as the manifesto of the Emperor NOPOLEON upon the Italian question, has elicited the general approval of all parties in England, as affording the only basis upon which a satisfactory and permanent peace can be established. The temporal power of the Pope is the knotty point of European diplomacy, and this is attempted to be untied by restricting this power to the City of Rome. The Papal sovereignty is thus made purely spiritual, and the freedom of his ecclesiastical functions is guaranteed by the municipal government of the city which is the seat of his spiritual empire. That this was the only solution of the Italian problem must have forced itself upon the convictions of the Emperor, and it affords another proof of his sagacity and boldness, that he is willing to accept it. The principle that he has so rigidly enforced against Austria, that the will of the people of Italy should not be frustrated by foreign interference, applies with equal force to the Papal d[???]minions, and must have led him to take the ground that neither by French nor Austrian arms, should the Government of the Holy Father be reinstated in the revolted Papal States. The nationality of the people of Italy -- to secure which was the object of the war -- the moral influence of the victory with which it was crowned, his own consistency -- all demanded this course on the part of NAPOLEON, and his adoption of it has given the strongest assurances of the disinterestedness of his motives and the sincerity of his professions in regard to the war itself.

abstract: Last evening, about 6 o'clock, a fire broke out on the second floor of the building No. 11 Coenties-slip, owned and occupied by Messrs. SHERMAN & WEEKS, flour dealers. It is presumed the fire was caused by the over-heating of the stovepipe. The stock of flour and the building were damaged to the amount of $2,500. Insured in the Howard and Ph[???]nix Insurance companies, of this City. MORRIS O'CONNELL, a member of No. 5 Engine, while going to the fire, slipped and fell at the corner of Wall and William-streets, and the engine passed over both his legs, injuring him severely. He was taken to the New-York Hospital, where his wounds were dressed by Dr. HULL.

abstract: THE WEATHER AND THE STREETS. On Saturday the mercury in the thermometer rose and the rain in the evening descended in torrents. The storm  passed away with the night, and Sunday and Monday were like days in June. But such walking! Mud to the right of you; mud to the left of you; mud in  front of you; wherever you rambled. No lady ventured forth without her Balmoral.
lead_paragraph: THE WEATHER AND THE STREETS. On Saturday the mercury in the thermometer rose and the rain in the evening descended in torrents. The storm passed away with the night, and Sunday and Monday were like days in June. But such walking! Mud to the right of you; mud to the left of you; mud in front of you; wherever you rambled. No lady ventured forth without her Balmoral. Water-proof boots were in demand. All who could ride rode. All who were obliged to walk bewailed the[???] dire necessity. But on such days of sunshine and such moon-lit nights, none but the decrepid or the spiritless could stay in the house; Broadway was as gaily crowded as ever. A thought of the advantage of a little judicious street-cleaning, just at this juncture, sprung spontaneously to the minds of all who went abroad. But no one was empowered to go on with the work. The officer to whom its superintendence is by law committed was powerless. Money makes the sweeping-machines go, and of money there was none, appropriated to street-cleaning purposes, in the City coffers. It is to be hoped that some measures will be taken to prevent the recurrence next year of the inconvenience which has resulted from this cause. The streets have not been cleaned since the last week in December, and cannot be until the tax levy passes. The City Inspector and the Comptroller have, however, arranged for the removal of ashes and garbage, though the work cannot be paid for until the annual appropriations are made.

abstract: Last night, at the Academy of music, that saltatory anniversary of the New-York Light Guard was observed with more than usual spirit. And they sang with a will.
lead_paragraph: Last night, at the Academy of music, that saltatory anniversary of the New-York Light Guard was observed with more than usual spirit. In the first place, to notice the decorations of the building, one hundred canary birds sang from one hundred cages, suspended from chandeliers, and from various projections of the ornamental protrusions, cherub's fingers, , of the boxes. And they sang with a will. DODWORTH's full band outdid them in strepitu, but not in perseverance. When the band ceased, the birds were in full voice; and, dividing their interests and their imagination between their seed and their singing, remained in full harmony all the night, till the last lady was fatigued with the last Redowa Polka.

abstract: An Anti-Slavery Convention is now in progress in this City. PARKER PILLSBURY, SUSAN B. ANTHONY,  A. M. POWELL, and other leading Abolitionists, are in attendance. The resolutions are characteristic, embracing the following ideas: American Slavery is the sum of all villanies, a combination of all cruelties and crimes, robbery, piracy, adultery, murder, and whatever else is impure, unholy and accursed.

abstract: The weekly report from the Institutions, to the Board of Governors yesterday, showed the number of persons remaining in them, Jan. 7, to have been 8,148, an increase of 166 as compared with the report of the previous week. When the Board of Governors met, the first proposition was to draw for seats. It was finally settled that members should be seated as during 1859. A requisition for one bale of blankets for the Institutions was granted, with the suggestion that it would be well to inquire what becomes of the old blankets.

abstract: We alluded some weeks since to the endeavor of Rev. S.H. MARSH, President of the Pacific University in Oregon, to obtain from the wealthy and liberal Christian communities of the older States, the means of establishing that important agent in the civilization and culture of the West upon a firm and a satisfactory basis.
lead_paragraph: We alluded some weeks since to the endeavor of Rev. S.H. MARSH, President of the Pacific University in Oregon, to obtain from the wealthy and liberal Christian communities of the older States, the means of establishing that important agent in the civilization and culture of the West upon a firm and a satisfactory basis. Mr. MARSH has since that time visited Boston, and obtained there $6,000 of the $20,000 which he requires. He has returned to this City, and we depart from our ordinary course in such matters, for the purpose of be-speaking the considerate and conscientious attention of those whom he may approach, to the claims of the enterprise upon their liberality.

abstract: Railway trains among the pyramids -- steamboats on the sacred Ganges -- the Great Eastern at the very shore where CANUTE forbade the rising tide -- traction engines on the deserts of California; -- truly the arts of engineering have fulfilled the old prophetic tales, save that for monsters of evil they have given us giants of good and engines of civilization. And it should be a source of encouragement and satisfaction to us, however we may have temporarily fallen behind in some matters, that the talent and works of our new country are already indispensable to the world's progress. Our machinery makes British arms and European enginery, defends foreign shores, and works out good for all nations. Not only does the East come to us for the hard forms of strength and power, but for the very appointments of luxury. The ready ability of our mechanicians and artists to respond to any call, is most satisfactorily instanced in the royal State carriage yesterday completed for the Viceroy of Egypt, by Messrs. T.W. WASON & Co., the famous car-builders of Springfield, Mass. This house had already furnished forty passenger cars for the Egyptian Government's Railway, extending from Alexandria to the Red Sea, some 275 miles. Among them was a first-class 16-wheeled car, which, upon trial, proved so easy and comfortable as to decide the order for the State carriage, while the general character of the work was so satisfactory as to induce another large contract, which they have filled.

abstract: One of the most appalling catastrophes which has ever shocked the country, occurred yesterday at Lawrence, Massachusetts. About 5 o'clock in the afternoon the Pemberton Mills fell with a tremendous crash. Six or seven hundred operatives were at work in them at the time, and the lowest estimates state that the number of those buried in the ruins way at least three hundred.
lead_paragraph: One of the most appalling catastrophes which has ever shocked the country, occurred yesterday at Lawrence, Massachusetts. About 5 o'clock in the afternoon the Pemberton Mills fell with a tremendous crash. Six or seven hundred operatives were at work in them at the time, and the lowest estimates state that the number of those buried in the ruins way at least three hundred. Eighteen dead bodies had been extricated when our dispatch was forwarded; twenty-five individuals had been taken out mortally injured, and fifty others, more or less mutilated, had been rescued. These details the telegraph gives us as a slight premonition of what must yet come. Amid the confusion which must have attended such heart-sickening slaughter, it is not strange that efforts to arrive at the cause of the catastrophe should have been fruitless. At midnight dispatches were added to those previously received, which swell the calamity into one of the most terrible ever recorded. While two thousand men were at work with that energy to which such suffering as they witnessed could prompt them, fire broke out in the ruins, and in ten minutes the whole mass was covered with a sheet of flame. The rescuers were driven back and obliged to leave the remainder to their fate.

abstract: When a house is on fire, it is generally considered the duty of every one to aid in quenching the flames. A person who should be detected in heaping fresh fuel upon the fire, would be dealt with as a miscreant and a public enemy. We do not see why political and social incendiaries should not be regarded in the same light.
lead_paragraph: When a house is on fire, it is generally considered the duty of every one to aid in quenching the flames. A person who should be detected in heaping fresh fuel upon the fire, would be dealt with as a miscreant and a public enemy. We do not see why political and social incendiaries should not be regarded in the same light. Yet we have a class of public journals, both North and South, which, taking advantage of the excited state of public feeling, devote themselves with miraculous industry to gathering up every wisp and straw of inflammable material, and scattering the blazing faggots broadcast over the country, that the smouldering flame of discord and disunion may be roused to a universal conflagration!

abstract: On the 22d September, as H.M.S. Spitfire was steaming to windward, a brigantine, suspected of being engaged in the slave-trade, was met off Aghway, Bight Benin, running to leeward, which shortly afterwards anchored at Whydah, a noted slave depot, at which place her Majesty's ship Spitfire likewise anchored. For three days the suspected vessel remained there, pretending to discharge plank and other cargo. On Sunday forenoon, Sept. 25, the weather being thick and squally, the brigantine left Whydah, and ran to leeward. Desiring not to lose sight of her the Spitfire steamed in the same direction that afternoon, and Lieut. CHAPMAN, having ascertained that she was not anchored at Jackin, to which place the brigantine was said to have been bound, proceeded in chase, and came up with her working off the land, on a wind, at 10 P.M. No satisfactory answer being returned when hailed, she was boarded, and proved to be the suspected vessel. The boarding officers returned apparently satisfied with the result, and with the account given by the person representing himself as the master of the vessel. Notwithstanding all this, doubt as to her honesty remained in Lieut. CHAPMAN's mind, and there being almost a calm, he decided on steaming back to Jackin, to learn some particulars of her having been off that place, which is a noted slave station. Having ascertained early next morning that a vessel had shipped slaves there the previous afternoon, he proceeded again in chase of the brigantine, and came up with her at 10 A.M., Sept, 26. Lieut. CHAPMAN boarded in person, and not being satisfied with the answers given by the person supposed to be the master of the vessel, who said that he had no papers, directed the hatches to be opened, whe[???] issued immediately the frantic cries of s[???]ng hundreds of wretched human beings, who were huddled together in heaps, naked, regardless of sex or age. At the same time two or three of the crew leaped out of the hold, naked to the waist, and be-grimed with the blood of the wretched blacks, whom they cruelly lashed into keeping silence, looking in every respect perfect demons. The flag that she unwarrantably had laid claim to was hauled down by one of her own crew, and the British run up, amidst the hearty cheers and joyful shouts of the rescued Africans. The vessel was found to contain 500 slaves, and was taken in tow to Whydah, and dispatched to Sierra Leone, with the slaves all healthy, for adjudication in the Prize Court at that place.

abstract: Mr. IVERSON, of Georgia, made a rampant speech in the Senate on Monday. He first placed himself on the stool of repentance and confessed the sin of having formerly advocated the doctrine of Popular Sovereignty, of which he had duly repented, and for which he asked the pardon of all good Democrats and of the country. Having thus purged himself of this grave political offence, he proceeded to administer a severe castigation to Senator DOUGLAS for holding the same heresy, and, not for this alone, but for his consistency in its support.
lead_paragraph: Mr. IVERSON, of Georgia, made a rampant speech in the Senate on Monday. He first placed himself on the stool of repentance and confessed the sin of having formerly advocated the doctrine of Popular Sovereignty, of which he had duly repented, and for which he asked the pardon of all good Democrats and of the country. abstract: We are amazed to find that our neighbor the Tribune does not like the speech made by Mr. RAYMOND at the Troy Union meeting some time ago, -- which was published in the TIMES on New Year's morning. The Tribune is so much in the habit of being delighted with Mr. R. is performances, and Mr. R. is so much in the habit of consulting the Tribune's tastes and predilections in what he says on public topics, that this little difference of opinion comes upon us with the freshness of a new sensation. We took it for granted instantly that our neighbor must have some very solid and substantial reason for its dislike of that speech, -- and curbing our impatience as well as we could, we waded through a long column of very melancholy wit, in order to find the whole case thus clearly and frankly stated:

abstract: The Mayor's scheme for the establishment of a "protective bureau" for the benefit of strangers and emigrants, promises to supply an unquestionable defect in our municipal system. It is certainly most desirable that there should be an office, occupied by employes  whose, sole business it shall be to afford information to new-comers, and protect simpletons from the hands of the sharpers who infest our streets.

abstract: A bill was noticed by Mr. CALVIN, in the Senate, to-day, relative to rents. Mr. CALVIN seeks to reopen the anti-rent question. It virtually nullifies the recent decision of the Court of Appeals against tenants, and provides that there is no rent where there is no subsisting reversion or interest left in the land in the party claiming such rent.

abstract: For many years I was thrown into personal contact with many men who occupied a prominent position before the public. abstract: I commence my term as Chief Magistrate of the commonwealth of Virginia at an evenful period in the history of the State and of the Union. No one of my predecessors has taken upon himself the duties and responsibilities of the office under the same circumstances. The Legislature and the people expect from me, therefore, an expression of my views upon the absorbing question of the day, and some suggestions looking to the future.

abstract: TAX RECEIPTS. -- Until the 1st of next June, twelve per cent. per annum, calculated from the 1st of last September, will be required on taxes now remaining unpaid. After the time mentioned the Clerk of Arrears takes these unsettled accounts in charge. Since the 27th-ult., the taxes paid in have amounted to $160,378 42, the interest on which sum has been $3,603 67, making a total during that period of $164, 9[???]2 [???]9. The Croton arrears which have been paid in sum up $1,589 79. The total receipts so far, on the tax Jevy of 1859. including Croton arrears, is $8,439, 419 46, leaving [???]1,479,588 80 for collection.

abstract: Mr. John Shakespear, of Langley Priory, provided in his will that his executors should pay out of his personal estate, "and before any other legacies, the sum of £2,500. to be laid out by them as they shall think fit, with the concurrence of the trustees of Shakespeare's house, already sanctioned by me [???] forming a museum at Shakespeare's house in Stratford, and for such other purpose as my said trustees in their discretion shall think fit and desirable for the purpose of giving effect to my wishes." He also directed that £30 a year should be paid to a person who should act as guardian of the house. The trustees of Mr. Shakespear's will objected to acting upon the terms of the bequest, conceiving that it was void, both under the statute of mortmain, and as tending to create a perpetuity. Yesterday, Vice-Chandler Wood sustained these objections.
