abstract: AN INCIDENT OF THE PURITY OF ELECTIONS. -- In Vermont a case is on trial of James Nicholas vs. John, Mudge. According to the reports of the case, the defendant owed plaintiff about $165. The auditor reports that in the Fail of 1854 plaintiff aspired to the honor of representing the town of Westford in the State Legislature, and intimated to defendant that if he would use his influence in procuring his election, he need not trouble himself about the account, gave him ten dollars to use "to the best advantage," and particularly indicated one man who was friendly to his election, but refused to attend the polls unless he was paid a dollar. Mr. NICHOLS was elected. The latter, however insists on his right to recover, and the defendant refers to the Court to decide whether the agreement to electioneer was legal, and, if so, a sufficient discharge of the plaintiff's claim. -- Baston Traveler.

abstract: SMALL POX AT ST. JOHN, N.B. -- We have received St. John (N.B.) papers of the 5th inst., by which we learn that the small pox is raging there to some extent. The News says there are twenty-two cases in the Old Poor-house Building, so called, opposite the old burial-ground, among men, women and children, all of whom are in the most wretched state of poverty and suffering, and completely cut off from the rest of the world. Unless aid be immediately afforded, many of these unfortunates must perish for want of the common necessaries of life and fuel to keep them warm. The people of St. John are bestirring themselves to afford these afflicted people relief.
lead_paragraph: SMALL POX AT ST. JOHN, N.B. -- We have received St. John (N.B.) papers of the 5th inst., by which we learn that the small pox is raging there to some extent. abstract: One of the most terrible calamities it has been our lot to record was that which occurred at Lawrence on Tuesday afternoon. Some seven hundred persons were in one of the large mills at the time, when, without premonition, it began to give way, and the whole number, with a few exceptions, were buried in the ruins. One hundred and fifteen were killed ...
lead_paragraph: One of the most terrible calamities it has been our lot to record was that which occurred at Lawrence on Tuesday afternoon. Some seven hundred persons were in one of the large mills at the time, when, without premonition, it began to give way, and the whole number, with a few exceptions, were buried in the ruins. One hundred and fifteen were killed outright, and many more seriously, if not fatally, injured. Many of the victims died in excruciating torture, their bodies being shockingly mangled, and some were literally roasted alive.

abstract: SEIZURE OF A SPANISH STEAMER. District Attorney ROOSEVELT, yesterday morning, received a communication from FRANCISCO STOUGHTON, the Spanish Consul in his City, inclosing copies of a remonstrance which had been addresed him by Captain JOSE M. VIADENTE, of the steamer Pojaro del Oceano, (Ocean Bird,) stating the circumstances of an alleged seizure of his vessel.
lead_paragraph: SEIZURE OF A SPANISH STEAMER. District Attorney ROOSEVELT, yesterday morning, received a communication from FRANCISCO STOUGHTON, the Spanish Consul in his City, inclosing copies of a remonstrance which had been addresed him by Captain JOSE M. VIADENTE, of the steamer Pojaro del Oceano, (Ocean Bird,) stating the circumstances of an alleged seizure of his vessel. He says that Capt. JOHN GRAHAM on Monday night, boarded the vesse with a number of armed men, and afterwards removed portions of her machinery. The Spanish Consul in his communication condemns the transaction as piratical, and urges that prompt measures for re tress should be adopted. The trouble is said to have originated in the recent suit of GRAHAM vs. MEYER," which was tried in the United States District Court, to determine the validity of the sale of four steamships, of which the vessel in question was one. Capt. GRAHAM, who gained the suit, did not give the Marshal the necessary indemnification bond, and the latter therefore refused to execute the process, and Capt. GRAHAM has thus taken the matter into his own hands.

abstract: Col. Peter A. Browne died at his residence in Walnut-street, Philadelphia, on Saturday, in his 78th year. Col. Browne took a prominent part in constructing the Arcade on Chesnut-street, and the Chinese Pagoda near Fairmount. The latter building was once an exceedingly popular place of resort. Lately Col. Browne devoted much of his time to the growth of wool, not neglecting, meanwhile, scientific and political matters. His successful defence of Wood and Mercer, whom he succeeded in getting acquitted of the charges of murder preferred against them, on the ground of insanity, did much to enhance his extended reputation as a lawyer. His pen was often employed in writing articles for the Press, which were marked by great vigor. He compiled two volumes of Reports of Decisions in the Court of Common Pleas.

abstract: THE LATE JUDGE NEVIUS. -- An adjourned meeting of the Bar of Hudson County, N.J., was held yesterday morning, at the Bergen Court-house, to take action in reference to the death of the late Judge NEVIUS. Judge OGDEN presided, and Mr. J.R. HARDENBURGH acted as Secretary. Resolutions expressing the high esteem in which the deceased was held were adopted, and remarks were made by Mr. MILLER and Judge OGDEN. The latter took occasion to speak of the inadequate compensation allowed the Judiciary, alluding to the fact that the late Judge NEVIUS had died without having been able to provide for the future support of his family.

abstract: The Count de Lauriston, whose duel with the Marquis de Galliffet has been narrated by "Malakoff," has written the following letter to the Independence Belge, whose correspondent had spoken of him as a man of sixty years old: "Monsieur le redacteur -- I am one of those who think it is always well to defend one's ground, inch by inch. In now writing to you, the only ground I have to defend is that of my age; but I nevertheless wish to have this letter inserted, in order to correct a mistake in one of your Paris letters of the 9th -- a letter, in all other respects, extremely flattering for me. This mistake is, morally speaking, somewhat of a detriment to my honorable adversary, and, in regard to the physical fact of my age, it is detrimental to myself. I am nearer to fifty than sixty years of age. I am a great sportsman; would you like to see my license to shoot? I often travel. Will you see my passport? It is my grey beard which has played me this shabby trick; my beard makes me look much older than I am, and is much greyer than my mustachios. I have been advised to shave my beard and keep only my mustachios, and I really think I must do so till I reach the age of sixty."

abstract: Little business was transacted yesterday at the weekly meeting of the Commissioners of Emigration. The application of the parents of a child named Augusta Lindsted, a deaf-mute, to be placed in the Deaf and Dumb Asylum, was denied, the Commissioners declining to incur expense in the present state of the treasury. The week's statement showed that 873 emigrants had arrived since the last report, and that $1,668 had been received for commutations. The amount overdrawn was $10,585 16.

abstract: ANOTHER MYSTERIOUS CASE.--One week ago last Saturday, a man named McNAMARA, residing at No. 202 Columbia-street, South Brooklyn, took a gun and went into Tiffany-place, just at the rear of his residence, for the purpose of killing a dog, which had bitten one of his children. Several hours after this he was brought home in an insensible condition by members of the family owning the dog.
lead_paragraph: ANOTHER MYSTERIOUS CASE.--One week ago last Saturday, a man named McNAMARA, residing at No. 202 Columbia-street, South Brooklyn, took a gun and went into Tiffany-place, just at the rear of his residence, for the purpose of killing a dog, which had bitten one of his children. Several hours after this he was brought home in an insensible condition by members of the family owning the dog. They stated that MCNAMARA came into their house, and while there he fell upon the stove while in a fit, and injured himself seriously. They had tried several hours to resuscitate him, but had not sent for a physician. Medical attendance was immediately procured, but MCNAMARA was not restored to consciousness before his death, which occurred yesterday. Coroner HORTON, upon hearing the particulars of the case, took charge of the body, and last evening a post mortem examination was made by Police Surgeon BALL and Dr. COCHRANE. They found the vertebrae of the neck broken and a clot of blood in the brain. There were no other indications of violence, and none of disease, except a slight enlargement of the heart. The friends of deceased say that he was temperate and in good health, and never had a fit to their knowledge, and from all the circumstances they were inclined to the belief that his injuries were the result of foul play. The case will be thoroughly investigated to-day by the Coroner.

abstract: EXTRAORDINARY ATTEMPT AT SELF-MURDER. -- The Cleveland Herald tells the following: "An old woman, 80 years of age, residing near Auburn, the county seat of De Kalb County, Ind., beat her husband, who was as old as herself, with an axe and club, till he died. This was six weeks ago to-day. She was lodged in jail, and on the following Sunday she procured a common case-knife, and sharpened it on the stove pipe in her cell, with the intention, she said, of cutting her throat; but fearing the knife was not sharp enough for the operation, cut or sawed a hole through into the cavity of the abdomen, tore out a portion of the caul, and then seized the large intestine, divided that, and cut off a piece about five inches long, throwing the piece into the stove, but it was secured before it was burnt too much for identification. She is now getting well. The reason she assigned for the act was she wanted to go where her old man was. No surgical aid was rendered, as it was thought she would die, but the inflammation has subsided -- the stomachic end of the intestine protruding about two inches out of the wound, through which the secretions pass.
lead_paragraph: EXTRAORDINARY ATTEMPT AT SELF-MURDER. -- The Cleveland Herald tells the following: "An old woman, 80 years of age, residing near Auburn, the county seat of De Kalb County, Ind., beat her husband, who was as old as herself, with an axe and club, till he died. This was six weeks ago to-day. She was lodged in jail, and on the following Sunday she procured a common case-knife, and sharpened it on the stove pipe in her cell, with the intention, she said, of cutting her throat; but fearing the knife was not sharp enough for the operation, cut or sawed a hole through into the cavity of the abdomen, tore out a portion of the caul, and then seized the large intestine, divided that, and cut off a piece about five inches long, throwing the piece into the stove, but it was secured before it was burnt too much for identification. She is now getting well. The reason she assigned for the act was she wanted to go where her old man was. No surgical aid was rendered, as it was thought she would die, but the inflammation has subsided -- the stomachic end of the intestine protruding about two inches out of the wound, through which the secretions pass.

abstract: We publish in another column a reply, in the interest of the City Railroad Companies, to our recent strictures upon the manner in which their duties to the public are performed.
lead_paragraph: We publish in another column a reply, in the interest of the City Railroad Companies, to our recent strictures upon the manner in which their duties to the public are performed. It is a refreshing specimen of the tone generally adopted by the managers of these roads. It would be a very great hardship, according to this writer, to require the Companies to furnish any better accommodations than they do at present. True, they make enormous profits; but then the public is already greatly benefited by them. Those who ride in their cars get more than they pay for already; the roads have improved the value of real estate uptown, and the City is much better off than it would be without them.

abstract: Hon. MORTON J. WILKINSON, the Senator recently elected in Minnesota, for six years, commencing on the 4th of March 1859, appeared in the United States Senate, yesterday, and was sworn in. Mr. GREEN subsequently resumed his remarks on the Territorial Question, controverting the position of Mr. DOUGLAS, and was followed by Mr. PUGH, of Ohio, in response to the attacks of Mr. IVERSON. Mr. PUGH early gave way to an Executive Session.
lead_paragraph: Hon. MORTON J. WILKINSON, the Senator recently elected in Minnesota, for six years, commencing on the 4th of March 1859, appeared in the United States Senate, yesterday, and was sworn in. Mr. GREEN subsequently resumed his remarks on the Territorial Question, controverting the position of Mr. DOUGLAS, and was followed by Mr. PUGH, of Ohio, in response to the attacks of Mr. IVERSON. Mr. PUGH early gave way to an Executive Session. In the House, Mr. SCRANTON, of Pennsylvania, justified his votes for Mr. SHERMAN, on the ground that the latter had given him personal assurances of his soundness on the doubtful point of favoring servile insurrection, or other interference with Slavery where it is protected by law. Mr. SCRANTON claimed for himself a position independent of all parties; and as evidence of his willingness to facilitate organization, referred to the fact of his having twice voted for Mr. GILMER. He also presented resolutions adopted at a Union meeting held in Luzerne, Penn., in which BROWN's attempt was strongly reprobated, and his punishment as warmly approved. Such, he declared, were the sentiments of the entire population of Pennsylvania. Mr. CAMPBELL, of the same State, indorsed the latter assertion to the fullest extent. Pennsylvania had been uniformly loyal to the Union and the Constitution, and would be so to the end. He ridiculed the idea that any particular man could be prevented from filling the Presidential office if duly elected. He, too, had sustained Mr. GILMER, because he regarded that gentleman as faithful to the laws and the existing order of things. In reply to a remark of Mr. GARTRELL, in his speech of Tuesday, to the effect that the cotton crop of Georgia alone would buy up the State of Pennsylvania, arms, ammunition and all, Mr. CAMPBELL averred that the mineral and agricultural productions of Pennsylvania fall very little short, in value, of the cotton crop of the entire South. After some further debate, a vote for Speaker was had, 111 being necessary to a choice. Mr. SHERMAN received 108; Mr. HAMILTON, 81; Mr. GILMER, 19; scattering, 13. A second ballot was ordered. While the roll was called, several Southern American members announced their determination to vote no longer for a Democratic candidate, as it was evident none such could be elected, and as the Democrats refrained, when this fact was so apparent, from voting for an American. They accordingly gave their names to Mr. GILMER. Mr. CLARK, of New-York, without consultation with his fellow Anti-Lecompionites, expressed his disbelief in the possibility of electing either a Lecompton or Anti-Lecompton Democrat, and his willingness to support any of the Southern Opposition -- individualizing Mr. ETHERIDGE, of Tennessee. Mr. ADRAIN reproached Mr. CLARK for thus speaking without consultation; and repeated his previous declaration that when the selection of a Speaker became obviously dependent upon the votes of himself, or his friends, they would be prepared to assume the responsibility. The ballot resulted: Mr. SHERMAN, 106; Mr. HAMILTON, 75; Mr. GILMER, 25; Mr. DAVIS, of Indiana, 8; scattering, 7. Necessary to a choice, 111. The House adjourned.

abstract: We have received the "Report on Federal Relations," submitted by a Select Committee to the House of Representatives of the State of Florida. It is a well-written document, and states the grievance of the South with apparent candor and considerable force. We do not ...
lead_paragraph: We have received the "Report on Federal Relations," submitted by a Select Committee to the House of Representatives of the State of Florida. It is a well-written document, and states the grievance of the South with apparent candor and considerable force. We do not care to go into a discussion of its different points, some of which we admit to be well taken. We have only a word to say about the accompanying resolutions, which, to our mind, are neither logical nor legitimate in their conclusions.

abstract: THE DEFAULTING TREASURER OF MAINE. -- The Bangor Evening Times says: "We understand that Mr. PECK states that he has in his possession evidences of having paid over considerable sums on the State's account, which had not been entered on the books at the time of the exposure of his defalcation, and which he has since had no opportunity of entering. It is said that he estimates the amount of State funds involved in his business operations at no more than $14,000 or $50,000, and the checks and drafts given by him, for which his bondsmen are not liable, at about the same amount."

abstract: The feeling which our correspondent reports as prevailing at Washington, at least among those who hold themselves amenable to "the code," touching the termination of the difference between BRANCH and GROW, is a curious illustration of the grotesque way of looking at things into which people drift who live long in contact with a strong prejudice.
lead_paragraph: The feeling which our correspondent reports as prevailing at Washington, at least among those who hold themselves amenable to "the code," touching the termination of the difference between BRANCH and GROW, is a curious illustration of the grotesque way of looking at things into which people drift who live long in contact with a strong prejudice. In this particular instance BRANCH is held to "stand sound on the record, while GROW has not toed the mark." The facts are that BRANCH challenged GROW for words spoken in debate; that GROW declined to fight, because he disapproved of dueling, and because the laws forbid it. He added that he "would defend his personal rights" if assailed -- a sort of warning that he will not allow himself to be kicked in the street, which it seems to be necessary to tack on to every refusal of an invitation to mortal combat in Washington. It appears, however, that the fireaters consider Mr. GROW as under a cloud, not so much because he declined a set duel, but because he declared he would defend "his personal rights" if attacked, instead of alleging, as Senator WILSON did, that he would defend himself, if attacked, "for the language" which had given offence.

abstract: MY DEAR SIR: You have an excellent memory to remind me, after so long an interval, of my promise to visit you when next on a tour to the South, and I owe you an apology for not earlier acknowledging your kind letter. It was handed to me just as I was about to leave Charleston, and I have been since too constantly in motion (to Augusta, and back here) to allow me to write.
lead_paragraph: SAVANNAH, Dec. 14, 1832.

abstract: Wilkes' Spirit of the Times states that the Racket-players of New-York are stirring again in the matter of a grand international match with England for the Championship.
lead_paragraph: Wilkes' Spirit of the Times states that the Racket-players of New-York are stirring again in the matter of a grand international match with England for the Championship. In an equally earnest spirit for such a meeting, a written proposition has already been sent to ERWOOD, the British Champion, by prominent members of the Racket Courts of this City, for an early meeting in the Spring, and suggesting that Mr. ERWOOD, Mr. MITCHELL, or Mr. PRINCE, whose pretensions to the palm of superiority in England are now in dispute, play among themselves for the mastery there, so that it be made certain that the best man of all shall come across. With the view, however, of preventing all disappointment among the rival champions of England, by one being chosen in preference to another, it has also been proposed that the two best players shall come out, and the two rival champions of this side play them a four-handed match.

abstract: There is one feature in the case between the City railroad companies and the public which the apologists of the latter entirely overlook, and that is, the rights not of those who stand in their cars, but of those who sit down in them. The obvious intention of the law in granting their charters, and fixing the rate of fare, was that every person who paid five cents for a seat in a ear thereby became entitled not simply to a seat, but to as much room in front for his legs as the width of the passage, minus the space occupied by the legs of his vis-a-vis, afforded; to as much light and ventilation as can be had when all the seats are full, and no less, and to perfect freedom of ingress and egress along the passage-way. Under the present system these undeniable rights of the stated passengers are entirely ignored. The passage-way is crammed full, their toes are trampled on, their legs cramped up, and the air, on a stormy or cold day, rendered so foul, that even half an hour's exposure to it is most injurious to health. Now, we maintain that when all the scats in a car are filled, the Company has contracted with every one of the passengers to secure him the accomodation, space, light, air and facility for egress which he then enjoys, and that, when a single person is admitted to stand up and hang on by the strap, their contract is violated. It is the duty of the Company to refuse to admit anybody else. The willingness of those outside to accept the standing-room has nothing to do with the question, any more than the willingness of a new corner at a crowded hotel to put up with half of a bed, the whole of which another guest has already engaged for himself, has to do with the landlord's bargain with the latter. The conductor of a car has but one answer for those who apply for admission after the seats are all taken, and that is that there is no room. If this rule were forced upon the companies, as it ought to be, they would soon be compelled to do their duty, and run, if need be, twice as many cars as at present. The crowds, who are now so anxious to get home that they are ready to be packed like sheep in the gangway, to the annoyance and discomfort and injury of those who have already engaged the car, would, if left on the sidewalk one or two evenings, speedily find means to bring the Presidents of these corporations to a sense of their obligations to the public. We should like to know how much longer New-Yorkers will be satisfied with being dependent on the good nature of corporations for the means of reaching their homes in the evening; how much longer, in short, the space to which citizens are entitled in licensed public vehicles will be left dependent on the caprice of conductors.

abstract: Adolph Crononine, of Pittsburg, suspected William Langner of improper intimacy with his wife, and meeting him at a tavern, discharged a pistol at him. He was so intoxicated by liquor and enraged with passion, that he missed the mark he aimed at and shot away two of his own fingers instead. He stands committed on a charge of assault with intent to kill.

abstract: The Herald points to the contrast which the catastrophe at Lawrence suggests, between the condition of Northern operatives and Southern slaves. Negro slaves at the South are never shut up six or seven hundred at a time in a rickety factory, by parsimonious and reckless employers, but tenderly cared for, and so forth. Our Abolitionist cotemporary might have carried the comparison further, with equal success.
lead_paragraph: The Herald points to the contrast which the catastrophe at Lawrence suggests, between the condition of Northern operatives and Southern slaves. Negro slaves at the South are never shut up six or seven hundred at a time in a rickety factory, by parsimonious and reckless employers, but tenderly cared for, and so forth. Our Abolitionist cotemporary might have carried the comparison further, with equal success. Negro slaves are never allowed to enlist in the army or navy, and expose themselves to the Indian or Mexican rifles, or British broadsides. On the contrary, our soldiers and sailors are all poor white men, whom stern necessity drives into the ranks, and who, in time of war, are launched by cruel commanders into the most horrible dangers. The condition of the European whites is, in this respect, just as bad as our own, and contrasts sadly with the happier lot of our Southern Sambos. We believe it is no exaggeration to say that since the commencement of the present century a million and a half of poor Englishmen, Irishmen, Frenchmen, and Americans have fallen in battle, or been horribly mutilated by sabre, bullet and bayonet. Yet during the whole of that period, we do not believe twelve negroes have been slain in action, including those who were slain at Harper's Ferry. Their masters carefully prevent them from going under fire or exposing themselves to any of the thousand chances of war, and, instead of condemning them to pass their days in learning to destroy their fellow-beings, confine them to the peaceable and useful labors of the plantation.

abstract: Rev. Dr. RYDER, of St. Joseph's Church in Philadelphia, died of inflammation of the bowels, in that city, yesterday morning. He was born in Ireland in 1800, went to Rome to study theology in 1820; in 1825 was appointed a teacher of theology in the College of Spoleti, where the present Pope was then Archbishop, and three years afterwards resigned the position and came to this country. In 1840 he was elected President of Georgetown College, and afterwards held the same position in the College of Worcester, Mass. He was also Superior of the Order of Jesuits in the Province of North America.

abstract: The inaugural message of SAM HOUSTON, on assuming his seat as Governor of Texas, opens with a candid confession of ignorance of local affairs, a result of Senatorial labors, which have withdrawn attention from State topics; and the people of the State are warmly thanked for the last expression of their favor. The Governor urges economy in the administration of the Government, commends the rail-read interests to the fostering case of the Legislature, recommends educational appropriations, and insists that the State has a right to look for Federal protection on the frontier. In reference to the disturbances at Brownsville, the message is full and explicit. The Governor is satisfied that the Cortinas affair has grown out of local abuses, and that no premeditated insurrection was intended, but urges the importance of a protectorate over Mexico. He says:

abstract: In the Senate of the United States yesterday an exciting debate took place on Mr. PUGH'S resolution, in which Messrs. PUGH, DOUGLAS, DAVIS, GREEN and CLAY participated. Mr. DOUGLAS defended the consistency of his course. He charged that others had changed their views, and said that he would not accept a nomination at Charleston, unless on a platform acceptable to him. He would reply fully hereafter to attacks made on him.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate of the United States yesterday an exciting debate took place on Mr. PUGH'S resolution, in which Messrs. PUGH, DOUGLAS, DAVIS, GREEN and CLAY participated. Mr. DOUGLAS defended the consistency of his course. He charged that others had changed their views, and said that he would not accept a nomination at Charleston, unless on a platform acceptable to him. He would reply fully hereafter to attacks made on him. In the House of Representatives, Mr. SHERMAN inquired of Mr. HOUSTON whether, in his remarks of the preceding day, he intended any personal allusion by stigmatizing the possible election of Mr. SHERMAN as a "burning, withering curse and shame." Mr. HOUSTON at once disclaimed any design to allude to Mr. SHERMAN personally. Mr. HARRIS, of Maryland, proposed that Mr. CLARK's Anti-Helper resolution be removed out of the way, and that the House adopt the substitute adopted by the Committee of Democrats, Americans and Anti-Lecomptonites at the meeting held Sunday, in which they declared that no man, who recommended, or still insists on and does not disclaim HELPER's doctrines, and who is not opposed to further agitation of the Slavery question, is fit to be Speaker. Various gentlemen explained the circumstances under which this substitute was adopted. Mr. HASKIN asked a question of Mr. MCRAE, which elicited from Mr. CLARK, of New-York, the words, "It is none of my colleague's business." Mr. HASKIN made some remarks, amid cries of order. Soon the members on all sides were on their feet, and many rushed to the area and main aisle. The Sergeant-at-arms was called on. He appeared with his mace, demanding peace. The Clerk kept on rapping to order. The utmost possible excitement prevailed. Subsequently, Mr. CLEMENS said that he saw Mr. HASKIN take a pistol out of his breast. Mr. DAVIDSON, jocularly, gave notice that when he again came to the House he would bring his shot-gun with him. Mr. HARRIS, of Maryland, said that was making game of the House. Mr. HASKIN subsequently explained how the pistol happened to fall from his breast. Every one who knew him, knew he would not use it except in an honorable way. Mr. CLARK, of New-York, apologized for the harsh remarks, and the House adjourned in good order and humor.

abstract: The Young Men's Democratic General Committee met last evening, for the purpose of organizing for 1860. The meeting was temporarily organized by calling Mr. J. AUGUSTUS PAGE to the Chair, and JOSEPH W. CORLIES, Jr., and HENRY J. CAMPBELL -- to act as Secretaries. On the motion to organize permanently, the above gentlemen were elected to the offices named. Subsequently, GEORGE W. JENKINS was elected Treasurer, and EDWARD DONNELLY, Sergeant-at-arms. Committees on By-Laws were appointed, and a Committee was selected to inform the Old Men's Committee of the organization. The then Committee adjourned to the second Thursday in February.

abstract: PATRICK MAUDE was executed at the jail in Newark, shortly before 12 o'clock yesterday. The charge upon which he was convicted was the murder of his sister, Mrs. MARY TURBOTT, by shooting her with a pistol, on the evening of Saturday, May 28, 1859. The circumstances of the murder were briefly these: In April, 1858, MAUDE, who had been employed, off and on, at the Zinc Works in Newark, and who was generally esteemed a desperate, quarrel some and revengeful character, was arrested for a felonious assault upon his wife, and also upon WM. O'CONNELL, an alleged paramour of his wife, both of whom he attempted to shoot with a pistol. He was tried and convicted of the offence, but his strange conduct during the trial raised doubts of his sanity, which were afterwards confirmed by the decision of a board of medical men, who were appointed by the Court to examine him, and who without hesitation pronounced him insane. He was accordingly sent to the Insane Asylum at Trenton, where he remained until the night of the 26th May, 1859, .when he made his escape by removing a window in his room. Previous to, and during his confinement in the Asylum, he had frequently made threats against the Prosecuting Attorney and the Judge who tried him, as well as against his wife, his sister, and others. On escaping from the Institution, he left a note behind him, indicating his purpose of carrying out these threats. He walked on foot to New-Brunswick, and there took a boat to this City, where he purchased a pistol, powder and ball, with which he immediately started for Newark. He concealed himself in that city until after dark of the evening of the 28th of May, when he proceeded to the residence of his sister, Mrs. TURBOTT, in Madison street. He arrived there about 9 o'clock in the evening, and found his sister behind the counter in her husband's store. While she was in the act of pouring out some beer for a customer, MAUDE suddenly entered the store, and fired two shots at her, both of which took effect in the breast, producing almost instant death. MAUDE was soon after arrested and placed in prison, where he remained until his trial, which took place in October last. On the trial, MAUDE refused the assistance of counsel, and declared his determination to defend himself. The Court, however, assigned C.L.C. GIFFORD and F.H. TEESE, Esqs., as his counsel, and although they received for their kind offices nothing but interruption and abuse from their client, yet they continued their labors in his behalf throughout the trial, basing his defence on the ground of insanity. The prosecution was conducted by the Attorney-General, CORTLANDT PARKER, and WM. L. DAYTON, Esq. MAUDE made a speech in his own behalf during the trial, in which he repudiated the defence of insanity, boldly denied his guilt, and made many telling points in his favor.

abstract: A Union meeting was held in Albany last evening, and another expression of the conservative sentiment of the North has been uttered, to convince, if convince it may, our Southern brethren that we neither desire their humiliation in the Union, nor plot their ruin out of it. These meetings have now been held in very many of the cities and large towns north of Mason and Dixon's line, and though we certainly cannot approve of all the views which have been advanced under cover of such gatherings, nor of the spirit in which some of their orators have spoken; though in some cases they have, doubtless, been made subservient to party ends, and used for the advancement of personal interests, yet, upon the whole, it cannot be questioned that their influence has been salutary at the North, and deserves to be so at the South. They have roused Northern men into thinking seriously upon the dangers and duties of the present crisis; they have opened a way for the general instinctive disavowal of Northern sympathy with all plans of intrusive Anti-Slavery in the States in which Slavery exists; they have led the community to feel that open attempts to nullify the action of the law for the rendition of fugitives from service, which has been pronounced constitutional by the highest judicial tribunal of the land, are serious offences against the Federal rights of the South; they have proclaimed the fraternal regard of the masses of the North for their Southern fellow-citizens. Surely then, they ought to strengthen the hands and encourage the spirits of the patriotic and conservative men of the South who, in the all-pervading excitement and alarm of their own section, are trying to stand up nobly for the preservation of the Federal Union, and to rebuke the mad spirit of revolution.

abstract: John Jay vs. George Bruce -- This is an action to recover damages for alleged injuries to the plaintiff's property on the corner of Canal and Elm streets, caused by the grade of the street having been changed by the defendant, in 1856. The case is now on trial before Chief-Justice BOSWORTH in the Superior Court. The complaint alleges that in 1853 he erected on his lots a block of buildings, with careful reference to the grade of Canal-street at that time; that the water from the street then flowed off regularly in a culvert; that in 1856 the defendant built on the opposite corner, and applied to the plaintiff for his (plaintiff's) consent to raise the grade of the street and sidewalk in front of defendant's premises, which was refused in express terms; that upon the refusal of the plaintiff, the defendant continued his work -- with a view to raise the grade, under a pretended authority from the Common Council; that the plaintiff then obtained an injunction from Justice HOFFMAN to restrain the proposed change in the grade; that the injunction was served, and to get rid of it the defendant then proposed an arbitration of the question of damages, as to the probable amount the plaintiff would sustain by reason of the raising the grade; that the injunction was withdrawn, and the matter referred by consent to Messrs, James T. Brady and Ex-Judge Thompson, as arbitrators; that the matter was postponed for different reasons on the part of the plaintiff, until Mr. Brady went to Europe, and Thompson finally declined to act; that pending this proposed arbitration, the defendant proceeded to build, and did raise the grade in front of his premises, on Canal-street, and a like elevation on the westerly side of Elm-street, and thereby changed the watercourse of Canal street to plaintiff's side, which rendered the construction of a culvert necessary, and deprived the plaintiff of the space under the sidewalks for use as vaults, &c.; that now the plaintiff's premises are constantly overflowed by water from the streets and that to remedy the matter be would be subjected to alterations and great expense. The damages claimed are $10,000.

The damages claimed are $10,000.

abstract: One of the largest and most respectable meetings ever held in this village was convened, last evening, for the purpose of considering the recent Virginia invasion. Empire Hall, the largest in the place, was filled to overflowing from the commencement of the meeting, at 7 1/2 o'clock, until its close, at 10 1/2 o'clock. The meeting was called to order by Dr. W.B. SHAW, on whose motion Hon. R.H. TYLER was chosen President, with the usual number of Vice-Presidents and Secretaries. Judge TYLER, on taking the Chair, addressed the meeting at considerable length, taking high conservative grounds; denouncing in terms of severity the raid of JOHN BROWN, and all acts of sympathy with the crime or the criminal, and asserting that the North, almost as a un[???]deprecated all violent and offensive interference with the institutions of the South.

abstract: The City Railroad Companies will forgive us for once more returning to the subject of their crowding their cars, when we mention that we have a suggestion to make for their benefit. They have laid down the doctrine that the passengers who have seats have no rights which a corporation is bound to respect, and that everybody who is willing to be packed into the inside, and left to stand up, ought to be packed in. In short, those who come up after the car is full, are entitled to more consideration than those who already occupy the seats. We controverted this theory yesterday, but as we do not expect the Companies to adopt our views until our logic is aided by the police -- which we confidently hope will shortly be the case, -- we beg to recommend that, in the meantime, in order to afford more standing room, the seats be removed in all the cars. If the Directors are really sincere in the wish they express to accommodate as many as possible, this is the way to do it. The benches and cushions once gone, the passengers can be packed close to the windows all round, and by making them stand sideways, and squeezing them a little more, there is no doubt double the number could be inserted than find entrance under the present ridiculously liberal system. This would also do away with the expensive necessity for straps overhead. In a tightly packed car, of course, jolting and swaying could throw nobody off his balance, and in cold weather the advantages of close contact with one's fellow creatures would only need to be felt in order to be appreciated. The fares might be collected through holes in the roof, and a small light ladder or flight of steps could readily be affixed to the side of the car to enable the conductor to mount for that purpose. In short, as the problem which the Directors have given themselves to solve, is how to carry the greatest number in a given space, without reference either to comfort, light, ventilation, or common decency, we feel satisfied that our scheme will meet with instant adoption.

abstract: THE AMERICAN INSTITUTE. -- A meeting of the American Institute took place on Thursday evening to hear the report of the Committee appointed at an informal meeting, to select names to put in nomination for office for the ensuing year. The meeting was not so large as the previous one, but was less divided in opinion, the majority being of the old complexion. The nominations were as follows: President -- ROBERT L. PELL. Vice-Presidents -- D.R. JAQUES, -- LAWTON, JOHN C. JOHNSTON. Recording Secretary -- H. MEIGS. Agent and Corresponding Secretary -- WM. B. LEONARD. Treasurer -- B. LEWIS, Jr. Finance Committee -- THOS. WILLIS, Jr., S.R. COMSTOCK, C.A. WHITNEY, P.H. TITUS, J.C. PARSONS. A motion also to publish the list in one of the three leading papers was voted down. There is some talk of nominating another ticket.

abstract: The following incidents, which occurred last Sunday morning in the church of Rev. Dr. CHEEVER, which stands upon Union-square, in the heart of the City of New-York, and which arrogates to itself a monopoly of Christian charity, sympathy and philanthropy, so far as the enslaved negro is concerned, will be of peculiar interest at this special time to your readers.
lead_paragraph: The following incidents, which occurred last Sunday morning in the church of Rev. Dr. CHEEVER, which stands upon Union-square, in the heart of the City of New-York, and which arrogates to itself a monopoly of Christian charity, sympathy and philanthropy, so far as the enslaved negro is concerned, will be of peculiar interest at this special time to your readers. A European gentleman, high in rank and titles, and connected with the English service visited Dr. CHEEVER's church on Sunday morning last, accompanied by his wife, and attended by a female servant and a colored men in livery. His attendants followed him op the aisle of the church and seated themselves, according to European custom, in the pew behind him. The audacity of the negro servant, exhibited by so cool and unpardonable an act, amused the Christian sentiments and philanthropic feelings of the Abolition representatives of the congregation. Two young men, of high promise in the community, who have been heretofore actively identified with the Anti-Slavery designs of the Church requested the sexton, very politely, to suggest to the colored gentleman the practicability of his taking a seat in the gallery -- reserved seats for negroes, of course, in the dress circle, being a necessary concomitant of Abolition theatricals. This request the sexton (being a doughface, I expect, and "sold to the South") refused to acquiesce in. One of the Trustees of the Church then called upon the gentleman, whose servant had committed a "breach of the Abolition peace," and informed him of the habits and customs upon Union-square. The gentleman very specifically and emphatically inquired if "he was in Dr. Cheever's Church, -- the Church which was soliciting British aid?" Also, "whether colored men were not allowed there?" He was told that they did not mingle promiscuously with the audience, -- the audience, I suppose, not being entitled to reserved seats. The gentleman then inquired "which door the colored people could go out of" and, on being satisfactorily informed, he ar[???]se and left the Church, accompanied by all the party. At the door he handed out his card, and requested that it should be sent to the pastor.

abstract: At the request of Marshal RYNDERS, a force of thirty Policemen was yesterday ordered on board the steamer Ocean Bird, lying at the foot of Tenth-street, E.R. It was thought that during the night an attempt would be made to take forcible possession of the vessel by certain parties, but up to a late hour no disturbance had occurred, and the Policemen were quietly sipping their lager and smoking the pipe of peace in the cabin of the vessel. abstract: The late Judge Boone, of New-Mexico, whose death at Philadelphia, Jan. 12, has been announced by telegraph, had returned to that city but a few days previous to his demise, after an absence of nearly two years. He had occupied a number of prominent positions, having represented Philadelphia in the State Legislature, the Federal Government in Nicaragua, and was, at the time of his death, acting as Judge of the Supreme Court in New-Mexico. The fatigue and exposure of his return trip was no doubt the immediate cause of his last illness.
lead_paragraph: The late Judge Boone, of New-Mexico, whose death at Philadelphia, Jan. 12, has been announced by telegraph, had returned to that city but a few days previous to his demise, after an absence of nearly two years. abstract: INCREASE IN THE POSTAGE ON NEWSPAPERS ADDRESSED TO THE EAST INDIES, CEYLON, MAURITICS, &c. -- From an increase in the British postage upon news-papers sent from England, by way of Southampton and Suez, to the East Indies, Ceylon, Mauritius, Hong Kong, China, Australia, or any other place to the eastward of Suez, hereafter, the postage upon all newspapers mailed in the United States, addressed to the above mentioned companies and places (via England) by way of Southampton and Suez, will be six cents each -- prepayment required. -- Washington Star.
lead_paragraph: INCREASE IN THE POSTAGE ON NEWSPAPERS ADDRESSED TO THE EAST INDIES, CEYLON, MAURITICS, &c. -- From an increase in the British postage upon news-papers sent from England, by way of Southampton and Suez, to the East Indies, Ceylon, Mauritius, Hong Kong, China, Australia, or any other place to the eastward of Suez, hereafter, the postage upon all newspapers mailed in the United States, addressed to the above mentioned companies and places (via England) by way of Southampton and Suez, will be six cents each -- prepayment required. -- Washington Star.

abstract: At the meeting of the Police Commissioners yesterday, in accordance with a resolution of the Board, General-Superintendent Pillsbury reported the facts brought out during an investigation of the recent arrest of an alleged fugitive slave. From the evidence it appeared that on the night of the 30th of December, Officer Terhune, of the Fourteenth Precinct, while on the corner of Crosby and Spring streets, found a negro whom he took to the Station house, and preferred a charge of intoxication against him. In the morning the negro was arraigned before Justice Brennan, and committed temporarily. Subsequently he was discharged, and since then his whereabouts has been unknown The Superintendent reported the account received of the whole transaction correct, and that an investigation, could only determine the validity of the charge of intoxication, which appeared to have been made in good faith. On these points the officer who arrested him had testified at the time of the arrest, and to his having seen him standing against a railroad car; that he took him to the Station-house, and charged him with being intoxicated, and also that he was a fugitive slave. When the prisoner had been committed temporarily, Judge Brennan and Deputy-Superintendent Carpenter told him to go to the Marshal, who would instruct him how to proceed. He did so, and Marshal Rynders gave him a letter, asking the Judge to hold the fugitive. Marshal Rynders told him to keep the matter still, and tell no one about it. He then returned to the Judge and reported, when the Judge informed him that his prisoner had gone. The Officer said, "I can't help it." The Officer also testified: "I did not expect a reward. I said, in jest, to several persons, that I did expect a reward. The negro told me, on the night I committed him, that he was a slave of Mr. Talbert, a dealer in cotton, in Richmond, Virginia, and that his name was George Keyo. He said he would as soon go back as stay here, and it was at his request that I charged him with being a fugitive slave. The negro was badly clothed. I asked him how he got here. He said he left on the Monday of the week previous, and that when he started he had $3. He said Mr. Talbert owned twenty-seven slaves, and that his father, mother and one brother were among them. If I had obtained any reward I should have given it to the Police Fund.

abstract: Certain swindlers -- who they are or where they are now nobody knows -- have recently visited a number of clergymen in this City, represented themselves as attaches of the City Inspector's Office, and demanded the fees which each clergyman is compelled by law to pay to the City Inspector for all the marriages solemnized by him. Many of the clergymen unwittingly paid the bogus claim, and have just awakened to a sense of the injustice which they thereby did themselves. The marriage fee in each case is ten cents, and many of the clerical gentlemen were mulcted by these rascals in the sums of $2 or $3. The law requires the ministers to pay the fees at the City Inspector's Office, and their failure to do so has resulted in their own discomfiture.

abstract: Barnard Levi, a lad about 15 years of age, was brought on from Boston on Thursday evening, by Detective Bennett, to answer a charge of having stolen $70 in cash, besides a gold watch and chain, valued at the same sum, from Mr. Pollitzer, a silver plater, doing business at the corner of Broadway and Cortlandt-street. Last Summer, Levi, according to his own statement, was employed as office boy by the complainant. Observing one night, when he closed the store, that Mr. Pollitzer had omitted to lock the safe, he determined to return and perpetrate a robbery. This was easy of accomplishment, as he always retained the key of the store-door. After he reached the store, it took him a long time to conquer his conscientious scruples, but the temptation proved irresistible. The watch which he took was immediately presented to a friend, and with the cash he departed for Philadelphia. After having spent his money, he left for Boston via this City, accomplishing the journey (about 350 miles) in seven days, doing without sleep for thirty-six consecutive hours, because he could, not discover a decent barn in which to repose. After reaching Boston, he sold some of his clothes to procure a meal of victuals, and then searched for employment. For some time he was unsuccessful, and each night he lodged in the cell of a Boston station-house, which, incidentally, he commended for its comfort and cleanliness. Finally he effected an engagement with a traveling theatrical company, and made the tour of the State of Massachusetts with them, acting, as occasion required, the role of call-boy, prompter and "general utility" man, in which latter character he achieved a decided success. After spending three weeks in this way, with "plenty to eat and little to do," the company disbanded on account of internal difficulties, and young Levi was again thrown upon his own resources and the charity of the Boston Police. In his strait he wrote a letter to a brother in this City, requesting funds wherewith to defray his expenses to Texas, where he had previously lived. The Detective Police gained possession of this document, and telegraphed to Boston requesting the apprehension of the young man, for whom the New-York officers had been looking for several months. Accordingly, his arrest was effected, and Detective Bennett was sent to take charge of him. The prisoner takes the matter philosophically, and says he shall probably spend the ensuing six years in the House of Refuge, where he hopes to acquire a trade that will enable him to live honestly after his release, as he wishes to correct his wandering and erratic habtts. He is now in the Tombs, pending an examination by Justice OSBORN of the charge against him.
lead_paragraph: Barnard Levi, a lad about 15 years of age, was brought on from Boston on Thursday evening, by Detective Bennett, to answer a charge of having stolen $70 in cash, besides a gold watch and chain, valued at the same sum, from Mr. Pollitzer, a silver plater, doing business at the corner of Broadway and Cortlandt-street. Last Summer, Levi, according to his own statement, was employed as office boy by the complainant. Observing one night, when he closed the store, that Mr. Pollitzer had omitted to lock the safe, he determined to return and perpetrate a robbery. This was easy of accomplishment, as he always retained the key of the store-door. After he reached the store, it took him a long time to conquer his conscientious scruples, but the temptation proved irresistible. The watch which he took was immediately presented to a friend, and with the cash he departed for Philadelphia. After having spent his money, he left for Boston via this City, accomplishing the journey (about 350 miles) in seven days, doing without sleep for thirty-six consecutive hours, because he could, not discover a decent barn in which to repose. After reaching Boston, he sold some of his clothes to procure a meal of victuals, and then searched for employment. For some time he was unsuccessful, and each night he lodged in the cell of a Boston station-house, which, incidentally, he commended for its comfort and cleanliness. Finally he effected an engagement with a traveling theatrical company, and made the tour of the State of Massachusetts with them, acting, as occasion required, the role of call-boy, prompter and "general utility" man, in which latter character he achieved a decided success. After spending three weeks in this way, with "plenty to eat and little to do," the company disbanded on account of internal difficulties, and young Levi was again thrown upon his own resources and the charity of the Boston Police. In his strait he wrote a letter to a brother in this City, requesting funds wherewith to defray his expenses to Texas, where he had previously lived. The Detective Police gained possession of this document, and telegraphed to Boston requesting the apprehension of the young man, for whom the New-York officers had been looking for several months. Accordingly, his arrest was effected, and Detective Bennett was sent to take charge of him. The prisoner takes the matter philosophically, and says he shall probably spend the ensuing six years in the House of Refuge, where he hopes to acquire a trade that will enable him to live honestly after his release, as he wishes to correct his wandering and erratic habtts. He is now in the Tombs, pending an examination by Justice OSBORN of the charge against him.

abstract: I perceive, in a recent issue of the TIMES. an article chiding the Republican party for being behind many of their fellow-citizens of the Northern States in their public avowals of attachment for the Union, and urging them to enter the field in its behalf, and demonstrate, by a public expression, their fidelity to the Constitution and laws of the land. A number of Republican members of Congress, I also observe, have taken occasion to express that sentiment, and to repudiate, as a calumny, the charge that they are inimical to the Union.

abstract: The Mayor of Lawrence on Wednesday night gave the ruins up to the proprietors of the mills, and they have set a good force at work to clear out the rubbish. There have been some expressions of surprise that creamer progress has not been made in clearing the rubbish away, but the mixture of heavy machinery, shafts looms, and innumerable iron rods and pipes, are so interwoven and mixed up that it would require more than manual strength to remove even a comparatively small piece of machinery. During Thursday two large derricks were erected, and yesterday four or five more were to be put up, with which the heavy machinery can be lifted out. At the time Mayor SAUNDERS delivered the ruins to the proprietors, he offered them the services of fifty men, in addition to their own force. It was almost impossible to find any considerable number of men in the city who could be of much service, as all who were able had completely exhausted themselves in their exertions on the night of the disaster and the day following. The greater part of the men employed by the proprietors were brought from Lowell. It was thought that by last night or this morning the greater part of the remaining bodies will be recovered.

abstract: MARRIAGE EXTRAORDINARY -- In the Toronto Colonist, under the matrimonial head, appears the following singular notice: MARRIED -- By Rev. JOHN BROWN, Presbyterian minister, at the village of New-market, township of Whiteburch, C.W., at the residence of the bride's father, BENJAMIN HEWSON, Toronto, Orange Brigade Drum-Major, in full scarlet regimentals, with Orange sash, sword, &c., to FLORA, eldest daughter of Mr. ARCHIBALU MCMILLEN, of East Gwillimbury, C.W. When the minister got through with the necessary ceremony by law established, with a very appropriate lecture on the occasion, the bridegroom immediately afterwards requested to add a few words on the subject, and after he had got the sanction of all invited as witnesses, drew his sword from the scabbard, and giving it into the bride's hand, said, in the presence of all there assembled, "I now authorize you, my dear wife, to plunge this naked sword in my breast in case you find me unfaithful to the marriage lie now taken place between me and you, (as unworthy of a moment's longer existence;) henceforth you will have this sword placed at the head of your bed at your service." All present seemed very feelingly impressed on the hearing of his heartfelt remarks, and so it ended.

abstract: Charles Mallory, Charles H. Mallory, Charles Grinnell, Elihu Spicer, Jr., Samuel Willetts, Robert Willetts and Daniel J. Willetts vs. The Commercial Mutual Insurance Company. This is an action involving an important question as to the nature and construction of policies of insurance.
lead_paragraph: Charles Mallory, Charles H. Mallory, Charles Grinnell, Elihu Spicer, Jr., Samuel Willetts, Robert Willetts and Daniel J. Willetts vs. The Commercial Mutual Insurance Company. This is an action involving an important question as to the nature and construction of policies of insurance. The plaintiffs allege that on the 15th day of November, 1856, they were the owners of the ship Samuel Willetts, which was duly registered at the port of Stonington, Conn., and which was of 1,387 tons burden; that on that day the cargo of the said ship was insured by the defendants for one year thereafter, by their agents in this City, Messrs. J.D. Fish & Co., for the sum of $5,000, on all trade voyagers "between Atlantic ports of the United States, or the ports of Liverpool, London and Havre, and the Pacific Ocean, the China Seas including Australia, Van Dieman's Land, and ports in the Indian Ocean," -- the cargo to be valued at $20,000; that in the month of July of that year, on the 3d day of the month, the ship was lost by the perils of the sea, together with her cargo, of value equal to the said sum of $20,000.

abstract: SUDDEN DEATH. -- WALTER BRIDGES, for many years prominent in the organization of Building Associations, died suddenly in his office, No. 1 Montague-street, at about 5 o'clock last evening. He had been in the Circuit Court during the afternoon, apparently in the enjoyment of good health. At a little before 5 o'clock he went to his office to transact some business with a lady, and while talking he seemed to swoon, and slipped from his chair to the floor. Police Surgeon BALL was immediately called in, but life was extinct. It is supposed that he died of heart disease. The Coroner was notified, and, soon after, the body was removed to the late residence of deceased, No. 266 Union-street.

abstract: William Hutchinson, indicted for taking letters which did not belong to him from the Post office, withdrew his plea of not guilty and pleaded guilty.
lead_paragraph: William Hutchinson, indicted for taking letters which did not belong to him from the Post office, withdrew his plea of not guilty and pleaded guilty. William Muehle was put on trial, charged with the same offence. Evidence was given to show that a letter, containing a draft on Belmont, in favor S.H. Strouse & Bro., was put in the Post-office in Columbus, Ga., addressed to S.H. Strouse & Bro.; that about the time when the letter should have arrived here, letters were delivered from the Post-office to a man who was identified by the Post office Clerk as the accused; that the draft was presented at Belmont's and paid, and the Cashier identified the accused as the man who presented it and received the money, and that he recollected him because he asked him if his name was Strouse, and if he had indorsed the draft.

abstract: The Second District alarm, just before 1 o'clock yesterday morning, was caused by the discovery of a fire in the liquor store of THOMAS SHERIDAN, No. 385 Seventh-avenue. The firemen extinguished the flames before much damage was done. When the doors were broken in, flames were discovered in three different places, and an examination by Fire Marshal BAKER proved that the incendiary had used kindling-wood and straw in firing the premises. As the bartender, JAMES CARROLL, had acted very suspiciously before and after the fire, the police took him into custody, and he was locked up to await an examination.

abstract: Judging from the multiplicity of notices of bills which are pouring in upon both branches of the Legislature at Albany, we fear the approaching session will be as prolific in laws as so many of its predecessors. Before it is too late, however, it may not be amiss to beg of the members to remember, that the curse of the country and of the age in which we live is over legislation.
lead_paragraph: Judging from the multiplicity of notices of bills which are pouring in upon both branches of the Legislature at Albany, we fear the approaching session will be as prolific in laws as so many of its predecessors. Before it is too late, however, it may not be amiss to beg of the members to remember, that the curse of the country and of the age in which we live is over legislation. The habits and training of the American people are happily such that they can live with very little government, and everything which is left entirely to itself, and in which the law does not meddle, is pretty sure to be well done. Most of our troubles and griefs and annoyances are, in fact, caused by acts of Congress, or acts of the Legislature. If our statutes were diminished by one-third, we verily believe we should be much better off than we are. The mania for bringing fresh ones into existence, by which all members of the Legislature are actuated in these latter days, is one of the worst evils of the times. It burdens the Courts, confuses the bar, and unsettles business. It leads, moreover, to the introduction of hasty and ill-considered bills, which after annoying the whole State by their brief operation, bring all law into contempt by their sudden repeal. An act of the Legislature ought to be the fruit of much thought and much discussion, and ought to embody not the whim or crotchet of an individual, but the clearly and thoroughly expressed will of the public. If ambitious politicians will only devote a small portion of their energy to the work of securing a better execution of the laws already in force, we will cheerfully excuse them from the consideration of new ones. There are but few things in the social or political condition of the State of New-York at this moment which would not be the better for being let alone. If the Legislature knew its duty, it would make the smallness of the volume which is to contain the result of its labors the great object of its ambition.

abstract: Three more bodies were taken from the ruins to-day. These were all badly mutilated two of them so much so that they could not be identified. The third was discovered, by fragments of clothing, to be that of Mrs. AUGUSTA ANN ASHWORTH. She was 18 years of age, and was married in March last. Her husband is a shoemaker, and works at North Salem. Her body was nearly consumed.

abstract: The composition of the Italian Opera companies, all over Europe, is now becoming curiously polyglott -- nowhere more so than in Berlin. The prime donne were Mesdames Lorini and de Wilhorst, American ladies; the mezzo soprano is Mile. Artot (Belgian;) the tenor. M. Carrion, is Spanish; the basso, M. Bremond, is French. A French tenor, M. Nandin, has appeared with great success at the Madrid Opera. M. Elisa Marechal, whose birthplace is Rio Janeiro, is about to appear, under the auspi[???]es of Signor Mercadante, at the Teatro San Carlo, Naples. Miss Balfe has gone to Russia to sing in concerts.

abstract: Bad weather, which compelled the screw-steamship New-York to call at Halifax for a fresh supply of coals, places us under obligations for European advices to Dec. 29. The news is extremely meagre. In reference to the Congress, it was stated that the Pope had declined to send a representative thither, without a distinct repudiation, on the part of NAPOLEON III., of the remarkable pamphlet, reproduced in the TIMES on the 9th inst. No further events had occurred in the Morocco war. The Queen of Spain had given birth to a daughter. From China we are informed that the Emperor of China has demanded the mediation of the American Government to avert the war threatened by France and England. Business was active in England. Consols closed on the 28th at 95 3/8@95 5/8. It is gratifying to be able to announce, in connection with this news, that the questions at issue between the Nova Scotia Telegraph Company and the New-York Associated Press have been adjusted; and that our European dispatches from Halifax will hereafter be forwarded without resort to the employment of a horse express between that point and Sackville.

In reference to the Congress, it was stated that the Pope had declined to send a representative thither, without a distinct repudiation, on the part of NAPOLEON III., of the remarkable pamphlet, reproduced in the TIMES on the 9th inst. No further events had occurred in the Morocco war. The Queen of Spain had given birth to a daughter. From China we are informed that the Emperor of China has demanded the mediation of the American Government to avert the war threatened by France and England. Business was active in England. Consols closed on the 28th at 95 3/8@95 5/8. It is gratifying to be able to announce, in connection with this news, that the questions at issue between the Nova Scotia Telegraph Company and the New-York Associated Press have been adjusted; and that our European dispatches from Halifax will hereafter be forwarded without resort to the employment of a horse express between that point and Sackville.

abstract: Mr. PENNINGTON, of New-Jersey, made a brief, manly, and sensible speech, yesterday, in favor of the adoption of the plurality rule, and the immediate organization of the House of Representatives, no matter under what auspices. Such a speech might have been more effective in the House, perhaps, had it not proceeded from a member of the party which is likely to profit by the adoption of the suggestion it contains; but this circumstance will not at all impair the force upon the country of its vigorous and patriotic protest against the clamorous trifling in which the delegates of the American people have consumed so many dreary weeks. Such displays as took place in the Representatives' Hall, on Thursday night, are not more truly disgraceful, though they are more flagrant and startling, than the imbecility, want of public spirit, and intensity of partisan greed which can obstinately impede for weeks and months the organization of a great body of public servants, to the instant detriment of every public interest, and the prospective demoralization of the whole political life of the country. That Mr. CLARK should insolently snub Mr. HASKIN, and Mr. HASKIN raise revolvers upon the floor; that Mr. SMITH, of egg-nogg notoriety, should declare Mr. BINGHAM "worthy of the scorn and detestation of every man who forms part of the American Union," assure him that if he were one of Mr. SMITH's slaves "he would get what he deserved," notably a sound whipping, and "direct" him to take his seat;" and that Mr. BINGHAM should thereupon do as he was bid, "regretting that the gentleman was so ill-mannered" -- all this is certainly a very pitiful and contemptible exhibition. Neither can it be thought very creditable to the wit of Mr. STEVENS, that he should quiz the Clerk by sending up a "German paper," with a request to that hapless functionary to read out an extract from its, to him, hieroglyphical columns; nor highly indicative of the general good sense of the elect of the Union, that they should have been thrown into convulsions of anxiety, because Mr. CONKLIN sent Mr. BARKSDALE, a note "containing a small bit of court plaster," no doubt in view of probable contingencies in which such a styptic might be of use to the member from Mississippi. But these are all things which, as Mr. ETHERIDGE, of Tennesssee, with complacent philosophy, remarked, "must be sometimes expected to occur." No man is always wise, and parliaments of fools may have their place in Heaven's design, with the earthquake and the storm, the BORGIA and the CATILINE.

abstract: The Charleston Mercury, with the view of contributing to the settlement of the Slavery question, has been looking into the state of Northern morals, and has discovered, from "reliable statistics," that more wives of Northern men, in proportion to the whole number, run away from their husbands than negro slaves from their masters. This is a step in the right direction. Let this fact, and a few more like it, be once well authenticated and widely circulated, and peace will soon reign within our borders. For this purpose we cordially recommend the Mercury to publish the said "reliable statistics," and also to indicate where they may be found. The horrible infidelity of Northern wives which our Southern contemporary has so properly exposed, is clearly another proof of the "failure of free society." We believe, too, that if our contemporary will extend his researches, he will discover that most of these frail and erring creatures have taken their departure from their husbands' homes by railroad. We mention this fact to show the iniquity of maintaining, at such enormous expense, the vast network of lines which now covers the North. A mode of conveyance, which can thus be made subservient to the worst passions of our nature, which affords to women -- who, from their earliest years, have witnessed the monthly degradation of their parents in paying the servants' wages -- the means of breaking their marriage vows, ought not to be tolerated one minute longer than can be helped. Northern women, our contemporary will agree with us and every friend of virtue in thinking, are not persons who can be safely permitted to have railroad trains shrieking and rumbling temptation under their windows four or five times a day.

abstract: DODWORTH's ROOMS. -- Mr. J.R. THOMAS, one of the most delicious of our song composers, and a vocal artist of the first class, is to be the recipient of a complimentary concert on Tuesday next, to which we desire to direct attention. The programme is attractive, the price of admission moderate, and the beneficiare a gentleman of merit and acknowledged capacities. We have not many composers in America, and it is the duty of the public to support the few that can honestly claim the name. Mr. THOMAS' compositions are hummed and whistled by the masses from Maine to Florida, and we hope, for the sake of a gift that gives so much and produces so little, that Mr. THOMAS' first concert will be adequately recognized by the public. A number of popular singers will assist on the occasion.

abstract: We have the returns of the British Post-office Department to compare, or rather contrast, with those of our Postmaster-General. The two documents are as unlike in their general style as in the results which they unfold. The one is a clear, precise, business-like statement the other a document confused in its general plan, and most discouraging in the conclusions to which it leads.

abstract: Joaquin, C. de la Rua vs. Jose M. Pie. -- The plaintiffs in this action are a mercantile firm in Havana, and allege that the defendant did in April last, being their collecting clerk, fraudulently convert and appropriate to his own use the proceeds of certain bills of theirs in his hands for collection, amounting to the sum of $10,000. The defendant came to this City, where he was subsequently arrested on the charge and put in prison, where he has remained ever since.

abstract: The news brought by the Hungarian is but a day later than that forwarded from the New-York, at Halifax; but is more detailed. It is said that Count WALEWSKI has made a very guarded denial of such authorship, having said to
lead_paragraph: The news brought by the Hungarian is but a day later than that forwarded from the New-York, at Halifax; but is more detailed. The statement that the Pope had refused to participate in the Congress without a disavowal by NAPOLEON III. of the authorship of the pamphlet on the temporal authority of the Roman See, is confirmed. It is said that Count WALEWSKI has made a very guarded denial of such authorship, having said to a German diplomat that were such the fact, he was unapprised of it, and that, if fully verified, he should resign his position in the Ministry. The pamphlet is generally accepted as evidence of an entire restoration of the entente cordiale between France and England, not only upon the Italian, but in regard to all other questions. To the same purpose, a dialogue purporting to have occurred between an Englishman and a Frenchman, upon the relations of the two countries, but in which the Emperor himself is understood to have been the chief interlocutor, is reported in the London Times, and gives occasion for general comment and much felicitation. Mr. RICHARD COBDEN is said to have represented England in the colloquy. There has been more skirmishing between the Spaniards and the Moors, but no general action. Italy is tranquilly awaiting the action of the Congress. The French pamphlet and the delegation of Count CAVOUR, as representative of Piedmont, are regarded as securities that the national claims are to be fully conceded. The report that the American mediation has been sought by the Emperor of China to avert the attack of France and England is founded upon a brief dispatch dated at Shanghai.

abstract: The flurry and fuss of last evening having subsided, we may expect, or at least hope, for a Oalm to-day. Last night the whole city was in a buzz and perturbation--every bar-room doing a big business on the strength of the pistol-scene--every hotelhall swarming with excited groups--every political parlor filled with declamatory disputants, and the lady-circles all rustling and quivering, fanning them

abstract: SUNDAY-SCHOOL MISSIONARY MEETING.--The large hall of the Cooper Institute was two-thirds full, last evening, in pursuance of a call for a meeting, "in aid of the missionary work of the American SundaySchool Union." After reading the Scriptures and prayer by Rev. Mr. CLARK, and singing a hymn by the congregation, Rev. C.C. Goss, missionary of the Sabbath-School Union for the past two years, in Nebras
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY-SCHOOL MISSIONARY MEETING.--The large hall of the Cooper Institute was two-thirds full, last evening, in pursuance of a call for a meeting, "in aid of the missionary work of the American SundaySchool Union." After reading the Scriptures and prayer by Rev. Mr. CLARK, and singing a hymn by the congregation, Rev. C.C. Goss, missionary of the Sabbath-School Union for the past two years, in Nebraska, gave an interesting account of his missionary labors and the results. He had established over two hundred schools and gave away an equal number of libraries. He closed with an urgent appeal for contributions, stating that although there was a disposition on the part of the people of Nebraska to aid in starting and supporting Sunday-Schools, they had not the money to give. An address of equally interesting character was given by Rev. B.N. CHIDLAW, who has been a missionary in behalf of the Union in Ohio, for over twenty-two years. He gave a vivid picture of his early labors and struggles, and the contrast now presented in Ohio. Much, he urged, remained to be done, not two-thirds of the field having been fitly explored and cared for. A printed account shows that during the six months ending with last September, there had been organized 1,776 schools where none previously existed, in which had been collected 138,865 pupils, and whose united libraries amounted to 180,000 volumes. A collection was taken up, when the exercises terminated with the benediction and singing the doxology.

abstract: We cannot help congratulating the Bench and Bar of Memphis, Tenn., upon the death of Dr. PALMER, of that city, who was recently held to bail on a charge of inciting slaves to insurrection. The proof, our readers may remember, on which a Tennessean Judge, after hearing counsel, thought himself justified in sending
lead_paragraph: We cannot help congratulating the Bench and Bar of Memphis, Tenn., upon the death of Dr. PALMER, of that city, who was recently held to bail on a charge of inciting slaves to insurrection. The proof, our readers may remember, on which a Tennessean Judge, after hearing counsel, thought himself justified in sending him before a jury, consisted of a letter purporting to be signed by a person named THATCHER. This letter was sent to Gov. WISE by an anonymous correspondent, who stated that he had picked it up in a railroad car. WISE of course sent it to the Governor of Tennessee, and the Governor of Tennessee, who had not WISE's excuse for his folly, instituted a judicial proceeding upon it. Thus there was no proof that the letter was picked up in a car, or that THATCHER ever wrote it, or that there was such a person as THATCHER in existence; and yet a man was actually, in a State in which the common law is administered, and before a Judge responsible to the people, obliged to find bail to answer the charges which it contained.
