abstract: On Saturday (Dec. 24) one of those brutal cases which have too often recently brought disgrace upon the mercantile marine of the United States, was investigated at the Liverpool police court, before Mr. J.S. MANSFIELD. PHILANDER HAIL, second mate, and DANIEL DAVEN PORT, boatswain, of the American ship John Bright, were brought up charged, with, having caused the death of a seaman named GREEN, on board that vessel. Two passengers, named PRITCHARD and HACKITT, stated that on several occasions during the voyage from New-York, the two prisoners had beaten deceased very severely with a rope knotted at the end, kicked him, and then when he was unable to do work they put him in irons. On one occasion the deceased was sent into the fore rigging, though he was unable to stand on his legs, and the mate followed him about deck, kicking him, because he did not go fast enough. At another time HACKITT saw the second mate take a large packing needle and commence "probing" the deceased with it all along the deck. It was also stated that a few days before GREEN died he expressed a wish that some one would throw him overboard. HACKITT found him covered with black and blue spots in various parts. The body also bore marks of still more horrible ill-treatment. During the voyage he was scarcely ever free from a black eye. A surgeon named MOORE, who was also a passenger on board the same ship, stated that he had examined the deceased before he died, and found him suffering from inflammation of the lungs. Not having been frequently on deck, this witness could not say how often the deceased had been ill-used; he did not see him treated as the other witnesses alleged. The deceased had reported that he had been ruptured, but he, witness, had examined him, and found no trace of a rupture, nor yet of bruises. He believed that deceased had died of inflammation of the lungs. The case was remanded for a week, and in the meantime the evidence of the witnesses examined will be laid before the American Ambassador and the Home Secretary.

abstract: Lord PALMERSTON has, it is said, given a direct negative to the proposal of the Hanse Towns, which we discussed a few days ago, to bring before the approaching Congress the propriety of placing private property at sea on the same footing as private property on shore. The London Times backs him up, by asking, sarcastically, why a proposition is not made to...
lead_paragraph: Lord PALMERSTON has, it is said, given a direct negative to the proposal of the Hanse Towns, which we discussed a few days ago, to bring before the approaching Congress the propriety of placing private property at sea on the same footing as private property on shore. The London Times backs him up, by asking, sarcastically, why a proposition is not made to declare invasion of enemy's territory unlawful, and thus protect private individuals from the annoyance of having troops quartered in their houses. The question is a very silly one, and the answer very simple. War is a means of deciding quarrels between nations, and it is the only means that, in the existing state of human nature, will answer the purpose. It ought, however, to be deprived of every feature of harshness or severity which will not interfere with its efficiency as an arbitrator. It does not hasten the decision of the controversy to kill prisoners, or to rob houses, as the sorrowful experience of many ages and countries has proved. For a similar reason, it is unnecessary to rob vessels at sea. In fact, the great and only mode of putting an end to war, is seizing on the enemy's territory and holding it, or, in other words, assuming the government of it. This ends the dispute, and is consequently a complete justification of invasion, and the only one. If the Times is prepared with a substitute for war, it may ask to have the right of invasion abandoned; but until it is, its sneer is pointless; -- and unless those who refuse to place private property at sea at the same footing as property on land, can show that the right of plunder with regard to the former does more to hasten the decision of an armed controversy than the right of plundering the latter would do, they are fairly chargeable either with gross inconsistency, or with standing up in defence of one the worst relics of barbarism.

abstract: The steamer brings us reports of sundry proceedings in Scotland concerning Slavery in America. Abolition emissaries from this side the water are appealing for sympathy and material aid to the people of Great Britain. FRED. DOUGLASS is vindicating the memory of JOHN BROWN, and holding him up to the admiration of his audiences as a hero and a saint, on ...
lead_paragraph: The steamer brings us reports of sundry proceedings in Scotland concerning Slavery in America. Abolition emissaries from this side the water are appealing for sympathy and material aid to the people of Great Britain. FRED. DOUGLASS is vindicating the memory of JOHN BROWN, and holding him up to the admiration of his audiences as a hero and a saint, on substantially the same grounds as are taken by PHILLIPS and his colaborers here. At Edinburgh a public meeting has been held to take into consideration Dr. CHEEVER's case, and to devise ways and means for enabling him to continue to "bear testimony against Slavery" in the Puritan Church of New-York City. Dr. CANDLISH, whose name is well known in this country as that of an able and eloquent divine, made the only speech of any consequence on the occasion, and gave the weight of his influence in favor of the appeal. Collections were to be made in the several churches of Edinburgh in aid of Dr. CHEEVER.

lead_paragraph: January is the month for publishing and for purchasing almanacs. Every one is expected at that time to lay in his stock of astronomical, meteorological and miscellaneous information for the year. Politicians, farmers mechanics, and all other classes of the community, have editions prepared for their special use; but few persons are aware, we suspect, of the extent to which this annual tract is used for the dissemination, among our doctor-loving and dose-swallowing community, of the multitudinous quack medicines of the day.

They had not walked far, however, ere the countryman's wallet. containing $36, which
lead_paragraph: On Friday night, a countryman named James Burns met James Brennan, a sharper, in the saloon No. 523 Canal-street. Burns entered into conversation with the stranger, for whom he professed much friendship, drank several times to his health and prosperity, and finally invited him to take a stroll and view the City sights. They had not walked far, however, ere the countryman's wallet. containing $36, which he had unguardedly shown his companion, was missed. Suspecting his newly-made friend had stolen it, Burns caused his apprehension, and Justice QUACKENBUSH committed the prisoner to answer. The complainant also was held in bail to appear as a witness.

abstract: Coroner JACKMAN, at a late hour on Friday night, concluded an investigation relative to the death of Mr. GEORGE W. CHURCH, who, on the 2d inst., while endeavoring to quiet a disturbance between a number of rowdies, was struck on the head with a cart-rung, and injured so severely that he died on the Sunday following. The inquest had been several times adjourned because of the absence of important witnesses. A verdict was rendered that death ensued from compression of the brain, caused by a fracture of the skull, the result of a blow on the head with a cart-rung, in the hands of MARTIN TOOLE. STEPHEN S. KENNEDY was also implicated in the homicide, as he procured the cart-rung, and struck the deceased after he had been rendered insensible by the blow which caused his death. Both the accused are in custody. TOOLE is a native of this country, a butcher by occupation, and but 16 years of age. KENNEDY is a carman, 28 years of age.

abstract: Several months ago the roof of the New Arsenal in Seventh-avenue fell, from its own weight, causing a large loss of property, but happily none of life. It was immediately repaired, and, as before, the large hall to the upper part of the building was used as a drill room. Of late, however, and before the disaster to the Pemberton Mills, there has been a growing suspicion of the insecurity of the structure, and we learn that quite a number of the members of the Seventh Regiment refused to attend the last drill which was held at that place, preferring to pay their fines rather than to risk their lives. The solid, simultaneous tramp of an hundred men is one of the severest tests to which any structure can be put, and when a building, originally weak, is called on to undergo, such a trial for hours at a time, it is not strange that those who are soldiers by profession should decline to allow themselves to be used for experimenting where mechanical appliances might be used much more satisfactorily and appropriately. Those of the Regiment who place a pecuniary value on their lives have been somewhat alarmed by a rumor which has been industriously circulated that the life-insurance companies have, some of them, threatened to cancel the policies which they may hold on the lives or those who obey the summons to attend drills which may hereafter be ordered in the building.

abstract: Caracas advices to the 17th inst. represent that the civil war continues with undiminished vigor, and business throughout the Republic is entirely prostrate. A great battle had been fought in Barcelona, where SOTILLO, the insurgent leader, had been beaten by Gen. RUIZ, with a loss of 200 killed. Gen. RAMOS, at the head of the Government forces in the West, had obliged Gen. FALCON to retreat upon Barinas. Senor ROSAS, who is now in New-York upon a special mission, has been elected to the Venezuelan Congress.

abstract: The incendiary Press throughout the country, but more especially that portion in this City, of which the Herald is the chief, in atteampting to fan the flame of political strife and civil discord, are not only publishing the most fiagrant falsehoods concerning the actual state of business, but are upsetting all the fixed and well-known laws that regulate...
lead_paragraph: The incendiary Press throughout the country, but more especially that portion in this City, of which the Herald is the chief, in atteampting to fan the flame of political strife and civil discord, are not only publishing the most fiagrant falsehoods concerning the actual state of business, but are upsetting all the fixed and well-known laws that regulate industry, capital, trade and commerce. The fire-eating and flame-spouting portion of the political community, North and South, is straining every nerve to hold these United States up to the world as a huge jug with but one handle, and that handle on the Southern side. It is proclaimed in awful tones that the Northern States are about to wilt down like a field of rank potato-tops struck by the frost, and that the streets of New-York are soon to be laid out in grassy lawns, where the children of ruined parents can gambol with the lambkins, because the South is arranging to establish a complete non-intercourse with the North by refusing to make their purchases here and opening a direct trade with Europe or some other part of the world!

abstract: Advices from Calcutta are to Nov. 22, and from Hong-Kong to Nov. 15. At Calcutta there was little or nothing doing in exports. The prices of leading articles of produce were too high to admit of speculation, and the reports from England, which were to Oct. 18, were considered as not encouraging any hope of improvement. Piece Goods had declined, and Yarns were lower. Metals steady. Freights to Liverpool 32s. 6d. @35s.

abstract: Letters from Constantinople of the 14th state that, after numerous sittings, resolutions have been adopted calling upon Europe to settle the Suez Canal question in its political hearing, by guaranteeing the integrity of the Turkish Empire. M. THOUVENEL, French Minister, and the four other Ambassadors, had agreed to that arrangement. The Grand Vizier and FUAD PASHA had drawn up notifications to that effect, which were sent to different Powers. Le Nord says the French Government will cease to press the Suez Canal question for the present.

abstract: This popular place of amusement was reopened last evening, after a short recess, with "an entire change of performances." The RAVELS, whose two-legged gambols have been the delight of the City for many weeks past, have succumbed to quadrupedal rivals from Coos's Royal Amphitheatre, of London.
lead_paragraph: This popular place of amusement was reopened last evening, after a short recess, with "an entire change of performances." The RAVELS, whose two-legged gambols have been the delight of the City for many weeks past, have succumbed to quadrupedal rivals from Coos's Royal Amphitheatre, of London. Every one has heard of ASTLEY's -- the scene of DUCROW's triumphs, and the great centre of the British horse-drama. The Company from this theatre, (now under the management of Mr. COOKE,) or a part of it, is for the time at NIBLO's beautiful establishment. Suitable alterations have been made in the stage, and there is an intention, we hear, to bring out the most celebrated spectacle pieces in a way which, both as regards the horse and his rider, has never before been attempted in this City.

abstract: One of Mayor WOOD'S organs--the Herald-- says, that "Mayor WOOD proposes to have the authorities at the different ports of emigration in Europe thoroughly posted relative to the  'Protective Bureau,' so that all necessary information may reach strangers even before arriving on our shores."
lead_paragraph: One of Mayor WOOD'S organs--the Herald-- says, that "Mayor WOOD proposes to have the authorities at the different ports of emigration in Europe thoroughly posted relative to the 'Protective Bureau,' so that all necessary information may reach strangers even before arriving on our shores." This would be only repeating, through the "Bureau," what the Commissioners of Emigration have already done, and are probably, as they ought to be, still doing. Any suggestions the Mayor may have to make in this line would more appropriately be addressed to that Commission, of which he is, ex officio, a member.

abstract: LONDON--Saturday morning. The Daily News' City Article says that the  Funds on Friday were firmer. There was a partial recovery on the Paris Bourse, and the disquieting rumors relative to the Congress met with less countenance. The market closed at 1/8@ higher than on Thursday. The demand for Money was pressing in the open market, and the rates were generally 1/3@ above the Bank minimum.
lead_paragraph: LONDON -- Saturday morning.

abstract: In another column, we give place to a communication touching the McLane Mexican Treaty. The writer says it is in reply to an article in the TIMES of the 5th inst. No such connection appears, however, in the communnication, which in the main, is but a repetition of the reasons that first appeared in the ...
lead_paragraph: In another column, we give place to a communication touching the McLane Mexican Treaty. The writer says it is in reply to an article in the TIMES of the 5th inst. No such connection appears, however, in the communnication, which in the main, is but a repetition of the reasons that first appeared in the Tribune adverse to said Treaty, and which the TIMES fully and satisfactorily answered at the moment. But the present communication is more enthusiastic, and contains more exaggerated and mistaken assertions than anything that has come to our notice. For instance, the assertion that "the route from Guaymas to Arizona will have to be made through an unsettled, dry and desert waste, and will not serve the interests of the Arizonians as well as a road leading to the mouth of the Gila River or the Pacific," is totally at variance with the facts as set forth by the people of Arizona themselves. The Arizonians state that freight from Guaymas to Tucsen, in the centre of Arizona, is four cents per pound, and that the trip is made with ease, from end to end, in sixteen days, over as level and good a natural road as can be found in the United States; while freight from the mouth of the Gila to Tucson, though no further than from Guaymas, is twelve to fifteen cents per pound, and that owners of mules or cattle can scarcely be induced to go over the route at any price, because it is through an "unsettled, dry and desert waste," and the best of fortune is required to get men and animals through alive within thirty days. "C.T.C." has got these routes transposed in his mind. The citizens of Arizona are praying for the ratification of the McLane treaty on the ground that the Guaymas right of way is alone worth $4,000,000 to that portion of United States territory known as Arizona. This is an important point which has never before been properly set forth.

abstract: FIRE AT POUGHKEEPSIE. -- On Friday afternoon last fire was discovered issuing from a large tenement house in Water-street. Poughkeepsie. The firemen experienced great difficulty in getting to the place, as the roads were obstructed by snow, and, when they did arrive, it was sometime before water was to be had. These delays permitted the flames to have their own way, and the building was entirely destroyed. It had been occupied by nine or ten families. Nearly all the furniture and contents were lost. The fire is supposed to have originated from a quantity of shavings in one of the rooms. The house was owned by the Poughkeepsie Iron Works Company, and was insured for $2,000. The entire loss will probably amount to between $5,000 and $6,000.
lead_paragraph: FIRE AT POUGHKEEPSIE. -- On Friday afternoon last fire was discovered issuing from a large tenement house in Water-street. Poughkeepsie. abstract: No one who has paid much attention to the drift of American politics for the last thirty or forty years, has failed to perceive that next to the difficult task of reconciling the jarring interests of free and slave labor, the knottiest problem which awaits solution is the best manner of preventing the large cities, ...
lead_paragraph: No one who has paid much attention to the drift of American politics for the last thirty or forty years, has failed to perceive that next to the difficult task of reconciling the jarring interests of free and slave labor, the knottiest problem which awaits solution is the best manner of preventing the large cities, whose growth and greatness ought to be the flower and fruit of our civilization, from becoming a nuisance and a curse. It is the large influx of ignorant foreigners, unused to the freedom, and incapable of the self-control which our system of government requires, which unquestionably has converted them into the hot-beds of crime and vice and disorder which we see them to be. But those who propose to make them moral and virtuous by excluding the people who have made them vicious and immoral, forget that our cities owe their greatness to the very same cause as their evils and abuses. The foreign immigration undoubtedly fills the jails and the almshouses, but it has also built the streets, and warehouses and quays and parks, and performed the heaviest portion of the vast amount of physical toil which have made Boston, New-York and Baltimore what they are, and upon it will fall the burden of the work which is still to be done.

abstract: James Malone was arrested in Tenth-avenue, yesterday, by Officer Henley, of the Sixteenth Precinct, on suspicion of having stolen two overcoats, valued at $40, from the hall of Mr. Alva Clark's residence, No. 70 East Thirty-first-street. Malone said that he had been hired by a lady to convey the garments to the corner of Sixteenth-street and Eighth-avenue, and that he was to receive a quarter for his pains. The story, though plausible, was not believed, and the messenger was held by Justice KELLY to answer a charge of larceny.

abstract: On the 31st ult. Mr. Moses Ross, of Uniontown, while attempting to cross the Monongahela River to visit his brother, who lived immediately opposite the village, broke through the ice just before he reached the shore. Two little girls who were on the bank witnessed his struggles, and saw him finally place his hat on the ice to mark the spot where he sank. As he did so be remarked, "I am ready to go now." The girls were so paralyzed with fright that they were unable to procure the drowning man assistance.

lead_paragraph: MR. PRESIDENT AND FELLOW-CITIZENS: I suppose the first thing in order to-night is to return our humble and hearty thanks to the State Assembly for the privilege of occupying this Hall. [Cheers and laughter.] I am not sure but that honorable body consulted the proprieties of the occasion a little more closely than they were aware of at the time, for as things go nowadays, it is by no means certain but that the proper place for men who would save the Union is outside the halls of legislation. [Laughter, and cries of "Good."] But whether inside or outside, I, for one, am proud to be here to-night for such a purpose and with such an audience. I am glad to find myself among men who, even in these days of wild excitement, can lift themselves out of the smoke and stir of partisanship into the purer atmosphere of constitutional obligation -- who can apply themselves, without regard to party interests, in a spirit of elevated American patriotism, to the consideration of their duties to their common country. [Applause, mingled with talking and confusion from the attempt to approach the speaker by those at the further end of the Hall.] I must respectfully request, said Mr. R., that while I am talking others at the opposite end of the Hall shall keep silence. I cannot talk here against a dozen there. [Cries of "Silence," "Shut the door," &c.] I am here not to retract any political opinions I have ever held, nor to repent of any political action I have ever taken. I have held no sentiment at any time which would prevent me from joining, heartily and sincerely, in the objects of this meeting, and if there is any party in the country which dare not, or which will not respond to the demands of the call under which this meeting is held, I am thankful that I have never shared its hesitation or had any part or lot in its fastidious scruples. [Applause.] It is true that under ordinary circumstances it ought to be superfluous for Americans to meet together and declare their attachment to the Union and their loyalty to the Constitution under which they live and move and have their being. Love of the Union and loyalty to the Constitution ought to be taken for granted on the part of every citizen -- just as love of father and mother, of sister or of wife, is assumed in domestic life; and there can be no occasion for assembling together to proclaim our loyalty unless on the one hand it be suspected, or unless on the other the object of our regard may be menaced by some unusual peril. [Applause.]

abstract: The pertinacity and perfect impunity with which CASSIUS M. CLAY continues to denounce Slavery and to advocate emancipation in any part of Kentucky he pleases, form a curious commentary upon the oft-repeated assertions of the more violent portion of the Southern public, that the gagging of all discussion is absolutely necessary to their safety.
lead_paragraph: The pertinacity and perfect impunity with which CASSIUS M. CLAY continues to denounce Slavery and to advocate emancipation in any part of Kentucky he pleases, form a curious commentary upon the oft-repeated assertions of the more violent portion of the Southern public, that the gagging of all discussion is absolutely necessary to their safety. We find that at this moment, and in a less degree for some years past, all unfavorable comment on Slavery is met by mob law; books or papers questioning even its economical expediency are rigidly excluded. Persons holding abolitionist opinions are summarily driven out from all parts of the country. A single unguarded utterance leads to banishment at least, without trial or opportunity of defence. When the South is asked to account for this highhanded violation of the Constitution and the laws, and this close imitation, in a Democratic Republic, of the forms and precautions of rank despotism, we are told that as long as Slavery lasts, the interests of the white population absolutely require them.

abstract: The arrival of the Europa at Halifax, and of the Jura at New-York, continue our European intelligence to the last day of the last year. Little of interest had transpired in addition to the advices of the Hungarian, save the sudden death of the greatest of British historical writers, Lord MACAULAY, an event which occurred in London on the 28th ult.
lead_paragraph: The arrival of the Europa at Halifax, and of the Jura at New-York, continue our European intelligence to the last day of the last year. Little of interest had transpired in addition to the advices of the Hungarian, save the sudden death of the greatest of British historical writers, Lord MACAULAY, an event which occurred in London on the 28th ult. The health of the historian had been failing for some months past, but there was no reason to anticipate a result so early and fatal. His disease was of the heart. As Lord MACAULAY was unmarried, the title has lapsed. Serious rumors in regard to the Congress were in circulation, and were not without depressing influences upon the money markets. Russia, it was reported, had protested against the pamphlet on "the Pope and the Congress," and had announced its unwillingness to enter the Congress until its doctrines, which it regards as subversive of legitimate authority, should be disavowed. A similar protest had already been received from the Pope. Possibly, to these and other like difficulties is due the delay in the opening of the deliberations, the meeting having been postponed from Jan. 19 to a day not yet indicated. No fresh encounters had signalized the Hispano-Moorish war. The Spanish, fleet, which had been lying at Algesiras, had sailed with sealed orders. An enlargement of the story touching American mediation in China, states that Mr. WARD, our Minister, had gone to Foo-Chow to meet Ho, the Governor of that Province, and confer with him on the course to be pursued in order to avert the attack of the Europeans. The statement is not generally credited.

lead_paragraph: The Ashland Association of the City of NewYork celebrated the thirteenth anniversary of their organization, at the Waverley Hotel, corner of Broadway and Fourth-street, last evening. There were about fifty members of the Association and invited guests present; but though the number was small, there was no lack of enjoyment. The most prominent at the table were Hon. Hiram Ketchum, Hon. Erastus Brooks, Gen. Talmage, De Peyster Ogden, Hon. Thomas H. Bond of New-Haven, and Hon. Charles C. Eagen of Brooklyn.

abstract: Some years ago, soon after the National Police Gazette passed into the hands of its present proprietors, our sanctum was invaded one morning by a smallsized portly, heavy-bearded, swarthy man, who, addressing us in very broken English, introduced himself as Herr Schonnberg, formerly optician to His ...
lead_paragraph: Some years ago, soon after the National Police Gazette passed into the hands of its present proprietors, our sanctum was invaded one morning by a smallsized portly, heavy-bearded, swarthy man, who, addressing us in very broken English, introduced himself as Herr Schonnberg, formerly optician to His Imperial Majesty, the Czar of all the Russias. Of course, a gentleman who had held such a high position must be treated with the consideration due to his grandeur, and the best seat in the office was tendered to him; and while we gazed upon him with something of awe, we must confess to a feeling of deep curiosity as to the purport of his visit to our humble apartments.

abstract: WASHINGTON, Saturday Evening, Jan. 16, 1860. everything goes wrong here, and the natural  milk and honey, forming the fluid extract in the veins of your correspondent, incurs every hour closer approximation to the fermenting and souring processes. This blessed extra day of rest, this bow of the covenant, which arose in the shape ...
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Saturday Evening, Jan. 16, 1860. everything goes wrong here, and the natural milk and honey, forming the fluid extract in the veins of your correspondent, incurs every hour closer approximation to the fermenting and souring processes. This blessed extra day of rest, this bow of the covenant, which arose in the shape of WINSLOW's resolution -- holding out hope that the deluge of debate would cease to wash the reportorial ark for an interval of sixty hours -- this one sole genuine act of Congressional philanthropy, has been estopped and defeated of all its legitimate benefit by a total loosening of the plugs up above, and the consequent on our city of illimitable rain-torrents, swelling the gutters to rivers, and forcing all our visitings and junketings to be done at a cost of one dollar perforty minutes -- which period, according to the immemorial usages of this city, has been established as the carriage-driver's hour.

abstract: We publish this morning, at considerable sacrifice of space, another of those Union speeches which our neighbor the Tribune considers so utterly superfluous. We think it quite likely the Tribune is right,--but in these days of multitudinous speeches, essays and newspaper disquisitions, it is not quite easy to decide, ...
lead_paragraph: We publish this morning, at considerable sacrifice of space, another of those Union speeches which our neighbor the Tribune considers so utterly superfluous. We think it quite likely the Tribune is right,--but in these days of multitudinous speeches, essays and newspaper disquisitions, it is not quite easy to decide, with any great certainty, what is and what is not superfluous. We suspect that even our critical neighbor would not like to be held too rigidly to the rule which he lays down upon this subject.

abstract: It is with feelings of deep regret that we announce the death of the eminent essayist and historian, Lord MACAULAY, which melancholy event took place at eight o'clock on Wednesday, evening, at the residence of the noble lord, Holly Lodge, CampdenHill, Kensington.
lead_paragraph: It is with feelings of deep regret that we announce the death of the eminent essayist and historian, Lord MACAULAY, which melancholy event took place at eight o'clock on Wednesday, evening, at the residence of the noble lord, Holly Lodge, CampdenHill, Kensington. For many years past Lord MACAULAY's health had not been good; out in 1852 he had a serious illness, consequent on disease of the heart, the circulation being extremely languid. The attack was subdued, and his lordship's health continued to be tolerably good up to a fortnight ago, when he had a second attack, from which, however, he rallied to such an extent that his medical men ceased to apprehend danger. He continued to improve, and, on Friday last, when seen by a friend, he looked much as usual. A relapse seems to have subsequently taken place, and his lordship expired suddenly, as we have said, on Wednesday evening. Lord MACAULAY never was married, and the title consequently dies with him.

abstract: William Johnson vs. Edward Kelly. -- This was an action for libel; the plaintiff alleging that the defendant had published a charge against plaintiff of having stolen certain keys of his (defendant's) premises, [???] appears that the parties to the action were formerly partners in business, in Cherry-street, and dissolved their connection in 1858; that some time after the dissolution the defendant missed the keys in question, and procured a summons from Justice Steers, commanding the plaintiff to appear and answer the charge of stealing them, and afterward exhibited that summons to different parties, stating that he had obtained it from Justice Steers against the plaintiff for the theft of the keys, &c. That summons was never heeded by the plaintiff. The matter was not prosecuted, and there ended.

abstract: THE NEW STORE ON THE SITE OF THE BROADWAY THEATRE.--The five-story marble building, lately completed on the site of the Broadway Theatre, for C.W.  J.T. MOORS  Co., is the largest structure for wholesale mercantile purposes in New-York. it covers over half an acre of ground, and has three fronts, on Broadway, Worth and Pearl streets, the ...
lead_paragraph: THE NEW STORE ON THE SITE OF THE BROADWAY THEATRE.--The five-story marble building, lately completed on the site of the Broadway Theatre, for C.W. J.T. MOORS Co., is the largest structure for wholesale mercantile purposes in New-York. it covers over half an acre of ground, and has three fronts, on Broadway, Worth and Pearl streets, the width on Broadway being 75 feet, and on Pearl and Worth streets 75 and 25 feet, respectively. The lot is in the form of the letter T, the depth from Broadway to the rear being 175 feet, and the width from Pearl to Worth streets 200 feet. The style of architecture is Norman. The main and attractive features of the front are the columns, which extend up two stories, and are finished, with boldly-carved capitals and semicircular arches. For its vast extent, elegant finish and uniform distribution of light, the first story -- which is the leading salesroom -- is unsurpassed. Standing in the rear, one has an unobstructed view of the entire room. In the rear is an iron sky-light, as also one over the main centre; the latter, with the front windows, affording abundant light for the upper stories. The basement affords as large a salesroom as the stories above. The sub-cellar and the upper story are used as storage and packing rooms. Both basement and sub-cellar extend under the street on Broadway, the former being lighted by an illuminated iron platform extending the width of the entire front, and the latter by foot-lights in the basement floor underneath the illuminated platform. To facilitate the changing of goods from different stories, numerous "dummies" have been constructed. The goods are received into the basement and sub-cellar from Worth and Pearl streets by an elevator and inclined iron planes or slides, and are taken to and from the lofts by steam elevators, each being driven by a six horse power steam engine. The building is heated by steam throughout, and is fire proof. The lot is estimated at $365,000, and the building cost $225,000. The firm of C.W. & J.T. MOORE & Co., it is an interesting fact to mention, is the oldest importing and jobbing dry goods house in New-York, it having been established over forty years -- an unprecedented length of time in this City of mercantile vicissitude for a firm to remain unchanged.

abstract: William Wallace vs. The Mayor,  c., of NewYork.--This was an action for damages for injuries received by plaintiff, through falling into a hole in the sidewalk at the corner of Eleventh avenue and Thirty-second-street, and was tried before Judge HILTON, of the Common Pleas. The plaintiff was the principal witness in his own behalf.
lead_paragraph: William Wallace vs. The Mayor, c., of NewYork.--This was an action for damages for injuries received by plaintiff, through falling into a hole in the sidewalk at the corner of Eleventh avenue and Thirty-second-street, and was tried before Judge HILTON, of the Common Pleas. The plaintiff was the principal witness in his own behalf. He stated that he was a machinist by trade, and formerly worked in a foundry in the upper part of the City. On the night of the accident he worked late; and on his way home, the night being dark, he fell into the hole in question. He had no previous knowledge it was there. It was a large hole, tome ten feet by seven, and five feet deep, and unprotected. It took in the sidewalk, and curb and gutter-stone. Witness was much in-injured. Two policemen got him out of the hole and helped him home. He was sick some time at home and at the hospital. His knee-pan was broken, also several of his ribs and his left shoulder; and his neck and head injured.

abstract: Yesterday a special and very important meeting of the Board of Police Commissioners was held at the Police Head-quarters. It is said that the meeting was called at the suggestion of Mayor Wood. The reason given for holding the meeting, was, that Mayor ...
lead_paragraph: Yesterday a special and very important meeting of the Board of Police Commissioners was held at the Police Head-quarters. It is said that the meeting was called at the suggestion of Mayor Wood. The reason given for holding the meeting, was, that Mayor WOOD called on General Superintendent PILLSBURY yesterday morning, and requested that ten policemen should be transferred from the City Hall Police, (Twenty-sixth Precinct,) and that ten others should be sent in their places -- the latter to be selected by the Mayor. Mr. PILLSBURY replied that Commissioner BAILEY was out of town, and it would be impossible to do anything until his return. Mayor WOOD then said, "Well, if Mr. BAILEY is the General Superintendent, why, I must look into it," and proceeded to the office of the President of the Board, Mr. STILLMAN. A call was immediately issued for a meeting in the afternoon. At about 2 o'clock there were present Mayor Wood, President Stillman, and Commissioners Bowen, Stranahan and Ulshoeffer -- Mayor Powell and Commissioner Bailey being out of town.

abstract: PLYMOUTH CHURCH AND THE A.B.C.F.M.-- ANOTHER ADJOURNMENT.--The adjourned annual meeting of Plymouth Church convened in the lectureroom of the church, last evening, about two hundred persons being present. Mr. H.C. BOWEN occupied the Chair, and the exercises commenced with prayer.
lead_paragraph: PLYMOUTH CHURCH AND THE A.B.C.F.M.-- ANOTHER ADJOURNMENT.--The adjourned annual meeting of Plymouth Church convened in the lectureroom of the church, last evening, about two hundred persons being present. Mr. H.C. BOWEN occupied the Chair, and the exercises commenced with prayer. The Clerk read the minutes, showing that the pending question was on the following amendment: "That the collection for Home Missions be paid to the Home Missionary Society, and that the collections for Foreign Missions be taken up; one of which shall be paid to the American Missionary Association, Foreign Department, and the other to the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions."

abstract: Congress preserves its attitude of masterly inactivity. In the Senate, various bills of secondary importance having been introduced, Mr. BROWN, of Mississippi, proceeded to correct a report of one of his recent speeches, in which he was made to use an expression derogatory to the dignity of Northern labor. The error corrected, and the business of choosing a Printer Coming up in order, Mr.
lead_paragraph: Congress preserves its attitude of masterly inactivity. In the Senate, various bills of secondary importance having been introduced, Mr. BROWN, of Mississippi, proceeded to correct a report of one of his recent speeches, in which he was made to use an expression derogatory to the dignity of Northern labor. The error corrected, and the business of choosing a Printer Coming up in order, Mr. BROWN gave his reasons at length for not supporting Gen. BOWMAN. They involved charges of gross partiality, corruption and total incapacity, urged with unsparing rigor by the Mississippi Senator. Vainly, however, as Mr. BOWMAN was subsequently chosen. The House of Representatives addicted itself to the discussion of the plurality rule. Mr. HUTCHINS, who represents the District of Ohio, which for so many years returned the veteran GIDDINGS, advocated that plan, demonstrating the urgent need of organization, the impossibility of obtaining it without such resort, and pointing out the relative rights and duties of majorities and minorities in such contingencies. By the practice of both leading parties in previous instances, he showed that the plurality rule had always been regarded as constitutional; and into the question of its constitutionality he entered at some length. Mr. HUTCHINS was repeatedly interrupted by Southern members controverting his points; but eventually concluded by moving that the House proceed to vote for Speaker viva voce, and that he who should receive the highest number of voices should be declared elected. Points of order were raised at once, and an animated discussion resulted, in which Mr. HICKMAN vehemently denounced Northern Democrats who did the bidding of the South. Mr. MCCLERAND, of Illinois, and Mr. PRYOR, of Virginia, retorted upon Mr. HICKMAN, showering bitter personalities upon his head, and the latter charging him with falsehood. The House finally adjourned without vote or action.

abstract: Benjamin Newhouse vs. James C. Willett. -- This is an action to recover of the defendant the value of certain property, consisting of household furniture alleged to have been wrongfully taken by him as Sheriff. The amount sued for is $218. The case is on trial before Judge HILTON, in the Common Pleas. The defence is, that the property belonged to one H.R. Prentiss, and that it was seized in pursuance of a judgment recovered against him by Charles S. Benson, in 1857; that subsequently to the seizure the warrant under which the property was taken was discharged, and that the Sheriff immediately returned to said Prentiss the possession of the property, the value of which is now sought to be recovered, since which time the defendant denies any knowledge of the same. Case still on.

abstract: THE COLORED PEOPLE AND MR. CHARLES O'CONOR.--An adjourned meeting of the colored people who feel aggrived at the address of Mr. CHARLES O'CONOR, at the Union meeting some weeks since, was held on Monday night at the church corner of...
lead_paragraph: THE COLORED PEOPLE AND MR. CHARLES O'CONOR.--An adjourned meeting of the colored people who feel aggrived at the address of Mr. CHARLES O'CONOR, at the Union meeting some weeks since, was held on Monday night at the church corner of Broadway and Eleventh-street. Rev. Mr. HODES, Pastor of the church, made a speech, expressing great indignation at the "infamous lies" uttered by Mr. O'CONOR against the African race, and was followed by Mr. WM. J. HODGES, who spoke much in the same vein. A long series of resolutions expressing the sense of those present was then adopted, and the meeting adjourned.

abstract: The death of Lord MACAULAY rounds with a certain sorrowful splendor the stately show, upon which we have a all of us so recently commented, of the last year's proud necrology. PRESCOTT, DE TOCQUEVILLE, HUMBOLDT, IRVING, DE QUINCEY, seemed trophies rich enough for one twelve-month's reaping in the field of letters. But another name was to be added to
lead_paragraph: The death of Lord MACAULAY rounds with a certain sorrowful splendor the stately show, upon which we have a all of us so recently commented, of the last year's proud necrology. PRESCOTT, DE TOCQUEVILLE, HUMBOLDT, IRVING, DE QUINCEY, seemed trophies rich enough for one twelve-month's reaping in the field of letters. But another name was to be added to the shining list, and the writer who had been confirmed by the admiring applause of two continents in his self-appointed task of illustrating the greatest political convulsion of English history, and of defending the memory of the men who settled the English State upon the solid foundations of Liberty and of law, sleeps now with the heroes of his epic task. The historian has become himself historical ere half his work was done. There is an especial pathos in the death of an illustrious man who passes -- like Lord MACAULAY -- from the scene of his honorable labors at the zenith of all his powers, his hand still firm upon the plow, which now must rest forever in the unfinished furrow he had traced. The lost books of LIVY are a perennial source of lamentation to all students of history; but while one nook of soil that once was Roman remains unsearched, of them there is always hope that they may one day revisit the glimpses of the scholar's lamp. But the unwritten chapters of a PRESCOTT and a MACAULAY belong to that saddest of all categories, the tale of the things "that might have been."
headline: {'main': 'The Death of Macaulay.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Death of Macaulay.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The reason why the deeper and more earnest feelings of hatred to Slavery which the execution of JOHN BROWN kindled in the Northern States of the American Union is not dying out but increasing in intensity is, that the citizens from the first distinguished between the generous motives of that heroic old man and the calamitous mistake he made when
lead_paragraph: The reason why the deeper and more earnest feelings of hatred to Slavery which the execution of JOHN BROWN kindled in the Northern States of the American Union is not dying out but increasing in intensity is, that the citizens from the first distinguished between the generous motives of that heroic old man and the calamitous mistake he made when he chose insurrection as a means of attaining his wishes for the liberation of the African. The apologists of American Slavery in this country, who represent the New Englanders as desiring those consequences which they see, but which BROWN did not see, must have followed his success, have the means of knowing that the assertion is entirely unfounded. The intelligence of that rising was received by the true friends of the negro throughout the North with profound regret. It was seen at once that the best thing that could happen for the cause of liberation was the prompt suppression of that movement. It is a senseless calumny which the advocates of Slavery, whether in Virginia or Middlesex, utter when they pretend that the North wishes to see fire and slaughter carried into the homes of the white people in the South. We are at a loss to conceive what cause is to be served by these assertions. Made at Richmond or at Washington, they are explained by the medium of excited party feeling with which every occurrence is viewed; but how an English journalist can sit down and write such libelous nonsense we cannot for the life of us imagine.

abstract: ANNUAL MEETING OF THE EXEMPT FIREMEN.-- A number of veterans in the Fire Department were in attendance last evening at the annual meeting of the Exempts. Among them were Chairman P.W. Engs, who was a fireman nearly half a century ago James Gulick, who acted as Chief Engineer in 1836; Zophar Mills, Now Foreman of the Exempt Engine Company, and Jonas B. Philips, ex-President of the ...
lead_paragraph: ANNUAL MEETING OF THE EXEMPT FIREMEN.-- A number of veterans in the Fire Department were in attendance last evening at the annual meeting of the Exempts. Among them were Chairman P.W. Engs, who was a fireman nearly half a century ago James Gulick, who acted as Chief Engineer in 1836; Zophar Mills, Now Foreman of the Exempt Engine Company, and Jonas B. Philips, ex-President of the Board of Trustees, and the Board of Councilmen The following officers of the Society were reelected viva voce and nem con: Philip W. Engs, President; Zophar Mills, 1st Vice-President; Adolphus Oskershausen, 2d Vice-President; George W Wheeler, Recording Secretary; Francis Hagadorn Financial Secretary; Joseph M. Price, Treasurer The Treasurer reported that the receipts of the Association, last year, were $366 50, and the expenses $266 48, making the total fund of the Association $1,285 31. The President announced that two other members had died during the year -- S.A. FREER and JOHN R. BARKER. No necessity had arisen for making funeral arrangements for them. Mr. JONAS B. PHILLIPS said that he knew of the decease of another old member, who had at one time left the City, and forfeited his membership -- Mr. JOHN ELY. Mr. ZOPHAR MILLS remembered that Mr. ELY was Foreman of Engine No. 37 in 1835. The Chairman appointed the following Executive Committee for the year: J.Y. Watkins, J.R. Titus, N. Finch, H. Feeks, David Logan, Alfred Ashfield, Mark Fowler, Jacob L. Smith. Messrs. A.W. TURNBULL and J. COGER, Jr., were appointed Representatives, and the crusty Sergeant at-Arms was continued in office. The Chairman presented a beautifully engrossed list of the Exempt Firemen in San Francisco, which was referred to the Executive Committee, and ordered to be framed and hung in the Exempt Firemen's room until further orders. The meeting then adjourned.

abstract: It is unfortunate that assumptions of exclusive goodness or superiority by any sect or class of men are always followed by contradictions of conduct, so ludicrous often, as to provoke laughter as well as cause regret.
lead_paragraph: It is unfortunate that assumptions of exclusive goodness or superiority by any sect or class of men are always followed by contradictions of conduct, so ludicrous often, as to provoke laughter as well as cause regret. Thus Spiritualists are practically the most unspiritual of men, and Perfectionists exhibit traits we should never think of associating with perfection.

abstract: It has been briefly mentioned by telegraph that the Palace of Fredericksborg, in Denmark, had been destroyed by fire. There are two royal resicences in Denmark which bear nearly the same name. The one, close to Copenhagen, is Fredericksberg, built in the 18th century by FREDERICK IV., in the Italian style, and afterwards enlarged by CHRISTIAN VI.,
lead_paragraph: It has been briefly mentioned by telegraph that the Palace of Fredericksborg, in Denmark, had been destroyed by fire. There are two royal resicences in Denmark which bear nearly the same name. The one, close to Copenhagen, is Fredericksberg, built in the 18th century by FREDERICK IV., in the Italian style, and afterwards enlarged by CHRISTIAN VI., and from the balcony of which there is a [???] view over the city, the Sound, and the coasts of Sweden. The other palace, that of Fredericksburg, which has been just destroyed, was five miles from Copenhagen, and was the Pantheon of the glories of Denmark. It was divided into three parts, separated from each other by fortified fosses. The principal edifice had four stories, with handsome towers and pinnacles. It had vast cellars extending under water, for the chateau stood on an island in a lake, but they were built so substantially that no dampness could penetrate. What more particularly attracted the attention of strangers visiting this place was the chapel situated in the left wing and embe[???]shed with sculptures, pictures, and the most exquisite carvings in wood. King CHRISTIAN the Fourth himself turned several of the arabesques and flowers in ivory found there. The altar was a masterpiece of workmanship, and had no less than 150 kilogrammes of silver employed on it. Over the gallery stool an escutcheon with the arms of Denmark, surrounded by those of the knights still living of the orders of the Elephant and of DanfDanish, an I German languages. It was a real nebrog. In an adjoining hall were the escutcheons of the deceased knights, and among them that of NAPOLEON I. The hall of the knights, one of the largest in Europe, being not less than 150 feet long, was all of marble; its handsome mantel-piece had been unfortunately injured by the Swedes during the wars. The ceiling was ornamented with innumerable figures, groups, and symbolical and emblematical representations of all kinds, intermingled with sentences in the Latin. Danish an I German languages. It was a real theatrum mundi, and twenty-six artists were employed on it for seven years. The portrait gallery was unique of its kind, and of great value for the history of Denmark. Each sovereign had a space reserved for him, and round him were grouped the members of his family, ministers, and all who had made themselves conspicuous under his reign. In the collection were portraits of the astronomer. TYCHO BRAHE, the poet HOLDERG, the historian SUHM, and numerous others. The portraits of STRUENSEE and the unfortunate Queen MATHILDA, were not suspended in the gallery, but visitors were shown the words "O, God, keep me innocent!" which the Queen had cut on one of the windows with a diamond ring. Fredericksburg was, as has been above mentioned, situated in the middle of a lake, a site expressly chosen by CHRISTIAN IV., who was an experienced sailor, and one of the most popular kings every known in that country. It was his favorite place of residence. The courtiers laughed at the idea of building a palace in such a spot, out the King paid no attention to their remarks, and by the aid of English architects and workmen, whom he procured for the purpose, succeeded in carrying out all his plans successfully, and completing a magnificent pile of building.

abstract: When an Ohio member, Mr. HUTCHINS, gave as a reason why Congress refrains from night sessions, that fights would be their inevitable attendants, he doubtless told a calamitous truth. If in broad daylight, with nerves untried by a protracted sitting, and tempers unvexed by
lead_paragraph: When an Ohio member, Mr. HUTCHINS, gave as a reason why Congress refrains from night sessions, that fights would be their inevitable attendants, he doubtless told a calamitous truth. If in broad daylight, with nerves untried by a protracted sitting, and tempers unvexed by justifiable provocation, members give way to the most undignified squabbles, and lavish names that elsewhere are challenges to mortal feud, it is easy to understand that among circumstances of so much greater aptitude for a quarrel, the upshot would quite likely be the discharge of pistols and the display of bowie-knives.

abstract: The Boston Journal of the 16th inst. says operations have been entirely suspended in the Duck Mill since the calamity, none of the late operatives being found willing to risk their lives in the building. The apprehension for its security is greatly increased by the falling of a portion of the coving on the Southern end of the mill. This accident happened about a month ago, and resulted in the demolition of the coving on one-half of the roof from the eaves to the ridge-pole. This was probably occasioned by the location of heavy duck looms in the fourth story, the operation of which produced greater jarring than exists in mills generally.

abstract: ST. LOUIS, Tuesday, Jan. l7. The Overland Mail, with San Francisco dates of  the 26th ult., passed Malloy's Station this morning. Business at San Francisco remained unchanged since the departure of the previous mail, and the large number of vessels due tended to increase the indisposition to operate. No change is expected until the new year opens.

Judge ROOSEVELT, who appeared for the United States, said that the consequences of this doctrine...
lead_paragraph: The United States vs McAnoy.--The question which arose in this case and others, whether the indictment was valid, being found at a time when there was no United States District-Attorney, came up this morning. Judge ROOSEVELT, who appeared for the United States, said that the consequences of this doctrine if such a one were to be established, were so serious, that he did not feel disposed to have the matter brought up without further time for preparation and consideration of the matter than had been allowed thus far.

abstract: The body of Mr. LAFAYETTE F. BRANCH, the only overseer who was killed by the accident, was recovered Sunday afternoon, just outside of the east wall of the mill, near the southeast corner. His body was not at all burnt, the fire not having reached him, but considerably bruised. He looked very natural, and was very easily recognized. In his pockets were found his watch -- which had stopped at thirteen minutes before five o'clock -- his knife, some keys, one or two memorandum books, and a few other articles, was doubtless standing near the wall, and fell with it. It is considered very remarkable that he was no more mutilated. His wife was deeply affected on hearing of the finding of the body.

abstract: The most striking characteristic of the late revolutions in the Italian Peninsula is the great care with which the animals of sober pace have always been placed in the van of the match. abstract: For the purpose of verifying as far as possible the truth of statements obtained directly from leading mercantile houses in this City, touching the present condition of southern business, diligent inquiries have been made of the agents, pursers and freight clerks of all the principal lines of southern steamer,
lead_paragraph: For the purpose of verifying as far as possible the truth of statements obtained directly from leading mercantile houses in this City, touching the present condition of southern business, diligent inquiries have been made of the agents, pursers and freight clerks of all the principal lines of southern steamer, and of other transportation companies engaged in the Southern carrying trade. If any difficulty exists in learning the precise condition of this department of trade by inquiries of the merchants themselves, on account of the extensive field to be canvassed, the quantity of merchandise actually going forward, as compared with the same period of the previous year, must settle the question.

abstract: Application of Margaret Niaroney. -- This was an application of a Celtic mother for the discharge of her son Patrick from military duties and the privilege of "dying for his country." She averred that he would not be 20 years of age until the 6th of March next, and that he was a good, honest boy -- the "stay of her life," if his Honor "plazed." He never drank nor did anything naughty.

abstract: The trial of Henry Karples, Jr., for embezzlement and larceny--the specific charge against him being the sending of twenty barrels of flour, on, a forged order, to a firm in New-Haven, from the mills of Hecker  Bros., in whose employment he was engaged as delivery clerk--was continued yesterday morning, and occupied the entire day, the Court
lead_paragraph: The trial of Henry Karples, Jr., for embezzlement and larceny--the specific charge against him being the sending of twenty barrels of flour, on, a forged order, to a firm in New-Haven, from the mills of Hecker Bros., in whose employment he was engaged as delivery clerk--was continued yesterday morning, and occupied the entire day, the Court having sat on the previous day till near midnight to finish the testimony. The most striking points against the young man were, his confession of guilt, as testified to by a single witness, and his flight into Canada. These, probably, would have been sufficient to convict him, without demur on the part of the jury, but for the astute manner in which his defence was managed by his counsel, Messrs. Oakey Hall and Edmon Blankman. As it was, they fairly won Judge RUSSELL to charge directly in the prisoner's favor. The Judge told the Jury that the offence committed by Karples -- supposing him to have committed one -- could not be one of embezzlement, inasmuch as the flour had been in the possession of Hecker Bros., and they could only, therefore, pass upon the indictment for larceny. After commenting upon the testimony, the Judge asked what evidence there was against him, except his confession? Confessions, he proceeded, were to be received with much caution. There was no evidence that the order was forged, except the alleged confession, and confessions were the worst species of evidence ever presented to a Court and jury, because there was in most cases, as in this, no person present but the witness and the party making the confession, and the latter's mouth being closed on his trial, he could offer no explanation, while the witness might have an object in perverting the substance of the so-called confession, or might do so inadvertently, through infirmity of memory. The Judge quoted Greenleaf on Evidence, relating to Confessions. It rested, he said, with the jury to receive the confession of the defendant or to reject it. Was the evidence conclusive as to the guilt of the prisoner? Might it not be consistent with the hypothesis of his innocence? His good character was to be steadily kept in view. The circumstance of his flight into Canada was not to be taken as evidence of his guilt, for fear operates differently on the minds of men, and an innocent person, suspected of crime, might fly because he was suspected.

abstract: This world is generally conceded to be a vale of tears,--and there are certainly a great many things in it calculated to make men unhappy. But if there is anything more thorougly melancholy than the mirth of the Tribune,--anything more heart-rending than its fun and humor,-- we have been lucky enough hitherto not to
lead_paragraph: This world is generally conceded to be a vale of tears,--and there are certainly a great many things in it calculated to make men unhappy. But if there is anything more thorougly melancholy than the mirth of the Tribune,--anything more heart-rending than its fun and humor,-- we have been lucky enough hitherto not to come into contact with it. As our cotemporary's pathos commonly reminds one of the ingenious gentleman in the play, who "thrust his hands into his pockets like a crocodile, and burst into tears," so his facetiousness imitates the pleasing antics of an acrobatic elephant dancing the tight-rope.

abstract: BALTIMORE, Wednesday, Jan. 11, 1860. Our State Legislature is now in session at An  napolis. Its proceedings are, and will be, looked to with deep interest. Measures of decided moment having especial reference to Baltimore, have already been introduced. Amongst these is a Metropolitan Police bill, to regulate the Police Department of our city. This, to us, is a matter of vital importance.

abstract: ALBANY, Tuesday, Jan. 17, 1859. Both Houses in session last evening, made some  progress in the transaction of the public business--at least, such is the popular expression. I confess, for myself, that I am never half so much convinced that legislators are serving the people "to the best of their knowledge and belief," as when they take a long recess, and go home to their constituents.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY, Tuesday, Jan. 17, 1859.

abstract: A movement having for its object the reform of inebriates, and intended to be conducted upon the principles of the old Washingtonian Reform, has been commenced by several active friends of temperance, and a meeting to inaugurate the reformation was held last evening at No. 154 Chatham-street.
lead_paragraph: A movement having for its object the reform of inebriates, and intended to be conducted upon the principles of the old Washingtonian Reform, has been commenced by several active friends of temperance, and a meeting to inaugurate the reformation was held last evening at No. 154 Chatham-street. At this place a large hall has been leased for one year, and fitted up for the purpose of holding temperance meetings. Connected with the hall are also sleeping rooms, where the poor drunkard can be furnished with temporary shelter and repose, and have food supplied to him when it is required. In a word, it is to serve as a temporary home for this unfortunate class of persons until they can be cared for by their Washingtonian friends.

The whole country still wears its emerald

abstract: In another part of this morning's TIMES we publish sundry statements, based upon inquiry in the proper quarters, concerning the condition of commercial intercourse at the present time between this City and the Southern States.
lead_paragraph: In another part of this morning's TIMES we publish sundry statements, based upon inquiry in the proper quarters, concerning the condition of commercial intercourse at the present time between this City and the Southern States. They leave no room to doubt that the extravagant and alarming assertions of the Herald and kindred journals, upon this subject, have been pure and willful fabrications. Their object has been to alarm the commercial classes in both sections, and to produce everywhere a political and financial panic. These sheets live by excitement. In times of calm and prosperity they are utterly stupid and insignificant -- without interest or influence: -- and it is only by lashing the public mind into a fever of wrath or of apprehension, that they become important or notorious.

abstract: In a letter to the London Times, Mr. W. SAVAGE LANDOR Says: "The French can never long be free; the Italians of the north can never long be slaves. Ardent in their aspirations, they are calm and steady in their march towards the recovery of their rights. The air of Venetia and of Etruria is of the same temperature; the pulses of the heart are the same in both. Italy is the only country that can present to Europe a balance of power. The fi[???]ger of France has lowered the scale on her side. It is only by the Union of all Italian States and their dependencies that the fairest portion of the globe can long exist in peace or recover its lost prosperity. England will no longer be apprehensive of injury by the canal (if canal be practicable) across the Isthmus of Suez. She will enjoy the full benefit of trade with Italian Companies now impoverished, but not ruined utterly. There are cities in Italy and Dalmatia destined to be as opulent and enterprising as Venice and Genoa were in former times. Russia is interested -- I will not say equally -- in the resurrection of Italy under one supreme ruler. She has obtained a privilege on the Mediterranean; she will obtain a similar or greater one on the Adriatic. Austria is crumbling to Pieces, and can neither help or hurt us. She refused the former in the Crimea, the latter she has exhibited in Italy with constancy and success. This is over with her now. Russia may, do us either service or injury, as she lists; but she well knows which is best for her. She abates her desire to snatch the turban off the Sink Man's head; she sees him wasting away irremediably, and she will attend his funeral decently and demurely. Meanwhile a fable may be acceptable to your readers, who will not find it in 'AEsop' or 'La Fontaine.' A traveler had been receiving a legacy left him by as old relative, and was returning homeward with a part of it, when he was accosted in a threatening attitude by a stalwart young man who stood before him. Almost at the same instant ran up another from behind, and offered him assistance. 'Don't be afraid,' cried he, and tripped up the traveler's heels. It appeared by their winks and grimaces that they were confederates. They threw him face downward and rifled his pockets. They told him then very civily that he might get up and stand upon his knees -- no higher; that they would send a priest to comfort him and hear him confess. Presently a fat priest came up, and devoutly said, 'Ave, mi fili!' holding out his band for some money in repayment of this funzione. Being told that he had none left, the priest d -- d him heartily, adding, 'The devil a mass will I say for your wicked soul, nor shall anybody else, under pain of excommunication.' The traveler took up his flaccid purse, and found only a false louis at the bottom."

abstract: PARIS, Thursday, Dec. 29, 1859. A great excitement reigns in our political circles.  Many rumors are afloat, and the result has been a decided baisse at the Bourse. I must relate to you what these rumors are, praying you to hear in mind that they are but on dita, and must be taken with due reserve.
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Thursday, Dec. 29, 1859.

abstract: We have already, several times, expressed the belief, from the facts within our knowledge, that the statements with which the Herald and other incendiary journals, both North and South, are filled, that the Southern people were rapidly withdrawing their
lead_paragraph: We have already, several times, expressed the belief, from the facts within our knowledge, that the statements with which the Herald and other incendiary journals, both North and South, are filled, that the Southern people were rapidly withdrawing their trade from New-York and other Northern cities, were grossly exaggerated, and in the main, the most flagrant falsehoods, designed only to increase the prevailing political excitement.

abstract: The attempt of certain fanatics in the Southern States to coerce the public sentiment and political action of the North, by menaces of commercial non-intercourse, is producing its natural effect.
lead_paragraph: The attempt of certain fanatics in the Southern States to coerce the public sentiment and political action of the North, by menaces of commercial non-intercourse, is producing its natural effect. abstract: John Holsing, a laborer, employed by Mr. Theodore Weiss, a New-Jersey farmer, availed himself of the opportunity afforded by the temporary absence of the latter from home, to steal about $100 worth of clothing and other property. Holsing reached this City with the booty on Monday evening, but his ...
lead_paragraph: John Holsing, a laborer, employed by Mr. Theodore Weiss, a New-Jersey farmer, availed himself of the opportunity afforded by the temporary absence of the latter from home, to steal about $100 worth of clothing and other property. Holsing reached this City with the booty on Monday evening, but his strange actions on leaving the Weehawken ferry-boat decided officer Bernholy, of the Twenty-second Precinct, to take him into custody on suspicion of being a thief. It was subsequently ascertained from Mr. WEISS that the officer's surmises were well-founded, and Justice KELLY held the prisoner to answer.

abstract: -Notice has been  given of the introduction of a bill into the Legislature, making the offices of Commissioners of Deeds and Notaries Public elective. As there are several hundred of these gentlemen in this City, their appointment by universal suffrage would lend additional animation to our election days,--and anybody who is fond ...
lead_paragraph: -Notice has been given of the introduction of a bill into the Legislature, making the offices of Commissioners of Deeds and Notaries Public elective. As there are several hundred of these gentlemen in this City, their appointment by universal suffrage would lend additional animation to our election days,--and anybody who is fond of uproar, confusion, corruption, irresponsibility and worthless officials, will, of course, be delighted to have the bill pass. Our main objection to it is, that it does not go far enough. The principle on which it is based -- that every one who performs any service for the public ought to be elected by the popular vote -- is capable of indefinite expansion. Why not deliver the Police, the Central Park laborers, and the City scavengers from their present degrading position, and let them derive their powers and privileges from the ballot-box alone? It is disgraceful that three or four thousand public functionaries should thus be left to owe their appointment to arbitrary commissioners and superintendents. Moreover, hotel keepers would do well not to maintain their present insolent attitude much longer. The proper way to select waiters is clearly to have them elected by the guests and boarders. Thus and thus only can they be protected from the abuses of power, and hotel-keeping be carried on with efficiency. The same thing may be said of bank clerks. The stockholders should choose them by ballot. The interference of the president and directors in their selection is utterly opposed to the spirit of the age as well as of our manners and government. In fact, the people at large are notoriously so diligent in ascertaining the fitness of candidates for the public service, in voting for the best that present themselves, and after their election in seeing that they do their duty, that it is clear the more officers we ballot for the happier and better governed we shall be.

lead_paragraph: Application of Robert T. Haws.--This was the return of an order to show cause, directed to the parties interested, why certain judgments heretofore obtained against the City should not be vacated. The motion in the case of the Sharp judgment, "which was recently set aside by Justice. Ingraham, having terminated so succeesfully in favor of the City the Comptroller is now encouraged to proceed in like manner against the remainder of those judgments which he believes to have been obtained improperly, or by fraudulent appliances. The Comptroller proceeds under the 5th section of the Act of 1859, authorizing him to take such a course in all cases wherein he is persuaded judgments were obtained by collusion or fraud. Of the judgments so sought to be vacated, the following were obtained in the Court of Common Pleas:

abstract: Rev. Dr. CAHILL, on a visit from Ireland to this country, is writing letters to the Press at home descriptive of our City and its people. The Doctor sees everything in its most brilliant and attractive aspect. Our streets, omnibuses and hotels all command his unqualified approbation. He has never seen, he says, either in Great Britain or on the Continent, such a magnificent city as New-York. Labor is high -- "laborers and hodmen getting from $2 to $2 50 a day," -- and provisions low. It is the worst country in the world for a drunkard, who is shunned like the plague. It is very pleasant to find our country and institutions thus warmly praised, -- but we fear the Doctor may be preparing some of his friends at home, who intend to emigrate, for a bitter disappointment.
lead_paragraph: Rev. Dr. CAHILL, on a visit from Ireland to this country, is writing letters to the Press at home descriptive of our City and its people. abstract: A serious collision--the result, apparently, of carelessness--occurred about 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon on the Hudson River Railroad, some two miles north of Tarrytown. The Albany Express train was run into by the Sing Sing way-train, the rear car completely demolished, and the one next to it badly broken.
lead_paragraph: A serious collision--the result, apparently, of carelessness--occurred about 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon on the Hudson River Railroad, some two miles north of Tarrytown. The Albany Express train was run into by the Sing Sing way-train, the rear car completely demolished, and the one next to it badly broken. It appears from a statement made by a passenger, who was in the last car but one at the time of the accident, that the Albany Express train was standing still when the collision occurred, having stopped for the purpose of making repairs to the engine. It is also worthy of note that this was the third stoppage made for the same purpose after the train left Albany.

abstract: Dates from Hayti to Dec. 24, are at hand. On the 22d ult., the first anniversary of the restoration of the Republic was celebrated, by a salute at sunrise' and by religious ceremonies at the Cathedral at 8 o'clock, which were attended by the different officials' the students of the Government Schools, the Professors, and the Marine and Post Officers. The exercises included a grand Te Deum, and at their conclusion the President made a tour of the city, being received on his return to the palace, by the public officials and a number of citizens. The city was Illuminated in the evening, and displays of fireworks were made.
lead_paragraph: Dates from Hayti to Dec. 24, are at hand. The exercises included a grand Te Deum, and at their conclusion the President made a tour of the city, being received on his return to the palace, by the public officials and a number of citizens. The city was Illuminated in the evening, and displays of fireworks were made.

abstract: WASHINGTON, Monday, Jan. 16, 1860. The House came together this morning with  greater appearance of good humor than has been heretofore witnessed. It is clear that the adjournment over Saturday had a good effect, and it is to be hoped that this experiment may be repeated from week to week--should the contest continue so long-- with the improvement of adjoursments from Thursday night to Monday morning.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Monday, Jan. 16, 1860.

abstract: The jury, in the case of Henry Karples, "remained out," as it is teramed, all night by which it is meant that they snatched sleep on benches, tables, and on the floor, during Tuesday night and Wednesday until daybreak. At the opening of Court, Yesterday morning, they appeared, and asked the Judge if they could discard the alleged confession of Karples.
lead_paragraph: The jury, in the case of Henry Karples, "remained out," as it is teramed, all night by which it is meant that they snatched sleep on benches, tables, and on the floor, during Tuesday night and Wednesday until daybreak. At the opening of Court, Yesterday morning, they appeared, and asked the Judge if they could discard the alleged confession of Karples. The Judge (RUSSEL) said they could. Whereupon they retired for five minutes, reappearing with a verdict of "Not Guilty." The Court-room was crowded with friends of the prisoner, but there was do demonstration of approval -- the general opinion prevailing that his acquittal was certain and just. He was not, however, discharged, other indictments being held against him on the files of the Court.

abstract: On the 13th inst., the negro mart of Messrs. FOREST, JOKES & Co., in Memphis, Tennessee, fell, burying beneath its ruins "six valuable negro men," as the Bulletin expresses it. Soon after this casualty the ruins caught fire. Fortunately it was soon extinguished and the negroes were exhumed, when it was found that two of them, valued at $1,800 each, were killed. The building was of brick, three stories in height, and cost, when first erected, $4,000. Had not the fire been put out, bills of sale of negroes, amounting in the aggregate to $400,000, would have been destroyed.
lead_paragraph: On the 13th inst., the negro mart of Messrs. FOREST, JOKES & Co., in Memphis, Tennessee, fell, burying beneath its ruins "six valuable negro men," as the Bulletin expresses it.
