abstract: The rules promulgated by Mayor WOOD with regard to the business transactions of his office are strictly adhered to, except so far as regards the transaction of business in the departments recently occupied by Judge WELSH'S Court, which the Common Council has not yet authorized him to take possession of.
lead_paragraph: The rules promulgated by Mayor WOOD with regard to the business transactions of his office are strictly adhered to, except so far as regards the transaction of business in the departments recently occupied by Judge WELSH'S Court, which the Common Council has not yet authorized him to take possession of. The office is closed for the transaction of business regularly at 3 P.M., and two policemen stationed outside inform all who call after that hour that such is the fact. The Mayor is waited upon by visitors, whose name is legion, every day. Poor people, who are in difficulty, apply at the office for aid numerously. Whatever their complaint they seem to think Mayor WOOD can right them and redress their wrongs. Daily, women with young babes present themselves there, tell the story of their grievances, and ask that faithless husbands may be compelled to support them, or gay Lotharios forced to give them back their "peace of mind." The Mayor's Private Secretary, Mr. THOMPSON, or his chief clerk, Mr. AULD, converse with these, tell them that the Mayor is powerless to serve them, and inform them where and by what means they will be most likely to obtain assistance. The same gentlemen attend to all other applications for aid or information which are presented. The Mayor never receives any of them. The old complaints of ticket-swindling are frequently preferred. They present no novel features commonly. It is the old story in each case. A stranger in the City -- bound to California -- obliging friend -- regular ticket office -- a swindle -- applies at the Mayor's office -- no law against ticket swindling -- an officer sent to the bogus ticket-agent -- ticket-agent refunds part of the money, so as to "keep on the right side of the authorities" -- stranger departs disgusted. These bogus ticket-agents, now-a-days, are too cunning to sell bogus tickets to their dupes. They procure bona fide tickets, and sell them at exorbitant prices to the green ones. By so doing, in the eye of the law, they commit no crime. There should be some special legislation on this subject without delay. The Mayor claims that the new Emigrant and Strangers' Protective Bureau, which he has asked the Common Council to create, will be a fountain-head of information to strangers in the City, who, for the want of it, are now defrauded in this and other ways daily.

abstract: CONCERTS. -- Mr. C. JEROME HOPKINS, a rising young American artist, who has associated himself with native music, gave his first concert on Monday evening at Chickering's Rooms. The attendance was good, and particularly flattering to Mr. HOPKINS, inasmuch as the programme consisted mainly of that gentleman's compositions. We are not certain that it is judicious for any composer to submit out of twelve pieces, eight productions of his own pen. The first principle of a concert should be variety. Mr. HOPKINS' efforts, however, were received with great favor, and we anticipate from his versatility much permanent excellence. Dr. GUILMETTE and Miss ANDEM received encores in their songs. Mr. HOPKINS played three of BACH's fugues, and was encored in the concerto by MENDELSSOHN, playing PAUER's "Cascade" as a substitute. Another concert will be given on Monday evening next at the same place.

abstract: The Common Council have just inaugurated their year of office by appointing a committee whose duty it will be to convict Mr. JAMES GORDON BENNETT of slander, and in doing so, to prove to the public that the members of both Boards are persons of principle, well educated, and of frank and loyal dispositions,--in other words, that they are not what the Herald alleges them to be, "unprincipled, illiterate, and scheming."

abstract: SARAH ANN NICHOLS, a woman 84 years of age, slipped and fell from the back stoop of the house No. 105 Lewis-street, on Sunday, sustaining such severe internal injuries that her death resulted on Monday afternoon. Coroner SCHIRMER held an inquest....... On the 6th inst. MART RYAN, a woman 65 years of age, fell down a flight of stairs at No. 202 East Seventeenth-street. The accident was caused by some water having frozen on the stairs. Deceased died in consequence on Sunday. An inquest was held by Coroner JACKMAN..... On Monday last ANN MURPHY, an infant 15 months old, whose home was in Twenty-first-street, was fatally scalded by the upsetting of a boiler of hot water which was on a grate near which the child was sitting. Death ensued in a few moments. An inquest will be held to-day.

abstract: It has grown to be almost a maxim with whimsical travelers, careful of their persons, to take the leading cars in an European railway train, and the last cars in an American. This custom originated, of course in the impression which was at one time borne out perhaps ...
lead_paragraph: It has grown to be almost a maxim with whimsical travelers, careful of their persons, to take the leading cars in an European railway train, and the last cars in an American. This custom originated, of course in the impression which was at one time borne out perhaps by the statistics, that railway accidents in Europe commonly occurred from the too rapid multiplication of successive trains upon one line of the road, while in America they were generally the result of the mis-called and murderous "economy" of single tracks, necessarily liable to be traversed in opposite directions, by antagonistic engines, at all hours of the day. Two fearful and, let us say, shameful catastrophes, which happened yesterday upon two of our roads which have lately enjoyed a special reputation for care and fidelity of management must go far to shake the credit of this traveler's rule.

abstract: The City Railroad Companies, under the law thereunto compelling, are renewing their car-licenses at the Mayor's Office. They pay $50 for each car drawn by two horses, and $25 for each one-horse vehicle. This is the rule which the exception in the case of the Ninth-avenue Railroad Company proves. Exceptio probot regulam. This Company, by a clause in its charter, is permitted to renew the licenses for each of its cars, of both classes, on the payment of $20. It has paid this sum for thirty cars this year. The Eighth-avenue Railroad Company has renewed the licenses of forty two-horse and eighteen one-horse cars; the Sixth-avenue Railroad Company has paid the fee for forty-two-horse and twenty-one-horse cars; the Fourth-avenue Railroad Company has not yet renewed its licenses and the Second and Third-avenue Railroad Companies, which refused to take out licenses, last year, on the ground that their charters protected them from the imposition of the tax, are litigating the question.

abstract: The proceedings of Congress yesterday lost some of their fatiguing monotony. After some preliminary business, in the course of which Mr. GWIN introduced his bill providing for a trans-continental telegraph, and Mr. BROWN his resolutions as to Congressional protection of Slavery in the Territories, a question as to the power of the Senate to ...
lead_paragraph: The proceedings of Congress yesterday lost some of their fatiguing monotony. After some preliminary business, in the course of which Mr. GWIN introduced his bill providing for a trans-continental telegraph, and Mr. BROWN his resolutions as to Congressional protection of Slavery in the Territories, a question as to the power of the Senate to legislate prior to the organization of the House was raised and discussed. Mr. HALE desired to put a naval appropriation bill upon its passage. Mr. HUNTER objected on the ground that after the action of the House last Summer it would be discourteous to originate appropriation bills in the Senate; while others took the ground that there can be no legislation until the House shall have organized. Mr. CRITTENDEN asserted that the House is as much a legislative body now as it will be after organization. This view was rebutted by Mr. TRUMBULL, of Illinois, who asked if the House, as now constituted, were to pass a bill to-morrow, and send it to the Senate, whether it could be accepted as valid legislation? Mr. BAYARD offered a resolution that no bills be put upon their passage prior to the choice of a Speaker in the House, and so the controversy ended. The attention of the House was claimed by Mr. CLOPTON, of Alabama, and after Mr. WASHBURNE, of Maine, had vainly attempted to stop further debate, Mr. CLOPTON had his hearing. His speech, while it differed from that of Mr. CURRY, of the same State, in its extreme violence of tone, offered no points distinguishing it from the mass of Southern oratory this Winter. Mr. CARTER, of New-York, then defined his position, declaring himself independent of the Republicans, and yet avowing opinions quite in advance of the Philadelphia platform. His interrogatories addressed to Southern Americans elicited from four of them declarations in favor of Congressional legislation protecting Slavery in the Territories, and. from ETHERIDGE, of Tennessee, an opinion adverse to such legislation. The sentiments of the Northwestern Democracy were expressed by Mr. COX, of Ohio, Mr. HOLMAN, of Indiana, and Mr. MCCLERNARD, of Illinois, as hostile to any intervention of Congress in Territorial questions. A heated, personal conversation between Mr. MONTGOMERY, of Pennsylvania, and two or three of his Republican colleagues, closed the day's proceedings.

abstract: WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Jan. 18. Mr. McREA, of Mississippi,(Dem.,) was entitled  to the floor, but yielded it to Mr. CLOPTON, who was about to address the House, When Mr. WASHBURNE, of Maine,(Rep.,) interrupted him by calling for a vote on Mr. HUTCHINS' resolution for the adoption of the plurality rule. He insisted that they were obliged by law to proceed to vote for Speaker without debate and delay.

abstract: ALBANY, Wednesday, Jan. 18. The Select Committee on pro rata freight peti  tions held a meeting this afternoon. abstract: ADDRESS OF GOV. BANKS TO THE EXECUTIVE COUNCH. -- GOV. BANKS, of Massachusetts, on Tuesday gave his Council come of his views on State affairs, in the form of an address. After defining what he thinks to be the duty of the Council, he says that the first matter which they will need to attend to is the approval of bonds in favor of the Troy and Greenfield Railroad, in aid of the Hoosac Tunnel. Three instalments of this scrip, amounting to $198,000, have already been issued. In the next place they are to look after the final disposal of the interests of Massachusetts in the public lands of Maine. He proposes that American and foreign paupers in the State institutions shall be separated, and objects to rending children to the State Reform School upon complaints by Justices of the Peace for mere stubbornness or idleness.

abstract: The authorities of Baltimore are now edifying their fellow-citizens and the world with an inquiry into the circumstances which attended the late election in that city.
lead_paragraph: The authorities of Baltimore are now edifying their fellow-citizens and the world with an inquiry into the circumstances which attended the late election in that city. The results already attained afford a curious commentary upon the indignation to which certain of the Baltimore partisan journals gave way on finding that the independent Press of the country had ventured to question the propriety, decorum and civilization displayed by the Plug-Uglies, Awl Clubs and other agreeable associations of Baltimorean sovereigns, upon that occasion. The editor of the Baltimore Exchange, as our readers will remember, was forced to defend himself from the assaults of some of these offended depositories of political power, by a recourse to the "last argument of Kings," simply and solely because he had shown manliness in admitting, and good citizenship in denouncing, the outrages perpetrated at the polls upon unarmed voters. The NEW-YORK TIMES was in a like spirit set upon by some of its contemporaries for calling attention to the shame and peril of such occurrences in a great American city. It now appears that the system of intimidation by personal violence has become thoroughly organized in the Monumental City; and that the excesses of Baltimore elections are not to be treated as mere sporadic cases of popular ebullition. The Jacobin Clubs of France were not more thoroughly drilled in the art and mystery of harmonizing public opinion than are the so-called "Americans," of Baltimore. Several days before the late election, these indefatigable men were in the field. They scoured the city, as eagerly bent upon finding "foreigners" as any Dublin oysterman upon dredging for "natives." Irishmen, Germans; all who fell in their way, were harpooned, carried off to subterranean cells, locked up, compelled from time to time to drink great quantities of whisky -- reduced, in short, to a state of complete submission. When the day of election came, these captives were paraded openly in the streets, in custody of a guard with cocked revolvers, marched from poll to poll, forced to vote five or six times over, returned to their dungeons, beaten again, and finally released when the great issue had been decided, and the "unbought voice of freemen" had selected the officers by whom the laws of an American community were to be administered and its rights defended. All this took place in a wealthy city, in open day, under the eyes of an organized City Government, and in defiance of every functionary known to the law.
headline: {'main': 'The Beauties of Baltimore Voting.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Beauties of Baltimore Voting.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Mr. ARCLARIUS introduces a bill in the Assembly, which amends the New-York Charter, so as to give increased power and petronage to the Mayor.
lead_paragraph: Mr. ARCLARIUS introduces a bill in the Assembly, which amends the New-York Charter, so as to give increased power and petronage to the Mayor. It allows the Mayor, during absence or sickness, to appoint an Alderman to act as Mayor. In the absence of such appointment, or in case of any disability of the Mayor, the President of the Board of Aldermen is to fill the office. Gives the Mayor power to appoint such clerks as he deems necessary, and to fix their salaries. Makes the Mayor elective for three years, the Corporation Counsel for four years, and the Comptroller, on a separate ballot, for five years. The Street Commissioner, City Inspector and Chamberlain to be appointed and removed by the Mayor alone. The other heads of departments to be appointed and removed by the Mayor and Comptroller jointly. The heads of departments to have power of appointment and removal of all chiefs of bureaus, clerks and subordinates in their several departments. The bill circumscribes and defines the powers of the Almshouse and Croton Departments; cuts off all fees and perquisites of all officers, except in the case of the City Inspector, and substitutes a salary, to be fixed by the Common Council; and fixes the salaries of members of the Common Council at $1,000.

The plan is to get together, as into a great reservoir, from whatever sources it may best be obtained, a ...
lead_paragraph: --A move has recently been made in the matter of Agricultural education at Yale College, which deserves the attention of all persons interested in that subject, and especially of the agricultural community. The plan is to get together, as into a great reservoir, from whatever sources it may best be obtained, a vast fund of agricultural knowledge and experience for subsequent distribution and diffusion The programme according to which the idea is to be carried out presents the names of twenty-five gentlemen well known in science and agriculture who propose to occupy the whole month of February with lectures and discussions on agricultural subjects, for the benefit of all who may choose to attend.

abstract: THE LIMITATION OF THE POWER OF SUPERINTENDENT PILSBURY.--The difficulty between Mayor WOOD and the Superintendent of Police, which has already been referred to, originated in the following manner: A few days since Mayor WOOD sent Capt. HARIT to Superintendent PILSBURY, with a message stating that he desired twelve extra men, whom he specified, to be detailed for extra duty at the City Hall Precinct.
lead_paragraph: THE LIMITATION OF THE POWER OF SUPERINTENDENT PILSBURY.--The difficulty between Mayor WOOD and the Superintendent of Police, which has already been referred to, originated in the following manner: A few days since Mayor WOOD sent Capt. HARIT to Superintendent PILSBURY, with a message stating that he desired twelve extra men, whom he specified, to be detailed for extra duty at the City Hall Precinct. Superintendent PILSBURY replied that he would inquire into the matter, and if it appeared that the men were of the right character he would make the changes with pleasure. At the special meeting on Monday Mayor WOOD insisted that he had the exclusive right of determining who should serve him, and that he had seie[???] men in whom he had confidence. Superintendent PILSBURY claimed that he had not abused the authority vested in him, and that if any could be shown he would return it to the Board. The members present declared their confidence in him, but immediately passed the resolution which limits his powers. Superintendent PILSBURY feels aggrieved, but has declared no intention of resigning, although he still asserts that he will not submit to be made an automaton.

abstract: ALLEGED FORGERIES BY A MEMBER OF THE MASSACHUSETTS LEGISLATURE. -- For a day or two past rumors have been current of forgeries committed by a member of the Massachusetts Senate, without, however, the mention of any names. The Courier of this morning alludes to the subject, and speaks of the guilty party as "a member of the Legislature." The amount mentioned is $3,500, and names and circumstances are given in the street, which we do not propose to mention at present, as the matter, it is said, has been adjusted, and the spurious paper withdrawn from circulation. -- Boston Traveller, 17th.

abstract: BOARD OF SUPERVISORS.--At a meeting of this Board last evening the Land Committee reported against the application to the Leglelature for an increase of the salary of the Judge of the City Court and voted to remonstrate against the same.
lead_paragraph: BOARD OF SUPERVISORS.--At a meeting of this Board last evening the Land Committee reported against the application to the Leglelature for an increase of the salary of the Judge of the City Court and voted to remonstrate against the same. The Committee presented with their report a batch of testimony relative to the affairs of the Court, which were received, notwithstanding a protest of the City Judge that the testimony was taken in his absence and without affording him an opportunity to rebut the evidence. The protest was laid on the table. A Special Committee reported in favor of applying to the Legislature for the power to raise money to erect a county building to accommodate county and public officers. The report was laid on the table, and the Board adjourned to this afternoon, when the subject will be taken up for consideration.

abstract: We observe that notice has already been given in the Legislature of sundry bills for City Railroads. We trust the projectors of these schemes will bring them forward at once, and submit them to full and fair discussion, and to such amendments and conditions as may be considered necessary.
lead_paragraph: We observe that notice has already been given in the Legislature of sundry bills for City Railroads. We trust the projectors of these schemes will bring them forward at once, and submit them to full and fair discussion, and to such amendments and conditions as may be considered necessary. The chief difficulty with these schemes hitherto has been, that they have been concealed from public knowledge until late in the session, -- engineered stealthily through Committees, and then sprung upon the Legislature at the last moment, and in such a shape as to convince everybody that they were to be passed, if at all, not upon their merits, but by corrupt and disgraceful means. This style of proceeding has naturally disgusted everybody with the very mention of City Railroad schemes, as it has been taken for granted that they involved Legislative corruption, and were called for only by the greed of the speculators and lobby-men who had them in charge.

lead_paragraph: GOV. RANDALL, of Wisconsin, in his Message, sent to the Legislature on the 12th inst., states that the aggregate receipts into the General Fund, during the year just closed, were $531,051 28; and the disbursements, $490,522 96. Of this amount, $188,835 46 was extended in carrying on the State Government. The number of persons of school age--i.e., between four and twenty years--is $278,871, and the amount paid for teachers' wages during the year has been $536,860, which is an increase of $200,000 over the amount paid during the previous year. At the first of the year just closed, there were 99 banks in operation, and a capital of $8,045,000, and on the 1st of January, 1860, there were 108 in operation, with a capital or $7,700,000. After discussing various topics of exclusive local interest, the subject of Slavery is taken up. First, Gov. RANDALL declares that it was, at the organization of the Government, merely tolerated. He denounces the doctrine that slave property should be protected in the Territories. He thinks it cannot be conceded that the black man has no business on the earth; touches upon the inhumanity of the Slave trade; fears that the increase in the number of slaves in the Southern States will in time accomplish evils too terrible to anticipate or contemplate, and urges peaceful emigration of the blacks who may desire it to Central or South America. In support of this view, Gov. RANDALL quotes largely from Mr. JEFFERSON's writings, and recommends that the Legislature should memorialize Congress on the subject. He says:

abstract: Visitors to the City, as well as those of its residebts upon whom business or pleasure has devolved the necessity of traveling daring the past few months, have not failed to notice the market degree of order which now prevails at the various steamboat landings and railroad depots, as contrasted with the confusion which existed prior to the organization of the...
lead_paragraph: Visitors to the City, as well as those of its residebts upon whom business or pleasure has devolved the necessity of traveling daring the past few months, have not failed to notice the market degree of order which now prevails at the various steamboat landings and railroad depots, as contrasted with the confusion which existed prior to the organization of the Steamboat and Railroad Police. Before the present effective police arrangements were made, the temper of the traveling public was sorely tried by the importunities of hackmen, the insolence of runners and boarding-house keepers, and the annoyance of thievish boys, who were always solicitous to relieve passengers of valises and other small articles which they preferred to carry themselves. Now the citizen, returning to his home, may pass off the dock without receiving a jostling in the crowd, or losing his temper and his pocket-book; while strangers, ignorant of the City and its ways, receive information from the Police, which, if followed, will keep them from falling into the hands of sharpers.

abstract: The  debate in the House, on Wednesday, indicates that an "irrepressible conflict" is ripening between the two sections of the Democracy. The persistent, if rather impertinent, catechism of Mr. CARTER, elicited responses from the Northern and Southern wings of the party which threaten anything but harmony for the Charleston Convention.
lead_paragraph: -- The debate in the House, on Wednesday, indicates that an "irrepressible conflict" is ripening between the two sections of the Democracy. The persistent, if rather impertinent, catechism of Mr. CARTER, elicited responses from the Northern and Southern wings of the party which threaten anything but harmony for the Charleston Convention. Southern Democrats appear to cling with tenacity to the doctrine of legislative protection of Slavery in the Territories, while the Democrats of the North know that by any avowal of the same doctrine, or any affiliation with those who hold it, they would surely sign their political death warrant. Mr. COX of Ohio, Mr. MCCLERNAND of Illinois, and Mr. HOLMAN of Indiana, affirmed their adhesion to Popular Sovereignty, and deprecated the effect upon the Democratic Party of the North of any departure from the Cincinnati Platform. It is not easy to see any way of reconciling the existing differences of opinion upon this subject, and to ignore them would subject the Party to the well-founded charge of double-dealing and dishonesty. If Southern gentlemen expect to go into the next Presidential campaign upon a platform which recognizes the right and duty of Congress to interfere against the will of the people of a Territory -- for in only such a case would intervention be necessary -- without experiencing a Waterloo defeat, they will find themselves laboring under an egregious mistake. A ticket paraded on such a platform could not receive one electoral vote north of Mason and Dixon's line. We do not care, at the present time, to argue the matter, but it is our province to give a fair and truthful representation of the public sentiment of the country. It may be that some of the more extreme men of the South take this ground for the very purpose of hastening the crisis which they pronounce inevitable in the event of their political defeat. To suppose that they seriously urge the adoption of this doctrine as a party test, with any hope of its indorsement by the country, is to give them credit for a talent at blundering worthy the Roman soldier whom GALLIENUS decorated with a silver medal for missing the mark sixty consecutive times in his target-practice.

abstract: The few persons who were able to hear Prof. SILLIMAN'S second lecture, at Cooper Institute, last evening, were no doubt highly interested, but the number of such persons was necessarity limited, in consequence of the presence of several hundred unruly,...
lead_paragraph: The few persons who were able to hear Prof. SILLIMAN'S second lecture, at Cooper Institute, last evening, were no doubt highly interested, but the number of such persons was necessarity limited, in consequence of the presence of several hundred unruly, noisy, and disorderly boys from some of our Ward schools. Through some mistaken generosity, free tickets were given to the Grammar school pupils of schools Nos. 11, 45, 3, 16, 41, 48, and 35. The boys looked upon the entire proceedings as excessively amusing, and made so much disturbance that most of the adults left the Hall before the conclusion of the lecture. The busy hum of conversation, cat-calls, and whistles, finally rose to hooting and howling, and eventually terminated in prolonged shouting, to the great chagrin of the unfortunate M.P., who vainly strove to preserve decorum among the juveniles. As nearly as could be gathered, during the confusion, Prof. SILLIMAN commenced with an explanation of the character and extent of the Pennsylvania coal-fields, the nature of anthracite and bituminous coal, the geological formation of the coal-beds, and the evidence drawn from the subterranean strata that plants which now are the inhabitants solely of the tropics were once the products of Baffin's Bay and Vancouver's Island. The lecturer then proceeded with his interesting experiments, receiving little attention, and plentiful "hi, hi's" from young New-York. He demonstrated the properties of oxygen in sustaining combustion -- relighting a candle just blown out, by plunging it into the gas; and by the burning of phosphorus in a jar of oxygen, showing a brilliant light, which was immediately extinguished on being placed in a jar of nitrogen, and burned with ordinary flame in common air. He filled an inverted jar with hydrogen and held a lighted candle in it. The candle was extinguished and the gas took fire -- the reverse effect taking place when the candle was withdrawn. The extreme lightness of gas was shown by weighing it against common air, which proved the heaviest. The fact that carbonic acid results from respiration was proved by breathing into a jar, the acid being subsequently tested in various ways -- with a lighted candle and lime water, the former going out, and the latter being turned to chalk. Various effects were shown by the combustion of hydrogen, including the deposit of moisture, and the singing noise produced by burning the gas in a confined space. In this connection the lecturer demonstrated the explosive nature of hydrogen, by making bubbles filled with the gas, which exploded with loud reports on being touched with a lighted candle. The fact that there is no combustion in the centre of a flame, and that the greatest heat is at the top, was illustrated by passing a card through the flame at different points. The principle of Sir. HUMPHREY DAVY's safety lamp was shown by the holding of a piece of common sieve over a volume of flame, which was turned down, although some of the combustible gas escaped through the pores, and could be lighted by the application of flame to the upper side of the gauze. The philosophy of this lamp, he thought, could be properly applied to the prevention of camphene and burning-fluid accidents, by the application of a small piece of fine gauze sieve to the mouth and neck of the can containing the fluid.

abstract: A topographical and historical album of the campaign in Italy is being at present prepared at the French War Office. This great work, to be published by order of the Emperor, contains topographic plans and views of the various fields of battle of the two armies. In order to make the work as complete as possible, the Minister of War requested of the Austrian Government to give him the official documents...
lead_paragraph: A topographical and historical album of the campaign in Italy is being at present prepared at the French War Office. This great work, to be published by order of the Emperor, contains topographic plans and views of the various fields of battle of the two armies. In order to make the work as complete as possible, the Minister of War requested of the Austrian Government to give him the official documents relative to the Austrian army. The Emperor of Austria hastened to accede to the request, and Marshal Hess was commissioned to prepare the documents. The choice of Marshal Hess indicates the importance attached by the Austrian Government to the communication. In fact, the documenta supplied by Marshal Hess are of great historical interest, and cast a new light on the campaign of 1859, showing the importance of the measures adopted by the Austrian Government, and, consequently, the talent displayed by the French Generals and the bravery of the officers and soldiers. The Emperor is said to be well pleased with these documents, and has expressed his satisfaction to Marshal Hess.

abstract: Only about $300,000 remains unclaimde of the $2,500,000 of Croton Water Stock issued in 1834, due and payable on the 1st ult. Most of the holders resided in Europe, and on this account there has been some delay in the presentation of their scrip, which bore interest at 5 per cent. per annum -- a rate which offered no inducement for American capitalists to invest in the stork when it was issued. Now the City can get all the money it wants at 6 per cent. Very few payments were made until the 10th of January.

abstract: The opposition which has thus far been aroused in this country to the ratification of Mr. McLANE'S recent treaty with Mexico has been of a mainly partisan character. It has been assumed that no treaty negotiated under Mr. BUCHANAN'S Administration could possibly be advantageous to the interests of the country or the world; and this presumptive argument...
lead_paragraph: The opposition which has thus far been aroused in this country to the ratification of Mr. McLANE'S recent treaty with Mexico has been of a mainly partisan character. It has been assumed that no treaty negotiated under Mr. BUCHANAN'S Administration could possibly be advantageous to the interests of the country or the world; and this presumptive argument against the most important achievement of recent American diplomacy has been too commonly accepted without inquiry by thousands of the public, merely because the very name of Mexico has become odious in their ears. It is well, however, to remember that when California was ceded to us, the same general disposition to think slightingly of all Spanish-America, made the most intelligent men in the nation blind to the value of the acquisition, which might never have been developed to this day had not the instincts of the American settler been considerably more catholic than the prejudices of the American politician. There is a dawning hope now discernible on the horizon, we are glad to believe, that the mercantile common-sense and enterprise of the American people may do as good service in the case of Mexico, as they have already done in the case of California. While party manoeuverers are doing their best to blacken the Mexican Treaty as a mere scheme for conjuring four millions of dollars into the pockets of some designing Democratic cabal, the far-sighted, practical men who know what Mexico is, and what a vast treasure-house of wealth and prosperity there awaits the magic open sesame of civilized commerce, are giving us every day fresh indications of their faith in the results which must flow from Mr. MCLANE's conventions so soon as they shall be fairly put into force.

abstract: -- By the loosening of a wheel of a car attached to a train on the Boston and Worcester Railroad, a cattle train was thrown from the track on Tuesday afternoon, while crossing the bridge over Charles River. The first car was precipitated to the ice, a distance of thirty feet. A number of the cattle which were in it fell through the door, which was forced open, and were drowned, while others were killed by the force of the concussion.

abstract: It is always doubtful whether it be not a waste of time to discuss the merits of the "bills" which find their way into the NewYork Legislature, as, fortunately for the State, the proportion of those brought in which eventually receive the Governor's signature is almost always very comfortably small.
lead_paragraph: It is always doubtful whether it be not a waste of time to discuss the merits of the "bills" which find their way into the NewYork Legislature, as, fortunately for the State, the proportion of those brought in which eventually receive the Governor's signature is almost always very comfortably small. But no session ever passes in which little bits of mischief are not perpetrated "on the sly," and without exciting much public attention. A little oversight or neglect on the part of the better disposed members of the body is often sufficient to put the whole community, for at least one year, under the operation of some carefully concocted device for their spoliation and annoyance. Between the blunders of blockheads who meddle with things they do not understand, and the tricks of knaves who never meddle with anything with out knowing exactly what object they have in view, nothing but extreme vigilance on the part of the Members and the Press can insure us against having two-thirds of our ordinary relations and interests in life upset and deranged every Spring. One of the most ingenious of these attempts at effecting a great deal of mischief with very little noise, is just now going on in the form of a bill introduced into the Assembly by Mr. WALSH, to amend the Central Park Act. In order to avoid doing the promoter of this proposition injustice, we shall repeat the summary of its provisions, which we published yesterday, and which we believe to be substantially correct:

abstract: From a date whereof the memory of the TIMES, at least, runneth not to the contrary, our contemporary of the Albion has persevered in a pleasant pracice of being better than his word. After obliging his subscribers with a twelvemonth of entertainment and instruction of a specifically literary kind, he has invariably astonished them on New-Year's Day with a refined and delightful engraving.
lead_paragraph: From a date whereof the memory of the TIMES, at least, runneth not to the contrary, our contemporary of the Albion has persevered in a pleasant pracice of being better than his word. After obliging his subscribers with a twelvemonth of entertainment and instruction of a specifically literary kind, he has invariably astonished them on New-Year's Day with a refined and delightful engraving. The readers of the Albion know that this agreeable weekly has always maintained a high rank in the strictly critical world, and they have therefore been proportionably exacting in their expectations of its own artistic achievements. But it is due to justice and simple truth to say that the prints which have succeeded each other from its press during the last few years might be safely referred to to-day as illustrations of the gradual but decided progress which the art of engraving has been making on this side of the Atlantic. They have been chronicles of the burin as faithful, exact and impartial as could be asked for. With the present year, our contemporary reverts from the field of purely journalistic interest to the unchangeable domain of natural beauty. We have no Florence Nightingales now, nor Havelocks, but a most loyal and careful reproduction of one of LANDSEER's noblest works -- "The Deer-Pass." This picture is in every respect a fine companion-painting for the well-known "Monarch of the Glen." It represents, like that admirable composition, a wild, precipitous, solemn gorge of the Highland hills. The mosses are deep on the mountain sides -- the riding and rolling vapors cloud and cloak the deep rifts of the eternal rocks. The sense of space and of silence broods throughout the canvas. On the narrow pathway which winds through the formidable defile, the deer are clustered -- their many-antlered king in the van. Flights of hill-birds lead the eye gently away from the foreground over the vastness of the glooming distance. The engraver has followed the nervous, expressive pencil of his author with singular fidelity, and the picture is a success, which the subscribers of the Albion -- let us say it without compliment -- abundantly deserve. It is their just reward for believing with our contemporary, that an interesting record of the world's events, from week to week, may be made up without appealing to any sectional or political passions, on the broad Catholic ground of a general sympathy with literary aspiration, artistic culture and humane common sense all the world over. Our only quarrel with our neighbor is, that he is apt to fall into the Anti-Napoleonic craze of his countrymen, and to shoulder his old Queen ANNE's musket whenever he hears so much as a salute from the guns of a French man-of-war. But to ask the Albion newspaper to be wiser than Albion herself, would be absurd; and so taking our contemporary as right is, with all due recognition of his nationality and his notions, we can heartily rejoice in his prosperity, and wish him many long years of the same.

abstract: One of the most ingenious, novel, and, we believe, useful inventions of its kind, is a plan recently brought out, of applying power to agricultural and other hand or horse-propelled machinery, without the serious disadvantages attending the great weight, and consequent propulsive power ordinarily required.
lead_paragraph: One of the most ingenious, novel, and, we believe, useful inventions of its kind, is a plan recently brought out, of applying power to agricultural and other hand or horse-propelled machinery, without the serious disadvantages attending the great weight, and consequent propulsive power ordinarily required. The cutters, and working parts of mowers, reapers, and tilling machines, are ordinarily driven from a wheel which carries the principal weight of the implement, and is itself rotated by its adhesion upon the ground, as the implement is drawn forward. Now, if the weight upon this wheel were very light, and the power required from it considerable, the wheel would slip over the ground like a sleigh runner, and the attached machinery would not be propelled. To avoid such a result, not only is the implement itself made very heavy, but the driver adds his weight to it, and the tread of the wheel itself is in most cases roughened with spikes or projections like a steamer's paddles, so that it shall more firmly adhere to the ground. That is to say: a light frame-work is amply sufficient to carry the working machinery, but for the simple purpose of adhesion, we add a tremendous and otherwise unnecessary load, provide several times the otherwise requisite power to draw it, and still further obstruct its easy action by driving the spiked wheels into the ground, and in thereby giving them a jarring and unsteady motion. Therefore the aid of the horse is called in; man power will not answer for even the lightest work.

abstract: JAMES SOUTHWARD, an Englishman, 48 years of age, fell down a flight of stairs in the house No. 282 West Sixteenth-street, on Wednesday night, and sustained such severe internal injuries that his death resulted almost instantly. Coroner SCHIRMER held an inquest .... The same Coroner investigated the circumstances attending the death of RICHARD BARRY, a middle-aged Irishman, who slipped on the ice and struck his head so forcibly that he expired yesterday in consequence. Deceased was an itinerant musician, and a man of good reputation .... LOUIS BEILSTEIN, a child three years of age, fell from the third-story window of the house No. 302 East Twelfth-street, and was instantly killed. Coroner O'KEEFE held an inquest.

abstract: The incendiary Abolitionist organ of this City sticks stoutly to its congenial work of manufacturing a commercial and political panic. Argument and ridicule are alike thrown away upon a madness which is very full of method indeed. The Herald is improving upon the egotistical tactics of the Chinese gourmand...
lead_paragraph: The incendiary Abolitionist organ of this City sticks stoutly to its congenial work of manufacturing a commercial and political panic. Argument and ridicule are alike thrown away upon a madness which is very full of method indeed. The Herald is improving upon the egotistical tactics of the Chinese gourmand whom CHARLES LAMB describes as setting his neighbor's house on fire to roast a pig for his own dinner. Incapable of talking common sense with common decency, our frantic cotemporary is trying his best to make nonsense and indecency marketable by frightening the North into a pecuniary ague, and scaring the South into a social fever of fury. The more his neighbors demonstrate the absurdity of his outcries the more violent those outcries become. The daily pyrotechnics of this extraordinary journal would furnish forth a hundred Feasts of Lanterns.

abstract: We trust we shall not be suspected of intending anything so base as a pun when we say that this exquisitely published volume of verses, from the press of Messrs. RUDD & CARLETON, breathes throughout the "Dorian mood of flutes and soft recorders." That Mrs. EMMELINE SMITH is, indeed, the happy wife of one of the most respectable and, in this particular, enviable ex-occupants of the Recorder's chair of New-York City, cannot be denied; but the Miltonic line we quote would rise to the mind in speaking of her book, just as naturally, had her husband been an Ex-Mayor or an Ex-General of Artillery. It exactly expresses the prevalent temper and tone of her productions, which whisper always in soothing accents the tender and touching emotions of domestic life; the joys and sorrows proper to a well-balanced womanly nature fulfilled in all its beautiful relations, filial, conjugal and maternal. They are, as their author styles them, "household lays," painting the world of external nature, it is true, as well as the altar of home, but dwelling upon every theme in that ordered, loving spirit which only a true and quiet home-life can develop. Many of them found their way at first into the world through the Home Journal, the very name of which most aptly hints at their specific merits. To turn the leaves of the book in which they are now enshrined is like glancing through the open window of some pleasant country-house, the abode of quiet luxury and graceful truth, where Art and Nature are combined to minister their purest lessons to a ready woman's heart and tasteful mind.

abstract: THE COLORED POPULATION VERSUS CHARLES O'CONOR.--The Metropolitan Assembly Rooms, in Prince-street, were filled last evening with colored people, who had met to express their indignation at the speech of Mr. CHARLES O'CONOR, at the Union meeting in the Academy of Music on the 19th ultimo. Rev. H.H. GARNET, who presided, made a speech in which he handled Mr. O'CONOR with unsparing severity.
lead_paragraph: THE COLORED POPULATION VERSUS CHARLES O'CONOR.--The Metropolitan Assembly Rooms, in Prince-street, were filled last evening with colored people, who had met to express their indignation at the speech of Mr. CHARLES O'CONOR, at the Union meeting in the Academy of Music on the 19th ultimo. Rev. H.H. GARNET, who presided, made a speech in which he handled Mr. O'CONOR with unsparing severity. He assured the audience that the name of CHAS. O'CONOR would go down to posterity linked with infamy and oppression. Dr. J. MCCUNE SMITH followed in a similar strain, and, at the conclusion of his remarks, offered a series of resolutions requesting Mr. O'CONOR to deliver a course of lectures upon the justice of negro Slavery, and, in the event of his succeeding, the colored population of this City would recommend him to the President as a candidate for the next vacancy on the bench of the United States Supreme Court. Mr. STEPHEN D. DOUGLASS then read a lengthy criticism upon Mr. O'CONOR's speech. He was followed by Messrs. T.S.W. TITUS, J.P. POWERS and P.S. PORTER. The assemblage listened with attention to the speakers, but manifested little enthusiasm for their sentiments.

abstract: Rev. J.P. NEWMAN delivered a lecture last evening, before the Yonng Men's Christian Association, of the Trinity Methodist Episcopal Church, on Whitfield, in their church in Thirty-fourth street. After describing somewhat at length the religious condition of the world at the beginning of the eighteenth century, the lecturer said that on...
lead_paragraph: Rev. J.P. NEWMAN delivered a lecture last evening, before the Yonng Men's Christian Association, of the Trinity Methodist Episcopal Church, on Whitfield, in their church in Thirty-fourth street. After describing somewhat at length the religious condition of the world at the beginning of the eighteenth century, the lecturer said that on the 16th of December, 1714, GEORGE WHITFIELD, the sixth son of THOMAS and ELIZABETH WHITFIELD, was born in Gloucester, England. His father was an inn-keeper, and at the age of 14, GEORGE assisted his mother in a public-house. Thus humble was his origin. He was put to school at 17, where he remained nearly two years, and at the age of 18 he entered Pembroke College. Although he was a child of prayer, it was not till he entered Oxford, where he met with the two WESLEYS, that he received pardon for his sins. On the 20th of June, 1734, he was ordained priest in the Cathedral of his native city, and his sermon on that occasion shadowed forth his future course. Mr. NEWMAN then sketched the characteristics of the contemporaries of WHITFIELD who were prominent in the ministry, not forgetting to mention his patroness, Lady JANE HUNTINGTON. In this country, JONATHAN EDWARDS was then at the height of his power. He, said the speaker, was the great theologian who planted his theology on Mount Sinai; WHITFIELD planted his on Calvary; EDWARDS appalled; WHITFIELD aroused. In contrasting WHITFIELD with JOHN WESLEY, he said that the former was the mountain torrent; the latter the sparkling fountain. WHITFIELD was the wagoner who brought the timbers for the house; WESLEY the architect that created is. Happily for the world, these two men were contemporaneous, and, as it were, the supplements of each other. But if WHITFIELD was so great a man, what must he have been as an orator? In early life he gave special attention to declamation, for to him it was a duty to learn how to speak as well as what to speak. It is a shame to the Christian ministry that the stage is the only place where true oratory is cultivated. WHITFIELD was a master of eloquence. His accents of love soothed the heart of the mourner, while they broke upon the ear of crime with the thunder tones of Job. He could conjure up another Gethsemane, or light up another Tabor and drown it in Heaven's own glory. He spoke because he felt; his heaters felt because they saw. He was also a master of sacred rhetoric, which was defined tone the presentation of trite and familiar truths with striking power. The difference between ministers, is not in thought, but expression. If MASSILLON was great in his appeals, HALL in his fullness of definition, CHALMERS in his splendor of diction, WHITFIELD was greater in the sublime naturalness of his impersonations and the impressiveness of his apostrophes. At his command the dead would pass in review before our startled gaze, and at his bidding ranks of shining saints would appear to our vision and one could almost hear the music of Heaven. If such was WHITFIELD the orator, what was he as a divine?

abstract: THE GRAHAM HOME. -- The anniversary exercises at this Institution took place yesterday after-noon, in the "Home" Chapel, when addresses suitable to the occasion were made, and the annual and financial reports were presented. This institution was established and endowed by the late AUGUSTUS GRAHAM, and is intended as a Home for aged women who are reduced in circumstances, and who have, in early life, had the advantages of education and enjoyed the comforts of life. There is now in the treasury an excess over the expenditures of the last year of more than $2,000. The year previous showed an excess of $1,000, and during the year just passed the expenses of the management have been reduced about $400. The average number of inmates is 50. There were, during the past year, five deaths -- the youngest of the deceased was 74 years of age, and the oldest 90 years. Five persons were admitted during the year.

abstract: Last evening the Harbor Police arrested at the Quarantine grounds, Charles C. Cooper, a corporal of the United States steam-frigate Brooklyn, who is charged with having caused the death of George Rudder, a sailor onboard the steamer. On the afternoon of Nov. 7, 1859, Rudder had been punished for some misdemeanor, and was placed afterwards under the charge of Cooper. It is alleged the latter gagged and treated the unfortunate sailor in such a manner that he died a few hours afterwards. Coroner ROBERT HELSHELWOOD, of Richmond County, held an inquest on the body, and the verdict of the Coroner's Jury was, that Rudder died through the brutal treatment of Cooper. He was locked up in the First Ward station-house.

abstract: The Anglo Saxon, after a tardy voyage, reached Portland yesterday. The dates thus received extend to Jan. 5. Severe weather is reported to have visited the English coasts; and of a large number of marine disasters reported as occurring there or elsewhere on the trans-Atlantic side, a number had been experienced by American shipping. The political news is of interest. On New Year's day, at the imperial reception, NAPOLEON...
lead_paragraph: The Anglo Saxon, after a tardy voyage, reached Portland yesterday. The dates thus received extend to Jan. 5. Severe weather is reported to have visited the English coasts; and of a large number of marine disasters reported as occurring there or elsewhere on the trans-Atlantic side, a number had been experienced by American shipping. The political news is of interest. On New Year's day, at the imperial reception, NAPOLEON III. uttered the anticipated oracle, upon which hangs the fate of Europe. He declared, in answer to a laconic address of the Papal Nuncio, that his object was the restoration of "confidence and peace." The phrase greatly reassured the public mind, disturbed by rumors that the project of a Congress had been abandoned. Our latest dispatches correct this statement. The day of meeting is fixed in the middle of next month. The French army had been definitely placed upon a peace footing. A great and decisive victory has at last been gained by the Spanish army in Morocco. On the 1st inst. Gen. PRIM attacked the main body of the enemy, defeating them with great slaughter, and compelling them to abandon the field in confusion. The news from England lacks importance. The Conservative organs had been obliged to repudiate the draft of a Reform bill published in a London magazine, and attributed to the Tory leaders. The Reform bill of the Ministry is promised to be produced immediately after the meeting of Parliament. The funeral of Lord MACAULAY was to take place on the 9th inst. The remains were to be interred, with imposing solemnities, in Westminster Abbey. The London Times returns to the discussion of the Slavery question, attributing the just alarm and excitement at the South to the recklessness of New-England agitators. The intelligence from India and China is later, but not important.

abstract: -ADOPTION.  OF THREE PARKS AND A PARADE GROUND.--An adjourned meeting of the Park Commissioners was held last evening, when the Special Sub-Committee on Parks submitted a final report. They recommend for adoption "Prospect Park," with the following bound
lead_paragraph: -- ADOPTION. OF THREE PARKS AND A PARADE GROUND.--An adjourned meeting of the Park Commissioners was held last evening, when the Special Sub-Committee on Parks submitted a final report. They recommend for adoption "Prospect Park," with the following boundaries: Douglass-street, Washington-avenue to the city line on Montgomery-street, thence southwesterly in a straight line to the intersection of the city line and Ninth-street; Ninth-street, Tenth avenue, Third-street to the centre of the block between Eighth and Ninth avenues; thence northerly in a line parallel with Ninth-avenue to Douglass-street; thence easterly along Douglass-street to Washington-avenue, the place of beginning -- containing 200 acres, exclusive of Flatbush-avenue and the Reservoir, which together contain 17 acres, making the whole area of the Park about 267 acres. The estimated present value of the same is $l,000,000. The Committee also recommend the adoption of the "Ridgewood Park," with the boundaries as designated on the map prepared by THOMAS W. FIELD, Esq. This will contain 520 acres, 115 acres of which are permanently devoted to the Cemetery of the Evergreens, 48 acres to the Ridgewood Reservoir -- making the land to be purchased for Park purposes about 360 acres. The estimated cost of the land is $200,000. It also reported in favor of the land bounded by Third-street, Fifth-avenue, Sixth-street and Fourth-avenue as a local park, and of twenty-five acres of land at East New-York, in the town of New Lotts, to be taken from the southerly portion of land belonging to the heirs of -- HOWARD, deceased, for a parade ground. This land is located at the terminus of three City railroads, communicating with five different ferries across the East River, and is in full view of Ridgewood Park. The cost of this land wilt be about $25,000. This report was adopted. The plans now have to go before the Common Council, and, if accepted by that body, an application to the Legislature will be necessary for authority to raise the money to defray expenses. The Board adjourned for one week.

abstract: FOR CALIFORNIA.--The steamship Atlantic, Capt. PIERSON, of the North Atlantic Company, left yesterday. at 2 o'clock P.M., for Aspinwall, with about 700 passengers for California, among whom were the New-Granadian Minister, General HERRAN, and family, and Judge DEADY, of Oregon.
lead_paragraph: FOR CALIFORNIA.--The steamship Atlantic, Capt. PIERSON, of the North Atlantic Company, left yesterday. at 2 o'clock P.M., for Aspinwall, with about 700 passengers for California, among whom were the New-Granadian Minister, General HERRAN, and family, and Judge DEADY, of Oregon. The steamer North Star, Capt. JONES, of the Vanderbilt line, left at the same hour, with less than 200 passengers, chiefly in the steerage. On account of the irregularity of the California mails, the merchants, to a great extent, avail themselves of private enterprise for transmitting their correspondence, and the various express lines, and Mr. KENYON, each find profitable employment in carrying letters, several thousands of which went out by the Atlantic. Besides these, about ten tons of newspapers were among the fast freight of the Atlantic, the principal venders of newspapers having adopted the old line as the only sure mode of getting their "perishable" wares forward in season. Notwithstanding the vigilance of the police who have been specially detailed to protect strangers against swindlers, about one hundred and fifty tickets were sold by outside offices, at an advance of from ten to twenty dollars upon the rates current at the steamship offices. One victim lost nearly three hundred dollars.

abstract: MISS BUTT's "LEISURE MOMENTS." -- After all, New-York does not treat Virginia so badly! We give the warmest reception to the literary productions of the "Old Dominion," and have not the least prejudice against the daughters of the "Mother of Presidents." Miss MARTHA HAINES BUTT, OF Norfolk, Virginia, for instance, whose book -- Leisure Moments -- was published but the other day in this City, has already been "wood-cutted" for the benefit of posterity, by the Illustrated News, while the growing sale of her volume leaves very few "leisure moments" to her publisher. The woodcut is after -- and we must say "some distance" after -- a capital photograph by BRADY, and hardly does justice to the original. But how can a woodcut be expected to do justice to the bloom of youth and the eloquent light of womanhood?

abstract: Mr. JOHN CASSELL, of London, the well-known publisher of educational works, and who has been long prominent as an energetic promoter of every scheme which has for its objects the elevation of the working classes in England, has recently come to this country for the purpose of establishing agencies in New-York and elsewhere, for the sale of works published by the firm of CASSELL, PETTER & GALPIN, of Ludgate Hill. Mr. CASSELL has been for so many years before the English public as a coadjutor of Lord BROUGHAM, MILNER GIBSON, and other eminent men, in the crusade for the abolition of "the taxes on knowledge," -- the stamp duty and the paper duty -- and also as one of the earliest laborers in the diffusion of the mass of cheap and excellent literature which is effecting such a revolution in the British newspaper and book world, as well as in the habits of the people, that a majority of our readers are doubtless familiar with his name and works. The immediate object of his present visit to America is to inaugurate a more systematic distribution of his publications, by bringing out an illustrated family Bible, which has already attained an almost unprecedented circulation in Great Britain, and which, as far as paper, print, and wood engraving are concerned, is a model of cheapness and excellence. The text is elucidated by a copious commentary and marginal references; the drawings are all original, and by such artists as GILBERT, BEACH, PALMER, and NICHOLSON, in England; and COSTELLI, PHILLIPOTEAUX, GUSTAVE, DORE and HUARD, in France. When we add that they have been engraved on wood by W.J. HINTON, WILLIAMS, PEARSON and PANNEMAKER, and others of similar standing, any further enumeration of their merits will be unnecessary. The work is to be issued in forty-eight monthly parts, the first of which now lies before us. It contains fourteen large engravings and nineteen smaller ones, is quarto size, and is sold at fifteen cents. We wish the enterprise every success. When it costs so little to procure a specimen, further criticism on our part is unnecessary.

abstract: GOV, BLACK in his veto of the "Act to prohibit Slavery," passed by the Territorial Assembly of Nebraska, takes the ground that a provision of the organic act for the Territory which "leaves the people thereof perfectly free to form and regulate their domestic institutions
lead_paragraph: GOV, BLACK in his veto of the "Act to prohibit Slavery," passed by the Territorial Assembly of Nebraska, takes the ground that a provision of the organic act for the Territory which "leaves the people thereof perfectly free to form and regulate their domestic institutions in their own way, subject only to the Constitution of the United States," was never intended to give the "people" this power when acting through their Territorial Legislature, but only in their original and sovereign capacity exhibited in the formation of a State Constitution. The Governor may have meant to make out a good show of argument against the consistency of such a provision with the otherwise dependent condition of a Territory in having its Governor and other officers appointed by the Federal Government; but he has only succeeded in advancing an interpretation of a law of Congress, which is at variance with simple historic fact.

abstract: Worcester's New English Dictionary, the greatest literary enterprise of the time, is at length completed. It is comprised in 1,854 royal quarto pages, on clear, fine paper, with that peculiar clearness and beauty of typography which characterizes all the issues of the "Riverside" Press, and altogether is the most elegant and
lead_paragraph: Worcester's New English Dictionary, the greatest literary enterprise of the time, is at length completed. It is comprised in 1,854 royal quarto pages, on clear, fine paper, with that peculiar clearness and beauty of typography which characterizes all the issues of the "Riverside" Press, and altogether is the most elegant and massive volume which has been issued from the American Press. The author acknowledges, in the preface, the assistance of Professors Felton, Agassiz, Gray, Lovering, Horsford and Eliot, and of Mr. Henry James Clark, Mr. Charles Folsom and Mr. Richard Soule, of Cambridge, as well as of other well-known scholars. Profound scholarship and conscientious accuracy are manifest upon every page, while the completeness and comprehensiveness of the work, and its symmetrical arrangement, give the greatest facility of reference. Notes from WALKER, JOHNSON, LANDAIS, TRENCH and others, on the orthography, pronunciation and etymology of the language, are interspersed throughout the text; and these, with the articles on synonyms and the pictorial illustrations, or rather definitions, give the fullest information with regard to the origin, changes and usage of words.

abstract: The Democratic State Convention of Indiana, which assembled on the 11th inst., had an excited session, lasting two days. Mr. THOMAS A. HENDRICKS was nominated for Governor, and Mr. DAVID TURPIE for Lient.-Governor. The resolutions adopted were
lead_paragraph: The Democratic State Convention of Indiana, which assembled on the 11th inst., had an excited session, lasting two days. Mr. THOMAS A. HENDRICKS was nominated for Governor, and Mr. DAVID TURPIE for Lient.-Governor. The resolutions adopted were quite long. The second repudiates all connection with sectional parties, the third indorses the principle of non-interference by Congress with Slavery in State or Territory, or in the District of Columbia, and the fourth is an expansion of the third; the fifth urges the necessity of harmony in the Democratic Party, and declares it to be the duty of every member of it to support the regular nominee of the party. Those succeeding pronounce in favor of the peaceful acquisition of Cuba, and denounce any attempt to distinguish between citizens on account of their religious beliefs. Then occur the following:

abstract: We published yesterday a letter from Rev. Dr. BRECHINRIDGE, of Kentucky, a distinguished divine of the Presbyterian Church, upon the political state of the country. This letter is addressed to his relative, the Vice-President of the United States. The perusal of it must
lead_paragraph: We published yesterday a letter from Rev. Dr. BRECHINRIDGE, of Kentucky, a distinguished divine of the Presbyterian Church, upon the political state of the country. This letter is addressed to his relative, the Vice-President of the United States. The perusal of it must have satisfied most reasonable persons that there are some exceptions to the rule that clergymen should not meddle in politics. It is upon no question of party that this eminent and reverend gentleman interposes his calm and sensible voice. He speaks as an American minister of religion, and appeals to the patriotism and national feeling of the country, as in a season of great national peril.

abstract: The efforts that are being made to "turn a penny" by the prevailing political excitement are remarkable examples of the national enterprise. We alluded, a few days ago, to W. P. GILMAN  Co.'s grand plan of making a decent livelihood by establishing a registry in
lead_paragraph: The efforts that are being made to "turn a penny" by the prevailing political excitement are remarkable examples of the national enterprise. We alluded, a few days ago, to W. P. GILMAN Co.'s grand plan of making a decent livelihood by establishing a registry in which Northern merchants may have themselves certified as "sound on the goose," upon the payment of fifty dollars down, and the purchase of a book to be published annually by the said GILMAN & Co., at the small price of $3. A little journal in this City, which lives by praising Slavery and abusing negroes, and which is evidently very much too "cute" to make it necessary for us to advertise it by naming it, has come to the conclusion that GILMAN & Co. have "struck a vein," and is most anxious to share in the profitable working thereof. A lengthy editorial, accordingly, favors the enterprising GILMAN with a reasonable measure of approval. It thinks he can render the South good service, and confound the Abolitionists, if he will but take the right means of ascertaining which merchants are sound and which are not. But how is this to be done? How is W.P. GILMAN to ascertain whether the persons who pay him fifty dollars, and order his invaluable almanac, are really Pro-Slavery men, or only mercenary Abolitionists in disguise. "Fifty dollars," says our astute contemporary, "would be amazingly cheap for some persons to pay for being put down sound." So it would, and if Mr. GILMAN were wise in his generation he would arrange a sliding scale -- charging the rank Pro-Slavery men only fifty dollars; those who disapprove of Slavery in the abstract, but have no objection to its extension, seventy-five; those who object to its extension, but are willing to let it alone where it exists, one hundred; rank Abolitionists, for not showing them up and getting their collectors tarred and feathered, one hundred and fifty. This seems to us a very fail and feasible arrangement, provided the New-York merchants are as great fools as W.P. GILMAN & Co. evidently believe them to be. But even this plan does not provide for the great difficulty, that of classifying the applicants for W.P.G.'s indorsement.

abstract: The state of agitation into which the colored population and a considerable portion of the whites in this City have been thrown by Mr. O'CONOR's enunciation of his opinions on the subject of Slavery, though very complimentary to the learned gentleman himself, is certainly very unaccountable and even unnecessary. As Mr. O'CONOR did not attempt to sustain his position by argument, all that he said reduces itself to a simple expression of personal convictions. The convictions of a man like Mr. O'CONOR are always entitled to be treated with decent respect; but when, as in this instance, they are diametrically opposed to the opinions of nine-tenths of the greatest jurists, philosophers, statesmen and philanthropists of all countries and ages, we confess the convulsions into which they have thrown our Anti-Slavery friends are not quite comprehensible. Mr. O'CONOR is a leading member of the New-York Bar, and, so far as we know, has never tried or professed to be anything more than this. There is assuredly nothing in this fact to entitle his views on Slavery to any more special consideration than would naturally be given to his opinion on apple-dumplings or to his theory of comets. We cannot, therefore, help urging the "colored world" to expend no more time in demolishing the doctrines of this learned gentleman. As yet his speech has not caused, so far as we have heard, any considerable defection from the Anti-Slavery ranks. It will be time enough, therefore, to denounce him, when he has done some harm, or, at all events, when his loose assertions shall have been solemnly recast into an argumentative form, and put forward with some pretence of reasoning and precedent.

abstract: A new method of swindling, and a successful one, is exposed by the Lancaster (Pa.) Inquirer, which says : "A German in the employ of Mr. Wissler had, about a year since, gone to New-York to visit some friends; when he returned he brought with him a letter...
lead_paragraph: A new method of swindling, and a successful one, is exposed by the Lancaster (Pa.) Inquirer, which says : "A German in the employ of Mr. Wissler had, about a year since, gone to New-York to visit some friends; when he returned he brought with him a letter purporting to be from Germany. The letter stated that a near relative of his had died, and that he was heir to something like $7,000, for which a draft was inclosed, payable in November, 1859. The German man appeared to be much puzzled as to what he would do with his money, and finally made up his mind to go west and invest it in land, and for that purpose he asked Mr. Wissler for the loan of $600 until his draft became due, promising to give Mr. Wissler his foreign draft for security. Mr. Wissler furnished him said amount; he started off with his booty, but returned again in a short time, asking for $600 more, stating that he had bought a large tract of land, and would want that amount to complete the purchase. Mr. Wissler gave him $400 more and took his draft for security, which proved to be bogus."

abstract: Hon. A.R. WRIGHT, of Georgia, has written a letter, which is published in the Southern Confederacy, strongly urging Hon. A. H. STEPHENS as the candidate for the Presidency. His first choice, he says, would be Senator TOOMES, but he thinks Mr. STEPHENS, who is not his inferior, would be more sure of an election.
lead_paragraph: Hon. A.R. WRIGHT, of Georgia, has written a letter, which is published in the Southern Confederacy, strongly urging Hon. A. H. STEPHENS as the candidate for the Presidency. His first choice, he says, would be Senator TOOMES, but he thinks Mr. STEPHENS, who is not his inferior, would be more sure of an election. He says he (Mr. S.) is a Lecompton Democrat, and proved the salvation of the Administration. "When it saw the storm and sought shelter, he took it under his wing and saved its drooping vitality. Without htm it could not have survived the hail stones and the sleet. Shivering and cadaverous, it required more than shelter; it needed heat to preserve it. Mr. STEPHENS was good to it. They must be grateful." His moral character is good, and he could carry New-York beyond a doubt. Judge WRIGHT thinks that if the South is compelled at Charleston to take a Northern candidate, it should be Judge DOUGLAS, beyond all controversy. He says:

abstract: The Chicago Times of the 16th says: "Day before yesterday a large package arrived at the office of the United States Express Company in this city, from Toledo, directed to the address of "Charles Sanford." Looking into the directory the agents of the Express Company found CHARLES SANFORD to be a salesman in the dry goods store of P. PALMER & Co. The names of no other CHARLES SANFORD being found in the directory, they of course concluded that the package was for the one whose name appeared there, and accordingly the package was sent to him. He of course was somewhat surprised to receive a package he had not expected; but his surprise vastly increased when he found it to contain the handsome sum of $74,000 in notes of the "Hartford Exchange Bank." To verify his good fortune, he took the money to a banker, who at once pronounced it worthless. After communicating with the police he resealed the package and deposited it at the Express office, a watch having been set to detect the parties who should call for it. Towards evening of the same day, two produce dealers, giving their names as Messrs. CHARLES SANFORD and JOHN LESTER, called at the office and secured the package. A watch was kept on their movements, and the next day they were arrested, and each held in $1,000 bail to answer. Messrs. SANDFORD and LESTER stated that they had been gathering up the outstanding notes of this Hartford Exchange Bank, of Indiana, in order to sell them to Mr. KIBBER, of Detroit, who says that he has for some time been endeavoring to call in the circulation of the institution. The mystery attending this transaction is increased by the fact that Mr. GEORGE S. GILBERT is now in prison in Missouri for an attempt to pay for a large number of mules, which he purchased in the interior of the State, with bills on this identical bank.

abstract: Hon. John Nelson died at his residence, on Mount Vernon-place, Baltimore, about 9 1/2 o'clock on Wednesday night. He had only been confined to the house a few days, his disease being gout in the stomach. Mr. Nelson occupied a high position at the Bar, not only of Maryland, but of the country, and has at different periods filled offices of honor and trust with marked ability. He was Minister to Naples under the administration of President Jackson, and Attorney-General of the United States under President Tyler. He was born in Frederick County, Md., in 1791, but has resided in Baltimore for very many years.

abstract: The Circassian, at St. Johns, brings European advices to Jan. 7. They are of slight interest. The dismissal or resignation of Count WALEWSKI was the prominent topic of talk in political circles, the prevailing impression being that the
lead_paragraph: The Circassian, at St. Johns, brings European advices to Jan. 7. They are of slight interest. The dismissal or resignation of Count WALEWSKI was the prominent topic of talk in political circles, the prevailing impression being that the change indicated the final determination of the Emperor NAPOLEON to identify himself with the cause of the Italian people. M. DE THOUVENEL was to leave Constantinople to assume the duties of the Foreign Office immediately. Doubts still existed as to the meeting of the Congress. A visit which Lord COWLEY had made to London was understood to be connected with the arrangement of the Italian question without the aid of a Congress. The India and China mails had arrived, bringing nothing of public interest. The mails by the Anglo-Saxon were received in this City last evening. They supply us with correspondence and details of importance.

abstract: The skillful cross-questioning of Mr. COLFAX in the House of Representatives on Thursday elicited an open avowal of the fact that certain members of the Democratic Party--said to edual the Forty Thieves in number-had signed a mutual pledge to resist the adoption of the
lead_paragraph: The skillful cross-questioning of Mr. COLFAX in the House of Representatives on Thursday elicited an open avowal of the fact that certain members of the Democratic Party--said to edual the Forty Thieves in number-had signed a mutual pledge to resist the adoption of the plurality rule, in the election of Speaker, "to the bitter end." Mr. COLFAX, at the same time, proclaimed the willingness of the Republicans "to vote on any and every proposition, now pending, or which may be pending." In support of the constitutionality of the plurality rule, he referred to the two previous instances in which a Speaker had been elected under that rule without a question of the validity of the Congressional enactments of the period, and also to the fact that all the members hold their seats under the operation of the same rule, -- Rhode Island alone requiring a majority vote to elect her delegates. It might have been added that the President of the United States is elected in the same way; for though the Constitution requires that he shall receive a majority of the electoral votes, yet the electors themselves, in the different States, may be elected by a plurality. In fact the plurality rule is a practical necessity in the organization of any political body, or in the election of public officers, and all representative government might at any moment come to an end without it. But the question of the constitutionality of any action of Congress must originally be settled by that body itself; and the decision of the majority of its members in favor of such constitutionality is conclusive until it is reversed by the only competent tribunal -- the Supreme Court. There is no clearer principle than that, under our System, the majority should govern; and if a majority of the members of the House desire the adoption of the plurality rule, then the attempt on the part of the minority to prevent, by dilatory motions, and parliamentary tactics, the House from coming to a vote, is really factions, and will be eventually so understood by the country.

abstract: We learn from Mr. James B. abstract: There is a proverb, we believe of Scottish origin, which avers that the man must have a long spoon who would sup kail with the devil. Of the wisdom of this ancient adage, some of the leading Southern members of the House of Representatives are beginning to obtain a valuable personal experience.
lead_paragraph: There is a proverb, we believe of Scottish origin, which avers that the man must have a long spoon who would sup kail with the devil. Of the wisdom of this ancient adage, some of the leading Southern members of the House of Representatives are beginning to obtain a valuable personal experience. They have been trying to eat fire with, the Herald, and have neglected the preliminary precautions advisable in the case of such company. Mr. ROGER A. PRYOR, of Virginia, has been the first victim of this misplaced confidence, and we owe it to that distinguished gentleman to say that he calls out lustily when he finds himself scorched.
