abstract: The Tax Levy for 1860, as it has finally passed both Boards of the Common Council, and is now awaiting the signature of the Mayor, amounts in the aggregate to $9,545,000. It is less by $315,926 09 than that of last year, and, if the allowance this year, which was not made last year, is deducted, It is less
lead_paragraph: The Tax Levy for 1860, as it has finally passed both Boards of the Common Council, and is now awaiting the signature of the Mayor, amounts in the aggregate to $9,545,000. It is less by $315,926 09 than that of last year, and, if the allowance this year, which was not made last year, is deducted, It is less by over $600,000. It must be borne in mind, however, that the estimates of last year did not carry the Government through to 1860, and that towards the close of that year fresh appropriations were called for and made to provide for "contingencies." There is no reason to anticipate that it will be otherwise this year.

abstract: It is known to the public that twelve families, including thirty-six persons, farmers, artisans, teachers and missionaries, with their wives and little ones, including youth and the aged, several of them being natives of Kentucky, were, on the 23d of December last, forced out of Madison County and the State, by
lead_paragraph: It is known to the public that twelve families, including thirty-six persons, farmers, artisans, teachers and missionaries, with their wives and little ones, including youth and the aged, several of them being natives of Kentucky, were, on the 23d of December last, forced out of Madison County and the State, by "sixty-five citizens, comprising much of the wealth and influence of the County" -- the representatives of a public meeting -- not because they had violated any law, or been guilty of any misdemeanor, but simply for being engaged in promoting the cause of Christ and humanity as peaceful Emancipationists and Christians.

abstract: Mr. Thomas F. Gordon, formerly a member of the Philadelphia bar, and author of a number of valuable legal and historical works, died at Beverly, N.J., Jan. 17, aged 73. Among his published works were -- A Digest of the Laws of the United States; History of Pennsylvania, from its discovery to 1776; History of New-Jersey, from its discovery to 1789; History of America; Cabinet of American History; History of Ancient Mexico; Gazetteer of New-Jersey, and the Gazetteer of New-York.

abstract: This shows a falling off of about a hundred barrels per ship in the average. That is so much off the profits, and the margin was scanty enough previously, In many instances the losses are so great that the ships will be Withdrawn entirely from the trade, although at
lead_paragraph: This shows a falling off of about a hundred barrels per ship in the average. That is so much off the profits, and the margin was scanty enough previously, In many instances the losses are so great that the ships will be Withdrawn entirely from the trade, although at no previous time have they been able to refit here at more favorable rates, owing in part to a considerably increased competition in the ship-chandlery line; and what has been without previous example, whalers' exchange has been at par throughout the season, whereas, formerly, it ranged at a discount of from five to fifteen percent. Great and constant complaints are made by all kinds of merchants of the depression in trade, and it is freely prognosticated that the city will materially decline in all its interests in consequence of the diminishing whaling fleet and consequent cutting off of the peculiar traffic which has built up and supported the place. But I apprehend that meantime other interests have been growing up of which we do not yet appreciate the full importance, which will now go far to take the place of the old main dependence, and which will constantly increase in value as the capital now invested in business depending on whale fisheries is eliminated.

abstract: -- The Boston Board of Trade held its annual meeting on the evening of the 18th inst. The receipts of the year had amounted to $5,463 87, and the expenditures to $5,396 51. After the election of EDWARD S. TOBEY as President for the ensuing year, the annual report of the Secretary, Hon. LORENZO SABINE, was presented. The decimal system of weights and measures is strongly recommended; a general bankrupt law is regarded as of great moment, and Congress is urged to legislate so as to equalize the tariff. Allusion is then made to the action taken by the Board in urging upon the President of the United States to take measures having in view the conformation of our Maritime law with that of England and France. A plan to secure more certain and speedy communication with New-Orleans is under advisement. It is proposed to construct two first-class steamships, of not less than 1,600 tons each, at a cost of about $400,000. Some such action as this will be necessary, the report states, to maintain commerce with the great cotton mart of the South. The lines to Philadelphia and Baltimore have been so remunerative as to make additions to them necessary.

abstract: D.D. Owen, State Geologist of Indiana, reports to the State Board of Agriculture that during the progress of the survey of the State several beds of iron ore were found, usually either interstratified with the coal measures, or near the margin of the coal basin, some of which ores evidently contain a large percentage of iron, sufficient to make them valuable in the arts; some, however, from their proximity to sand-stone, appear too largely combined with silicious materials, which has a tendency to render them rather refractory under the process usually employed in the half-stack furnace; hitherto chiefly used in our Western States. Besides these iron ores of the coal region, large deposits of bog iron ore were partially examined.

abstract: OXFORD, OHIO. -- A correspondent of the Cincinnati Commercial writes that this building, the destruction of which has already been telegraphed, caught fire at 12 1/2 o'clock on the night of the 15th inst. There were 175 young ladies attending the institution. All of them were at once aroused, and while a delegation was sent to call upon the townspeople for aid, the rest formed a line and passed buckets to extinguish the fire. All efforts were futile, and it was immediately resolved to attempt to rescue the contents of the building. Many articles of value were saved through the exertions of the pupils. Miss SALLIB E. MOORE, thinking to preserve her books, returned a second time for a part of them, to her room in the fifth story. Finding exit by the stairway cut off by the flames, she deliberately tore the bed clothing into shreds, and, having fastened one end of her rope to the bedpost, stepped from the window and descended to the ground, a distance of forty-five feet. Kissings, greetings and other feminine demonstrations were made on ascertaining that all the inmates of the building were safe. The edifice is to be rebuilt immediately.

abstract: Capt. S. BOWEN, of the Clarke (Va.) Guards, has already applied to the Adjutant-General of Virginia, and through him to the Governor, to be one of the companies to fill up any requisition that may be made on Virginia in case of a war with Mexico at any future time. abstract: -- On Saturday morning last, about 7 1/2 o'clock, five new ice-houses, belonging to RADFORD SMITH & Co. of this City, were entirely destroyed at the New-Paltz Landing, opposite Poughkeepsie, by the sinking of the dock at that place, upon which they were built. When the dock gave way the whole was precipitated into the river and sunk. They were almost filled with the season's ice. The damage cannot be repaired this Winter. The loss is estimated, at from eight to ten thousand dollars.

abstract: The proposed increase in the Judges' salaries, which the late Board of Supervisors refused to consider, is now being forced upon the attention of the Legislature, both by a petition signed by a large number of the members of the bar and others, and, if we are to believe the statements of correspondents in Albany, by
lead_paragraph: The proposed increase in the Judges' salaries, which the late Board of Supervisors refused to consider, is now being forced upon the attention of the Legislature, both by a petition signed by a large number of the members of the bar and others, and, if we are to believe the statements of correspondents in Albany, by the personal lobbying and solicitation of the Judges themselves. The Legislature is asked to recommend that the salaries of those Judges of the Court of Appeals and of the Supreme Court who were in office before the 1st of January, 1858, be increased so as to place them on an equality with those who took office on that day, at a higher rate of compensation. It is alleged that to allow one portion of the Judges to be in receipt of larger salaries than their colleagues, who are performing precisely the same duties, and whose greater experience may reasonably be presumed to enable them to perform their duties even better than their juniors, is to create an invidious and unjustifiable distinction.

abstract: -- The Washington Star says: In consequence of the Mexican, and Indian wars of the United States, there are necessarily a number of widows and orphans who are enjoying abroad the small pittance granted to these whose husbands and fathers were slain in the service of the United States. However generous the allowance in spirit, still it is very small and insufficient for the support of the recipients, ($42 per annum in the case of a private soldier,) and Congress has, in raising the grade of pay of the army, overlooked to raise the grade of this half-pay to widows and orphans to the new standard even. On these small amounts the heavy Consular fees for authenticating the semi-annual vouchers were another disproportionate drawback, and made the Government appear in the light of one who discounts his own bounties. This subject having been properly represented to the Department of State, the following very creditable action has been had:

abstract: -- The Boston Traveller says: "JOHN E. FRYE, of Bolton, Senator from the East Worcester District, has resigned his seat at the Board. Mr. FRYE is a shoe manufacturer, and this, we believe, was his first term in the Senate. The resignation was probably brought about in consequence of allegations that he had forged notes, negotiated in this city to the extent of $3,500 or more. One of the names forged is stated to be that of Mr. GEORGE A. MANSFIELD, shoe dealer of this city. The amount is stated by some to reach $5,000. It is stated that Mr. FRYE contemplated the payment of these notes promptly at maturity, but that in consequence of neglect or political preoccupation, one was allowed to go to protest, when unexpected developments were made in the matter. In this case a bad memory was attended with disastrous results. The Worcester Spy says that his personal friends were astonished at the announcement. On Tuesday, after, the facts came out, his colleagues had a long conference in the Senate Chamber, when he agreed to resign his seat. It is a sad case, and quite contrary to the general estimate of Mr. FRYE's character.

abstract: Will of James P. Allaire. -- This will, which has been subjected to a long and severe contestation before the Surrogate, Hon. EDWARD C. WEST, has at last been admitted to probate. It will be remembered that the testator left very little personal estate, but a large landed property, of uncertain value, in New-Jersey. He left several children by his first wife, to whom he was married in early life. Four of those children survive, and two grandchildren, daughters of a deceased son. He also left a son by his second wife, the present Mrs. Allaire, to whom he was married in 1846, and who was a relative both of himself and of his first wife. This son was born about a year after the marriage.

lead_paragraph: The subject of Reformatory Education, and of the best methods of conducting it, is one of such importance, and involves the future prosperity and security of our large cities to such an extent. that we deem no apology necessary for presenting to our readers a short history of the House of Refuge, a brief description of its present management, and some suggestions as to the means of increasing its efficiency in the reformation of juvenile offenders.

abstract: The January number of the American Journal of Science and Arts, more popularly known as Silliman's Journal, contains numerous articles which will be found especially valuable by that class of readers whose wants the publication so fully meets. The introductory essay to the
lead_paragraph: The January number of the American Journal of Science and Arts, more popularly known as Silliman's Journal, contains numerous articles which will be found especially valuable by that class of readers whose wants the publication so fully meets. The introductory essay to the Flora of Tasmania, a work now in course of preparation by the eminent botanist, Dr. JOSEPH D. HOOKER, is the opening article. In the course of this essay, which treats particularly of the origination and distribution of species, Dr. HOOKER states that he has brought together evidence of nearly 8,000 flowering plants having been collected or observed in Australia, of which number he has seen a catalogue of upwards of 7,000. By permission of the Treasury Department, Prof. BACHE communicates a general account of the results of the discussion of the declinometer observations made at Girard College between the years 1840 and 1845. He treats particularly of these observations as they relate to the eleven-year period, or, as it is commonly called, the decennial period in the amplitude of the solar diurnal variation, and the disturbances of the magnetic declination. Prof. W.H.C. BARTLETT, of the West Point Military Academy, presents a brief paper on the comas and tails of comets, and Prof. W.A. NORTON an article in which he sums up the result of his calculations to determine the theoretical dimensions of the comet of 1858. Chemists will be interested in the paper on osmious acid and on the numerical relations existing between the equivalent number of elementary bodies; while geologists will find their wants attended to in the articles which discuss the new genus of patelliform shells recently discovered in the cretaceous rocks of Nebraska, and the new species of crinoidea from the subcar-boniferous rocks of Indiana and Kentucky. The geographical notices compiled by Mr. GILMAN, the Librarian of Yale College, and the exceedingly interesting summary of scientific intelligence, furnish the general reader with much valuable information which it would require extensive research to gain elsewhere.

abstract: Mr. SHERMAN's explanation of his position, on Friday, though rather tardy, was both manly and pertinent. while expressing a perfect willingness to avow or disavow every sentiment contained in HELPER's book, yet so long as the offensive resolution of Mr. CLARK lies
lead_paragraph: Mr. SHERMAN's explanation of his position, on Friday, though rather tardy, was both manly and pertinent. while expressing a perfect willingness to avow or disavow every sentiment contained in HELPER's book, yet so long as the offensive resolution of Mr. CLARK lies before the House -- a resolution introduced in an unparliamentary manner, and urged with arguments which have implied a prejudgment of the case -- Mr. SHERMAN refuses to enter upon any justification of himself against the charges which have been brought against him. If Mr. CLARK will withdraw his resolution temporarily, so that Mr. SHERMAN can feel his wounded self-respect relieved from a grievous pressure, the Republican candidate for the Speakership offers to give Mr. CLARK and the Democracy and the House full satisfaction. At the same time he renews his statement, previously made, that, at the solicitation of a colleague, he allowed his name to be attached to a recommendation of the too-famous Helper book for circulation as a political pamphlet, provided, as he avers, it contained nothing improper or offensive. This confession of Mr. SHERMAN, unconsciously to himself, no doubt, illustrates the grave mischiefs which have flowed in upon our national politics from dealing with great sectional passions as the basis of partisan action.

abstract: -- We learn by a gentleman who arrived in this City on Friday, by the Montreal passenger train on the Hudson River Railroad, that the express which left this City the night previous, ran off the track near Schodack. The accident was caused by a broken rail. The engine, baggage, and one passenger car, passed over safely, but the remaining four cars were thrown from the track. The passengers were taken to Albany in the baggage and passenger car, among whom were some who were injured in the late accident on that road. The track was not cleared until 5 o'clock on Friday morning.
lead_paragraph: -- We learn by a gentleman who arrived in this City on Friday, by the Montreal passenger train on the Hudson River Railroad, that the express which left this City the night previous, ran off the track near Schodack. The track was not cleared until 5 o'clock on Friday morning.

abstract: On resigning the Gubernatorial chair to GOV. HOUSTON, Gov. RUNNBLS delivered a brief valedictory address. He claimed that his recommendation to organize the militia, in view of the existing sectional difficulties, had been fully justified by recent events; that the history of the past five years demonstrated an unchangeable determination on the part of the Northern States to assail the dearest political rights of the South, and to destroy its domestic institutions. The history of the world, he says, does not afford an example of a nation so radically divided long remaining under a common Government. Preparation will not hasten coming events, and may avert the consequences of this inevitable separation; therefore the time has arrived for the South to look to her defences.
lead_paragraph: On resigning the Gubernatorial chair to GOV. HOUSTON, Gov. RUNNBLS delivered a brief valedictory address. abstract: body met yesterday morning at No. 281 Grand-street,` The Society numbers over 200 menbers, a large preportion of whom were present. It was announced  that $1,849 05 had been thus far collected for the re
lead_paragraph: body met yesterday morning at No. 281 Grand-street,` The Society numbers over 200 menbers, a large preportion of whom were present. It was announced that $1,849 05 had been thus far collected for the relief of the sixty-three sufferers by the fire of Dec. 9 -- of which $1,671 74 had been applied directly for the aid of the needy; $6 67 remained on hand, and the balance had been expended for necessary outlays in collecting, &c. The piano-forte makers of the City number about 1,200, and it is believed that should even half of them join the Association and contribute to its support, all could be aided in case of sickness, inability to obtain work, or loss of tools by fire, on the principle of a mutual insurance company. It was for the purpose of advancing these ends that the meeting of yesterday was convened. The discussion was quite protracted, and resulted in definite arrangements for forwarding the desired object.

abstract: The facts that CASSIUS M. CLAY on the 10th inst., was allowed to deliver from the steps of the capitol at Frankfort, in Kentucky, a speech more than three hours in length, in which the boldest if not the most radical view on the political relations of Slavery were taken, and the celebrated work of HELPER unequivocally indorsed, with the exception of a single point,
lead_paragraph: The facts that CASSIUS M. CLAY on the 10th inst., was allowed to deliver from the steps of the capitol at Frankfort, in Kentucky, a speech more than three hours in length, in which the boldest if not the most radical view on the political relations of Slavery were taken, and the celebrated work of HELPER unequivocally indorsed, with the exception of a single point, to which the speaker objected "not that it was incendiary, but that it was a blunder," and that this speech was listened to by a large auditory, many of whom were inflexibly hostile to the sentiments of the speaker, without the least interruption or molestation, though threats had been publicly made that he should not be permitted to speak, and an influential journal had counselled that he should be silenced by violence, and that Kentuckians would be proved to be cowards if he was not -- we say, these facts are most significant and striking. Northern men, and especially Northern philanthropists will do well to ponder their meaning.

abstract: Mr. William Howitt, in a note to the editor of the London Star, recommends all "who are desirous of listening to the very highest style of eloquence -- eloquence embodying the greatest and noblest truths -- to take the opportunity of hearing Rev. T.L. Harris, one of the greatest sacred orators that has ever appeared, and one whom all those who are engaged in attempting to elevate and Christianize the age ought to hear." Mr. Harris, he adds, is the medium of several volumes of poetry, The Lyric of the Golden Age, The Lay of the Morning Land, &c., than which there has been nothing finer since the days of Milton. This name will be recognized by New-Yorkers as that of a clergyman who created no very profound sensation during his ministration here.

abstract: The great non-intercourse movement has at last found an organ at the South. A journal published in Georgia, under the ominious and highly constitutional title of the Daily Southern Confederacy, has issued a, solemn list of the
lead_paragraph: The great non-intercourse movement has at last found an organ at the South. A journal published in Georgia, under the ominious and highly constitutional title of the Daily Southern Confederacy, has issued a, solemn list of the "Black" and another of the "White" houses of New-York engaged in the dry-goods business. In the first of these lists are comprised all the wicked creatures known "to be steeped and saturated in Sewardism, Brownism, Greeleyism, Helperism and incendiarism," which last phrase we should be inclined to regard as a bit of tautalogy, had we not the largest confidence in the rhetorical simplicity and accuracy of our contemporary.

abstract: A decision has just been given by Judge Chum, asero in the County Court of Monroe County, N.Y. which is in effect that a Board of Education has no corporate capacity in which it can be sued. The decision was made in a suit brought by J.W. Bissell for
lead_paragraph: A decision has just been given by Judge Chum, asero in the County Court of Monroe County, N.Y. which is in effect that a Board of Education has no corporate capacity in which it can be sued. The decision was made in a suit brought by J.W. Bissell for services as an architect rendered some five years since. The Judge intimated that the plaintiff can recover of the City of Rochester if his debt is such a one as the Board had a right to contract. The same decision applies to the Common Council.

abstract: SERIOUS ACCIDENTS--TWO CHILDREN DROWNED,--Yesterday afternoon, while MARY O'BRIEN, three years old, and MARY ANN CURTIS six years old, were playing in a yard at the rear of a horse corner of Van Brunt and Tremont streets, Red Hook Point, they were precipitated into a cistern by the caving in of...
lead_paragraph: SERIOUS ACCIDENTS--TWO CHILDREN DROWNED,--Yesterday afternoon, while MARY O'BRIEN, three years old, and MARY ANN CURTIS six years old, were playing in a yard at the rear of a horse corner of Van Brunt and Tremont streets, Red Hook Point, they were precipitated into a cistern by the caving in of the pavement, and were drowned before assistance could be rendered them. The water was only eighteen inches deep in the cistern, but it is supposed that they were stunned by the fall.... A German laborer, named CHARLES PRENZER, was seriously injured yesterday by falling through a hoistway in a distillery o??? Remsen-street, E.D. His skull was broken and one arm was fractured.... HENRY TUDOR, an elderly man residing at No. 40 Summit-street, was instantly killed on Sunday night by falling down a flight of steps.

abstract: A decision has just been given by Judge Chum, asero in the County Court of Monroe County, N.Y. which is in effect that a Board of Education has no corporate capacity in which it can be sued. The decision was made in a suit brought by J.W. Bissell for services as an architect rendered some five years since. The Judge intimated that the plaintiff can recover of the City of Rochester if his debt is such a one as the Board had a right to contract. The same decision applies to the Common Council.

abstract: -- Yesterday the special officer at the Central Railroad Depot received a telegraphic dispatch from JOHN MCCORMICK, who lives seven miles from Utica, requesting him to stop his wife if she would arrive in the next train, and deta??? two children she had with her, until he arrived in this city. Upon the arrival of the train the officer went through the cars and succeeded in finding the children, who he took to Troy, and placed them in charge of MCCORMICK's brother, who lives in that city. The husband arrived last evening and at once proceeded to Troy after his children. It seems that MCCORMICK and his wife separated in October last, since which time she had been residing with some friends or Staten Island. ???terday she paid a visit to the house of her husband and in his absence, took the children and started for State. Island with them. Unfortunately for her, her visit ???urned out to be a fruitless one and she was compelled to return to Staten Island without the objects of her journey. -- Albany Statesman, 20th.

abstract: -- The Tribune and the Express have seen fit to publish in their columns a certain "white list" and "black list" of the merchants of this City, which were originally compiled by The Southern Confederacy. We think this publication extremely ill-judged for two reasons. First, because it is not fair to the merchants who are so unceremoniously paraded before the world. The names of those comprised fn the "white list," and consequently commended to patronage at the South, were obtained, so far as we are informed, without any complicity on their part, and the attempt to injure them in their business at the North on account of an impertinent use made of their names by a Southern spy, without any authority of theirs, seems to us unjust in the extreme. In the second place, we object to this republication that it is made with the avowed purpose and with the manifest effect of retaliation. The prescriptive business policy into which certain persons at the South have been betrayed in a moment of irritation, is so absurd and impracticable that it would soon die out of itself if it were not kept alive by counter provocation. The sober second thought and real interest of the South would soon set this matter at rest, and trade would begin again to flow in order through its accustomed channels. Men will be foolishly fiery for a while for the good of the country, when their passions are aroused and their pride piqued, but their "spunk" will be very apt to glimmer out when it is only to be kept glowing to their pecuniary detriment, and proves to be steadily a losing investment of substance and spirit.
lead_paragraph: -- The Tribune and the Express have seen fit to publish in their columns a certain "white list" and "black list" of the merchants of this City, which were originally compiled by The Southern Confederacy. We think this publication extremely ill-judged for two reasons. First, because it is not fair to the merchants who are so unceremoniously paraded before the world. The names of those comprised fn the "white list," and consequently commended to patronage at the South, were obtained, so far as we are informed, without any complicity on their part, and the attempt to injure them in their business at the North on account of an impertinent use made of their names by a Southern spy, without any authority of theirs, seems to us unjust in the extreme. In the second place, we object to this republication that it is made with the avowed purpose and with the manifest effect of retaliation. The prescriptive business policy into which certain persons at the South have been betrayed in a moment of irritation, is so absurd and impracticable that it would soon die out of itself if it were not kept alive by counter provocation. The sober second thought and real interest of the South would soon set this matter at rest, and trade would begin again to flow in order through its accustomed channels. Men will be foolishly fiery for a while for the good of the country, when their passions are aroused and their pride piqued, but their "spunk" will be very apt to glimmer out when it is only to be kept glowing to their pecuniary detriment, and proves to be steadily a losing investment of substance and spirit.

abstract: Mr. DOUGLAS occupied the floor of the United States Senate yesterday, large crowds of the curious thronging the galleries and even the floor, to hear the Northwestern statesman. The immediate topic of the speech was the relation of the Federal Government to the States, and the obligation of...
lead_paragraph: Mr. DOUGLAS occupied the floor of the United States Senate yesterday, large crowds of the curious thronging the galleries and even the floor, to hear the Northwestern statesman. The immediate topic of the speech was the relation of the Federal Government to the States, and the obligation of the Executive, under the Constitution, to repress such incursions from one State to another as that of JOHN BROWN. Mr. DOUGLAS showed that in refusing such aid as Mr. WISE demanded from the President the latter fell short of his duty; and that no power of the National Government is more distinctly defined than its power to prevent domestic invasions. And the practical importance of such authority, Mr. DOUGLAS demonstrated by reference to the growing Anti-Slavery sentiment of the North. The speech was attentively listened to, and repeatedly applauded. In the House, where seats were almost deserted, so general was the desire to hear the Senator from Illinois, Mr. BARKSDALE spoke at some length in the extreme Southern sense; and was followed by Mr. CORWIN in defence of the leading doctrines of Republicanism. Mr. CORWIN had not finished at the adjournment.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN.--Miss MALTILDA HERON'S play of "Lesbia" was produced here last night and attracted a fine audience, both in numbers and in capacity to appreciate and pass just judgment on a new production. Miss HEBON has drawn her material from a drama by VICTOR SEJOURS, and has imitated some-what...
lead_paragraph: WINTER GARDEN.--Miss MALTILDA HERON'S play of "Lesbia" was produced here last night and attracted a fine audience, both in numbers and in capacity to appreciate and pass just judgment on a new production. Miss HEBON has drawn her material from a drama by VICTOR SEJOURS, and has imitated some-what too exactly the length of that distinguished author. The French reckon time by sensations; here we go by the watch, and growl audibly at the end of the third hour. Much cutting will be needed to render "Lesbia" of the proper length for general enjoyment; especially as Miss HERON, even with the present liberal text, is not provided with any unusual opportunities for the display of her peculiar powers.

abstract: At the meeting of the Board' of Supervisors yesterday, a communication was received from the Commissioners of Excise, to the effect that they are prepared to enter up newly one thousand judgments against parties for violation of the license laws. They ask that some arrangements be made with the County Clerk and Clerk of Common Pleas, in relation to the fees. The County Clerk had signified his readiness to file the judgments without fees, provided the Comptroller would so direct, but the Comptroller had declined on the ground that he had no power. The Commissioners, therefore, desired the Board to make some provision in the case, in order to prevent the loss of a large amount of money to the County. The communication was referred.

abstract: The new Senate Chamber at Washington yesterday witneased, for the first time, a scene which recalls the great debates of the nation in that old Hall made illustrious by the eloquence and the patriotism of WEBSTER and CLAY of CALHOUN and BENTON.
lead_paragraph: The new Senate Chamber at Washington yesterday witneased, for the first time, a scene which recalls the great debates of the nation in that old Hall made illustrious by the eloquence and the patriotism of WEBSTER and CLAY of CALHOUN and BENTON. It was crowed in every part, from floor to gallery. The Representatives left their own Hall; the citizens of Washington, the foreign diplomatists, the whole floating population of the Capital, thronged the huge gilded saloon in which the Senators hold their high council, to hear the gravest questions affecting the relations of State with State in the Union discussed by the champion of Popular Sovereignty. Thus much at least it is due to Mr. DOUGLAS to say, that, he dealt with the themes suggested by the crisis in which the nation is now struggling, in a temper and in a tone worthy of their importance. The proposition which he laid before the Senate is one which has already been demanded with less of form and detail by conservative men out of Congress, in speeches made before popular assemblies in various parts of the country, and through the columns of the Press. The Senator from Illinois very briefly, clearly and forcibly stated the case arising out of JOHN BROWN's arrest, between the Governor of a single Commonwealth and the President of the Union. Virginia found herself threatened with invasion, not by a foreign foe, but by an organized band of American citizens from a sister State. On application for protection to the Federal Executive, she was informed that no provision had ever been made for meeting such a contingency. It can hardly be thought discreditable to the sagacity of our fathers that this should be so, since even after the angry sectional collisions of the last few years, the tidings of JOHN BROWN's raid took the whole nation by surprise. But it will be very discreditable to ourselves, as Mr. DOUGLAS boldly and distinctly put it, should we now refuse to meet an issue which has actually arisen, and the recurrence of which cannot be safely regarded as improbable unless measures shall be taken to render it impossible. For while nothing can be more certain than that the attempt to render the Republican Party or its leaders, now dominant at the North, directly responsible for the deliberate conspiracy of JOHN BROWN, was a most senseless and indecent abuse even of the large license of partisan warfare, nothing at the same time can be more clear than that JOHN BROWN's conspiracy would never have been dreamed of, had not a widespread practical hostility to Slavery wherever it exists been developed throughout the Northern States during the fierce sectional conflict which followed the repeal of the Missouri Compromise.

abstract: A curious instance of that cheap Pharisaism which is so common all the world over, and which leads the British Abolitionist to look down with a sort of contemptuous compassion upon his benighted American brother as a...
lead_paragraph: A curious instance of that cheap Pharisaism which is so common all the world over, and which leads the British Abolitionist to look down with a sort of contemptuous compassion upon his benighted American brother as a covenanter with hell, just as it leads the American demagogue to pity his British kinsman as a serf of the "spangled aristocracy," has just occurred in London. Miss SARAH LENOX REMOND, a colored young lady of Massachusetts, who devotes a good deal of her time to the pleasing task of teaching the English idea of freedom to shoot envenomed arrows of scorn at the American fact of Slavery, found herself the other day in the British Capital on her way to Paris, and sent or took her passport to the American Legation for a visa in form. The passport appears to have been regularly issued from the office of the Secretary of State at Washington, and describes Miss REMOND as "a citizen of the United States." On the face of the passport there could be no question as to the right of Miss REMOND to demand a visa from the American representative. But the Secretary at the Legation seems to have been instructed to take his cue from the face of the bearer rather than from that of the document, and he accordingly refused to affix the official certificate to the paper in question. In this refusal he was sustained by his chief, who informed Miss REMOND that it was impossible for him to comply with her demand, without violating injunctions received from the American Government, July 8, 1856. It is sufficiently plain that the American Legation at London really did nothing more than its duty in this case, although it may well be a question whether the Secretary of State has a right to throw the responsibility of criticising and correcting passports signed by himself, upon his representatives abroad. A certificate of citizenship issued in this solemn form by the American Premier, ought not to expose persons who have left their homes, relying upon its validity, to such annoyances as overtook Miss REMOND in London.

abstract: A new club organization has lately been effected in Detroit, having for its design the improvement of trotting stock, and embracing in its plans an extensive enlargement of the present facilities for the cultivation and display of that very popular species of horseflesh. It is composed of gentlemen who are possessed of the means to carry out their projects fully. The necessary funds have been raised by stock subscription, the corporators being some twenty or thirty in number, and a lease of the old Hamtramck course has been obtained. Several thousand dollars will be expended on this ground.

abstract: Yesterday being the day appointed for the commencement of a large number of trials for murder, the Court of Oyer and Terminer was crowded, at the opening, by jurors, witnesses, and interested or curious spectators.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday being the day appointed for the commencement of a large number of trials for murder, the Court of Oyer and Terminer was crowded, at the opening, by jurors, witnesses, and interested or curious spectators. The bench was occupied by Judge INGRAHAM. Besides District-Attorney Waterbury, Mr. John H. Anthon, the new Assistant District-Attorney, vice Mr. John T. Doyle, resigned, was present, and made his first appearance as public prosecutor. The first case called was that of Mortimer Shay, indicted for the murder of John Leary, in Worth-street, on the 23d November, 1859. Mr. H.L. Clinton, counsel for Shay, moved a postponement, on the ground of the absence of two material witnesses, who saw the affray, and whom they had yet been unable to find. The District-Attorney opposed the motion, but the Court granted a postponement till Monday next.

abstract: LONDON, Friday, Jan. 6, 1860. The Rifle Volunteer movement is still on the  increase, but the fructification of the crop of Cadmus is by no means so real or so solid as may be imagined over Europe, except by the best-informed men, or even in England, where popular notions prevail.
lead_paragraph: LONDON, Friday, Jan. 6, 1860. The Rifle Volunteer movement is still on the increase, but the fructification of the crop of Cadmus is by no means so real or so solid as may be imagined over Europe, except by the best-informed men, or even in England, where popular notions prevail. A foolish Lord, one of the modern type of fussy, priggish, conceited, busy noblemen, is doing more to check, and injure the growth of the volunteer corps by his efforts to render them ridiculous in appearance, than the titled utilitarian coxcomb can possibly be aware of. Lord ELCHO has hitherto been connected with arts rather than arms. In the former he has displayed a connoisseurship just sufficient to obtain him the respect of the coteries in London, and the contempt of artists and amateurs on the Continent. That he is a humbug in judgment, and a flunkey in patronage, I scarcely think that MORRIS MOORE, that most renowned and ill-treated art-critic, would deny. There are men born to be wrong, even when most intending to do right. There are insects which perform the functions of life when their brains are removed and replaced by cotton-wool. Among human insects there is often to be seen a melancholy amount of activity coexistent with the normal absence of the cerebral matter. Give such a creature opportunities in the shape of a fortune, a title, a seat in the House, and a diarrhoea loquendi or scribendi, and it is surprising what mischief may be effected by so small a thing.

abstract: SHIPPING TRADE TO CALIFORNIA--There are at present only three ships on the berth in this port for San Francisco, which is the smallest number that has been advertised for the Golden State during the last ten years.
lead_paragraph: SHIPPING TRADE TO CALIFORNIA--There are at present only three ships on the berth in this port for San Francisco, which is the smallest number that has been advertised for the Golden State during the last ten years. This falling off in the demand for ships is due in part to the increase of facilities for the transportation of the valuable and lighter descriptions of freight by the way of Panama, but mainly to the overstocked condition of the California market, in all descriptions of Eastern manufactures. A large portion of mere randon shipments to California, heretofore made with the hope of "hitting a good market," is given up, and the present business is of a legitimate kind, intended to supply accruing wants among the established mercantile houses. The clipper-ship Carrier Dove, of W.T. COLEMAN & Co.'s line, has been receiving cargo for about one week, and is already about two-thirds full. She is a Boston-built ship, of good reputation, and has made several rapid and successful passages to and from the Pacific. Capt. MONTELL has been in command for nearly three years. She is to sail about the 28th inst. The Mary L. Sutton, of SUTTON & Co.'s dispatch line, is also on the berth, advertised to sail about the same time. The only other ship is the Polynesian, advertised by R.M. COOLEY, to sail to-day.

abstract: There are various indications that resolute and persistent attempts are about to be made to deprive Superintendent PILSBURY Of all real authority over the Police force, lodge it once more in the charge of the Commission, and thus bring the whole organization again into ...
lead_paragraph: There are various indications that resolute and persistent attempts are about to be made to deprive Superintendent PILSBURY Of all real authority over the Police force, lodge it once more in the charge of the Commission, and thus bring the whole organization again into complete and direct dependence upon political majorities, to be entirely regulated by political considerations. This attempt originated, so far as appears, with that model of all municipal virtues, Mayor WOOD, who began his term of office by requesting as a "personal favor" that he might be allowed to substitute one Police Captain for another in the command of the City Hall force, and followed up the success of this impertinent interference with a demand to be permitted to select the whole number of the officers detailed to the City Hall service. This demand Mr. PILSBURY very properly refused to comply with, on grounds perfectly respectful to the Mayor and connected with the exigencies of the Police Department. Thereupon Mr. WOOD, taking counsel with Commissioners STRANAHAN and BOWEN, procured the passage of resolutions, the tendency of which is simply to strip the Police Superintendent of all real authority over the force confided to his care. Now, as we cordially agree with Mayor WOOD in his loudly professed respect for a "one man power," and believe a force like the Police to be peculiarly adapted for its exercise, and as we furthermore consider Mr. PILSBURY to be the most efficient head the Police has ever had, we need hardly say that we deprecate in the strongest manner any interference with him until his own distinctly proved misconduct shall make interference necessary. It seems to be the inevitable fate of all Boards and Commissions in this unhappy country, and at this juncture of time, to be split up into at least two political parties, each of which is guided in all its acts by the sole consideration of their bearing on the next Presidential election, and on the question of Slavery. When any body of men, in such a perfectly frantic condition of mind, undertakes to interfere with the internal discipline of a military corps, the result is certain to be the destruction of all discipline, and the growth in its place of corruption and insubordination in all possible forms. The duty of a Police Commission is to indicate generally the policy to be pursued by their commanding officer; to supervise expenses, and to try delinquents. They may point out the duties of the Police -- but how those duties are to be performed, what men shall perform them, and what rules are necessary to secure efficiency, ought to be absolutely none of their business. The Superintendent ought, on all these points, to have an entire discretion, and to be held strictly responsible. It may perhaps be in the nature of news to the present Police Commission, to tell them that when an order is sent by a General of Division to have a certain service performed by a certain number of men, it would be a rank insult for him to ignore the existence of the General of Brigade and the Colonel of the regiment, and select the companies for the work himself, and that no army could be held together for a month under such a system.

abstract: WALLACK'S THEATRE.--An extremely clever version of OCTAVE FREUILLET'S "Romance of a Poor Young Man" was produced here last night. It has been written in collaboratin by Messrs. PIEREEPONT EDWARDS and LESTER WALLACK, and so well that it cannot ...
lead_paragraph: WALLACK'S THEATRE.--An extremely clever version of OCTAVE FREUILLET'S "Romance of a Poor Young Man" was produced here last night. It has been written in collaboratin by Messrs. PIEREEPONT EDWARDS and LESTER WALLACK, and so well that it cannot fail to become a standard piece at this popular and elegant place of amusement -- the only place, we may add, where a work so peculiarly domestic could be produced with entire effect. The difficulties which a dramatist experiences in fitting a narrative for the stage are often underrated. Condensation in all literary work is a task which few can perform satisfactorily, and the few that succeed in discharging it with a proper regard to dramatic effect, never fail of success.

abstract: MR. SIDDONS' LECTURE.--Mr. SIDDONS is an English gentleman who has just arrived from the old country, and has managed, within the last few days, to acquire, by advertisement, considerable celebrity as a lecturer. He delivered an address last night in Clinton Hall to an audience which, though not large, was usually given to compliment.
lead_paragraph: MR. SIDDONS' LECTURE.--Mr. SIDDONS is an English gentleman who has just arrived from the old country, and has managed, within the last few days, to acquire, by advertisement, considerable celebrity as a lecturer. He delivered an address last night in Clinton Hall to an audience which, though not large, was usually given to compliment. The subject of his discourse was, "The way to Travel in the Old World." His remarks were devoted in the main to a description of his personal experiences as a traveling physician in the remoter regions of the Eastern Continent. He alluded incidentally, however, to the requirements which foreign travel for its enjoyment necessarily presupposes. First, he recommended a sound condition of body, then a satisfied state of mind and a knowledge of at least the rudimentary facts of physiology, chemistry, botany, geology and geography; and finally, a thorough love of the Bible, which was not alone the traveler's best companion but his best consoler. His style is chatty, genial, rather prolix, but not unpleasant. At the close of his lecture a motion asking for its repetition was adopted unanimously.

abstract: -- The Abolitionists on Monday evening held a large meeting at Concert Hall, Poughkeepsie, at which AARON M. POWELL and PARKER PILSBURY delivered extended addresses, and a discussion between the friends and opponents of the Abolition movement took place. There was much interruption and confusion at the meeting. Yesterday afternoon another meeting was held, at which the same speakers spoke, and SUSAN B. ANTHONY addressed the audience on "Woman's Rights." The Convention was to hold its final session the same evening.

abstract: PATRICK KELLY, living in Roxbury, Mass., after laboring under great depression of spirits for several days finally determined to commit suicide, and as a preliminary step arranged all his business matters. Then having procured a pistol he loaded it with four bullets, and having retired to his room, seated himself upon his bed, carefully tucked up his under garment and shirt, and placed the pistol against the pit of the stomach and fired. The weapon was held in such a manner that the balls passed entirely through his body and came out through his shoulders and lodged in his undershirt. As soon as the pistol was discharged KELLY threw it from him and fell backward upon the bed, where he was found by his friends. He survived half an hour after the occurrence. He was about sixty years of age, and has left a wife and six children.

abstract: DEMOCRATIC CONGRESSIONAL CONVENTION. -- The First District Congressional Convention, to elect delegates to the Charleston Convention, was held yesterday, at DURLAND's Hotel, in Jamaica. Eighteen delegates were present. The Convention organized by electing the following officers: Chairman, JOHN G. LAMDERTSON, of Queens County; Secretaries, CORNELIUS T. BERGEN, of Kings County, and CHARLES H. CONLEY, of Suffolk County. J.H. BROWER, of Flushing, was elected as one of the delegates, by acclamation. The Convention then proceeded to ballot for a second delegate. The leading candidates were EPHRAIM CLARK, M.D., of Richmond County; GEORGE HOWELL, M.D., of Suffolk County; and Mr. CHURCH, of Queens County. Several ballots were had without any choice, when Dr. HOWELL withdrew in favor of Dr. CLARK, and on the next ballot Dr. CLARK was elected as second delegate. Messrs. CHURCH and DE BEVOISE were elected alternates.

abstract: The question of passports for colored persons, inhabitants of the United States, which has just been brought up in a practical way by the correspondence of Miss SARAH LENOX REMOND with tho American Legation at London, deserves the serious attention of the Department of State. As we yesterday observed, in commenting ...
lead_paragraph: The question of passports for colored persons, inhabitants of the United States, which has just been brought up in a practical way by the correspondence of Miss SARAH LENOX REMOND with tho American Legation at London, deserves the serious attention of the Department of State. As we yesterday observed, in commenting upon this case, it is equally unjust to persons bearing official passports from the Secretary of State and leaving their homes on the faith of such documents, that they should find themselves met at the first American Legation to which they apply abroad, with an invalidation of their papers; and unfair to our diplomatic agents abroad that they should be required to assume the odium of doing a very unpleasant duty, which need never have been thrust upon them at all, had the Home Government attended properly to its own affairs.

abstract: The favorite steamship Baltic has achieved another rapid passage, having left Aspinwall on the afternoon of the 17th, and reached New-York last evening. She brings $1,760,000 in treasure, and the passengers which left San Francisco on the 5th inst. Among the passengers from the Isthmus is Mr. Z.B. CALVERLY, Secretary of the American Legation at Lima, who returns to announce the definite refusal of the Peruvian Government to respond ...
lead_paragraph: The favorite steamship Baltic has achieved another rapid passage, having left Aspinwall on the afternoon of the 17th, and reached New-York last evening. She brings $1,760,000 in treasure, and the passengers which left San Francisco on the 5th inst. Among the passengers from the Isthmus is Mr. Z.B. CALVERLY, Secretary of the American Legation at Lima, who returns to announce the definite refusal of the Peruvian Government to respond to the demands of the United States for indemnity in several cases submitted through Mr. CLAY. It is presumed that coercion will be required to obtain any satisfaction whatever. General CASTILLA remains at Guayaquil, where he has been visited by Gen. FRANCO, one of the rival Presidents of the distracted Republic of Ecuador. It is reported that Guayaquil has been ceded to Peru, by this partisan leader. From Peru, there are items of interest. The Congressional elections were over. Important discoveries of silver mines, and of a shorter route to the navigable waters of the Amazon had been made. CASTILLA, URETA and ECHINIQUE, in the South, are actively plotting against the present Government, and expect to be joined by General SAN ROMAN, in which case ECHINIQUE, it is said, will declare openly against CASTILLA. The French claim against Peru was paid by CASTILLA, who sent the money ($8,000) from Guayaquil as soon as he learned that the Vice-President had refused to pay it. Affairs in Chili, with the exception of some disturbances on the Araucanian frontier, were tranquil. The revolution in New-Grenada had been brought to a close. The capture of Barranguilla, on the 9th ult., placed the Secessionists in full possession of Bolivar, and it is not thought probable that the Central Government will interpose to enforce the return of the State to the Federal Union.

abstract: The holidays are over and we are fairly embarked in the business and pursuits of a New Year. It came in blubbering like a boy the first time he is sent to school, and the almanac would have said, "showery about these days," in other words, it rained a little and was generally muggy and "soppy."

abstract: Mr. Wm. H. Nobles, of St. Paul, in reply to a letter of inquiry from Dr. T.E. Massey, of the Land office at Forest City, states that the white pines in Minnesota are not so well adapted for masts and spars as those which grow in some other parts of the country, but that the Norways are unexcelled. The sizes are from 3 to 3 1/2 feet diameter at the stump, 75 to 80 feet long, 18 to 20 Inches diameter at the top, and any size required under.

abstract: We are glad to see that Mr. DELAVAN, the City Inspector, has devoted a paragraph in his report to the car nuisance on the City Railroads. He calls the attention of the Common Council to the cramming system as now pursued on all of them, as most injurious to the public health. He alleges that the manner in ...
lead_paragraph: We are glad to see that Mr. DELAVAN, the City Inspector, has devoted a paragraph in his report to the car nuisance on the City Railroads. He calls the attention of the Common Council to the cramming system as now pursued on all of them, as most injurious to the public health. He alleges that the manner in which passengers are packed into the interior by the conductors, and compelled to stand there with closed windows and doors, makes the atmosphere so foul that the hour's ride, when the body is fatigued by the day's work, and its vitality lowered, is most injurious to health, and the susceptibility to contagion is thereby greatly increased. Moreover, as if they were determined to provide for every contingency, and harass the wretched passengers to the bitter end, the conductors frequently stop -- according to Mr. DELAVAN -- and take in persons afflicted with infectious diseases, on their way to the Hospital, and crowd them in upon the dense steaming mass of mortality which they have already caged up inside. We have no doubt that many a man who goes to his grave with a fever, bilious disorder, or lung or throat disease, owes his death to his occasional rides in bad weather in the disgusting little dens which the avenue railroads run for our accommodation; and many another has to thank the close contact with diseased persons, in the total absence of fresh air, which he incurred in the same place for a variety of complaints, if less fatal, not less disagreeable.

abstract: ARREST OF AN ALLEGED SWINDLER. -- A young man giving his name as DAVID MERRITT was arrested yesterday on a charge of having swindled various parties, both in the county and City, out of different amounts by methods which the ingenuity of a scoundrel alone could suggest. Messrs. MANY & LEWIS, jewelers in Grand-street, Messrs. HOYT, BADGER & DILLON, jewelers in Fulton-st., and Messrs. R. FERRIS & Co., jewelers in Eighth-avenue, are said to have lost by exchanging goods with him for worthless checks. His latest attempt was to swindle parties in the country by writing to them of mythical express packages, which they might have by sending money to cover the charges. He was arrested while inquiring at the Post-office for letters addressed to one of his numerous aliases.

abstract: On Monday, both branches of the Virginia Legislature passed the bill appropriating $150,000 to defray the expenses of crushing the Harper's Ferry Rebellion. This bill appoints the Secretary of the Commonwealth, the Auditor and Attorney-General a Board to audit the claims and issue warrants to be paid by the Auditor, provided not more than $150,000 be so paid; and that all claims shall be presented within six months; and provided, when doubts arise as to the claims, they shall be reported to the House. The bill also excepts, and requires to be reported to the Legislature, the claims of all general, staff and field officers, and all railroad companies.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, both branches of the Virginia Legislature passed the bill appropriating $150,000 to defray the expenses of crushing the Harper's Ferry Rebellion. This bill appoints the Secretary of the Commonwealth, the Auditor and Attorney-General a Board to audit the claims and issue warrants to be paid by the Auditor, provided not more than $150,000 be so paid; and that all claims shall be presented within six months; and provided, when doubts arise as to the claims, they shall be reported to the House. The bill also excepts, and requires to be reported to the Legislature, the claims of all general, staff and field officers, and all railroad companies.

abstract: -- Another Spanish-American difficulty has risen fairly above the diplomatic horizon. Mr. CAVERLY, the Secretary of our Legation at Lima, has come home in the Baltic, bringing the peremptory refusal of President CASTILLA, of Peru, to liquidate the claims pressed on his Government by our own. This action of the Peruvian President cannot be trifled with. It involves the dignity of the Union, and the nature of the claims thus contemptuously treated should be fully understood at once by the whole country.

abstract: Hamllin Blake et al. vs. Hugh Maxwell. -- This WAS an action brought to recover back duties imposed by the de'cudant as Collector of the Port, upon sheathing zinc, imported by the plaintiffs, who paid the duties under protest. The plaintiff claimed that the article should come in free of duty, as being sheathing metal for ships, while the defendant claimed that it was liable to a duty of 15 per cent. as sheet zinc. The points of law involved having been determined in another case formerly tried in this Court, there was no question but whether the article involved in this case was the same as in the other, and the Jury finding that it was, a verdict was rendered in favor of the plaintiffs for an amount to be settled by a reference.
lead_paragraph: Hamllin Blake et al. vs. Hugh Maxwell. -- This WAS an action brought to recover back duties imposed by the de'cudant as Collector of the Port, upon sheathing zinc, imported by the plaintiffs, who paid the duties under protest. abstract: FESTIVAL OF THE BURNS CLUB.--The Burns Club of the City of New-York held its anniversary last evening in honor of the birthday of ROBERT BURNS, at the Pacific Hotel. About one hundred and fifty guests were present. Mr. J. NICHOLSON, the President of the Club, presided, assisted by the VicePresidents.
lead_paragraph: FESTIVAL OF THE BURNS CLUB.--The Burns Club of the City of New-York held its anniversary last evening in honor of the birthday of ROBERT BURNS, at the Pacific Hotel. About one hundred and fifty guests were present. Mr. J. NICHOLSON, the President of the Club, presided, assisted by the VicePresidents. After the blessing was pronounced by Mr. GEORGE BRODIE, they took their seats at the table, which was spread with a substantial meal. The "Address to the haggis," a ceremony never omitted on such occasions, was pronounced by JOHN ROBERTSON. The dinner disposed of, the President announced the regular toasts of the evening, which he prefaced with appropriate remarks. These were responded to in the most patriotic and eloquent terms by the different gentlemen to whom each part had been assigned. In responding to the first toast, -- "The day we celebrate," Mr. GEORGE BRODIE drew a picture of the infancy of the great poet, his early struggles with hardship and poverty, the trials of his manhood, and his final triumphs as the poet of nature, all which were appropriately illustrated upon the canvas before them. "The genius of Burns," "The Land we live in," "The illustrious Sons of Scotland," and "The Lasses," all found appropriate responses, interspersed with songs and music, which occupied the company until a late hour, when they separated in the happiest of humors.

abstract: The value of Mr. O'CONOR'S labors in the Court of Appeals on behalf of Slavery, on Tuesday, must of course be left to the estimation of the Judges, and the task of refuting his arguments of necessity devolves on the opposing counsel. But there are one or two passages in his speech, as published by us yesterday, which the public will certainly set down as among ...
lead_paragraph: The value of Mr. O'CONOR'S labors in the Court of Appeals on behalf of Slavery, on Tuesday, must of course be left to the estimation of the Judges, and the task of refuting his arguments of necessity devolves on the opposing counsel. But there are one or two passages in his speech, as published by us yesterday, which the public will certainly set down as among the most curious of the very curious things the Courts of Justice in every country contribute to the national collection of jests. Mr. O'CONOR's method of disposing of the Somerset case, by an attack on Lord MANSFIELD, is not only a novelty in judicial procedure, but one of the best jokes of the season. We intend no disrespect to anybody when we say that we should feel that we were insulting the memory of the great Chief-Justice by attempting to defend him against the allegations contained in the extemporaneous harangue of Mr. CHARLES O'CONOR. Any one who undertakes such a task must have a very much lower estimate than we of the value of the unqualified admiration of the whole civilized world, ripened by the gradual verdict of nearly eighty years, and a much higher appreciation, not perhaps of Mr. O'CONOR's talents, as a common lawyer, but certainly of the importance of enjoying his good opinion. In fact, we feel no doubt whatever that, even for some time after the Lemmon slave-case shall have been decided, Lord MANSFIELD's name will continue to flourish with the reputation which has so long crowned his tomb, of having been the ablest lawyer, the most upright judge, the most graceful legal writer, and the most accomplished judicial scholar who has adorned the Bench of any civilized country, since the days of the immortal D'AURESSEAU. For these, as well as for a variety of other reasons, we also recommend the colored public of Brooklyn to restrain its righteous indignation, and let Mr. O'CONOR pass for this once without a repetition of the vigorous denunciations with which they visited the heresies uttered by him at the Union meeting at the Academy of Music.

abstract: Mr. ASHMORE, of South Carolina, yesterday called the attention of the house of Representatives to a, series of silly and indecent impertinences aimed at Hon. Mr. PRYOR of Virginia, in what purported to be a report of the proceedings of the House on the previous day, is the New-York Herald.
lead_paragraph: Mr. ASHMORE, of South Carolina, yesterday called the attention of the house of Representatives to a, series of silly and indecent impertinences aimed at Hon. Mr. PRYOR of Virginia, in what purported to be a report of the proceedings of the House on the previous day, is the New-York Herald. He very justly stigmatized this offensive drivel as an insult to the whole House, and demanded the expulsion of the reporter of the journal which had thus disgraced itself and, so far as lay in its power, the whole American Press. A further discussion of the matter, however, revealed the fact that all this vile twaddle had been interpolated at the Herald office in this City, into what was published here as a "special telegraphic dispatch" from Washington City; and the unhappy reporter was therefore exonerated from the reproach and ignominy which would otherwise most properly have attached to him. The matter, however, will doubtless be more decisively and fully dealt with when the House shall be finally organized -- if that millennial time, indeed, should ever arrive.

abstract: WASHINGTON, Monday, Jan. 23, 1860. To-day commences the eighth week of this,  Congressional struggle, and if an election of Speaker be not had before next Saturday, the conflict will exceed in duration that which resulted in the election of N.P. BANES. All sides begin to weary of the profitless and exhausting war. Many members begin to lack their pay.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Monday, Jan. 23, 1860.

abstract: A summons, says the Boston Traveller of Tuesday evening, for S.G. HOWE to appear before the Harper's Ferry Investigating Committee, at Washington, was yesterday left at the residence of that gentleman. Dr. HOWE had just left for Canada, to fulfill an engagement for an exhibition by the blind pupils of the Perkins Asylum. JAMES JACKSON, an uncle of J. MERRIAM, to whom, as it appeared by certain documents, he had sent money, was also yesterday summoned before the same Committee. F.E. SANBORN, of Concord, Mass., has also been summoned to Washington to testify before the Committee.

abstract: Mr. TOOMBS was intensely solemn in the Senate on Tuesday. He shook his portentous head, and pronounced his mild ultimatum, to the simple effect that, if the North would succumb--give up all its political convictions, and submit to the gentle and benignant sway of the Senator from Georgia--he would graciously consent to remain in the Confederacy;
lead_paragraph: Mr. TOOMBS was intensely solemn in the Senate on Tuesday. He shook his portentous head, and pronounced his mild ultimatum, to the simple effect that, if the North would succumb--give up all its political convictions, and submit to the gentle and benignant sway of the Senator from Georgia--he would graciously consent to remain in the Confederacy; otherwise he would be obliged to retire and set up for himself. Not only did he play the prophet of evil to the country, but he declared that he would himself become the author of the calamities he foretold. He would, Samson-like, "pull down the pillars of this glorious temple of liberty, and involve all in one common ruin." Many persons, perhaps, have already pronounced the speech of the honorable Senator a fearful omen of coming mischief; we do not so regard it. There is too much method in its madness for us to put full faith in all the revolutionary and bloody designs it parades before the country, with such minuteness of detail and such logical coherence. It lacks all the spontaneity and inspiration of genuine passion. It is, we fancy, a pure threat -- a cool, calculated, pre-determined menace, not forced to the lips by the pressure upon the soul of an intolerable grievance, but the studied rhetorical display of one who has his assigned part to fill. It seems to be produced according to a preconcerted programme, and if we had the book of stage directions we should expect to find in it, "Enter TOOMBS, breathing forth fire and slaughter." Its thunder has none of the grand roll of the artillery of the skies; it is manipulated from behind the scenes; -- we cannot even detect in it a sulphurous smell; and we seem to recognize the clanging traditional bang-whang of the tremendous tin. The play is put upon the stage for performance till November next, when the curtain is to drop, and exeunt omnes for four years.

abstract: Com. STOCKTON, of New-Jersey, in compliance with the request of Messrs. J.R. ROBERTS, J.B. GRAHAM, ABRAM REEVES, and other prominent citizens of Princeton, has expressed his views of "the dangers which threaten the Republic," in a letter of three columns. The Commodore explains his refusal to participate in the Union meetings recently held in ...
lead_paragraph: Com. STOCKTON, of New-Jersey, in compliance with the request of Messrs. J.R. ROBERTS, J.B. GRAHAM, ABRAM REEVES, and other prominent citizens of Princeton, has expressed his views of "the dangers which threaten the Republic," in a letter of three columns. The Commodore explains his refusal to participate in the Union meetings recently held in New-Jersey, by declaring that such convocations, composed promiscuously of all parties, are, in his opinion, "fallacious and calculated to deceive;" especially so when members of the Republican Party take part in them. The only description of Union meeting with which the Commodore has any degree of sympathy, he declares to be "one which should be so constituted as to speak substantial words of fraternity and encouragement to the South, and which should say that the Fugitive Slave law is right, and should be executed; which should say that Southern men may lawfully take their slaves into the Territories, and that the decisions of the Supreme Court must and shall be considered the supreme law of the land."

abstract: The case of the United States against Henry Williams came up before Mr. Commissioner BETES yesterday, the defendant being charged with taking from the Post-office a letter belongtng to Francis A. Wheeler, and atterwards appropriating about $3,000, obtained through Adams and Co.'s Express Company, the avails of a note which had been discounted of the Bank of Norwalk is favor of the said Wheeler.
lead_paragraph: The case of the United States against Henry Williams came up before Mr. Commissioner BETES yesterday, the defendant being charged with taking from the Post-office a letter belongtng to Francis A. Wheeler, and atterwards appropriating about $3,000, obtained through Adams and Co.'s Express Company, the avails of a note which had been discounted of the Bank of Norwalk is favor of the said Wheeler. Mr. Wheeler was the first witness called. He testified that he had known defendant for about two years, and had business transactions with him, Williams being engaged in the milk business, and acting as his (Wheeler's) agent. About the 14th of December he drew a note for $3,000, which, he desired to get discounted at the Norwalk Bank, and inclosed it to the Cashier, requesting the favor of a discount "if it was convenient." The note was dated Dec. 19, payable three months from date, at the Pacific Bank, New-York, and indorsed, by Charles Johnson, to whose order it was made payable. A note was shown to witness, and identified as the one he had drawn, with the exception of the first word, "three," which had been altered to "two" months. Getting no reply from the Bank, he called at the Pacific Bank and made inquiry concerning the note, but could get no satisfactory clue to it. He wrote several letters to the Cashier, requesting him to return the note, if it could not be discounted. Two days afterwards he met the Cashier of the Norwalk Bank, who told him his note had been discounted, and the money sent to him by Express. Both then went to Adams' Express Company, to inquire for the missing money. Here they ascertained that the money had been received and receipted for by a person signing the name of F.W. Wheeler. Witness had frequently seen defendant write, and had seen specimens of his handwriting. A piper was here shown and identified by witness as the handwriting of Williams. It was in the following words:

abstract: Nine clergymen of the Roman Church in America, styling themselves in a rather sumptuous fashion, the "Bishops of the Ecclesiastical Province of New-York, in Provincial Council assembled," have just issued a long and very elaborate pronounciamiento in favor of tho maintenance of the temporal rights of the ...
lead_paragraph: Nine clergymen of the Roman Church in America, styling themselves in a rather sumptuous fashion, the "Bishops of the Ecclesiastical Province of New-York, in Provincial Council assembled," have just issued a long and very elaborate pronounciamiento in favor of tho maintenance of the temporal rights of the Bishop of Rome, as a sovereign prince on the soil of Italy. In taking this step, these personages have but followed the example set them by their colleagues of the French and Irish Churches, and their action is avowedly intended to exert some measure of influence, more or less important, upon the minds of the rulers of Europe in the Congress which is expected shortly to assemble at Paris. It may possibly occur, not only to Protestant, but to Catholic laymen, here, as it has very distinctly occurred to Catholic laymen both in France and Ireland, that an explanation is required of this extraordinary zeal, on the part of men whose allegiance can in no just sense of that word be due to any sovereign but the States to which they are civilly subject, in behalf of the worldly position of a prince whoso claims to reverence are founded upon his pretensions to represent a Master whose "kingdom was not of this world." No such explanation is to be found in any part of the singularly loose, diffuse, clumsy and inaccurate paper which the nine American indorsers of the Papal throne have issued. The zeal is asserted, not explained. We are gravely informed that "an attack on the States of the Church shall be considered as an attack upon the nine Bishops and their rights," but we are not informed, either gravely or quizzically, in what way the rights of nine residents of the United States, subject to our laws and entitled to our protection, are to be imperiled by any imaginable invasion of the territories acquired by the Papal Government, through precisely such a series of usurpations, conflicts, intrigues and submissions as the territories held now by any other European Crown. It is upon this point, exactly, that we need the light which these nine candlesticks of the Church decline to vouchsafe to us. For we will not do Archbishop HUGHES and his suffragans the injustice of supposing that they have been at the pains of composing this long and solemn document merely as a literary pastime. They have, no doubt, borne in mind the actual position of affairs in Rome; and they have wished to be of some practical weight in the present crisis of the Papal history. This object they can hardly expect to attain by the force of their argumentation or the terror of their titles. If they had any purpose in view beyond that of airing their style, they must have hoped to bring the popular feeling of Americans, or at least of American Catholics, to sustain them in their fulminating declaration, that when "an attempt is made to destroy the sovereignty of the Holy Father, or diminish its extent, it is their right, as free American citizens, as well as prelates of the Church of God, to protest and resist."

abstract: Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, repelling the assaults of Messrs. DOUGLAS and TOOMBS upon the Republican Party, occupied the attention of the Senate yesterday. He entered into a recapitulation of the leading points in the history of the Slavery question from the Revolutionary period to the present time, tracing the circumstances among ...
lead_paragraph: Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, repelling the assaults of Messrs. DOUGLAS and TOOMBS upon the Republican Party, occupied the attention of the Senate yesterday. He entered into a recapitulation of the leading points in the history of the Slavery question from the Revolutionary period to the present time, tracing the circumstances among which the Republican organization originated, and its objects and results. He then turned upon the Democratic side, and charged it with employing the threat of disunion as it did in 1856, for purely partisan purposes. Messrs. CLINGMAN and IVERSON participated in the discussion as Senator WILSON proceeded, and the conversation became extremely animated. The Senate adjourned without an Executive Session. In the House, Mr. BRISTOW, of Tennessee, uttered some patriotic remarks in behalf of the Union, and after him, Mr. KEITT controverted some of the positions assumed by Mr. CORWIN in his speeches of Monday and Tuesday. Mr. ASHMORE, of South Carolina, moved a resolution in favor of excluding the Reporters of the New-York Herald from the Gallery, on the ground that their reports were a libel and shame inflicted upon the proceedings and upon the body. The resolution was not, however, pressed. A resolution was offered by Mr. ETHEREDGE, of Tennessee, that for a fortnight the House should cease talking, and confine itself to voting. The resolution was adopted, with the important modification that three ballots at least should be had daily, leaving the remaining hours for talk. One ballot was had on the spot, resulting, for SHERMAN, 105; for BOCOCK, 51: for SMITH, of N.C., 26 -- the remainder scattering. Necessary to a choice, 108.

abstract: The bark Laurel, Capt. PIERCE, cleared yesterday, and will leave to-day for Port-au-Prince. Hayti, having on board as passengers, eighty one free persons on color, who are emigrating from this State to try their chances in Hayti. These people are all from the Opelousas parishes, and all cultivators--well versed in farming, and in all the mechanical arts connected with a farm.
lead_paragraph: The bark Laurel, Capt. PIERCE, cleared yesterday, and will leave to-day for Port-au-Prince. Hayti, having on board as passengers, eighty one free persons on color, who are emigrating from this State to try their chances in Hayti. These people are all from the Opelousas parishes, and all cultivators--well versed in farming, and in all the mechanical arts connected with a farm. Among them are brickmakers, blacksmiths, wheelwrights, carpenters, &c. Some of them are proficient weavers, who have long been employed making the stuff called Attakapas cottonade, so favorably Known in the market. They take along with them the necessary machinery for that trade, and all sorts of agricultural and mechanical implements.
