abstract: At 8 o'clock last evening the coach-lamp factory of HENNRY EDWARD, on the first floor of No. 66 Duane-street, was discovered to be on fire. The flames extended to the third floor and basement, causing the following losses: Mr. EDWARD, $2,000, insured; A.W. METCALF manufacturer of brass faucets, $500, insured; Messrs. STRENLINS & PALMER, manufacturers of chocolate, $200, insured; Mr. JAMES R. RYAN, bookbinder, $2,000, insured in the American, Exchange and Hamilton Insurance Companies. Messrs. JAMES CONNOR & SONS and G.P. PUTMAN & Co. had books in Mr. RYAN's bindery, which are injured to the amount of $7,000, partially insured.... About midnight, on Tuesday, the fancy dry goods store of Mr. S.S. WALKER, No. 214 Sixth-avenue, was injured by fire to the extent of $1,000. The stock suffered to the amount of $800, and the building $200....Four horses, in a stable at No. 235 West Sixteenth-street, were suffocated by the building catching fire about six o'clock yesterday morning. They were valued at $1,000. Messrs. D.S. ORMSBY & SON, manufacturers of soda water and root beer, also lost $1,000; not insured....A young lady, while going out of the store of CHRISTIAN KRENSHER, No. 46 Lewis-street, accidentally knocked a fluid can on the stove. The flames which originated in this accident consumed property valued at $100; insured in the Rutgers Insurance Company. The building was injured to the extent of $100....Mr. BERNARD BARONN, dealer in ribbons and millinery goods, at No. 12 John-street, had his stock injured last evening by fire to the amount of $300; insured....The planing and moulding mill of Messrs. WELLS & CONKLING, NO. 322 West Twenty-eighth-street, caught fire by a spark from a foundry near by, and was injured to the extent of $3,000; uninsured.

abstract: Mr. BENJAMIN E. MACKIE, a lawyer doing business at No. 56 Wall-street, committed suicide yesterday by taking laudanum while laboring under an attack of delirium tremens....META C. WARD, a little girl, 3 years of age, living at No. 545 Greenwich-street, was fatally scalded on Wednesday by the overturning of a kettle of hot water. Verdicts of death by suicide and accident were given in the respective cases.

abstract: -- Capt. JENSEN, of the brig Conquest, from Angostura, arrived yesterday morning, brings dates to Dec. 24. The revolution was still going on, without any decisive results. The navigation of the liver was somewhat impeded, thereby preventing the forwarding of merchandise for vessels in want of cargo. The British gunboat Skipjack was in Angostura, from Trinidad, and would remain some time in port.

lead_paragraph: The New-Orleans Della, of the 19th, brings us the decision of Judge McCaleb, of the United States Court there, in favor of the patent of Horace H. Day, Mr. Day had brought suit against thirty-seven leading firms there, and the ease of L.W. Lyons Co., by consent, was made a test case. Hence, an injunction was granted in all the suits, restraining shirred defendants from making using or vending shirred or corrugated elastic goods of every description which contain vulcanized India-rubber, whether cemented, woven, sewed, or otherwise made, without hiving first obtained a license from Mr. Day.

abstract: -- Our readers, we trust, will not forget that this exquisite work of art is to remain on exhibition in this City only a few days longer. Boston clamors for its presence; and on Saturday next, the 28th instant, the doors of Mr. SCHAUS must positively close upon this vision of pure poetic grace and true artistic power. The statue is the property of a fortunate gentleman, who cannot be expected to give up always to mankind what he has been so happy and so wise as to secure for himself.

abstract: YOUTHFUL BURGLARS ARRESTED.--Three boys, named JOHN JOHNSON, JAMES KELLY and IGNATIUS SPHAZIL, were brought before Justice CORNWELL, yesterday, and committed in full to answer several charges preferred against them by different merchants doing business on Atlantic-street. The accused are members of a gang of youthful thieves located in the Second and Fifth Wards. .
lead_paragraph: YOUTHFUL BURGLARS ARRESTED.--Three boys, named JOHN JOHNSON, JAMES KELLY and IGNATIUS SPHAZIL, were brought before Justice CORNWELL, yesterday, and committed in full to answer several charges preferred against them by different merchants doing business on Atlantic-street. The accused are members of a gang of youthful thieves located in the Second and Fifth Wards. The oldest of the gang is not over eighteen years of age, and the youngest is ten years old.

abstract: Hon. F.P. BLAIR, JR., of Missouri, lectured last evening in the Cooper Institute, in compliance with the invitation of an association of Republicaus, who, in the campaign of 1856, assumed the title of the "Young Men's Freemont and Dayton Club." His audience was large, though not sufficient to fill the Hall. It was, however, exceedingly enthusiastic.
lead_paragraph: Hon. F.P. BLAIR, JR., of Missouri, lectured last evening in the Cooper Institute, in compliance with the invitation of an association of Republicaus, who, in the campaign of 1856, assumed the title of the "Young Men's Freemont and Dayton Club." His audience was large, though not sufficient to fill the Hall. It was, however, exceedingly enthusiastic. He was cheered throughout with a vehemence that would challenge a parallel. Among the audience were Ex-Governor KING, (who was cheered,) Mr. DAVID DUDLEY FIELD, Mr. BLUNT, many gentlemen known as active, if not prominent, members of the party with whose aims Mr. BLAIR has identified himself, and, strange to relate, Ex-Governor SEYMOUR. Mr. HIRAM BARNEY was elected Chairman, and made a brief introductory address.

abstract: A holiday absence from London prevented my despatching my usual letter yesterday. abstract: STEAMSHIP SERVICE. -- Notice has been received at the Post-office Department of the withdrawal of the steamship Tennessee from the New-Orleans and Vera Cruz route, where she has been temporarily employed in transporting the mails semi-monthly for the Postages as compensation, under act of June 14, 1858. The proprietor announces that he has been compelled to abandon this service on account of the by the insufficiency of the mail compensation as restricted by the aforesaid act, the business between the two ort not warranting the running of steamers unless they are aided by a remunerative mail contract. He expresses the hope that Congress will appreciate the necessity of making such special provision for the mail service on this route as will enable him to run his steamers without loss: and states that when such provision is made he will be prepared to put the service again in operation. -- Constitution.

abstract: REV. FREDERICK D. HUNTINGTON, D.D., has resigned his office as Preacher to the University, and Plummer Professor of Christian Morals at Harvard. This course of Prof. HUNTINGTON will doubtless tend to allay in a great degree the unfortunate state of feeling existing among the students at Cambridge in regard to the religious exercises and services of the College. As matters have stood the past two years, the preaching of "The Preacher" has been in vain. -- Boston Journal, Jan. 26.

abstract: John B. Livingston, a letter-carrier for Boyd's City Express, was taken to the Ninth Precinct Station house on Wednesday night, on a charge of having been found drunk in the street. A search of his pockets resulted in the discovery of twenty-one letters, from one of which, addressed to Dr. John B. Dodge, $2 had been abstracted. The prisoner admitted that he had taken the money from the letter, but disclaimed any intention to steal it. He also acknowledged having taken a check for $85, which was found in his pocket, from a letter that had been placed in one of Boyd's boxes at the St. Nicholas Hotel. In the morning Livingston was taken before Justice QUACKENBUSH, by whom he was fully committed for trial. All the letters were restored to Mr. John F. Boyd, the proprietor of the express.

abstract: From a private source at Acapulco, we learn only the artillery of the Liberal army, numbering about 2,000 troops, was engaged in the battle of the 21st, the main body of the troops, under ROCHA ROJAS, having failed to come up, owing, as was believed, to treachery. The artillery, which was under the command of Col. HAILE, an American, from San
lead_paragraph: From a private source at Acapulco, we learn only the artillery of the Liberal army, numbering about 2,000 troops, was engaged in the battle of the 21st, the main body of the troops, under ROCHA ROJAS, having failed to come up, owing, as was believed, to treachery. The artillery, which was under the command of Col. HAILE, an American, from San Francisco, was cut to pieces, owing to the fact that MIRAMON's artillery was much heavier and of larger range than that of the Liberals. Col. HAILE escaped to Mazatlan, where at last accounts he had purchased and was fitting out two small vessels, with which he intended to procceed to Manzanillo, for the purpose of capturing the two vessels seized in that port by MIRAMON.

abstract: JAMES BU
lead_paragraph: JAMES BUCHANAN alias J.B. Ross, alias J. Scratched, supposed to have been engaged in forgeries to the amount of $100,000, was arrested in Pittsburgh on Monday evening. He was living in magnificent style at one of the first-class hotels with his mistress and a slave whom he had lately purchased for $2,000. The latter, whose name is ROBERT BURNELL alias Smith, is nearly white, and seemed to be made in every respect an equal of his master, who went with him to the various billiard saloons and restaurants. At the time of his arrest the alleged criminal had no money on his person of any amount. He claims that some of his accomplices have proved false.

abstract: The example set by South Carolina in sending a Commissioner to Virginia is, it appears, about to be followed by Mississippi. This State is also about to dispatch a long-winded orator, to give to the Mother of Presidents a bit of the Mississippian mind upon the impending crisis in the South. The result of the Carolinian embassy has been, so far, nothing
lead_paragraph: The example set by South Carolina in sending a Commissioner to Virginia is, it appears, about to be followed by Mississippi. This State is also about to dispatch a long-winded orator, to give to the Mother of Presidents a bit of the Mississippian mind upon the impending crisis in the South. The result of the Carolinian embassy has been, so far, nothing more dreadful than the patient endurance by the Virginia Legislature of a four hours' speech from the inexhaustible Mr. MEMMINGER, in which the ancient tale of Southern wrongs and Northern violence and perfidy was told over in as sprightly a manner as the nature of the subject would admit of. The way in which we hear that the Virginian Legislature is about to deal with this oration fills us with the gloomiest forebodings as to the fate which awaits the coming envoy from Mississippi. They intend, it appears, to discuss it until the close of the session, and then say nothing more about it. They will neither take measures to call a Convention nor declare the Union dissolved, and poor MEMMINGER will go to the Springs next Summer without any other consolation than the -- in this instance -- rather melancholy one of having done his duty.

abstract: It is very desirable that we should have a clear understanding of the precise legislation which Mr. DOUGLAS requires to protect States from invasions such as that of the State of Virginia by JOHN BROWN and his confederates. If he means that any conspiracy in one State to run off slaves from another should be made a penal offence indictable in the Federal Courts, we...
lead_paragraph: It is very desirable that we should have a clear understanding of the precise legislation which Mr. DOUGLAS requires to protect States from invasions such as that of the State of Virginia by JOHN BROWN and his confederates. If he means that any conspiracy in one State to run off slaves from another should be made a penal offence indictable in the Federal Courts, we entirely agree with him. If, however, he means, as his language has in some quarters been construed to imply, that the Federal forces should be placed under the control of the Executive for the suppression of any movement in anticipation of such conspiracy, then we do as entirely dissent from his doctrine. That we may do the Senator no injustice, we refer to his own language, as reported to have been used in his speech of Monday in the Senate. Mr. DOUGLAS "then presumed there would be but little difference of opinion that it will be necessary to place the whole military power of the Government at the disposal of the President, with proper restrictions, to repress such invasion." This would appear to be meant to confer a discretion upon the President which would be unrestrained by any judicial interpretation, and would therefore be clothing him with a power not contemplated by the Constitution, and hostile to the genius of our institutions. The Executive province is limited, as its name implies, to the execution of the laws, but should the Executive be armed with the whole power of the Government to suppress, at his own discretion, any assemblage or political organization which he might interpret to be a conspiracy against the rights or institutions of any of the States of the Confederacy, he would be made in effect a military dictator, and under the cloak of powers so conferred upon him the reserved rights of the States and the liberties of the Republic itself might easily be sacrificed. This whole doctrine of the prevention of contemplated or anticipated crime is always a dangerous thing to meddle with. We have no objection that the overt act of conspiracy should be punished to the extent of any Federal law which may be passed on the subject, but when the President is allowed to snuff conspiracy on the tainted air, and to judge of the tendency and design of any movement in one State, which he may consider to be hostile to the peace and security of another State, we shall not be far from saying farewell to all constitutional guarantees, and to all individual liberty.

abstract: FATAL ACCIDENTS. -- WILLIAM HEATH, of No. 78 York-street, died in the City Hospital, yesterday from injuries received a short time ago by falling down a flight of stairs. On the night of the accident, after drinking freely, he went with a friend to his house in York-street. As he was about entering the rooms on the second floor, the wife of his friend closed the door against him with such violence that he was precipitated backwards down the stairs. A post-mortem examination was made yesterday, when the skull at the back of the head was found to be badly fractured. The deceased has until recently always been reputed a sober and industrious man, but the death of a favorite child caused him to resort to the use of intoxicating drinks to drown his sorrow....MARY KAUGH, an Irish servant, employed in a family on Henry-street, was taken to the City Hospital a few weeks ago in convulsions, and died yesterday morning. A post mortem examination disclosed the fact that death was caused by a softening of the brain, the result of a fracture of the skull sustained more than a year ago.

lead_paragraph: The Editor of the NEW-YORK TIMES, in that paper of the 9th inst., calls the attention of our citizens to the articles over the signature of "NewYork," published on the 7th and 9th insts. As stated by the Editor, the subject of which "New-York" writes, is one of vast importance to the whole country. The question that should be settled by our present Legislature is--Is the best method to protect our State Canal the one now proposed by many of the citizens of our State, or not? -- i.e., Would the whole community be better off by the passage of the Prorata bill," and the "Tax bill," or by adopting a more liberal plan to protect both Canal and Railroads. Our opinion on these subjects will be modestly set forth before we close this article. But we will first beg you to make place in your paper for a few lines in reference to the articles from "New-York."

abstract: The date of the introduction of swill-fed milk for the consumption of the inhabitants of New-York and vicinity is unknown. No such milk, however, was at that time to be found elsewhere. Notwithstanding the adulterations of this beverage and its ruinous sophistications in the great cities of Europe, no such nocuous, or perhaps so profitable a manufacture was elsewhere to be
lead_paragraph: The date of the introduction of swill-fed milk for the consumption of the inhabitants of New-York and vicinity is unknown. No such milk, however, was at that time to be found elsewhere. Notwithstanding the adulterations of this beverage and its ruinous sophistications in the great cities of Europe, no such nocuous, or perhaps so profitable a manufacture was elsewhere to be found. There were, therefore, no English, French or German microscopical examinations or chemical analyses ever made, -- no reports of its deleterious consequences, or eventheories why it is injurious. We are not, therefore, at all warranted in forming an opinion that the originators of swill-fed milk were knowingly defrauding and injuring the community, but rather that unknowingly they were deceived themselves. With the light which is now thrown upon the whole subject, we may be permitted to maintain this opinion of those now engaged in this traffic; for work after work has been written, proving first by theory and finally by argument, based upon accurate scientific examinations, that swill-fed milk is not only injurious, but in certain instances even deadly. In addition to the writings of some years past, we have now handed to us a pamphlet purporting to throw some new light upon the subject, entitled The Transactions of the New-York Academy of Medicine, Vol. II, Part IV, Containing a Report of the Committee on City Milk, by S.R. PERCY, M.D.

abstract: A motion of Mr. HUNTER, in regard to the resumption of the debate on the resolution of Mr. DOUGALS, was encountered by Mr. Davis with the objection that a Committee of the Senate had been appointed to investigate the Harper's Ferry tragedy, with a view to ascertaining what legislation the occurrence appeared to exact.
lead_paragraph: A motion of Mr. HUNTER, in regard to the resumption of the debate on the resolution of Mr. DOUGALS, was encountered by Mr. Davis with the objection that a Committee of the Senate had been appointed to investigate the Harper's Ferry tragedy, with a view to ascertaining what legislation the occurrence appeared to exact and that the resolution of the Illinois Senator was an unfair and needless anticipation of the Committee's action. Mr. DAVIS could see no motive for the course of Mr. DOUGLAS, save hostility to the Administration; and distinctly objected to investing the Federal Executive with power to invade sovereign States, under pretence of suppressing insurrection. Mr. DOUGLAS replied by charging the Senator from Mississippi with misrepresenting his position. What he wanted was such legislation as should oblige Federal Grand Juries to find bills against the invaders; and as should authorize the President, in the event of a State calling for aid to repel invasion, to furnish it without awaiting Congressional sanction. Mr. WILSON subsequently resumed his remarks from the session of Wednesday, entering minutely into the history of Slavery aggression, and incidentally alluding to the imprisonment of colored sailors in South Carolina, and the treatment, of Mr. HOAR, the Massachusetts Commissioner. Messrs. HAMMOND and CHESNUT, the Senators from that State, explained that the imprisonment of negro seamen was purely a Police regulation, and that it had recently been modified. The expulsion of Mr. HOAR, while it was necessary, was accomplished with all possible respect and gentleness. Mr. WILSON's further remarks elicited from Mr. DAVIS an admission that the election of a Republican President of the conservative class of which Mr. FOOT, of Vermont, is a type, would not constitute a basis for Southern secession; and from Mr. FITCH, of Indiana, a declaration, that in the event of dissolution, the Northwest would go with the South, and not with the North. The Senate adjourned to Monday. The House of Representatives, agreeably to the project propounded by Mr. ETHERIDGE, of Tennessee, on Wednesday, was to have proceeded at once to balloting for Speaker, and in that practical and pleasant way to have occupied the ensuing fortnight, without further debate. Mr. HICKMAN, however, on the Republican side, protested that he was not bound by the suggestion of the Tennessee member; and from all quarters on the Democratic side, came similar protests, and refusals to abstain from talk. A ballot, thanks to Republican urgency, was at length obtained -- 226 voting, thus rendering 114 necessary to a choice. Of these Mr. SHERMAN had 109, Mr. BOCOCK 58, Mr. SMITH, of North Carolina, 37, Mr. DAVIS, of Indiana, 5, Mr. MCCLERNAND 3. The rest were scattered. While the ballot was proceeding Mr. HAMILTON, of Texas, withdrew his name from the list of candidates, using the occasion to thank the partiality of his friends, and to protest the devotion of his constituents to the Union. A point of order was raised by Mr. HICKMAN, when the result of the ballot was announced. He argued that a motion to proceed to vote was as much out of order as a motion to adopt the plurality rule, and he objected to any more useless balloting. The objection was eventually withdrawn, and two more ballots were had, the number voting being as before. The last ballot resulted as follows: Mr. SHERMAN 109, Mr. BOCOCK 51, Mr. SMITH, of North Carolina, 33, Mr. GILMER 4, Mr. DAVIS, of Indiana, 7, Mr. FLORENCE 4; the rest scattering. The House then adjourned.

abstract: A RUNA WAY WIFE. -- The Stamford Advocate has the following story of a runaway wife: "A few weeks since a young and beautiful girl took up her residence in that town, and entered the High School as a pupil. Every body, especially the young men, were curious to know who the young stranger was, and where she came from; but with all the ingenuity invented on such occasions, the interested ones were completely baffled in their efforts to ascertain her place of residence. A few days since, however, a gentleman from New-York made his appearance, and claimed the fair incognita as his lawful wife. The husband insisted on taking his wife with him, but the lady resisted his importunities, and kept her person beyond his reach. Hereupon the gentleman became more violent in his demonstrations, and would probably have resorted to forcible means to coerce the return of the lady but for the arrival of her brother. The two men met at the Stamford House on Friday last, when an excited colloquy ensued, during which the husband indulged in remarks derogatory to the character of his wife and her family. These remarks were followed by a blow from the fist of the brother, which laid the disconsolate husband at full length on the marble floor. The spectators here interfered, and prevented any further demonstrations of this character. On the following morning the brother and sister took passage on the cars for New-York, whither they were followed by the baffled but not yet despairing husband. Further this deponent sayeth not."

abstract: Coroner JACKMAN yesterday held an inquest upon the body of WILLIAM CARTER, a lad 16 years of age, who was found dead in the upper story of Messers. BENEDICT, HALL  Co.'s boot and shoe establishment, No. 21 Park-place. Deceased had been employed for nine months past, as errand-boy and to assist in stringing shoes. About 4 o'clock on Wednesday afternoon he was seen to go down stairs, and as he did
lead_paragraph: Coroner JACKMAN yesterday held an inquest upon the body of WILLIAM CARTER, a lad 16 years of age, who was found dead in the upper story of Messers. BENEDICT, HALL Co.'s boot and shoe establishment, No. 21 Park-place. Deceased had been employed for nine months past, as errand-boy and to assist in stringing shoes. About 4 o'clock on Wednesday afternoon he was seen to go down stairs, and as he did not close the shutters in the upper part of the building, which duty also devolved on him, the porter attended to it, thinking the lad had for once been negligent and gone home. His parents, who reside at No. 100 Hudson-street, quieted the apprehensions which his absence at first excited by the supposition that he had spent the night with some friend, but when Mr. CARTER went to the store to inquire with reference to his son, he learned that he had not been seen since about 4 o'clock on the previous afternoon. A search which was immediately cemmenced resulted in finding the body of the missing lad in the upper loft of the building, suspended by a long roller-towel between two high piles of packing boxes. He had apparently ranged these packing-boxes, layer upon layer, with the ends against the wall, having removed the centre pile, thus forming a niche, in which the body was found suspended. A piece of timber resting upon the top of the other piles of cases forming the cross-piece, around which the towel was placed. The knot was skillfully tied, and the position of his legs showed that he had stood upon an empty box and dropped from it. What induced the commission of the act is a mystery, as the deceased was of an uncommonly cheerful disposition, and by his amiability and attention to business had won the favor of his employers, who had increased his salary at the beginning of the year. He remarked, in conversation with a girl who worked beside, him, a few hours before he disappeared, that he was tired of this world, and had had enough of it: still it was not suspected that his mind was deranged.

abstract: About 2  o'clock yesterday morning flames were seen issuing from the stable No. 265 West Thirty-fourth-sheet, occupied by RICHARD FARRELL, M. W. LATTEMORE, WM. FARMER, and W. C. SEAMAN, milkmen, all of whom lost their horses, sleighs, wagons and harness, as the building was entirely consumed. Mr. Farrell's loss was $500, insured for $200; Mr. Lattemore's, $450, insured for $300; Mr. Farmer's, $500, uninsured; Mr. Seaman's, $500, insured for $125.

abstract: Mayor WOOD, we are informed, intends to sign the Tax Levy to-day, so that the document may be immediately forwarded to Albany. As soon as his name is affixed to the instrument, the City Inspector will take measures for cleaning the streets. The expenditures of the City Inspector's Department, during the period of the suspension of street-cleaning operations, have been reduced from $2,000 to $1,100 per, week. Many of the employes have been suspended from pay and duty all this time.
lead_paragraph: Mayor WOOD, we are informed, intends to sign the Tax Levy to-day, so that the document may be immediately forwarded to Albany. As soon as his name is affixed to the instrument, the City Inspector will take measures for cleaning the streets. The expenditures of the City Inspector's Department, during the period of the suspension of street-cleaning operations, have been reduced from $2,000 to $1,100 per, week. Many of the employes have been suspended from pay and duty all this time.

abstract: We do not often offer advice to the Board of Aldermen, but after the foolish scene of yesterday, in which the Boole, Bagley and Bradley Committee sat waiting open-mouthed for BENNETT's appearance, we cannot help counseling them in the strongest manner to revoke its appointment, and put an end to the farce. The Common Council has not for many years had much dignity to damage; but as it represents New-York, and uses the City Hall, we have a fair claim upon it for the display of a little common sense. If BENNETT praised the Board of Aldermen with just as much vigor as he abuses it, we can assure that reverend body that it would not stand one particle higher in the public estimation than it does at this moment, with all the weight of his charges resting upon it. And even if he appeared before this ridiculous tribunal, and recanted on his bare and horny knees, no human, being who now believes his accusations to be true would on that account conclude that they were false. The whole, proceeding is too intensely absurd to be allowed to go on in any building belonging to the municipality. If the investigation is to continue, we beg of the Committee to betake themselves, and their culprit with them, to some commodious and congenial bar-room.

abstract: How a HACKMAN WAS OUTWITTED.--A few days since, a gentleman who has "seen the elephant" had occasion to hire a hack at 11  P.M., to proceed from Twenty-seventh-street to the New-York TIMES Office. On entering the vehicle he inquired what was the legal fare, and was answered "a dollar and ahalf." He knew this was on overcharge, but quietly
lead_paragraph: How a HACKMAN WAS OUTWITTED.--A few days since, a gentleman who has "seen the elephant" had occasion to hire a hack at 11 P.M., to proceed from Twenty-seventh-street to the New-York TIMES Office. On entering the vehicle he inquired what was the legal fare, and was answered "a dollar and ahalf." He knew this was on overcharge, but quietly requested the Jehu to "hurry down," and ensconced himself on the cushions in deep meditation how to avoid the swindle. While passing the brilliant lights in Broadway, his eye caught the card nailed up in the carriage, and containing the "rates of fare" according to law, and his determination was instantly formed. As soon as the hackman drew up in front of the TIMES Office, the gentleman opened the carriage door, having the aforesaid card in his hand, and politely requested the driver to "step into the light, and he would settle with him." Jehu followed with alacrity, and expressed no little astonishment at being requested to point out, on the card, his authority for charging the dollar and a half. Surprise, indignation, chagrin, entreaty, and expostulation, were alternately expressed on the countenance of the outwitted coachee. But all was of no avail, and he surlily departed with a dollar and the assurance that, if he thought he hadn't enough, he had better meet his passenger at the Mayor's Office in the morning. Moral: When you hire a hack, look out for yourself and your spare cash.

abstract: -- A contractor on one of the mail routes in New-York. Writes to the Post-office Department in a very touching and pitiful strain, saying that for more than six months he has not received a cent of pay for services rendered the United States, although he has traveled within that time about twenty-eight hundred miles. He says that his credit is exhausted, and he cannot get a dollar on the strength of his prospect from the Government, the people having lost all confidence in the pay department; and they advise him to abandon the route and go at something that will pay. He admits that Congress may have failed to make appropriations, but that there is an abundance of money in the Post-offices on his route which, by order from the Department, has hitherto been applied to the payment of the Contractor, and he sees no reason why it should not still be the case. He prays and supplicates for money to keep him and his family from starving, and to procure clothing to keep them from cold; and ends by declaring that unless help comes shortly he must resign. This letter is only a fair specimen of the many which are daily crowded upon the Post-office Department. -- Constitution.

abstract: We have already called attention to the peremptory fashion in which President CASTILLA has met the claims advanced against Peru by the Government at Washington. The matter is a serious one, for it involves the national honor, and the rights of American citizens in a region of the world in which the American flag ought to be recognized as the symbol of power
lead_paragraph: We have already called attention to the peremptory fashion in which President CASTILLA has met the claims advanced against Peru by the Government at Washington. The matter is a serious one, for it involves the national honor, and the rights of American citizens in a region of the world in which the American flag ought to be recognized as the symbol of power as well as of justice. We therefore hasten to lay before our readers the fullest and most accurate account which has yet appeared, of the number and nature of the claims thus contemptuously dealt with. The chief of these claims are four in number -- two referring to the unlawful seizure of American vessels in Peruvian waters, and two to outrages committed upon the persons of American citizens.

abstract: The case of the Government against Henry Williams was resumed yesterday, before Mr. BETTS, and was principally devoted to the examination of witnesses for the defence. Several Bank officers among, others B. Lewis, Jr., cashier of the Botchers and Drovers' Bank and G.E. Baser, teller of Tradesman's bank, were examined as experts, in reference to the handwriting of exhibit No. 2. which was the order written in Adams' Express office, and signed "F.A. Williams," and other papers. The admitted hand of Henry Williams. As a general thing, these witnesses failed to detect more than a similarity in the two and were of the opinion that the two were not written, by the same hand. Several witnesses connected with H. Williams in the milk business were sworn to prove an alibi on the 28th of December, the day Adams' clerks swear he called at their office and received the package of money. The case was again adjourned to to-day at 12 o'clock. For the Government, Mr. Wight, Assistant U.S. District-Attorney; for the defence, Judge Maynard, of the Marine Court.

abstract: -- We have already announced the death of Mr. WM. D. ROY, Senior Editor of the Vicksburg Southern Sun, in a fight with one SHEPPARD. His colleague notices the dead or Mr. RAY in the Sun in the following terms: "The cold-blooded assassin, for such we deem him, is now in the county jail awaiting his trial; and, unless the eyes of Justice are closed to the doings of the evil-minded, the gallows is destined to be his fate. The base-minded enemies of the deceased who urged it upon the roof that was fitted to their hands to deprive an honest man, and a self-sacrificing Democrat, of his life, have every reason to rejoice, for their mission has been successful, albeit, their gain is all honest, true men's loss. A purer heart never beat within the bosom of man than that of the unfortunate subject of this notice. A more gallant spirit never animated any man to deeds of noble daring. True to his friends, magnanimous as an opponent, and unflinching as a Democrat, his worth will be remembered when the small curs that basket at his heels while having shall have descended to lower deep of Lethe's waves."

abstract: Mr. TOOMBS, of Georgia, rests his hopes of victory for the South in the great civil war for which he longs, upon the promptness of his countrymen in "defending their honor." We must, therefore, commend to his immediate and earnest attention a little proceeding which has just taken place in Columbus, Mississippi.
lead_paragraph: Mr. TOOMBS, of Georgia, rests his hopes of victory for the South in the great civil war for which he longs, upon the promptness of his countrymen in "defending their honor." We must, therefore, commend to his immediate and earnest attention a little proceeding which has just taken place in Columbus, Mississippi. In that happy city lived but the other day a gallant gentleman, Dr. SHEPHERD by name, once Secretary of the Texas Navy under General HOUSTON's Presidency, and distinguished more recently in the American service in Mexico. This gallant gentleman has just been shot dead in the public streets by a chivalric and high-toned person named BLAIR, in the following circumstances.

abstract: In commenting upon the remarks of Mr. FESSENDEN, of Maine, uttered in the Senate on Monday, we took occasion to lament that the Senator should have thought it necessary to compassionate Mr. SEWARD for the rhetorical mistake made by him in his use of that now famous phrase, the "irrepressible conflict;" and also to animadvert upon what we regarded...
lead_paragraph: In commenting upon the remarks of Mr. FESSENDEN, of Maine, uttered in the Senate on Monday, we took occasion to lament that the Senator should have thought it necessary to compassionate Mr. SEWARD for the rhetorical mistake made by him in his use of that now famous phrase, the "irrepressible conflict;" and also to animadvert upon what we regarded as Mr. FESSENDEN's own evasion of the practical issues presented in the resolution of Mr. DOUGLAS demanding new legislation to meet the crisis of intersectional feeling produced by the affair at Harper's Ferry.

abstract: -- The Convention to elect delegates to the Charleston Convention from the Second Congressional District assembled last evening in Montague Hall, when DANIEL F. CHAUNCEY and Dr. HAZLETT were elected delegates, and JOSEPH WILSON and R.H. TUCKER, alternates. A Committee on resolutions reported that the party appointing HUGH MCLAUGHLIN and FRANK SPINOLA as delegates to the Charleston Convention have violated the trust of the party, and recommended the organization of a new County Committee. The report was adopted and the Convention adjourned.

abstract: In Mott-street, near Grand, stands the "People's Washing and Bathing Establishment" -- a building of considerable pretension to architecture for that section of the City. It was erected in 1851 for the purpose of affording cheap bathing and washing for the people, by a number of benevolent gentlemen, who believed that "cleanliness is next to godliness." Baths of all kinds were furnished, at prices varying up from three cents to twenty five, the latter price, however, was charged only for medicated vapor baths. In other portions of the building are conveniences to enable women to do their own washing, ironing and drying, at a charge of four cents per hour. The edifice and internal improvements cost about $40,000; but, unfortunately, the machinery was not all perfect, and tended in a measure to prevent the complete success of the establishment. Up to November, 1858, however, the establishment was much patronized, especially in Summer, and as many as 1,528 persons, have bathed in the house on a Summer's day, while to the women who washed there the place was an appreciated convenience.

abstract: The Committee of the Confederation, appointed to consider the establishment of a General Supreme Court for Germany, have called VON LINDE to aid them in making their report. We may consider this as a favorable omen, since this eminent jurist has long been known as a strenuous advocate for the creation of such a court.
lead_paragraph: The Committee of the Confederation, appointed to consider the establishment of a General Supreme Court for Germany, have called VON LINDE to aid them in making their report. We may consider this as a favorable omen, since this eminent jurist has long been known as a strenuous advocate for the creation of such a court. The influence of Prussia will be in favor of the movement, as she is supposed to occupy the same position in regard to it as when at the Vienna Congress, she presented the paper signed by Prince HARDENBERG and WILLIAM VON HUMBOLDT, which demanded in the new confederation these elements: a war constitution, representative chambers in all the States, and a Supreme Court. The establishment of such a court has become an imperative necessity; and after the usual six or eight months of talking, we may expect to see it accomplished.

abstract: On the night of the 21st of last September, the residence of Jacob B. Herrick, in West Farms, Westchester County, N.Y., was entered by burglars, who forced open the basement windows and took about $250 worth of silverware.
lead_paragraph: On the night of the 21st of last September, the residence of Jacob B. Herrick, in West Farms, Westchester County, N.Y., was entered by burglars, who forced open the basement windows and took about $250 worth of silverware. On Friday night last the same house was again entered in a similar manner, and $500 worth of property stolen. Saturday night, as Sergeant Dickson, of the Detective Police, was proceeding through Broome-street, near Centre Market, he observed a negro with a bundle under his arm. Having a suspicion that the negro was a thief, he followed him until he turned into Elm-street, when the supposed culprit seeing that he was watched dropped the bundle and started to run. After a short chase Sergeant Dickson overtook him, and conveyed him to the Police Head-quarters. The prisoner gave the name of James Wilson, and said that in connection with three men name W.H. Stephens, Joseph Britto and William Mayor, he had robbed the house of Mr. Herrick on Friday night and also last September. A description was given of his confederates, and yesterday afternoon Detective Farley, seeing Britto in Pearl street, watched him until he entered a cellar in Grand-street. Haws procured the services of Sergeant Dickson and Detective Eustace; a descent was made on the place, and Stephens, Britto and Mayor were all captured. The latter was found in bed suffering from small-pox. The officers recoverd a portion of the stolen property, and also found a lot of safe-keys, burglars' tools and a quantity of cheap jewelry. The prisoners, except Mayor, were all locked up at the Police Headquarters.

abstract: Clinton Hall was crowded last evening with an appreciative audience, on the occasion of Mr. ETHAN ALLEN'S lecture for the benefit of the Widows' and Orphans' Fund of State Rights Lodge, I.O. of O.F. Mr. ALLEN commenced by saying: Odd Fellowship imposes upon all who seek its honors or material advantages the first great duties of a Christian life--benevolence and work.
lead_paragraph: Clinton Hall was crowded last evening with an appreciative audience, on the occasion of Mr. ETHAN ALLEN'S lecture for the benefit of the Widows' and Orphans' Fund of State Rights Lodge, I.O. of O.F. Mr. ALLEN commenced by saying: Odd Fellowship imposes upon all who seek its honors or material advantages the first great duties of a Christian life--benevolence and work. The illiberal man finds no congeniality in the lessons of the lodge-room; the drone finds there, for him, no refuge nor a home. According to the Odd Fellow's Lexicon, "mutual dependance," the basis of the Order, meant something more than ministration to mere physical wants; it meant, as well, mutual encouragement, and mutual instruction in fostering among its members those attributes of character which ennoble life and make the real man. The lecturer, therefore, invited attention to the importance of "heroism in character." Very few in life appreciate the importance of giving thought to the regulation and improvement of their own characters. Many passed from the cradle to the grave, as if the Omnipotent at their birth had granted them a patent for perfection, and all that was required of them by human or divine laws was an unrestricted progress wherever unchastened desire should point the way. Such -- and their name is legion -- are the mere counterfeits of manhood; by irresistable demonstration they are false and unimportant in the economy of life. At all times they have the ring of a base metal, and finishing their mortal pilgrimage they drop into the grave without leaving any void behind them or diminishing in the least the life capital of the world. [Applause.] Of the various elements of character, "heroism" is so important that the ancient moralists classed it among the four cardinal virtues.

abstract: Mr. CALEB CUSHING is in a terrible state of mind about the prospects of the country. He says if Mr. SHERMAN be elected Speaker, there will be "social convulsions, hostile combats in the town streets, predatory guerilla bands roving up and down the country, shootings and hangings." Why all these horrible things should occur, the ex-hero of Mexico does not state, but the matter certainly needs explanation. One of the advantages which are secured to us by a Federal Government is, that it does not make much difference to us what happens at Washington. The dissolution of the Union would no doubt be very injurious to business at the North; but why it should cause hostile combats in Northern streets, and lead to hangings and shootings, we do not very well see. We are greatly afraid that Mr. CUSHING has been reading the New-York Herald, in spite of his friendship for Ex-President PIERCE.

abstract: The Leavenworth Times gives brief details of the fight which occurred recently at Salt Lake City, between BILL HICKMAN and LOT HUNTINGTON, both members of the Danite Band -- the former its leader for many years. The cause the difficulty was not known; it was one with which the Gentiles had nothing to do. The parties met on the street, and after a few words had pased between them, HUNTINGTON and HICKMAN clinched, the former inflicting a severe would in the back of the latter. After the parties became separated a general melee ensued; pistols were fired and knives drawn. A shot from HUNTINGTON struck HICKMAN's hunting watch, which pvreented the ball from penetrating his body. The next shot took effect in his thigh, and up to the last accounts he was lying in a critical condition. HUNTINGTON was shot by one of HICKMAN's friends, in the thigh, but the wound was a flesh one. There were many shots fired by the friends of both parties, but no one else was injured.

abstract: The House of Representatives has at last evinced the possibility of an organization. After certain Anti-Lecompton and Pennsylvanian members had explained their positions for the hundredth time, a ballot was ordered; and while it was proceeding, members of all parties found it necessary to account for their votes.
lead_paragraph: The House of Representatives has at last evinced the possibility of an organization. After certain Anti-Lecompton and Pennsylvanian members had explained their positions for the hundredth time, a ballot was ordered; and while it was proceeding, members of all parties found it necessary to account for their votes. The South Americans having cast their vote solid for Mr. SMITH, of North Carolina, the Democrats followed the lead, voting almost unanimously for the North Carolinian. The Republican members from Pennsylvania, who on a previous occasion had supported Mr. GILMER, also gave their ballots for SMITH, and his election was regarded as secured, when Mr. JOHN COCHRANE changed his vote to Mr. MILLSON, alleging Mr. SMITH's former affiliation with the Know-Nothings as his reason. Immediately the Pennsylvania members abandoned the almost successful candidate, voting for Mr. CORWIN; and when the vote was counted it stood as follows: SMITH, 112; SHERMAN, 106; CORWIN, 4; scattering, 6; necessary to a choice, 115. The moment when the Pennsylvanians changed their vote, Mr. SMITH had the necessary number. The change, which was greeted with hisses from all parts of the House, was understood to have been produced by an intimation from the Republican side that Mr. SHERMAN should be forthwith withdrawn and Mr. CORWIN substituted. It may be added that, previously to the announcement of the vote, Mr. COCHRANE, having satisfied himself that the Know-nothing imputation against Mr. SMITH was incorrect, restored his suffrage to that gentleman. The House adjourned until Monday.

abstract: Running for dear life away from the cold weather of the North about a month since, I reached here by steamer Karnak after a run of five days--pleasant, except the two first, which were cold and blustering, and the saloons miserably warmed by two weak excuses for stoves, both of which would have not kept the ticket-office of the Peck-slip ferry comfortable.
lead_paragraph: Running for dear life away from the cold weather of the North about a month since, I reached here by steamer Karnak after a run of five days--pleasant, except the two first, which were cold and blustering, and the saloons miserably warmed by two weak excuses for stoves, both of which would have not kept the ticket-office of the Peck-slip ferry comfortable. Soon, however, the winds were tempered and softened to the growling passengers, and shedding their overcoats and thick clothing, Spring, then Summer, styles came in vogue with the warm air, and a seat on the deck under an awning was pleasant to those who had been shuddering with cold for four days before. When we landed here we found men, apparently in their senses, walking about the clean, white streets of this quiet town, wearing Panama hats and white linen suits, and young negroes with nothing but their wool and a moderately long shirt; -- that, too, in the middle of December. Such has been the weather, here, for the greater part of the past mouth -- the weather of a Northern July -- while you have the shivering mercury crouching below zero. When the wind blows from the North, it is somewhat cooler, but such, a thing as frost, is, I believe, quite unknown here.

abstract: The District-Attorney, at the opening of Court yesterday morning, commenced to sum up for the prosecution in the case of John Donnelly, charged with the murder of Charles Cobane on Oct. 28, in West Sixteenth-street. abstract: A curious debate took place on Thursday in the Senate between Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, and Mr. DAVIS, of Mississippi, each interlocutor being sustained by friends, who played for each the parts of Aaron and Hur holding up the hands of Moses; on the relations which exist, and which ought to exist, between the slaveholdieg and the non-slaveholding States of the Union.
lead_paragraph: A curious debate took place on Thursday in the Senate between Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, and Mr. DAVIS, of Mississippi, each interlocutor being sustained by friends, who played for each the parts of Aaron and Hur holding up the hands of Moses; on the relations which exist, and which ought to exist, between the slaveholdieg and the non-slaveholding States of the Union. The debate was marked by a good deal of rather exasperating recrimination on both sides, and can hardly be regarded as likely to conduce of itself to a better mutual understanding between the people of the North and their brethren of the South. Mr. WILSON charged Mr. CALHOUN with insulting the moral sense of the country by declaring that we had annexed Texas for the purpose of extending Slavery, and Mr. HAMMOND, of South Carolina, abused Massachusetts for sending Mr. HOAR to Charleston to create an excitement. Discussions of this kind in the actual crisis of American history can have but one effect, and every good citizen who honestly desires the maintenance of the existing Union, with its solid guarantees of State independence and of individual liberty, must earnestly deprecate their recurrence. But the debate of Thursday was not altogether absorbed by these acrid antagonisms of sectional passion. It afforded to Mr. DAVIS an opportunity for asking, and to Mr. DOUGLAS an opportunity for answering, grave questions of the broadest national import, in relation to the resolutions introduced on Monday by the Senator from Illinois, in reference to the maintenance of order between the several States of the Union. The results of this brief conversation afford the best possible commentary upon the remarks which we yesterday felt constrained to make upon the proposition of the Northwestern leader of the Democracy. Proceeding in these remarks upon the report which lay before us of Mr. DOUGLAS' speech of Monday, we could not feel ourselves exempted from the necessity of questioning the drift of the legislation apparently suggested in that speech. For it is clear that nothing could be more dangerous to the principles of Republican Liberty than a doctrine of inter-sectional law, which should so much as imply the right of the Federal President to anticipate the movements even of seditious conspiracy in any State of the American Union. Mr. DAVIS, of Mississippi, evidently sharing this conviction, urged the Senator from Illinois, on Thursday, to explain whether he meant to be understood as intending to confer upon the President authority either to suppress by anticipation, conspiracies formed in one State against another, or to enter the several States with the power of the Union, and suppress conspiracies actually developed into a practical shape. Mr. DOUGLAS met these queries with a frank and decisive reply. He explained the object of his resolution to be simply the clothing of the Grand Juries of the United States Courts, with power to indict conspirators in one State against the peace of another, and of the courts of the United States with power to punish conspirators so indicted.

abstract: -- The aptitude and acquirements of the pupils of the New-York Colored Orphan Asylum were subjected to the test of a public criticism last night in the principal hall of the Cooper institute. The assemblage was large and attested its approval by frequent applause. On tiers of benches, erected on the platform, were seated the children, who, in matters of personal cleanliness and robust health, would challenge comparison with the attendants of any free educational institution in this City. Among them were many whose fairness of face and Caucasian contour of feature shone strangely from out the dark mass of countenances by which they were surrounded. Mr. JOSEPH COLLINS, a member of the Advisory Committee, was chosen President. The exercises were conducted by Miss YOUNG, the principal teacher. The exhibition included moral dialogues, questionings on the rudimentary branches of childish study, and singing. The musical taste and tenacity of memory exhibited in these performances were surprising. The songs were in several instances led by a most diminutive specimen of the colored race, whose old-fashioned antics excited immense laughter, and on one occasion even evoked an encore.

lead_paragraph: The war between Buenos Ayres and her sister States is at an end; the arbitrament of the Paraguayan President has proved successful, and we have recently received, via Southampton, the text of the Convention to which the representatives of the late belligerents have agreed, and which is to reunite the recusant Republic to the other members of the Confederation.

abstract: Judge BROWN, of Lewis Country, and "half a dozen other judges," have, according to our correspondent at Albany, testified to their desire for an increase of salary by addressing a petition to the Legislature in favor of an amendment to the Constitution for that very purpose.
lead_paragraph: Judge BROWN, of Lewis Country, and "half a dozen other judges," have, according to our correspondent at Albany, testified to their desire for an increase of salary by addressing a petition to the Legislature in favor of an amendment to the Constitution for that very purpose. We commend this fact, with all its incidents and consequences, to the attention of our critic, Judge HILTON, of the Common Pleas, who disapproves so strongly of our making any comment upon the doings of the Bench. We still think that any amendment relating to the Judiciary, which does not effect a radical change in the manner of its appointment, will prove worse than useless. Instead of more, we want fewer judges; and we want the salaries made so high that they shall furnish a reasonable temptation to leading lawyers to accept the office. When the Democracy took it into their head to bring justice to every man's door by filling the State with Judges, they took no precaution to make it worth having when it came. The result has been that every one is convinced that there is no justice so dear as cheap justice. We have swarms of judges, and the result is, that the honors which once clustered round the office, the general public respect and veneration for it which were the means of illustrating the forensic annals of America with such names as KENT, and STORY, and WALWORTH -- which, in short, made the Bench the prize of talent and of worth, are all gone, we can only hope not never to return. Finally, as if we wished to degrade the ermine still further, we placed the selection of the candidates in the hands of that numerous, energetic, and universally esteemed body of men, the professional politicians in caucus assembled. The only consequence of these changes which bears even the appearance of being advantageous, is the cheapness of lawsuits, and the multiplicity of the courts. But the general estimate of cheap law and numerous courts is best illustrated by the number of cases that are carried to the Court of Appeals. The truth of the matter is, that this Court has now become, to all intents and purposes, a court of original jurisdiction, and the Special and General Terms of the Supreme Courts have resolved themselves into tedious and useless forms, through which the suitor has to pass in order to reach the one respectable tribunal of last resort at Albany. Everybody has his case tried first before a single judge, and then argued on exceptions before the General Term, because the law compels him to do so; but he does not pay the least attention either to what the one judge or the four judges may say. They do not, in the least, shake his confidence in his own view of his case. Everybody, in short has the law at his elbow, but as is usual in most such cases, familiarity breeds contempt, and nobody is ever satisfied till he gets the decision of the one court which is hardest to reach and farthest away.

abstract: The Freeman's Journal states that the injury sustained by Bishop McCloskey, by the late collision on the Hudson River Railroad, is more serious than was apprehended at the time of its occurrence. He is, however, out of danger, but will probably be unable to repair to his Diocese for several days. The Bishop is the guest of Rev. Father Hackett, of Tarry-town.

abstract: Affairs at Annapolis, where the Legislature is in session, still absorb general attention. The "Ancient City," as it is termed, is literally packed with parties from almost every precinct in each county, all of whom have some favorite project on hand.
lead_paragraph: Affairs at Annapolis, where the Legislature is in session, still absorb general attention. The "Ancient City," as it is termed, is literally packed with parties from almost every precinct in each county, all of whom have some favorite project on hand. Many of these are professional lobby members, who are supposed, either in their own estimation, or by others, to possess more or lees influence. Lobbying, in fact, has settled into a profession or business with this description of outsiders, of whom a large proportion are lawyers, Ex-Delegates, Ex-Senators, Ex-Governors and Ex-Members of Congress. They usually take rooms at the State Capital, to be in readiness at all times if their services should be required. Like Beau HICKMAN, in Washington, they talk up or talk down measures that parties directly interested therein have paid them for. The specific qualifications requisite to fill such an office, are unquestionable impudence, moderate intelligence, any amount of self-conceit, elasticity of conscience, want of fixed principle and a love of money rising paramount to all other considerations. These, together with liberality, when some desired point is to be gained by being liberal, a barrel or so of good whisky, a fair supply of wines, cigars, brandies, &c., furnish the ingredients and qualifications which, as a general thing, make up the lobby member's stock in trade. He is then considered a graduate and may hang out his shingle, not only at our State Capital, but within the locality of all other legislative bodies, not excepting the Federal Metropolis. The party -- JONATHAN BROCK & Co. -- who own, or claim to own, the franchise of our city passenger railway, and who are now endeavoring to obtain a charter, Rumor says, have at present an almost in-indefinite number of these adjuncts employed.

abstract: The North China Herald, published at Shanghai, says that, of the many beautiful productions of art in which Japan abounds, none has excited greater or more deserved admiration than a complete suit of armor, purchased on his late visit to that country by his Excellency Mr. WARD, United States Minister to China. This curious and magnificent suit is of mixed chain and lacquered copper plate; and although evidently of great antiquity, is yet in a complete state of preservation. The helmet is of polished steel, engraved and richly inlaid with gold. Upon the summit is an aperture for the insertion of a small staff with a Japanese flag. The mask and gorget are of fine elastic plates of steel. The armlets, anklets, and gauntlets are likewise of steel, with concentric hoops in front for the purpose of entangling and breaking a sword or lance. The cuirass, or body armor, is of copper, covered and ornamented beautifully with silk. The designs and chasings are of the most exquisite workmanship, and the entire panoply has been pronounced by those familiar with the armories at Malta and the Tower of London the most perfect and unique specimen extant.

abstract: The fair setting-in of the rainy season makes merry times among the miners. From all quarters we hear that immense flumes are just being set to digging down hills and washing into the mountain sides, and everywhere preparations approach their completion for beginning the golden harvest. From all the mines the most encouraging accounts are daily received. But the great rush next Spring will be for the Washoe and Mono Diggings.
lead_paragraph: The fair setting-in of the rainy season makes merry times among the miners. From all quarters we hear that immense flumes are just being set to digging down hills and washing into the mountain sides, and everywhere preparations approach their completion for beginning the golden harvest. From all the mines the most encouraging accounts are daily received. But the great rush next Spring will be for the Washoe and Mono Diggings. There has been the biggest kind of speculating in claims, and as very often the same claim is covered by two claimants, and as there is an army of squatters hastening to precede them all, a bit of a row in that region would not be surprising. It is a barren, desert region, covered with snow during the Winter, and, indeed, throughout the year snow caps the hill tops, and supplies the streams, without which mining is impossible. None doubt that there is gold there, or indulge the least skepticism as to the wealth of the silver leads. To get the silver, however, great capital and few men are required. There is no little capital setting that way, but, to all appearance, more men than will be rewarded for their abandonment of sure and slow gains in regions that they quit.

abstract: The Boston Journal, 21st, says there was a great panic on that day among the parents and children of the Adams School District in East Boston, in consequence of a rumor that the school-house was unsafe.
lead_paragraph: The Boston Journal, 21st, says there was a great panic on that day among the parents and children of the Adams School District in East Boston, in consequence of a rumor that the school-house was unsafe. It appears that since the Lawrence calamity a certain individual in East Boston sent a letter to Mayor Lincoln, stating that the building was unsafe, and requesting the attention of the city authorities to it. Yesterday afternoon the joint committee of the City Government went to the school-house during school hours, and made a critical and thorough examination on of the entire building, from cellar to garret; and they came to the conclusion that the rumors were entirely unfounded. The children, however, seeing the examination and overhearing the remarks, got the idea that the walls were going to tumble down at once, and went home with frightful stones to their parents.

abstract: A fugitive slave made his appearance in Stam ford, Connecticut, a few days ago. Alarmed by the questions put to him by a man of whom he asked a ride, he took to his heels; but was pursued, found ensconced on top of an organ in a church, which he had broken into; was brought down, questioned, quieted, fed and sent on his way rejoicing.

abstract: At about 10 1/2 o'clock last evening a fire broke out in a row of frame stables in Fourteenth-street, near Eleventh-avenue. The fire-bells gave the alarm for the Third District, but the stables were nearly desroyed before the firemen arrived on the spot. There were ten horses in the stable, all of which were suffocated. The stables were owned by HUGH LEAHY, kindling-wood dealer, and nine of the horses were owned by him; the other horse belonged to Messrs. WOOLY & ANNIN, lumber dealers. Mr. LEAHY's loss is about $1,500; insured for $400 in the Wall-street Insurance Company. The cause of the fire is unknown....A fire broke out in the basement of No. 290 Greenwich-street, about 8 o'clock last evening, occupied by Messrs. WARREN PLATT & BROTHER, manufacturers of kerosene oil and lamps, and JAMES LYNCH, gas-fitter; loss about $300, said to be insured....About the same time a fire which occurred in the basement of No. 70 Essex-street was extinguished before material damage was done....At 12 o'clock last night a fire was discovered in the store of Messrs. SOHINZEL & Co., importers of toys, No. 282 Grand-street. It was extinguished, with a loss of $100. There are several suspicious circumstances attending the case, which require investigation.

abstract: The visit of the Legislatures of Kentucky and Tennessee to Ohio, and their enthusiastic reception by the Governor and Legislature of the latter State, are amongst the most convincing of the many indications which already exist that the dissolution of the Union is not quite so close at hand as a good many of the fire-eaters and Abolitionists would fain have us believe.
lead_paragraph: The visit of the Legislatures of Kentucky and Tennessee to Ohio, and their enthusiastic reception by the Governor and Legislature of the latter State, are amongst the most convincing of the many indications which already exist that the dissolution of the Union is not quite so close at hand as a good many of the fire-eaters and Abolitionists would fain have us believe. The fact -- and it is a fact, which ought never to have been doubted -- is, that the number of those at the South, and particularly in the border States, who see in the Union the best, if not the only, remedy for all existing evils and grievances, is far larger than that of the noisy crowd whose patriotism expends itself in rhodomontade and tar and feathers. But it happens, as it always happens in such cases as these, that it is the brawlers and disturbers of the peace who are active and energetic in politics, and the conservatives who lie still and say nothing. No man who renders himself really very valuable as a citizen by attending to his own business, and entertains a salutary distaste for spouting, is willing to serve in the front ranks of a brawling agitation. But when an opportunity offers itself of declaring, in a sober and respectable way, their loyalty to order and law, it needs but a very small amount of demonstration on the part of those who abhor violent courses, to outweigh the tumultuous threatenings of adventurers and conspirators. The border States clearly entertain no intention of electing Gov. WISE to the Presidency, or giving him a "long, low, rakish, black steamer" as a navy, or of aiding and abetting in any scheme of anarchy or disunion.

abstract: At the meeting of the Board of Police Commissioners at 2 P.M., Commissioners STRANAHAN and BAILEY were not present. George Foster, a Doorman, who was dismissed from the Department on the 16th of January, 1859, was reappointed.
lead_paragraph: At the meeting of the Board of Police Commissioners at 2 P.M., Commissioners STRANAHAN and BAILEY were not present. George Foster, a Doorman, who was dismissed from the Department on the 16th of January, 1859, was reappointed. The following new appointments were made: B. Morrissey, J. Schneidecker, W.L. Griswold and J. Halloran. Four special policemen were appointed.

abstract: The Boston Atlas of Saturday reports the arrest of ULLMANN and STRAKOSCH, managers of the Italian Opera troupe now performing in that city, at the suit of Mme. GAZZANIGA. The Atlas says; ï¿½It appears that after the failure of some of the European artists, either through sickness or inefficiency, the managers, hoping to retrieve their losses in New-York, entered into a contract with Mme. GAZZANIGA. She was engaged, as they assert, more upon a past reputation than any positive knowledge of her present capacity to fulfill the duties belonging to a prima donna assoluta. For her services she asked the sum of $2,200 per month. The managers took the risk and tried the experiment. It failed from the beginning. Either through incapacity of voice or from lack of novelty and attraction, it is asserted that Mme. GAZZANIGA has not in New-York, Philadelphia or Boston, in either performance in which she has been the prima donna, proved sufficiently attractive to render the receipts equal to the expenses.

abstract: A public dinner was given to Col. WILLIAM SPRAGUE, at Providence, R.I., on the evening of the 24th inst., upon his return from Europe. One hundred and seventy guests sat at table, including the most distinguished dignitaries and citizens of the State. Speeches were made by Ex-Gov. HOPPIN, ...
lead_paragraph: A public dinner was given to Col. WILLIAM SPRAGUE, at Providence, R.I., on the evening of the 24th inst., upon his return from Europe. One hundred and seventy guests sat at table, including the most distinguished dignitaries and citizens of the State. Speeches were made by Ex-Gov. HOPPIN, Chief Justice AMES Gov. SAUNDERS, Mayor KNIGHT, Ex-Mayor RODMAN, and others. The occasion had a marked significance, as the Democratic nomination for Governor has been offered to Col. SPRAGUE, and it is believed he can control all the conservative vote of the State, and defeat Mr. PADELPORD, the "John Brown" candidate. Frequent allusions were made to Col. SPRAGUE as Governor, which were loudly cheered. We take from the Rhode Island Press the following:

abstract: Late on Saturday evening a notification was received by Coroner SCHIRMER to take the ante-mortem deposition of THOS. H. BARNES, residing at No. 10 Depeyster-street, who was believed to be dying in consequence of injuries received last Monday evening by a slung-shot in the hands of JOHN BURKE. The injured man stated that onthe day in question, between five and six o'clock, he was standing at the door of his grocery store, No. 10 Depeyster-street, when BURKE came up and spoke roughly to Mrs. BARNES. This led to an altercation, and at length BURKE struck him about the head and face with a slung-shot, so violently as to render him insensible. Had not THOS. KEATING interposed and prevented further violence, when he was unable to defend himself, BARNES thought that he would have been killed outright. The parties previous to the occurrence had had no difficulty. BARNES' injuries made it necessary for him to have a physician, but as he continued to grow worse, his assailant on Friday night was taken into custody, and is now in the Tombs awaiting the result of his victim's injuries. The prisoner resides at No. 20 Burling-slip, and keeps a junk-shop at No. 8 Depeyster-street.

abstract: Peter H. Folsom, recently a clerk in Mr. Treadwell's bakery in Pearl-street, was apprehended on Friday night on charges of forgery preferred by several flour dealers. It is alleged that the accused for several months past has obtained a barrel of flour at a time, for which he would tender a check, drawn upon one of the City Banks, for from $30 to $50, bearing forged signatures, as well as a counterfeit indorsement of the bank cashier, and receive the difference between the cost of the flour and the amount of the check in good money. In this manner he has disposed of checks on the Bank of New-York, City, Broadway and Chatham Banks, whose worthlessness was only found out on presentation to the institutions upon which they purported to have been drawn. Folsom was held to answer by Justice BRENNAN, after he had been fully identified by several of his victims

abstract: The Grand Jury of the Quarter Sessions at Philadelphia has presented the case of the drug shops, for carelessness in putting up physicians' prescriptions. The presentment says: "The practice of verbally directing the compounding of prescriptions without written directions, should be wholly discontinued; and no one should in any case perform that delicate and important business, without having the written ...
lead_paragraph: The Grand Jury of the Quarter Sessions at Philadelphia has presented the case of the drug shops, for carelessness in putting up physicians' prescriptions. The presentment says: "The practice of verbally directing the compounding of prescriptions without written directions, should be wholly discontinued; and no one should in any case perform that delicate and important business, without having the written prescription before him, and being at all times fully able to comprehend it and know the medicines to be compounded. Neither should an apothecary suffer his attention to be divided between two or more prescriptions at one and the same time."

abstract: The United States Mails steamship Northern Light, Capt. TNKLEPAUGH, arrived on Saturday, from Aspinwall, with the California mails and specie, and 114 passengers. abstract: President MARTINEZ's leave of absence for one month is the reason that nothing of any moment has been done, either by the American or British Legation. We are altogether quite destitute of news, excepting the Transit news, which is only fit to keep up the excitement, but nothing has been done to secure a speedy opening of this naturally made route. Mr. ROSA PEREZ, Commissioner for the White-Stebbins Company (although annulled), proposes a new contract on more favorable terms, or rather, less oppressive than the original grants. He has not been able, yet, to make a definite arrangement. It is supposed that VANDERBILT is at the bottom of the concern. BELLY's contracts for transit were revoked by the Government for non-fulfillment, and still he sent news to the Government and private parties that, although he has retired from the business, the Company has been re-organized under new auspices, and that they will send the money to make the contract good again. If the money should come by this steamer, it mightinduce the Government to make a new contract with them, if the terms are agreeable. Col. CAUTY, representative of an Anglo-American Company, has also made offers for the Transit business, but as it is for a monopoly, it is opposed to the Free Transit Decree, and although he has some favorable propositions, it is doubtful if he will do anything. The Government here is persuaded, by this time, that their true interest is to have the Transit business in the hands of Americans, and the only object of retarding it is to hear all the propositions, and to induce the American Company to better terms; it appears now to be only a matter of money -- an article which is extremely scarce -- and until we can get $1,000,000 per year of American eagles in circulation, by the way of transit, I don't expect anything else but Nicaragua will soon come down to exchange of goods for goods, as dimes are very rarely seen.

abstract: Mr. ROBERT BONNER, of the Ledger, who has been the cause of so many "sensations," has just experienced one himself. On Saturday afternoon the Ledger building was literally eviscerated by a terrible conflagration, which destroyed a large amount of property, including no less that ten cylinder-presses. Fortunately, however, for the mighty army of his subscribers, the greater part of Mr. BONNER'S edition for the current week was saved, and there will be no delay in the distribution of the paper. We should be disposed to add an expression of our sympathy with our contemporary in this severe calamity, were we not convinced that, with characteristic energy, he will convert it into an absolute advantage, and that what would prove a catastrophe in many another enterprise will figure simply as an incident in the history of the Ledger.

abstract: In the efforts made lately by Attorney-General BLACK and other Pro-Slavery zealots to show that slaveholders are entitled to carry slaves with them into the Territories, upon the same footing as any other property, their mode of replying to the argument that Slavery is the creature of local law has plunged them into a sea of troubles. It is impossible, of course, ...
lead_paragraph: In the efforts made lately by Attorney-General BLACK and other Pro-Slavery zealots to show that slaveholders are entitled to carry slaves with them into the Territories, upon the same footing as any other property, their mode of replying to the argument that Slavery is the creature of local law has plunged them into a sea of troubles. It is impossible, of course, to deny that the relation of slaves and masters has always to be called into existence by legislation -- that it is not a relation into which men fall naturally and spontaneously, in the free exercise of their own wills. So, to get rid of the embarrassment due to this unquestionable fact, they are making a desperate attempt to place all property in the same category. "You could not hold these men as slaves," we say, "in a state of nature, -- your title to them has to be created by law of your own making; and whenever your law is not in force, your right to possess falls to the ground." "And you," they reply, "hold your cattle and furniture by precisely the same tenure. Your interest in them was created by the law -- enacted by the society in which you live. If that society were broken up, you would have no property in anything you now enjoy."

abstract: A proposal to cut down the elm in front of the Granary Burial Ground, Boston, has called forth a report against such action from the Committee on Common and Squares. It is very much in the "Woodman, Spare that Tree," style. When it was submitted, the Alderman who moved for the action originally acquiesced in the report; all he made the proposal for was to elicit an expression of public opinion.

abstract: It has become generally conceded by capable engineers and builders, and by those who have attentively followed the inquest evidence and the circum-- stances daily elicited, that the direct cause of the terrible catastrophe at Lawrence, was the breaking of one or more of the iron columns that supported the floors of the building.
lead_paragraph: It has become generally conceded by capable engineers and builders, and by those who have attentively followed the inquest evidence and the circum-- stances daily elicited, that the direct cause of the terrible catastrophe at Lawrence, was the breaking of one or more of the iron columns that supported the floors of the building. Many theories have been promulgated to account for the disaster, such as ill-constructed walls, the quicks and character of the foundation, and the uniformity of the motion of the machinery, taken in connection with the weak construction of the building; but the testimony of nearly every one who had anything to do with the erection of the mill, decisively controverts all statements and theories, so far as they attempt to throw the immediate cause of the calamity upon the incompetency of the walls.
