abstract: The news of Count WALEWSKI's resignation had produced a very painful impression on the Pope. He called together the principal members of the Sacred College, and declared to them that he would never fail in the mission which God had intrusted him with, but that, like his predecessor, PIUS VII., he would suffer exile and even martyrdom rather than do so.
lead_paragraph: The news of Count WALEWSKI's resignation had produced a very painful impression on the Pope. abstract: The trial of Frank Fowler, charged with defrauding Christian Heine of $35, by selling to him for that sum a worthless piece of paper, purporting to be a genuine passage ticket on the steamer Hammonia to Bremen, such steamer not belonging to the Bremen line, and the said piece of paper being entirely useless for any passage in any steamer whatever.
lead_paragraph: The trial of Frank Fowler, charged with defrauding Christian Heine of $35, by selling to him for that sum a worthless piece of paper, purporting to be a genuine passage ticket on the steamer Hammonia to Bremen, such steamer not belonging to the Bremen line, and the said piece of paper being entirely useless for any passage in any steamer whatever. The trial of this man was resumed on Saturday morning in the Court of Oyer and Terminal, before Judge INGRAHAN, his counsel opening the case to the Jury for the defiance, and proceeding to call witnesses. The court-room was densely crowded with runners, bogusticket sellers, and interested citizens generally. The case was quite an important one, and the friends of Fowler -- and that person himself, as evidenced by the nonchalance of his demeanor -- confidently anticipated a verdict of acquittal.

abstract: The Prussian organ of the Ministerial party in Prussia is still of opinion that the restoration of the Dukes in Italy would have been the most desirable solution of the Italian question. It, however, gives up the subject as impossible, and thinks the annexation of these States to Sardinia by far the next best thing.
lead_paragraph: The Prussian organ of the Ministerial party in Prussia is still of opinion that the restoration of the Dukes in Italy would have been the most desirable solution of the Italian question. abstract: At Boston, Jan. 28, one Peck, a butter-dealer in Boylston Market, was arrested for the crime of giving a check for $200, without having funds in bank to redeem it. It appeared that he had been in the habit of overdrawing his account, and making the checks good another day; nevertheless, the Court held him to bail to appear for trial.
lead_paragraph: At Boston, Jan. 28, one Peck, a butter-dealer in Boylston Market, was arrested for the crime of giving a check for $200, without having funds in bank to redeem it. It appeared that he had been in the habit of overdrawing his account, and making the checks good another day; nevertheless, the Court held him to bail to appear for trial.

abstract: Steam is getting to be a power in earnest in the working of our Fire Department. To the successes achieved, at the severe fires in Broadway, Prince-street, Greenwich-street, and, most of all, in Beekman-street, the experience of the past forty-eight hours has added two others. The fire on the John J. Boyd was one of those "cotton fires," calling for wearing and protracted work, without the encouragement of obvious results corresponding to the amount of labor bestowed. The "Niagara" worked about nineteen consecutive hours; the "Manhattan" and the little steamer of the Valley Forge Hose Company about twelve each. To say nothing of the good directly accomplished, it is obvious that, indirectly, by saving the strength of the firemen, they have been the means of preventing a very disastrous conflagration, as the fire in the Ledger Building must have been, if they had had to grapple with it when worn out with the labors of a day and night on the burning vessel. We think these experiences must convince the Department that steam is a friend, if they choose to adopt it, and that, if they wish to maintain their present organization, they had much better make a friend than an enemy of it. Many of them, we are glad to see, are already convinced, as no less than four companies have recently applied to be furnished with steamers. It is noticeable, however, that no one of the engines already named as yet belongs to the City. The "Manhattan" Company own their engine; the "Niagara," which has done such signal service on several occasions, is a volunteer, having been put on duty by the builders, in place of the "Storm," disabled by a broken axle, for which good office the City is indebted to those professional axle-breakers, the Harlem Railroad Company.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN.--The repetitions of Miss HERON'S "Lesbia" have been attended with good success; the "house" on Saturday being better probably than on any previous night. The strong emotional interest of the play readily converts the lachrymose to the true SEJOURS standard of dramatic faith. Novelty being the order of the day at the Winter ...
lead_paragraph: WINTER GARDEN.--The repetitions of Miss HERON'S "Lesbia" have been attended with good success; the "house" on Saturday being better probably than on any previous night. The strong emotional interest of the play readily converts the lachrymose to the true SEJOURS standard of dramatic faith. Novelty being the order of the day at the Winter Garden, it is announced that "Lesbia" will only be performed twice more -- to-night and to-morrow. On Wednesday the theatre will be closed for necessary rehearsals, and on Thursday Mr. STUART will produce a new version of "Oliver Twist," prepared expressly for this establishment by Mr. JOSEPH JEFFERSON, Miss HERON, Mr. J.W. WALLACK, Mr. GEORGE JORDAN and other prominent members of the company, appear in the cast.

abstract: Two measures are now pending before the Legislature of this State, and threaten to become laws, which are based upon principles in political economy so false, and which would prove, in practice, so disastrous to all our great interests, that they deserve the most serious attention of the public. We refer to the bills ...
lead_paragraph: Two measures are now pending before the Legislature of this State, and threaten to become laws, which are based upon principles in political economy so false, and which would prove, in practice, so disastrous to all our great interests, that they deserve the most serious attention of the public. We refer to the bills for the reimposition of the Canal tolls upon our Railroads; and to compel them to transport local at very nearly the same rate as through freights, and under conditions most onerous to our Railroad Companies. The first named bill is proposed as a measure of Finance, a resort of Taxation. The reasons upon which it is urged may be stated as follows: Many years since, and under conditions entirely different from those which now exist, and which could not then be foreseen, very large expenditures were made, chargeable annually upon the Canals of the State. At that time the Erie Canal was the sole carrier between the East and the West. The capacity which Railroads have since shown themselves to possess was not then understood or anticipated. The Canal had so long enjoyed an undisputed monopoly of its business that successful competition was not dreamed of. Upon no other routes was a waterline between our rival States of the Atlantic frontier and the interior practicable. It was taken for granted, consequently, that the supremacy of the Canal would remain as it then was, undisputed and undisturbed.

abstract: The monthly journal of the University of Chile, for September, has been issued, and contains papers on the Geography of Chile regarding the Southern and less known districts; another on Meteorology, describing a remarkable Aurora Austral which was witnessed here on the 2d of September; another on the ...
lead_paragraph: The monthly journal of the University of Chile, for September, has been issued, and contains papers on the Geography of Chile regarding the Southern and less known districts; another on Meteorology, describing a remarkable Aurora Austral which was witnessed here on the 2d of September; another on the progress of the National Institute during the last three years; a fourth on the Condition of Common Schools, State and municipal, in Santiago; and shorter notices concerning the Lyceum of Concepcion, the National Library, doings of the Faculty of the University, and a "bulletin" of public education.

abstract: The last earthly honors were yesterday paid to the remains of the great man who has just gone from among us. Escorted by the noblest and highest in the land, the body of MACAULAY was left to mingle its dust with those of the great of past days who slumber in peace beneath Westminster Abbey.

abstract: -- The buildings of the Holliston Comb Factory, in East Holliston, were, with their contents, nearly consumed by fire, Jan. 25. There were $40,000 worth of combs finished and packed ready to be sent away, but with the stock and machinery they were destroyed. The loss is estimated at from $25,000 to $40,000, on which there is $10,000 insurance. The fire probably was the work of an incendiary. Mr. CYRUS HOUGHTON was the chief proprietor.

abstract: Yesterday morning the body of HENRY GAUKER was found in the Cohocksink Creek, under the bridge, at its intersection with Third-street, by a fisherman who had been searching for him during the day. The deceased was a single man about 21 years of age. He resided in Girard-avenue, near Charlotte-street and was a shoemaker by trade. He is represented to have been an honest, quiet, unoffending and steady man. He was last seen about 1 o'clock on Sunday morning last in Third-street, a short distance above George. The deceased was then in company with a man named MARINER, and another known as "Buckey." While walking up the street they were assaulted by a gang of ruffians from behind, and MARINER and "Buckey" ran up Third-street to Girard-avenue, after which they went back but could see nothing of GAUKER or the rowdies. Nothing further is known of the affair until search was made and the body found in the creek. The assailants, no doubt, knocked down the unfortunate man, robbed him of his watch and money and then threw his body into the creek. -- Inquirer, Jan. 28.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning the body of HENRY GAUKER was found in the Cohocksink Creek, under the bridge, at its intersection with Third-street, by a fisherman who had been searching for him during the day. abstract: By the arrival at this port of the Fulton, and at Portland of the Nova Scotian, we have European intelligence to Jan.12. There is much of interest in the news. The idea of a Congress seems to have been definitively abandoned, the policy dictated in the famous pamphlet forming the present programme of the Western Governments, viz.: that Italy be left to arrange her internal affairs absolutely without external intervention; that even ...
lead_paragraph: By the arrival at this port of the Fulton, and at Portland of the Nova Scotian, we have European intelligence to Jan.12. There is much of interest in the news. The idea of a Congress seems to have been definitively abandoned, the policy dictated in the famous pamphlet forming the present programme of the Western Governments, viz.: that Italy be left to arrange her internal affairs absolutely without external intervention; that even the French troops now stationed at Rome be instantly recalled, and that the Papal Government be prevented from drafting recruits in foreign countries. One result of this project, according to a French journal speaking, it is understood, the views of the Emperor, will be, that the Romagna and the Duchies will at once consolidate themselves under the Crown of Sardinia; and that from the pressure of liberal institutions in such close and menacing proximity, the rigor of Austrian rule in Venetia must be permanently relaxed. The Pope is said to be profoundly alarmed and offended by the attitude assumed by the French Government, and a cessation of diplomatic relations is hinted at as not an entirely improbable event. In the meantime, the undertalk at Paris Speaks of Marshal CANROBERT as on the eve of departure to Rome, to superintend the embarkation of the French army. The funeral of the regretted MACAULAY took place on the 9th inst. The line of the procession from Holly Lodge, the residence of the late historian, to Westminster Abbey, was thronged with spectators, while the procession itself was composed of a long line of carriages, belonging to the nobility and gentry. At the Abbey, there were assembled all the more noted representatives of current English literature. The most notable fact was the marked absence of the leading Conservatives, who seemed thus to express their unconquerable aversion to their veteran assailant. The assistant pall-bearers included the Lord Chancellor, the Speaker of the House of Commons, Lord JOHN RUSSELL, the Earl of Carlisle, the Bishop of Oxford, and other distinguished characters. The services were extremely solemn and impressive. The President's Message was received with general approval by the London press. The Times considers it minutely, and not unfavorably, so far as points of European interest are concerned. The later news we receive from India, China, and Australia, is without importance.

abstract: Yesterday morning, about 1 o'clock, a fire broke out on the second floor of the Four-story brick building No. 48 Ann-street, which extends through to No. 113 Fulton-street, and is occupied by Mr. ROBERT BONNER, the proprietor of the Ledger, and Messrs. WYNKOOP HALLENBECK  THOMAS, steam job-printers.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning, about 1 o'clock, a fire broke out on the second floor of the Four-story brick building No. 48 Ann-street, which extends through to No. 113 Fulton-street, and is occupied by Mr. ROBERT BONNER, the proprietor of the Ledger, and Messrs. WYNKOOP HALLENBECK THOMAS, steam job-printers. A number of circumstances conspired to enable the flames to gain full headway before effective efforts could be made to check them. The floor on which the fire was first discovered, as well as the entire building, was stored with printing paper, and there were, unfortunately, no large engines in the immediate vicinity. Some time elapsed before the Manhattan steam engine and the more powerful of the hand engines, Nos 6 and 21 could reach the spot. Company No. 5, whose house is almost opposite the building destroyed, had its engine ruined at the Beekman-street fire, two or three weeks ago, and the engine of Company No. 38, which is located in Ann-street, is out of repair. Both these Companies, in consequence were, using inferior apparatus, and were virtually crippled. Assistant Engineer CREGIER stationed Company No. 8 opposite the burning building as soon as it arrived. The great heat soon compelled the firemen to retire from this position, but they immediately took another, and threw two powerful streams on the burning structure over the building No. 111 Fulton-street. By this time the steam engine was well at work, and though the flames were soon subdued, it was about two hours before they were entirely extinguished. After the majority of the firemen had left the spot, the alarm bells again rang as fire had been discovered in the building No. 46 Ann-street. It was extinguished, however, with but little difficulty. The following is a correct list of the occupants of the building destroyed, and of the losses sustained, so far as they could be ascertained. The names of the insurance companies which hold policies on the property could not be learned, as the safes of some of the parties burned out are still in the ruins, and others refused to give the information asked for.

abstract: On Friday night, Jan. 27, at Troy, N.Y., a fire occurred in the clothing store of SYLLECK & MCVITY, No.232 River-street. The property was insured for about $5,000 in providence companies, which will not cover the lose, F.DAVIS, milliner, in No. 222 had his stock wet a little. The building on he north was somewhat burned. W.O. CARPENTER, ambrotypist, L.C. EVERETT, daguerreotype materials, CHUROHILL, gents' furnishing goods, and BROWNE, millinery, suffered from water. The buildings were owned by the estate of JACOB L. LANE, and are insured in the Liverpool and London Co.

abstract: Whatever opinions may have been entertained by independent observers as to the wisdom or patriotism of the course pursued by the Republican Party in Congress in their adhesion to Mr. SHERMAN as their candidate for the Speakership, there has never been any question about the manliness and dignity with which Mr. SHERMAN himself  has behaved throughout the struggle.
lead_paragraph: Whatever opinions may have been entertained by independent observers as to the wisdom or patriotism of the course pursued by the Republican Party in Congress in their adhesion to Mr. SHERMAN as their candidate for the Speakership, there has never been any question about the manliness and dignity with which Mr. SHERMAN himself has behaved throughout the struggle. And the manner in which, so far as he is concerned, he brought the conflict to a close on Saturday, will place him in a higher position, -- certainly in a higher moral position, -- than he could have occupied if the obstinacy of his friends had succeeded in elevating him from the floor to the Chair of the Representatives' Hall. The country will acknowledge that the man who ceases to compete for the Speakership, when competition has clearly degenerated into a factious opposition to all organization whatever, proves himself to have been not unworthy of the prize he has lost. Mr. SHERMAN's reported remarks, addressed to the Republican caucus on Saturday, were as creditable to himself as they were wise in point of policy.
headline: {'main': 'The Speakership.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Speakership.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Philadelphia Public Ledger calls attention to a fact which at this juncture deserves to be better known--which is, that the Constitution of the United States expressly provides, "that no State shall enter into any alliance, treaty or confederation," and adds subsequently, in order to prevent all misunderstanding about the matter, that "no State shall, without ...
lead_paragraph: The Philadelphia Public Ledger calls attention to a fact which at this juncture deserves to be better known--which is, that the Constitution of the United States expressly provides, "that no State shall enter into any alliance, treaty or confederation," and adds subsequently, in order to prevent all misunderstanding about the matter, that "no State shall, without the consent of Congress, keep troops or ships of war in time of peace, or enter into any agreement or compact with another State, or with a foreign power."

abstract: -The nineteenth anniversary of the Brooklyn City Bible Society was celebrated last evening in Plymouth Church, when addresses were made by Rev. Mr. ELLS, Rev. C. D. FOSS and Rev. RUFUS W. CLARK. By the annual report it appears that the Society during the last year has distributed 1,672 Bibles, and 1,714 tracts. The receipts for the year were $2,748, and the new year is commenced with $73 on hand, besides the collection taken up at the meeting yesterday.

abstract: The synopsis of Senator DOUGLAS' speech, published in the TIMES, has been read with interest in this section of the country, where all the Democrats, scarcely excepting the officeholders, are Douglas men.
lead_paragraph: The synopsis of Senator DOUGLAS' speech, published in the TIMES, has been read with interest in this section of the country, where all the Democrats, scarcely excepting the officeholders, are Douglas men. I think many of them have been a little disappointed by the extent of the concessions which he seems disposed to make to the demands of the ultraists of the South on the subject of Slavery. While they are disposed to excuse them as perhaps necessary to his nomination at Charleston, they cannot conceal the fact that they will tend seriously to weaken him in the Northern States during the canvass.

abstract: The decease of Mr. ELY MOORE, which the telegraph announces as having occurred at Lecompton, Kansas Territory, on the 26th inst., revives recollections of one formerly prominent in our own political circles. Mr. MOORE was born in New-Jersey about the beginning of the present century. He adopted printing as his profession in early life, and became very popular among his brethren of the craft, by organizing the Trades' Union movement. His fluent tongue and suavity of manner also secured him a prominent position among the Tammany Hall politicians, and for two terms -- those of 1835 and 1837 -- he represented his District in Congress. As a reward for his services to the party, Mr. POLK appointed him United States Marshal for New-York, a position which he filled with much acceptance to the powers that then were, by exhibiting great [???] in executing the Fugitive Slave law. After he had filled this office for a period, some fickle blast of fortune swept Mr. MOORE back among the mountains of New-Jersey, where he became the editor of the Warren Journal, which was published at Belvidere. The fidelity which he continued to display in the defence of Democratic principles, seemed him the appointment of Indian Agent for Kansas Territory. He exchanged this position for that of Registrar of the Land-office, a post which he held at the time of his death.
lead_paragraph: The decease of Mr. ELY MOORE, which the telegraph announces as having occurred at Lecompton, Kansas Territory, on the 26th inst., revives recollections of one formerly prominent in our own political circles. abstract: In a previous article we have given a sketch of the history and present condition of the House of Refuge for Juvenile Delinquents, an institution designed to reform those children whom the pressure of want, the power of temptation, or the contagious example and influence of parents or associates, had driven into crime.
lead_paragraph: In a previous article we have given a sketch of the history and present condition of the House of Refuge for Juvenile Delinquents, an institution designed to reform those children whom the pressure of want, the power of temptation, or the contagious example and influence of parents or associates, had driven into crime. The work of rescuing these youthful criminals from a career of vice and infamy, and a death ignominious or hopeless, is one of Christian charity, and those who conceived it, and those who, for thirty-six years, have promoted it, well deserve at our hands the meed of praise.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon it was discovered that JAMES STEPHENS AND FELIX SANCHEZ, the one convicted of having murdered his wife and the other of having killed his father in-law, were about to attempt to escape from the City Prison by murdering the two night watchmen.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon it was discovered that JAMES STEPHENS AND FELIX SANCHEZ, the one convicted of having murdered his wife and the other of having killed his father in-law, were about to attempt to escape from the City Prison by murdering the two night watchmen. The cells in which, the two felons are confined are connected by the waste-pipe, and STEPHENS, it is said, having discovered this fact, made this pipe the medium, of communication with his fellow convict. He proposed to provide SANCHEZ and himself with revolvers, and then to shoot the night watchmen, as they went their rounds to lock the cells, take from them the keys to the outer doors, and thug make their escape into the street. By some means at present unknown, but which it is not difficult to surmise, STRPHENS succeeded in procuring two heavily-loaded revolvers. One of these ha reserved for his own use, and the other was put in the possession of SANCHEZ, probably by the friend who procured the weapons for STEPHENS. Just as they had achieved what they considered the most difficult part of the plot the scheme was divulged to Mr. CHARLRS SUITOR, Warden of the Prison. Having acquainted Sheriff KELLY with the facts, the two went to STEPHENS' cell and declared their intention of searching him. The prisoner demurred, and on being told that he must submit, declared positively that he would not. Mr. SUTTON and Sheriff KELLY then seized him, are, after a desperate struggle, succeeded in overpowering him. They found in his pocket a six-barreled revolver, heavily loaded. After relieving him of the weapon, and ironing him heavily, the two went to the cell of SANCHEZ, and demanded an immediate surrender of the revolver which they had learned was in his possession. Perceiving that resistance was useless, SANCHEZ complied. He was also heavily ironed, and removed to a cell up stairs. By the opportune discovery and frustration of this plot the lives of the two night watchmen, Messrs. FINLEY and CUNNINGHAM, were undoubtedly saved, as those who are acquainted with the character of SANCHEZ and STEPHENS have no doubt but that they would have made a most desperate attempt to carry ant their design. It is stated that duly a few days ago a hole intended to communicate with the cell of SANCHEZ was discovered under the bed in STEPHENS' cell.

abstract: The New-York Tribune does not seem to be well informed in regard to the condition of the Republican Party in Congress.
lead_paragraph: The New-York Tribune does not seem to be well informed in regard to the condition of the Republican Party in Congress. We trust that in its anxiety to convict the TIMES of being the "organ of Senator DOUGLAS," our contemporary has not so far neglected the interests of its own friends as to have forfeited their confidence, but the case as it stands looks rather dark. In commenting upon the contest for the Speakership, a fortnight since, the Tribune, speaking as with authority, used the following emphatic language: "It is all nonsense for anybody to pretend that an election would be any nearer with another candidate than Mr. SHERMAN. We trust, therefore, that our opponents and everybody else will shut up on this point. We say SHERMAN or nobody." This declaration no doubt struck a good many worthy people, unfamiliar with the exigencies of party warfare, as slightly inconsistent with what have been commonly recognized as the feelings of a good citizen. To lay down a permanent Congressional disorganization as the alternative of the election of one particular candidate for whom no special inspiration setting him apart among his felows as the Heaven-intended Chairman of the American Representatives, had been claimed by his friends, or would have been allowed to be claimed by himself, must have seemed rather an exaggeration of party ambition, to those who look upon Congress in an old-fashioned way as a body of men sent to Washington to attend to the business of their constituents. Such critics do not know how grave a thing it is to make a President, nor how important a part of that manufacture a Congressional election is, like this now pending at Washington.

abstract: QUEEN ELIZABETH AND THE EARLY PROTESTANT STRUGGLES IN ENGLAND--This was the subject of a lecture delivered last evening by Rev. ALEXANDER CLEMESTS, in the Presbyterial Church in Twentyeighth street, near the Ninth avenue. The audience,  whose Hiberno-Scottish nationality was betrayed as much by their enthusiasm as by their faces, completely filled the edifice.
lead_paragraph: QUEEN ELIZABETH AND THE EARLY PROTESTANT STRUGGLES IN ENGLAND--This was the subject of a lecture delivered last evening by Rev. ALEXANDER CLEMESTS, in the Presbyterial Church in Twentyeighth street, near the Ninth avenue. The audience, whose Hiberno-Scottish nationality was betrayed as much by their enthusiasm as by their faces, completely filled the edifice. In treating of the character of ELIZADETH as a woman he described her as vain and a flirt; in reviewing her course as a monarch he awarded her the credit of having been the first to effect a thorough severance of Great Britain from any connection with or subjection to the Romish See. The act of Uniformity, passed in her reign, he regarded as not only unjust but as in direct hostility to the great principle which inspired the Reformation -- the right of freedom of thought. Protestantism, he admitted, was fragmentary, but every fragment had vitality and action. Some trees grow by slips; take a branch from such a tree and plant it, and its growth and vigor will be greater than that of the parent stem. So Protestantism, grew by slips. The great struggles of the early Protestants arose, first, he said, out of the unhappy tendency in some to make compromise, not thoroughness, their motive of action; and next, to sacrifice independence to uniformity. From these all their troubles began, but they did not retard the spread of the truth. It was, however, reason for humiliation that true Protestantism had not made more progress throughout the world, In Italy, in Hungary, in Eng-land, and in this City even the struggle was still going on. He called upon all his hearers, especially the young men, to gird on the armor of God, wielding the sword of the spirit, which is the Word of God, and boldly to mingle in this conflict between truth and error.

abstract: On Sunday night Arthur Carrigan, a resident of Cherry-street, was arrested and committed to Essex Market Prison on a charge of having been drunk in the streets. Soon afterwards he was attacked with delirium, tremens, and James Martin, an employe at the prison, and one of the keepers, entered his cell to secure him, so that he should not injure himself. Immediately on their approaching him, the madman caught Marin by the arm and stabbed him in the head with a knife, inflicting a horrible scalp wound.

abstract: Alderman BARRY presented a resolution to the Board of Aldermen, last evening, directing the Street Commisioner to remove the building No. 24 Roadestreet, because it projected beyond the line of the street, as widened.
lead_paragraph: Alderman BARRY presented a resolution to the Board of Aldermen, last evening, directing the Street Commisioner to remove the building No. 24 Roadestreet, because it projected beyond the line of the street, as widened. After some debate the resolution was withdrawn, and the same Alderman presented another resolution, directing the Street Commissioner to report to the Board, at its next meeting, the reason why the building in question has not yet been removed, in accordance with the ordinance so directing. This was adopted.

abstract: COMMON COUNCIL -- THE GRAND-STREET RAILROAD. -- A regular meeting of the Board of Aldermen was held last evening, A Special Committee reported in favor of giving permission to the Flushing and New-York Railroad Company to extend their road and run horse cars thereon, through Maspeth-avenue, North Second-street, Smith-street, Grand-street to Houston Ferry, and thence, by permission of the City Railroad Company, through Kingsland-avenue and Meeker-avenue to the Penny Bridge, provided that the road be extended through North Grand-street when it shall be completed, and that the road be built in the best style and furnished with two-horse cars; that no strain be used, and that the Company [???]e bonds in the sum of $50,000 as security for the faithful performance of the contract. The grant is to be for ten years, and the Company is to run under the same regulations as the other City Companies. The report was adopted, there being only four votes against it.

abstract: Recorder BARNARD has at last got one notorious ticket swindler named FOWLER, who once figured as one of Mayor WOOD'S Police, fairly into his judicial clutches.
lead_paragraph: Recorder BARNARD has at last got one notorious ticket swindler named FOWLER, who once figured as one of Mayor WOOD'S Police, fairly into his judicial clutches. This interesting gentleman is in prison under conviction for selling an emigrant a bogus ticket, and we hope nothing will now interfere to prevent him from receiving the full measure of punishment allowed by the law. Recorder BARNARD has already displayed praiseworthy vigor in relieving the City of the nuisance of such men as this, and we trust he will not now stay his hand. A few examples of the sternest character, and a vigilant well organized Police, are the true remedies for ticket swindling and its kindred iniquities, and will accomplish a great deal more, and in a much more legitimate way, than Mayor WOOD'S "Protective Bureau." Will Superintendent PILLSBURY therefore have the goodness to see that the culprit is not taken out for walks through, the streets, or allowed to dine at hotels in company with pleasant policemen? We do not wish to be too exacting, but we really think he might be kept in jail till his sentence is pronounced. We must "draw the line somewhere," and although it may be perfectly proper that murderers of good family should be allowed a little innocent recreation while loitering in the Tombs, we might as well shut the gates on such disreputable rascals as this FOWLER. And that at least a little supervision will be required to secure this object may be inferred, we suggest, from the extraordinary revelations of our system of Prison Discipline made yesterday afternoon, in the history of the attempt of two convicts to escape from the Tombs.

abstract: The public discussion on the constitution of the Royal Academy, (observes the Atkeneum,) pricks on the artists in their professional work. We recollect no year in which, at so early a date, we could announce so many remarkable works as are now in progress, and likely to be done in time for the opening in May.
lead_paragraph: The public discussion on the constitution of the Royal Academy, (observes the Atkeneum,) pricks on the artists in their professional work. We recollect no year in which, at so early a date, we could announce so many remarkable works as are now in progress, and likely to be done in time for the opening in May. A few of the more popular may be named. Mr. Clarkson stanne[???]d has on the easel a grand view of the Bay of Naples, taken from St. Elmo, looking down over the port, the blue bay, the soft sweep of green shore, past Torre del' Greco, up the slope of Vesuvius. Mr. David Roberts has a view of the front of San Marco, with a part of the shaft of the Campanile, and a glimpse of the Doge's Palace. Mr. Maclise has a figure picture "The Loving Cup," a horseman starting on a journey, taking from a fair hand the parting "God speed" in a beaker of wine, first kissed and tasted by her rosy lips. Mr. E.M. Ward has in hand a scene in the ante-room of the palace, adjoining the State apartment in which Claude the Second is dying, with a harlot at his side and a jest in his mouth. An episode in the life of Charles Du Val, the famous highwaymen, gives Mr. Frith a capital opening for his broad, pictorial comedy. The scene is Bagshot Heath; a great family vehicle lumbers up -- the gang cut the traces, lug the old gentleman out, and bind his arms, and the dashing highwayman dances a caper with the fair spouse or daughter, while his desperadoes rifle the coach inside and out. Mr. Phillip will be represented by his diploma picture, and his royal commission of the "Marriage of the Princess Royal." Mr. Elmore, once more well at work, and on a subject suited to his genius -- the story of Marie Antoinette. Mr. Egg will give us a new pictorial version of the inexhaustible quarrels of Katherine and Petruchio. Mr. Faed is elaborating a great picture not yet named. Mr. Millais is working on a love scene, in the character of his "Huguenots." We hear a good deal of Mr. Holman Hunt's "Christ in the Temple," but this picture is unlikely to be sent to the Royal Academy. Mr. O'Neal has in hand a Wreck, near a rugged coast, with the intensely-dramatic incident of a seaman volunteering to take a line on shore -- such a scene as occurred on the Royal Charter the other day. Mr. F. Good all is putting his Egyptian studies on canvas, in a picture illustrating the various Oriental life of an Arab encampment. Mr. Poole has a scene from the Last Days of Pompe[???]. Sir Edward Landseer is still employed on his great picture of the "Inundation," and we hope it will be ready for May -- but of this desirable result there are perhaps some doubts. Altogether, the prospects for May are unusually bright and various.

abstract: Mr. NICHOLSON, of Tennessee, held the attention of the Senate yesterday, speaking upon Mr.  BROWN'S resolution. There was little of novelty in his remarks. He regarded Mr. SEWARD as the source of Brownism and Helperism; pronounced  the Republican movement an attempt of Northern capital to divert Northern labor from the vindication of its own rights : and saw no escape from the mischievous tendencies of the Republican Party.
lead_paragraph: Mr. NICHOLSON, of Tennessee, held the attention of the Senate yesterday, speaking upon Mr. BROWN'S resolution. There was little of novelty in his remarks. He regarded Mr. SEWARD as the source of Brownism and Helperism; pronounced the Republican movement an attempt of Northern capital to divert Northern labor from the vindication of its own rights : and saw no escape from the mischievous tendencies of the Republican Party. The alternative of disunion he was unwilling to contemplate, but it was the only one left, if the North persist in its aggressive designs. He was hopeful that the calamity might yet be averted. After an executive session, the Senate adjourned. The House resumed its conflict over the Speakership. Long before the hour of meeting, the Hall, the Capitol and all the avenues to them, were thronged with multitudes eager to witness the scene. It was only after an hour's struggle that room could be obtained on the floor for the transaction of busidess. Order and space were finally obtained, when Mr. SHERMAN rose, and in a short and sensible speech withdrew from the contest. Mr. PENNINGTON was then promptly put in nomination and the ballot commenced. The whole number of votes was 234 necessary to a choice 118. Of these Mr. PENNINGTON obtained 115, Mr. SMITH 112, scattering 6. A second ballot, in which, Messrs. PENNINGTON and SMITH refrained from voting, thus reducing the number necessary to a choice to 117, gave Mr. PENNINGTON 115, Mr. SMITH 113, scattering 4. With this result the House ad-adjourned. The calculations of the Republicans for to-day are founded on the supposition that Mr. DAVIS, of Maryland, and RIGGS, of New-Jersey, will come to the aid of Mr. PENNINGTON, and so elect him. The Democrats, we are told, will abandon Mr. SMITH, and by putting in nomination a Northwestern Democrat, secure Messrs. ADRAIN and RIGGS, and so prevent the choice of PENNINGTON. At the Democratic Caucus last evening, a Committee of three was appointed to present a name to the party this morning. It was thought that Mr. LARRABEE, of Wisconsin, would be the selection.

abstract: The Finance Committee of the Virginia House of Delegates have reported a bill to that body entitled "A Bill making Regulations concerning Special Licenses," the design of which is to carry into effect, by legislative enactment, that famous policy of commercial non-intercourse with the North, which has, of late, been so extensively revived at the South.
lead_paragraph: The Finance Committee of the Virginia House of Delegates have reported a bill to that body entitled "A Bill making Regulations concerning Special Licenses," the design of which is to carry into effect, by legislative enactment, that famous policy of commercial non-intercourse with the North, which has, of late, been so extensively revived at the South. The bill substantially provides that certain enumerated goods, embracing the principal articles of Northern produce and manufacture, shall not be sold within the State of Virginia without a special license, and that a tax shall be levied on all such sales, unless the goods shall have been imported directly from abroad, or shall have been produced or manufactured in the State, or in any of the slaveholding States, or shall have been immediately carried by the purchaser beyond the limits of the State.

abstract: George C. Jordan vs. Laura Keene. -- This is another action for salary under the contract between the parties, by which the plaintiff claims to have been employed for the season to take the parts of �leading young man," on the defendant's stage. The season was to be from September until June, as testified by Miss Keene. The present action is only for the hundred dollars claimed as the salary of the fourth week. Two former actions under the same contract have been tried, one of which, for $100, resulted in favor of the plaintiff, and the other, for $200, in favor of the defendant. Both cases were appealed, and one still pending.
lead_paragraph: George C. Jordan vs. Laura Keene. -- This is another action for salary under the contract between the parties, by which the plaintiff claims to have been employed for the season to take the parts of �leading young man," on the defendant's stage. The season was to be from September until June, as testified by Miss Keene. The present action is only for the hundred dollars claimed as the salary of the fourth week. Two former actions under the same contract have been tried, one of which, for $100, resulted in favor of the plaintiff, and the other, for $200, in favor of the defendant. Both cases were appealed, and one still pending.
